column2: The defendant plead guilty for failing to comply with s. 153(1) of the Income Tax Act for failing to remit to the Receiver General of Canada money deducted and withheld from salaries, wages, or other remuneration paid to its employees. A fine was imposed pursuant to s. 238(1) of the Act. The defendant had filed for bankruptcy and argued that under s.168.1 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, he is discharged from all debts except matters referred to in subsection 178(1) of that Act.S. 238(1) of the Income Tax Act, falls within the definition of any fines, penalties, and restitution order as set out in s. 178(1) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act.  The Court's jurisdiction to make an order pursuant to s. 238(1) of the Income Tax Act is unaffected by a bankruptcy proceeding.
column3: The respondent pled guilty to 12 counts of failing to comply with the provisions of s. 153(1) of the Income Tax Act by failing to remit to the Receiver General of money deducted and withheld from salaries, wages or other remuneration paid to the employees of the Halifax Regional Protection Services Limited (HRSL). The Crown sought an order of compliance pursuant to the provisions s. 238(2) of s241(1)(a) of that Act, ordering the respondent to make payment of the sum of $22,069.23 to the receiver. HRSL was a corporation and operated the company with another investor. The Crown contended that the accountant and the other investor were relying upon the accountant to meet the requirements of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act including the remittance to the Revenue General of the money deducted from salaries and wages or the remunerations paid to employees of HRSHL. HELD: The respondent was found to be in a position to pay. The Court concluded that a compliance order falls within the definition of 'any fine, penalty, restitution order similar in nature to a fine, a penalty or restitution order imposed by a Court in respect of an offence...' as set out in s. 178(1(a) and s. 156 of the Insolvcy and Bankruptcies Act. Such matters were unaffected by an order for discharge under that Act. The respondent's liability for the failure or H.R.P.S. to remits that money and thus become party to the offences as described in subsections 153(2)(a), 238(1), and 238((1)) of the Act is unaffected by the bankruptcy proceedings and certificate of discharge arising therefrom. The court's jurisdiction to make an order pursuant to s241 (1) was unaffected by bankruptcy proceedings. The matter was adjourned to receive further submissions from counsel for both parties. The issue before the Court was whether have jurisdiction to issue an order under s241 to the respondent pursuant to subsection 238(3) of this Act. It is the Crown's position that: 1) The authority of the Court to make a compliance application pursuant to S241(2), discharging and releasing him from all debts except matters referred to in s178(1). 2) The Crown did not contest this Defence submission relative to the facts and circumstances surrounding the offences. The evidence and submissions did not reveal whether the accountant or investor were officers, directors or shareholders in HRSl.

[4] Sixteen days following the tender of guilty pleas and the imposition of the fines in relation to these 12 offences, Mr. Henneberry received a Certificate of Discharge pursuant to the provisions of S.168.1 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, discharging and releasing him from all debts except matters referred to in subsection 178(1) of that Act. [4] Sixteen days following the tender of guilty pleas and the imposition of the fines in relation to these 12 offences, Mr. Henneberry received a Certificate of Discharge pursuant to the provisions of S.168.1 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, discharging and releasing him from all debts except matters referred to in subsection 178(1) of that Act. [9] I conclude that a subsection 238(2) compliance order falls within the definition of “any fine, penalty, restitution order or other order similar in nature to a fine, penalty or restitution order imposed by a Court in respect of an offence...” as set out in subsection 178(1)(a) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act.
column17: The defendant plead guilty for failing to comply with s. 153(1) of the Income Tax Act for failing to remit to the Receiver General of Canada money deducted and withheld from salaries, wages, or other remuneration paid to its employees. A fine was imposed pursuant to s. 238(1) of the Act. The defendant had filed for bankruptcy and argued that under s.168.1 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, he is discharged from all debts except matters referred to in subsection 178(1) of that Act.S. 238(1) of the Income Tax Act, falls within the definition of any fines, penalties, and restitution order as set out in s. 178(1) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act.  The Court's jurisdiction to make an order pursuant to s. 238(1) of the Income Tax Act is unaffected by a bankruptcy proceeding.
column18: The respondent pled guilty to 12 counts of failing to comply with the provisions of s. 153(1) of the Income Tax Act by failing to remit to the Receiver General of money deducted and withheld from salaries, wages or other remuneration paid to the employees of the Halifax Regional Protection Services Limited. The Crown sought an order of compliance pursuant to s. 238(2) and the imposition of fines in relation to these 12 counts. The respondent operated the company with another investor. HELD: A compliance order fell within the definition of 'any fine, penalty, restitution order similar in nature to a fine or restitution order imposed by a Court in respect of an offence...' as set out in s.178(1)(a) of Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. Such matters were unaffected by an order under that Act. The court's jurisdiction to make an order pursuant to the provisions under s.238(2 of the income tax act is unaffected by bankruptcy proceedings and the certificate of discharge arising therefrom. The matter was adjourned to receive further submissions from counsel for both parties. 1) The Crown's position was that the Crown had jurisdiction to issue a compliance order. 2) The authority of the Court to make such an order was irrelevant. 3) The respondent was relying upon an investor of H.R.P.S. and/or the accountant of that company to make the deductions and necessary remittances. The implicit inference to be drawn from those submissions was that either of these individuals were at least equally, if not more responsible than the respondent for these offences. Expressed in another fashion, the Crown, in light of the guilty pleas, need not establish the existence of the matters set out by s.227(2).

column2: The accused, charged with fraud, brought a motion to stay the proceedings on the basis that his Charter rights had been violated by the RCMP and the Office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy. The accused asked the court to reconsider its decision to quash a subpoena issued to the former Superintendent of Bankruptcy on the basis of testimony presented from other witnesses after the subpoena was quashed. Application dismissed; the accused had not met the onus on the balance of probabilities of establishing that the former Superintendent had relevant or material evidence to offer concerning the issues raised by the Charter motions. The subsequent testimony and documentation did not support the accused's allegations concerning the former Superintendent's motives or conduct.
column3: The defendant was charged with three counts of fraud contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code relating to his activities as president and principal shareholder of a bankrupt corporation. He brought motions to compel the Superintendent of Bankruptcy to testify at the hearing of the Charter Motions. The defendant brought motions seeking an order compelling the Superintendent to testify. The applicant brought motions on the basis that his rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms were violated by the Office of the Superintendent and by the R.C.M.P. during investigations of his activities and of the administration of the bankrupt corporation and during the RCCMP's hearings. The reasons for giving the decision to quash the subpoena canvassed the involvement of the OSB in relation to Mr. Black's affairs, and explained the basis upon which determined that Mr. Redling was unlikely to be able to provide relevant or material evidence concerning the issues raised by the Charter. The application was dismissed. The court found that the defendant had not met the onus which rests upon him to satisfy the Court on the balance of probabilities that he has relevant or relevant evidence to give concerning the issue raised by to the Charter motions.
column4: MURPHY, J. [1] Frederick Black has been charged with three counts of fraud, contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code, relating to his activities as president and principal shareholder of NsC Diesel Power Inc. (“NsC”), a bankrupt corporation. Mr Black has brought motions (the “Charter Motions”) seeking a stay of those charges on the basis that his rights under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms were violated by the Office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy (“OSB”) and by the R.C.M.P. during investigations of his activities and of the administration of the NsC bankruptcy. The present application could be characterized as a request for re-consideration of the decision to quash the Subpoena, in light of additional information which Mr Black says has become available during subsequent testimony and from the documents which have now been provided. [4] After reviewing the Notice of Motion and Mr. Black’s affidavit, and hearing representations from Mr. Black, from Mr. Clarke on behalf of Mr. Redling, and from Mr. Holt, I have decided to dismiss the Application to require Mr. Redling’s attendance, and no subpoena will be issued to him. [12] The Application is accordingly dismissed.

column8: The defendant was charged with three counts of fraud contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code relating to his activities as president and principal shareholder of NsC Diesel Power Inc. (NYSE:NTSC). He brought motions seeking a stay of those charges on the basis that his rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms were violated by the Office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy and by the R.C.M.P. during investigations of his activities and of the administration of the bankrupt corporation. After the Subpoena was quashed, the defendant presented additional testimony from RCMP officers and evidence from a senior official in the Halifax office of the OSB during Mr. Redling's tenure. The evidence which those witnesses gave and the documents to which they referred raise issues which warrant compelling the defendant's attendance. After reviewing the Notice of Motion and the affidavit, and hearing representations from Mr. Black, Mr. Holt and Ms. Holt, the Application was accordingly dismissed. The defendant has not met the onus which rests upon him to satisfy the Court on the balance of probabilities that he has relevant or material evidence to give concerning the issues raised by the Charter Motions. The testimony and documentation presented since the SubPoena (quashed) do not provide any basis to compel his attendance.

column18: The defendant was charged with three counts of fraud contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code relating to his activities as president and principal shareholder of NsC Diesel Power Inc. (NYSE:NTSC). The defendant brought motions seeking a stay of those charges on the basis that his rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms were violated by the Office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy and by the R.C.M.P. during investigations of his activities and of the administration of the bankrupt corporation. After reviewing the Notice of Motion and the affidavit, and hearing representations from the defendant on behalf of the defendant and defence lawyer, that the defendant had not met the onus which rests upon him to satisfy the Court on the balance of probabilities that Mr. Redling has relevant or material evidence to give concerning the issues raised by the Charter Motions. The testimony and documentation presented since the Subpoena was quashed do not provide any basis to compel his attendance. HELD: The application was dismissed.  1) The defendant has not proven that his Charter rights were violated. 2) The evidence which has been available during subsequent testimony and from the documents which have now been provided does not support those beliefs expressed by the defendant. 3) There is no evidence that the OSB, under the Superintendent, did not pursue investigations into other parties' conduct and deflected suspicion of wrongdoing to him. 4) There has not been any evidence concerning the investigation into the conduct of other persons involved in the bankruptcy. 5) The application could be characterized as a request for re-consideration of the decision to quash the subpoena in light of additional information which have been provided. The reasons which provided when giving that decision canvassed the involvement of Mr.Redling and other persons in the OMB in relation to Mr. Black's affairs, and explained the basis upon which determined that Mr Redling was unlikely to be able to provide relevant information concerning issues. The evidence that those witnesses gave and the documents to which they referred raise issues which warrant compelling the defendant's attendance.

column2: Following a four day trial, the plaintiffs were successful in the recovery of the sum of $29,150 against the defendant. Under the usual tariff, costs would be fixed at $4,725. The plaintiffs sought substantially increased costs on the basis that the defendant should have admitted liability at the outset rather than forcing the plaintiffs to trial. Solicitor and client fees totaled over $21,000. Costs fixed at $10,000 plus disbursements; there was no obligation on the defendant to admit liability but considering the amount of legal fees incurred in relation to the amount recovered, it was appropriate to go outside the tariffs.
column3: The court fixed costs in a 4 day proceeding where the plaintiffs were successful in recovering the base amount claimed but did not succeed in their claims for aggravated and punitive damages. The defendant was justified in contesting the plaintiff's claim as it did and it did not unduly prolong the proceeding. Costs were increased above the usual party and party costs because, as he contended, the defendant ought to have admitted liability at the outset rather than forcing the plaintiffs to trial. The plaintiff's evidence was accepted, however, and the trial extended over 4 days. The court found no fault on the part of the defendant in its conduct of the proceeding and there were no factors (c) to (g) militate against the defendant.
column4: [9] I have concluded, therefore, that it is appropriate to go outside the tariffs in determining what is a reasonable amount for the defendant to contribute to the plaintiffs\' costs. In my view the plaintiff should contribute $10,000.00 toward the plaintiffs\' costs plus disbursements.

column2: The court had previously ordered interim joint custody of the child, with the primary residence being with the mother. The mother later unilaterally moved from Bridgewater to Halifax, frustrating the access provisions of the interim order. The father applied for interim custody and the mother replied, seeking sole custody. Children to remain with the mother until the end of the school year, at which point primary care of the children will be granted to the applicant; child support adjusted accordingly. The mother's decision to move was not in the children's best interests and it was done either to frustrate or with a callous indifference to the children's relationship with their father.
column3: The parties were to share joint custody of the children. The respondent was to have access with the children every Tuesday and Wednesday from after school until after school. The parties had been married for seven years and separated in 2002. The children went to school, had after school activities and had a doctor's appointment. The mother was to move to Bridgewater to live with the father. The father was to continue to pay child support. The court reviewed the circumstances and found that it was in the children's best interests to remain in the father's residential care beyond the end of the school year. The Court also varied the order for child support payable by the respondent to reflect his current income.
column4: I conclude that Ms. Bourque’s decision to move was not in the best interests of these children, not carefully made. I conclude that it was done either to frustrate or with a rather callous indifference to the children’s relationship with their father. [25] I conclude that it is not in the children’s best interests to remain in Ms. Bourque’s residential care beyond the end of the school year. I conclude that it is in their best interests to be in the primary care of their father effective the last day of June of 2005, that is at the end of the existing school year. [27] Finally, I would vary the existing Order for child support payable by Mr. Lemire to Ms. Bourque to reflect his current income.

column8: The parties were to share joint custody of the children. The respondent was to have access with the children every Tuesday and Wednesday from after school until the end of the school year. The parties had been involved in the parenting of these children since 1993 and separated in May 2005. In the interim, the respondent moved the children to Bridgewater, one hour from Halifax, changing their primary residence, changed their school and had their after-school care and activities in an area that both parties lived in. The appellant argued that this was in their best interests to remain in the respondent's residential care beyond the end-of-school year. HELD: 1) The respondent's current income was $33,000 per annum. column2: The accused is charged with driving without due care and attention contrary to s. 44(1) of the Highway Traffic Act. A pedestrian was crossing a road adjacent to a parking lot and, while walking directly in front of a stopped vehicle, was struck by the vehicle when it rolled forward. HELD: The accused is not guilty. The court accepted the accused's evidence that his vehicle rolled forward only a short distance of not more than one foot and not at a fast or accelerated speed and that the pedestrian was crossing outside of the cross walk and that the accused applied his brakes as soon as he saw the pedestrian. The accused did exercise due diligence.
column3: The accused was charged with driving without due care and attention contrary to s. 44(1) of the Highway Traffic Act. The accused had been on duty in a marked police car when the accused's vehicle rolled forward and struck the complainant. The complainant was crossing a street outside of a crosswalk when the Crown called three witnesses. The Crown called four witnesses, including the complainant, who was standing with their infant daughter. The defence called the complainant's husband, who had just come out of Super Store, to assist the officer. The officer asked the complainant if he could assist the complainant and the complainant backed up to speak with the officer, who then backed up and struck him. The police officer testified that he did not raise his hands or raise his hand. The defendant's vehicle did not move very short distance forward before striking the complainant; the Crown's evidence that neither seat belt, belonging to the officer or the Crown, locked upon striking the officer; the officer did exercise due diligence both before and after striking the victim. The court found that the accused drove careless. The Court found that both the complainant’s and the Crown’ s witnesses’ statements to the effect that the complainant was not shouting at the officer were not inconsistent. The issue was whether the Crown had proved that the defendant drove without due attention and care. The trial judge found that his vehicle rolled over only a short distance of not more than one foot and not at a fast or accelerating speed. The vehicle rolled into the complainant directly in front of the police vehicle. The pedestrian crossing road adjacent to a parking lot was a pedestrian crossing. The intersection was directly in the complainant area. The collision occurred within a short time. The impact on the complainant wasn't so minor that the Crown could reasonably conclude that the driver was careless.
column4: [1] Todd Tyndall is charged with driving without due care and attention at Yorkton, Saskatchewan on February 18, 2004, contrary to section 44(1) of the Highway Traffic Act. In particular, I accept that his vehicle rolled forward only a short distance of not more than one foot, and not at a fast or accelerating speed, that Mr. Kachur was directly in front of the police vehicle and was crossing the parking lot road outside of the cross-walk, and that Mr. Tyndall - without having applied any force to his accelerator peddle - immediately applied his brake when he saw Mr. Kachur, and immediately took steps both to assist Mr. Kachur by asking if he required an ambulance, and to have other officers attend at the scene. [26] In conclusion, I am satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that, given the situation Mr. Tyndall found himself in, he could not have reasonably anticipated that a person would have been so close in front of him, and further that Mr. Tyndall did exercise due diligence both before and after striking Mr. Kachur. [27] As a result I find him not guilty of this charge.

HELD: The accused is not guilty. column13: The accused was charged with driving without due care and attention contrary to s. 44(1) of the Highway Traffic Act. The accused had been on duty in a marked police car when he was struck by a vehicle. The Crown called three witnesses and the accused backed up to speak with the defence. The defence then called four witnesses. HELD: The accused was found not guilty of the charge. 1) The accused's vehicle rolled forward only a short distance, and not at a fast or accelerating speed, which was in effect careless driving, as distinguished from dangerous driving under the Criminal Code. The actions of the accused which could be considered careless are, firstly, the speed at which he drove past the stopped vehicle, and secondly, his driving forward into the accused. The evidence of the Crown witnesses was that the accused had an oblique motive for doing so, perhaps thinking that the police officer was being insolent and returning to set him straight. 2) The Court of Queen's Bench held that, given the situation, he could not have reasonably anticipated that a person would have been so close in front of him and the fact that the officer did exercise due diligence both before and after striking the accused, the Court of Appeal held that this driving was careless. 3) On a balance of probabilities, the Crown has proved that the driving by the accused was careless, as the Crown failed to prove state of mind, but the accused exercised due diligence and took reasonable care. The court found that the Crown had not proved that Mr. Tyndall's vehicle was moving too fast, as it did not accelerate and did not move forward quickly before striking the officer. The Court also held that the defendant did not have a due diligence defence including 'taking all reasonable steps to avoid the particular event'. The Court concluded that the trial judge erred in his assessment of the extent to which the accused's actions were careless.

column2: The accused is charged with driving while over .08 contrary to s. 255(1) and s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code and impaired driving contrary to s. s. 253(b) and 255(1) of the Code. HELD: The accused is not guilty on all counts.  1) A breath test and demand should be made as soon as the officer forms the requisite grounds for making it. Those grounds did not change between the time the accused refused to provide an ASD sample at 8:17 a.m., when the officer arrested her for impaired driving and 8:40 a.m. when the officer read the accused the breathalyzer demand. There was no reason for the breath demand not being made forthwith. The rights of the accused under s. 8 and s. 9 of the Charter were breached. 2) The officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds for making the breathalyzer demand. The officer testified she gave the ASD demand to find out if the accused had alcohol in her system. When the accused refused, the officer arrested her for impaired driving. The officer was unsure of whether the accused had alcohol in her system when she read the accused the ASD demand and there was no new evidence gathered between 8:17 a.m. and 8:40 a.m. to justify the breath demand. The evidence does not support a subjective honest belief on the part of the officer that the ability of the accused to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol. As the breath sample evidence was obtained as a consequence of the breach of the s. 8 and s. 9 Charter rights of the accused, it should be excluded from evidence pursuant to s. 24(2).  3) The accused testified that she had been drinking alcohol and was feeling the effects of the alcohol at the time she was operating the vehicle. She said she knew the alcohol would kick in and that she was not really feeling the effects until she arrived at the police station. She offered an explanation for her difficulty in driving testifying that she was tired. The evidence of the officer, which was insufficient to support a belief of impairment as a prerequisite to a breath demand, cannot prove impaired driving. There is insufficient evidence to conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused's ability to drive was impaired by alcohol at the time she was driving.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving and driving while her ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug, operate a vehicle contrary to s.255(1) and s.253(a) of the Criminal Code. The accused was found not guilty of both charges. The evidence of the officer was insufficient to support a belief of impairment as prerequisite to a breath demand, cannot alone prove impaired driving beyond a reasonable doubt. The breath sample evidence was obtained as a consequence of the breach of s.8 and s9 of the Charter of Rights. The officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds for making the breathalyzer demand and the evidence did not support a subjective honest belief on the part of the police officer that the accused was impaired. The Court found that the evidence of an officer who had not been convinced of the accused's impairment as a prerequisite to the breath demand was insufficient. The Evidence of the Officer, which was insufficient insufficient to show a belief in impairment as required to a demand, could alone prove impairment driving beyond the reasonable doubt; the evidence does not support an honest belief. The court found that there was no subjective honest evidence on the officer that she was impaired at the time she made the breath request. The issue was whether the accused could operate a Motor Vehicle while impaired by the alcohol or drugs. The police officer was unsure of whether the complainant had alcohol in her system when she read the accused the ASD demand and there was nothing new evidence gathered between 8:17 a.m. and 8:45 a. m. to justify the breath refusal. The Crown did not establish that the officer had reasonable and reasonable grounds for the breath seizure demand. The defence argued that the certificate of analyses should not be admissible because the breathalyszer demand was not made forthwith or as soon as practicable. The certificate of analysis should not have been admissible as it was insufficiently supported a belief that impairment as pre-condition to a request to operate the motor vehicle. The respondent's defence argued the certificate was not admissible due to the officer's failure to take judicial notice of the fact that she would have been more impaired later at the detachment than she would been at the moment in time when she was parking the truck. The trial judge concluded that the respondent's own testimony that she had been drinking alcohol and was feeling the effects of the alcohol at the same time was not enough to prove impaired.
column4: Count #3 and further that on or about the 21st day of July, A.D. 2004 at North Battleford, in the Province of Saskatchewan did while her ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or a drug, operate a motor vehicle contrary to Section 255(1) and Section 253(a) of the Criminal Code. Count #4 and further that on or about the 21st day of July, A.D. 2004 at North Battleford, in the Province of Saskatchewan did having consumed alcohol in such quantity that the concentration thereof in her blood exceeded eighty milligrams of alcohol in one hundred millilitres of blood, operate a motor vehicle contrary to Section 253(b) and Section 255(1) of the Criminal Code. [2] As there was no evidence before the Court of the undertaking alleged in Counts 1 and 2, the accused is not guilty of those two charges. [26] I conclude that the demand was not made forthwith or as soon as practicable and consequently, her rights under sections 8 and 9 of the Charter of Rights were breached. [27] I also conclude that the officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds for making the breathalyzer demand. Therefore, the evidence does not support a subjective honest belief on the part of the officer that the ability of the accused to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol. [30] As the breath sample evidence was obtained as a consequence of the breach of the Section 8 and 9 Charter Rights of the accused, it should be excluded under Section 24(2). [33] The evidence of the officer, which I have found insufficient to support a belief of impairment as prerequisite to a breath demand, cannot alone prove impaired driving beyond a reasonable doubt. When I consider those explanations together with the uncertainty of the police officer as to whether or not she had alcohol in her system at the time she read her the ASD demand, I am unable to conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that the ability of the accused to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol at the time she was driving. CONCLUSION [37] I find the accused not guilty of all counts.

[27] I also conclude that the officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds for making the breathalyzer demand. Therefore, the evidence does not support a subjective honest belief on the part of the officer that the ability of the accused to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol. [30] As the breath sample evidence was obtained as a consequence of the breach of the Section 8 and 9 Charter Rights of the accused, it should be excluded under Section 24(2). column27: The accused was charged with impaired driving and driving while her ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug, operate a vehicle contrary to s.255(1) and s.253(a) of the Criminal Code. The accused was found not guilty of both charges. The evidence of the officer was insufficient to support a belief of impairment as prerequisite to a breath demand, cannot alone prove impaired driving beyond a reasonable doubt. The breath sample evidence was obtained as a consequence of the breach of s.8 and s9 of the Charter of Rights. The officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds for making the breathalyzer demand and the evidence did not support a subjective honest belief on the part of the police officer that the accused was impaired. The Court found that the evidence of an officer who had not been convinced of the accused's impairment as a prerequisite to the breath demand was insufficient. The Evidence of the Officer, which was insufficient insufficient to show a belief in impairment as required to a demand, could alone prove impairment driving beyond the reasonable doubt; the evidence does not support an honest belief. The court found that there was no subjective honest evidence on the officer that she was impaired at the time she made the breath request. The issue was whether the accused could operate a Motor Vehicle while impaired by the alcohol or drugs. The police officer was unsure of whether the complainant had alcohol in her system when she read the accused the ASD demand and there was nothing new evidence gathered between 8:17 a.m. and 8:45 a. m. to justify the breath refusal. The Crown did not establish that the officer had reasonable and reasonable grounds for the breath seizure demand. The defence argued that the certificate of analyses should not be admissible because the breathalyszer demand was not made forthwith or as soon as practicable. The certificate of analysis should not have been admissible as it was insufficiently supported a belief that impairment as pre-condition to a request to operate the motor vehicle. The respondent's defence argued the certificate was not admissible due to the officer's failure to take judicial notice of the fact that she would have been more impaired later at the detachment than she would been at the moment in time when she was parking the truck. The trial judge concluded that the respondent's own testimony that she had been drinking alcohol and was feeling the effects of the alcohol at the same time was not enough to prove impaired.

column2: The appellant appeals his conviction of dangerous driving. The police did not see the appellant driving; they came across his minivan immersed in a slough in excess of 35 feet off the highway. Based on the tire tracks, the appellant was charged with dangerous driving. The trial judge concluded that the circumstantial evidence presented by the Crown was consistent with the appellant's guilt and the circumstantial evidence was inconsistent with any other rational conclusion. The appellant argues that without expert evidence called by the Crown to prove it was not possible for the appellant to have swerved in the manner he testified to create the same physical evidence shown in the photographs, the Crown has failed to prove that the appellant drove through the stop sign. In other words, the trial judge could not simply rely on his own experience to find that the appellant could not have been able to manoeuvre the minivan in the way he described. HELD: Because the Crown's evidence was not the only rational conclusion to be drawn by the trier of fact, the Crown has failed to prove the case beyond a reasonable doubt. While no accident reconstructionist was available to check the accident scene after the incident, the Crown could have called an expert to testify whether the defence's theory could hypothetically be rational. However, no expert was called. The appeal is allowed and the conviction set aside.
column3: The appellant appeals his conviction of dangerous driving. The trial judge concluded that the circumstantial evidence presented by the Crown was consistent with the appellant's guilt and the circumstANTial evidence was inconsistent with any other rational conclusion. The Crown's theory at trial was that, from the trajectory of the tire tracks, Fleury approached the 'T' intersection from the west, and had not stopped at the stop sign. The appellant's counsel argues that, without expert evidence called by the police to prove that it was not possible for Fleury to have swerved in such a manner to create the same physical evidence shown in the photographs, the Crown has failed to prove the case beyond a reasonable doubt. The appeal is allowed and the conviction is set aside.

column2: The two accused were found guilty, after trial, of robbery with violence contrary to s. 344(b) of the Criminal Code and wearing a mask with the intent to commit an indictable offence contrary to s. 351(2) of the Code. HELD: The accused are sentenced to 40 months imprisonment for the offence of robbery with violence and 4 months consecutive for the offence of having their faces masked. Having regard for the fact that the accused have been in custody for nearly 10 months, the Court gives them two for one credit for time served in remand which is 20 months. The sentence is 2 years to be served in a federal penitentiary. The sentence takes into consideration their lengthy record of offences committed as young offenders, the gravity of the offence, the violence used against the victim, the fact that a high speed chase ensued in the city, and the need to deter not only these accused but other who might consider committing the offence of robbery.
column3: The accuseds were convicted of robbery with violence and assault with a weapon. The accuseds had been in custody since January 2007 and had been on remand for 20 months. The Crown had previously applied for a capital sentence in this case. The court of appeal increased the sentence to two years less a day for the date of appeal. The sentence was based on the aggravating and mitigating factors of the offence, the defendant's lengthy record of offences committed as young offenders, the gravity of the offences, the violence against the victim, the fact that a high speed chase ensued within the city, and the need to deter not only these individuals but also anyone else who might consider committing the offence of robbery. The sentences were appropriate in the circumstances. The two accuseds' criminal records were appalling. The Court of Appeal gave them one credit for time served on remands which was 20 months and the sentence was reduced to two for one credit to be served in a federal penitentiary. The victim surcharge was waived. The offender's record as an adult consists of a conviction for driving while impaired and a conviction of having their faces masked. The offences were committed when the accuseds lived in Regina. The convictions were made in 2007 and 2008. The sentencing guidelines were set out in s. 718 and 718. The Criminal Code provides that a person convicted of a robbery is liable to imprisonment for life. For the offence that masking one's face with intent to commit an indictable offence, person can be sentenced to term not exceeding ten years. The offence of armed robbery is a serious and violent crime. The maximum sentence for each offence is two years imprisonment. The amount of time served is reduced to 2 years.
column4: He was sentenced to three months in secure custody and nine months of probation on each charge to be served concurrently. The trial judge, in our opinion, failed to adequately take into account the need for the protection of the public from individuals such as the accused. The Court of Appeal increased the sentence to two-years-less-a-day for the date of the appeal. column27: The accuseds were convicted of robbery with violence and assault with a weapon. The accuseds had been in custody since January 2007 and had been on remand for 20 months. The Crown had previously applied for a capital sentence in this case. The court of appeal increased the sentence to two years less a day for the date of appeal. The sentence was based on the aggravating and mitigating factors of the offence, the defendant's lengthy record of offences committed as young offenders, the gravity of the offences, the violence against the victim, the fact that a high speed chase ensued within the city, and the need to deter not only these individuals but also anyone else who might consider committing the offence of robbery. The sentences were appropriate in the circumstances. The two accuseds' criminal records were appalling. The Court of Appeal gave them one credit for time served on remands which was 20 months and the sentence was reduced to two for one credit to be served in a federal penitentiary. The victim surcharge was waived. The offender's record as an adult consists of a conviction for driving while impaired and a conviction of having their faces masked. The offences were committed when the accuseds lived in Regina. The convictions were made in 2007 and 2008. The sentencing guidelines were set out in s. 718 and 718. The Criminal Code provides that a person convicted of a robbery is liable to imprisonment for life. For the offence that masking one's face with intent to commit an indictable offence, person can be sentenced to term not exceeding ten years. The offence of armed robbery is a serious and violent crime. The maximum sentence for each offence is two years imprisonment. The amount of time served is reduced to 2 years.

column2: The claimant purchaser brought an action for breach of contract and negligent misrepresentation, claiming that although the defendant vendors had advised her that there had been some damage to the chimney base in the residence, she had been told that this was a minor problem which was under repair and she had not been properly advised of a history of repeated flooding.  Following the purchase of the property, the claimant had commenced renovations and discovered extensive mould or rot throughout the basement, to such an extent that the entire basement had to be gutted, disinfected and rebuilt. She also claimed that a buried cistern was discovered in the backyard, which had been partly filled with earth but still filled up with rainwater and melted snow, and that the water had nowhere else to go but against the foundation. When the defendants brought a motion for non-suit at the conclusion of her case, the unrepresented claimant expressed surprise and dismay that her case could be dismissed before both sides had testified as she expected her remaining evidence to come out through the defendants' testimony. Motion granted; the claim against the defendants is dismissed; it is the responsibility of the buyer to verify the accuracy of the Property Condition Disclosure Statement (PCDS) and, in this case, the claimant had made no inquiry as to the statements made by the defendants of structural problems or unrepaired damage or leakage in the foundation. The claimant had notification, both in the PCDS and from her home inspector, that there were leakage problems in the basement and the inspection report had advised her of the need to make further enquiries. There was no evidence the latent defects (the cracks in the wall, the mould and the rotten wood) were visible to the defendants when they occupied the home, that there was continual leakage of which the defendants were aware or that the defendants had performed any repairs to the home during their occupancy to cover up the wood rot. Although there was evidence that the defendants were aware of the cistern and had not disclosed this to the claimant, there was no evidence to conclude that the cistern was causing the problem.
column3: The plaintiff claimed $25,000 for damages for a house sale claim. The claim alleged that the plaintiff failed to disclose that the place had flooded in the past. The plaintiff alleged that there was damage to the chimney base, which was under repair and the heavy rain would cause seepage in the furnace room. The defendant claimed the plaintiff did not disclose that it had flooded previously. The court reviewed the evidence and found that the claim was not credible. The Court concluded that the defendant's disclosure statement did not adequately disclose the history of repeated flooding. The judge found that there were no errors in the disclosure statement and the plaintiff was not liable for any damages.

HELD: The claim was dismissed. 1)The court found that there was insufficient evidence to establish that the place had flooded in the past. 2)The defendant offered a plethora of defences, including a doctrine of caveat emptor and relying upon the law of agency. 3)The Court found that the plaintiff had proven or provided the court was sufficient evidence to show they had a case which was recognized by the law. 4)The test on a non-suit motion is whether the plaintiff has established a prima facie case, or, as it is sometimes described, whether a jury, properly instructed on the law could, on the facts adduced, find in favour of the plaintiff. The court concluded that this was not the case. 5)It is necessary to allow the parties to present all the facts that can be proven in a court of law. The test is whether a claim is made for damages based on a failure to disclose the facts relevant to a claim. 6)The plaintiff has demonstrated that the respondent did not make out her claim as evidence of the necessary elements to prove the claims are not present. 7)The evidence is not conclusive. 8)The judge must consider the sufficiency of the evidence, not the weight or the believability of evidence.

column2: The appellant was tried by Queen's Bench judge sitting alone and found guilty of operating a motor vehicle while his ability to operate the vehicle was impaired by alcohol, thereby causing death contrary to s. 255(3) of the Criminal Code, and causing bodily harm contrary to s. 255(2) of the Code. He was sentenced to 5 years imprisonment after having been given credit of 1 year for the time served on remand. The appellant appeals both his conviction and sentence. On the conviction appeal the appellant raises a technical ground in relation to the manner in which the appellant was charged as well as issues of the propriety and fairness of the cross-examination of himself by Crown counsel, the admissibility of his criminal record at trial, and the admissibility of opinion evidence proved in the testimony of the Crown's expert witness on accident reconstruction. He also argues that the trial judge failed to find that the fact that the appellant was impaired at the time of the collision was the cause of the collision and that his conclusion was unreasonable and against the weight of the evidence. HELD: Appeal dismissed.  1) The trial judge has a discretion pursuant to R. v. Corbett, [1988] 1 S.C.R. 670, to exclude prejudicial evidence of prior convictions in an appropriate case. This discretion is exercised by the trial judge on the application of an accused at the close of the Crown's case. See R. v. Underwood, [1998] 1 S.C.R. 77. As such an application was not raised in this case, and the questioning about previous convictions by the Crown was not objected to when it occurred, and the issue of the appellant's previous alcohol related offences was raised in the appellant's own examination in chief, this court concludes that there is no basis for this Court to conclude that the cross-examination was inappropriate or that the evidence adduced was inadmissible.  2) It is not proper for Crown counsel to ask an accused on cross-examination to explain the testimony of a Crown witness, and that it is highly unfair and prejudicial to require an accused to agree with a Crown witness or stigmatize that witness as a 'liar'. Crown counsel should not have put these sorts of questions and the trial judge ought not to have permitted them. Defence counsel did not object to them. However, this Court is not satisfied that this error had any effect on the trial and this ground of appeal fails.  3) The Crown elicited opinion evidence from Constable Gibson in the area of accident reconstruction. No evidence was at any time offered as to his expertise to do so, other than his curriculum vitae, which was filed. This witness's evidence as to how the bodies might have moved in the vehicle in the course of the collision and its aftermath, and in particular, his conclusory opinion that Ms. McDermott was the passenger and Mr. Bear the driver, ought not to have been received in the absence of a ruling that he was qualified as an expert in relation to those matters, and that his expertise was necessary in relation to the subject matter of his testimony, and that his opinion was based on facts before the Court. 4) The appellant was charged and convicted with offences pursuant to s. 255(2) and s. 255(3) of the Criminal Code. The appellant argues that conviction requires that the appellant has been charged with an offence pursuant to s. 253(a). There is no merit in this ground of appeal. Impaired driving causing death and bodily harm are routinely charged in this manner. 5) This Court's review of the cross-examination of the appellant supports the trial judge's assessment of it as unbelievable. In light of the trial judge's findings of credibility, and the results of the DNA analysis of the samples taken, the evidence overwhelmingly supports the verdict reached by the trial judge that the appellant was driving. The conclusory opinions expressed by Constable Gibson in relation to the movements of the occupants in the truck, and as to who was driving the vehicle, played no meaningful role in a conclusion that was, compelled by the remaining evidence. Notwithstanding the errors apparent in the receipt of opinion evidence from Constable Gibson, there was no substantial miscarriage of justice. The appeal from conviction is dismissed. 6) The trial judge did not commit any error of principle in coming to the conclusion that an appropriate sentence was 6 years imprisonment. While the sentence is at the high end of the available range, it is not outside the range available in the circumstances of this case.

column2: Mr. Kenny is charged under The Wildlife Act Regulations, 1981 with use of a searchlight when hunting. Specifically, the section reads: 11.1(2) For the purpose of ensuring the safety of hunters and the public, a searchlight shall not be used for the purposes of hunting wildlife. The case was decided on the basis of credibility. The Court reviewed the requirements for assessing credibility and found it did not believe the accused. The Court stated that, on all the evidence, it was convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused was using a searchlight for the purpose of hunting wildlife. HELD: The accused is guilty as charged.
column3: The defendant was charged under the Wildlife Act Regulations with use of a searchlight when hunting. The section of the Act that prohibits the use of searchlight in the context of hunting wildlife was amended to include the phrase 'hunting for wildlife' in the meaning of the words 'wildlife'. The defendant admitted to driving slowly in the dark and that he had seen a moose. The defendant acknowledged that he was driving slowly when he spotted the moose and that the mooses were located on the rear seat of the truck. The vehicle was under surveillance for approximately 30 minutes. The driver and owner of the vehicle were seated next to 30-30 rifles, 30-round rifles, and 14 rounds of ammunition. The Defendant acknowledged that they had fallen asleep within minutes of getting into the truck as they were traversing the forest. The searchlight was not used to search for wildlife. The Court was satisfied that the defendant was using the searchlight for the purposes of hunting. It was not reasonable to believe that the driver was looking for a moosed when he was first observed. The evidence was that he drove slowly in a forest, and then returned to pick up his son and nephew after they had returned to the house. The Crown had closed its case and the sole defence witness was the defendant. The court did not believe the evidence of the defendant and was not left in doubt by it. The trial proceeded on the basis of an Agreed Statement of Facts filed as Exhibit P-1 and the production of five other exhibits. The Criminal Code speaks to the monetary penalty for contraventions of the act or Regulations. The offence was committed under the Act. The accused was convicted of possession of a weapon for the purpose of hunting and was fined $22,000. The seizure of the licence was made in connection with the seizure of his hunting licence. The conviction was not subject to forfeiture. The officer who pulled the defendant over was convicted on a charge of possession for the offence of trafficking. The offences were not related to hunting.
column4: [1] Mr. Kenny is charged under The Wildlife Act Regulations, 1981 with use of a searchlight when hunting. [10] Having gone through that analysis, and for the reasons that follow, I do not believe the evidence of the defendant, and I am not left in doubt by it. [20] On all the evidence, I am satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that Mr. Kenny was using the searchlight for the purposes of hunting wildlife, and I find him guilty.

He also admitted that he had seen one in the forest earlier that morning, had then gone shopping in Prince Albert with his wife, and had returned to pick up his son and nephew after they had spent the night in a nearby forest. The Crown closed its case and the sole defence witness was the defendant. HELD: 1) Having gone through that analysis and for the reasons that follow, I do not believe the evidence of the defendant and am not left in doubt by it. On all of the evidence, am convinced of his guilt beyond reasonable doubt.  2) Having went through that Analysis, and for reasons that followed, the defendant is not left out by it and I am convinced that he is not in any doubt by the evidence.  3) On all the evidence the defendant was, as he says, looking at wildlife, and he was driving slowly on roads that were in prime hunting area, it is not credible to believe he happened to run into the complainant's wife. It is not reasonable to believe that he said that he was going into the forest to pick his son up, and that this woman would then ask him to look for her husband, who happened to also be in the same forest hunting. 4) The defendant was convicted of possession of a weapon during a search for wildlife. 5) The Court was satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that the evidence was not supported by the Crown's analysis of the facts. The Court held that the defendant's evidence was unreliable and the Court did not believe it.

The evidence is not supported by the Crown's argument that it is impossible to find someone in a vast tract of land in the dark, hoping to locate someone else who was there, hunting. It lacks any degree of probability that the first thought that would come to his mind, when he picked up his son and nephew, was that Mr. Black may have been hurt by moose. The Crown bears the burden throughout the case; there is no onus on the defendant to prove anything. In total, must be satisfied that the evidence is accepted by the Court. 2) The Court found that the accused was not guilty of the following offences: 1) The accused was convicted of possession of a weapon of mass destruction (a rifle) and possession of ammunition (a handgun) for the purpose of searching for wildlife. It is not reasonable to believe that he was looking for someone in vast area such as provincial forest in the first place, let alone at night. It cannot escape notice that there were two loaded firearms in the vehicle; cannot accept that they were loaded simply because there was a mere oversight by Mr. Kenny's companions, and him, in ensuring they were unloaded at the time he picked them up. What am left with are some uncontroverted facts, all of which are consistent only with an inescapable inference that the appellant was employing the search light as a hunting tool. The terms 'hunting' and 'wildlife' are all defined in the Act or Regulations. However, the moose caller was being used in this case. There was no evidence from anyone that any efforts whatsoever were being made to locate the individual other than shining the spotlight. If one were truly looking for an injured individual in large forest, certainly one would assume that the searching parties would have been yelling and making noise to attract the subject's attention.

column2: Rule 85.04 – Order for confidentiality The parties moved under Rule 59.60 to have the court seal their file after media asked to view it. They didn't ask to exclude the public from the hearing, nor did they seek a publication ban.  , the file will be sealed. While Rule 59.60 doesn't provide guidance on when it would be appropriate to seal a file, Rule 85.04(1) does. The SCC decision of Dagenais (and related cases) applies. A confidentiality order should only be granted when: necessary to prevent a serious risk to an important interest; there are no less intrusive measures available; and the benefits outweigh the costs. Personal embarrassment or damage to a party's reputation isn't enough. Here, the important public interest is the protection of personal identifiers (e.g. SIN's, addresses, bank account numbers and other personal information required on court documents). Having these identifiers accessible to members of the public can result in identity theft, which is a real and serious concern. The court is able to take judicial notice of the fact society values the prevention of identity theft (and that it exists in the first place). There are no less intrusive measures to prevent access to this personal information that aren't cumbersome and costly for the parties and court administration staff. The salutary effects of a sealing order outweigh its deleterious effects, especially since the public will still be permitted to access the court hearing and any decision that is rendered. The open court principle was crafted at a time when the internet wasn't a public source of information and manipulation.
column3: The parties had both requested an order to seal their divorce file. They had done so after receiving a request from the media to examine that file. The media requested that the file be sealed to protect their reputation and to allow the Maintenance Enforcement Program to find a payor of spousal or child support. The parties had previously agreed that the filing of the divorce application would be a form of invasion of privacy. The court found that the public in general had an interest in and expected personal identifier information to remain private and confidential. The public interest in an open court was not completely circumscribed by the sealing order. The salutary effects of a sealing order do outweigh its deleterious effects particularly because the public interest is not completely inhibited by this order.

HELD: The court found that the salutary effects of a sealing order do outweigh its deleterious effects. The public interest in an open court is not completely circumscribed by this order. The court has a supervisory and protecting power over its own records. It has a duty to protect the privacy of witnesses or children. It is not the case that the public has an interest in and expects personal identifier information to be protected in order to prevent identity theft. The general public has a right to know what evidence is likely to be called in matrimonial cause, what might be expected by division of property and how that evidence might be put forward. There must be some social value or public interest of superordinate importance in the context of these proceedings. There is a social value to be derived from the public expectation that personal identifiers will be kept private and confidential. The risk of identity theft is real. Should not have to wait until it occurs to recognize that risk. There are circumstances where the court must be open to public scrutiny to prevent serious risk to an important interest. There has to be a general interest in preserving confidential information. The applicant and respondent have both raised one proposition that has decided does not constitute a'social value' or public interests of super-ordinate importance' in this context. It does not require the court to consider the underlying principles set out in Dagenais and Canadian Broadcasting.

column2: The appellant appealed a decision of the trial judge declaring a mistrial in his summary offence trial and setting a new date for trial because the Crown had not disclosed a police record.  He argued the judge erred by not ordering a stay of proceedings and/or a dismissal at the beginning of the trial, and by failing to find the non-disclosure violated his rights under s. 11(d) of the Charter. He sought a stay of proceedings in this action. Dismissing the appeal, that a declaration is not an 'order' under s. 813(a)(i) of the Code in that it does not bring a final end to the matter. It is therefore not appealable.
column3: This was an appeal of a decision of His Honour Judge Randall wherein the trial judge declared a mistrial and set a new trial on a charge of failing to disclose a police record of the individual weighing of each set of wheels on a tandem axle truck. The offence is under the regulations of the Motor Vehicle Act. The appellant appealed the trial Judge's decision to declare a mistririal and/or a dismissal of the charge, which the Crown had not disclosed. The trial judge failed to find that the appellant's rights had been violated under s. 11(d) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms as a result of non-disclosure and erred at law by not finding pursuant to s. 24(2) of Charter of rights or in the alternative not admit the evidence.
column4: CARVER, J: This is an Appeal by the appellant, James F. Oickle, from a decision of His Honour Judge Randall, wherein the Trial Judge declared a mistrial and set a new date for trial because the Crown had not disclosed a police record that contained the individual weighing of each set of wheels on the accused tandem axle truck. 1. That the Learned Trial Judge erred at the commencement of proceedings upon motion by defence counsel for a stay of proceeding and/or a dismissal of the charge by failing to so order, as a result of non‑disclosure by the Crown, of information crucial to proving of the Crown\'s case. 2. That the Learned Trial Judge erred during the proceedings, upon evidence being called by the Crown, by declaring a mistrial upon motion by defence counsel for certain evidence not to be admitted as a result of non‑disclosure or, in the alternative, that a stay or dismissal be ordered as a result of non‑disclosure of additional information crucial to proving the Crown\'s case not being provided to defence counsel and being relied upon in the evidence of the Crown. That the Learned Trial Judge erred by failing to find that the appellant\'s rights had been violated under Section 11(d) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms as a result of non‑disclosure and erred at law by not finding pursuant to Section 24(2) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms that the appropriate remedy was to order a stay of proceedings or in the alternative not admit the evidence. A declaration of a mistrial and the setting down of the information for trial before another judge does not put an end to the proceeding which the information began. It is not a final order as contemplated by Section 813(a)(i) of the Criminal Code. The Appeal is dismissed and the case remitted to the Provincial Court for a new trial on the information still before the court.

A declaration of a mistrial and the setting down of the information for trial before another judge does not put an end to the proceeding which the information began. It is not a final order as contemplated by Section 813(a)(i) of the Criminal Code. The Appeal is dismissed and the case remitted to the Provincial Court for a new trial on the information still before the court.

column2: A Father appealed an order permanently committing his 3 children to the care of the Minister of Social Services. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)It is an established principle that an appeal court should not interfere with the findings of fact by a trial judge unless the findings are not supported by the evidence or the conclusions reached by the trial judge are clearly wrong so as to make the decision unreasonable. 2)The trial judge did not misdirect himself on the law or the evidence with respect to the governing principles applicable to applications of this kind.
column3: W. M. appealed the order of Diehl, P.C.J. pursuant to the provisions of s.37(2) of The Child and Family Services Act permanently committing his three children to the care of the Minister responsible for theadministration of the Act. The names and birth dates of the children were recorded as follows: D.W.M. born November 26, 1980; D.A.M., July 6, 1985. The age of the oldest child was recorded as D.M.'s. birth dates were recorded in 1980; A.M'a.M.; D.B.M'.s. born July 6 1985. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with costs. It was an established principle that an appeal court should not interfere with the findings of fact by a trial judge unless the findings are not supported by the evidence or the conclusions reached by the trial judge are clearly wrong. The trial judge did not misdirect himself on the law or the evidence with respect to the principles set out in Saskatchewan (Minister of Social Services) v. E.S.1984) and Sask.R. 262. It is an established fact that an appeals court should never interfere with findings of truth by a judge unless they are notsupported by the facts or the conclusion reached by trial judge. The judge did so clearly wrong so as to make the decision unreasonable.

In my view, the trial Judge did not directhimself upon the law, the evidence, or the Governing principles. The findings were clearly wrong. The conclusions reached were clearly reasonable. The decision was unreasonable. It is an established law that an appeals court should never interfere with findings of truth by a judge unless they are not adhered to. The verdict was unreasonable and the conclusions were clearly incorrect. The conclusion of the trial was clearly wrong and the decision was unreasonable.

column2: FIAT The Husband alleged that a child support order, originally in the amount of $1,200.00, had been reduced by mutual agreement to $500.00 per month in 1989 when the Wife commenced employment. He applied to vary the order to correspond to the alleged agreement. The Wife denied any agreement to reduce the original order and sought judgment for arrears in the amount of $55,000.00. HELD: On a review of all material filed, the Court concluded that it was not possible to resolve the matter summarily. The Court directed a trial of the issues between the parties.
column3: FIAT. The applicant applied for an order varying the support provisions of a 1989 Supreme Court judgment. He sought an order requiring a total payment of $570.75 per month for both children. The respondent opposed the application. HELD: An order for a trial of the issue. 1)The respondent wife was entitled to the petitioner husband's support upon the respondent obtaining full time employment. 2)The petitioner husband was responsible for child support. He was responsible to pay child support for two infant children. 3)The applicant's income was in excess of $55,000.00. The court ordered a trial.

column2: The Minister of Social Services applied for an order that the Public Trustee be served with notice of a protection hearing and act as litigation guardian for H.B. who was alleged to be of unsound mind. H.B.'s child born in 1995 was apprehended at birth and was currently subject of a child protection hearing. The Minister relied on the Public Trustee Act and, alternatively, on the court's inherent parens patriae jurisdiction.HELD: The Public Trustee was appointed amicus curae to act on behalf of H.B. upon being satisfied she is unable to act for herself. An assessment was ordered pursuant to s32 of the Child and Family Services Act. The order was to issue unless the Public Trustee shows cause as to why it is not the appropriate party within 10 days from the date of this order. 1)While the wording of s32 is ambiguous the Public Trustee was correct that the Act does not authorize it to represent an adult under a mental disability other than where a property interest is involved. Nowhere does the Act authorize the Public Trustee to act as personal guardian of a dependant or mentally incompetent adult. The PT Act does not authorize its appointment as litigation guardian in the matter of child protection proceedings. 2)Pursuant to its parens patriae jurisdiction the Court has a responsibility to protect the interests of H.B. who requires independent representation to ensure her rights are protected. If the court failed to intervene H.B. will be left in limbo, a victim of the system.
column3: The Minister of Social Services applied for an order that the Public Trustee be served with notice of a protection hearing and act as litigation guardian for the mother of a child who was apprehended at birth and is currently the subject of a Child Protection Hearing. HELD: The Public Trustees Act does not authorize the appointment of the Public trustee as a litigation guardian on the basis of s. 32 of the Act. The Minister relies on the Public Charter and the Child and Family Services Act. Pursuant to its parens patriae jurisdiction, this Court has a responsibility to protect the interests of the child and requires independent representation to ensure that her rights are protected (see: Child and Child Protection Act). The Public Charter does not permit the Public to act as a lawyer on behalf of a person who is of unsound mind in cases other than where a property interest is involved. If the court fails to intervene, the child will be left in limbo, a victim of the system. The Public is the appropriate person to act on behalf for the child. The Act does, however, authorize the Public the jurisdiction to act for the person alleged to be of unsounded mind in the matter of the Child Protection proceedings concerning her son. The Court will issue an order unless the Public is not the appropriate party to act.
column4:
The Minister of Social Services has applied for an
order that the Public Trustee be served with notice of a
protection hearing and act as litigation guardian for H.B. While the wording of s. 32 is somewhat ambiguous, in
my opinion the Public Trustee is right in asserting that the
Act does not authorize it to represent an adult under mental
disability in cases other than where a property interest is
involved. adults. Nowhere does the Act authorize the Public Trustee to
act as the personal guardian of a dependant or mentally
incompetent adult. I, therefore, conclude that The Public Trustee Act
does not authorize the appointment of the Public Trustee to
act as litigation guardian for H.B. in the matter of the child
protection proceedings concerning her son, R.J.B., Jr. Pursuant to its
parens patriae jurisdiction, this Court has a responsibility
to protect the interests of H.B.; she requires independent
representation to ensure that her rights are protected (see:
Re: Eve, supra, and S.L.R. [No. 1] (1993), 1992 CanLII 8052 (SK QB), 104 Sask. R. 81). If the court fails to intervene in this regard, H.B. will be

column7: The Minister of Social Services applied for an order that the Public Trustee be served with notice of a protection hearing and act as litigation guardian for H.B. who was alleged to be of unsound mind. H.B.'s child born in 1995 was apprehended at birth and was currently subject of a child protection hearing. column8: The Minister of Social Services applied for an order that the Public Trustee be served with notice of a protection hearing and act as litigation guardian for the mother of a child who was apprehended at birth and is currently the subject of child protection hearing. HELD: 1) The court relied on the Public Act s. 32(1)(d) and s. 43.1 as amended and, alternatively, on the court's inherent parens patriae jurisdiction. 2) The wording of s.32 is somewhat ambiguous. In certain jurisdictions Public Trustees have by statute been given specific authority to act as a litigation guardian on behalf of the child. However that does not fully determine the issue. The Minister contends the court can and should appoint the public trustee as a lawyer for H.B. Nowhere does the Act authorize the public trustee to act in the manner that it should. If the court fails to intervene in this regard, H.'s son will be left in limbo, a victim of the system. 3) The Public Truste Act does not authorize the Public trustee to act on behalf the person alleged to be of unsound mind in the matter of her son. It is intended to protect and administer the property of infants and dependant adults. Now there is a conflict (if such there be) between the Public and Queen's Bench Rules 22 and 46, the Act must prevail.

column2: The plaintiff was subcontracted by the City of Dartmouth to build a sports field. The defendant were the project consultants for the City, and were involved throughout the tendering process and construction. Their report indicated a number of significant potential problems. The plaintiff was not made aware of the report when it bid on the project. The plaintiff subsequently became aware of the problems, which made their work more costly. After completing the work, it commenced a claim for the additional work which had to be performed due to the undisclosed site conditions. The defendants were joined by the City as a third party to that action. The plaintiff was successful at trial, but the decision was overturned on appeal. The plaintiff then commenced the present action directly against the defendant, alleging negligent misrepresentation. The defendant applied to strike the action on the basis of res judicata and abuse of process. Granting the application, that the present cause of action is the same one litigated in the first action, simply under a different legal concept. To allow the plaintiff to relitigate the same action on the same factual basis would be an abuse of process.
column3: The plaintiff sought to have the defendant's statement of claim struck out on the basis of res judicata and abuse of process. The defendant argued that the plaintiff had failed to disclose material facts relevant to its action. The plaintiff argued that it had not been able to prove that the city's negligence had been decided by a combination of the trial judge's and the Court of Appeal's decisions in the first action. It also argued that there was no final decision or judgment on any of the issues alleged by the plaintiff to be the subject of issue estoppel. The court dismissed the application. The Court held that the defendant had not shown that it intended to relitigate the action on the same factual basis on a different legal concept.
column4: I find that, on the basis of all of the affidavits, the first action as amended from time to time and as adjudicated, the agreed statement of facts and the present pleadings, that the application of CBCL ought to be granted. I find that the present cause of action is the very same one litigated in the first action, simply under a different legal concept. I am satisfied that to allow Granview to now basically relitigate the same action on the same factual basis on a different legal concept which it considered but did not proceed with would be an abuse of process of the court. I therefore grant CBCL\'s application and strike out the statement of claim and dismiss the present action. The application of Granview is therefore dismissed.

column18: The plaintiff commenced an action under the Mechanics' Lien Act for unpaid monies, which in the end consisted primarily of claim for extra or additional work which had to be performed because of alleged undisclosed site conditions. Shortly after commencing the work Turf Masters, by then called Granview, the City, and third party indemnity claim by the City against CBCL which alleged negligence or negligent misrepresentation on the part of CBCL. The plaintiff commenced a quantum meruit against the City alleging breach of the standard of care, negligence on part of the city, and breach of contract or negligence against the third party. The city commenced a second action against the plaintiff, this time against a third party for non-disclosure of site reports, alleging negligence or misrepresentation by the city and that the city had abandoned the idea of an international calibre soccer field and instead proceeded with a recreational park with some playing fields. In this second action, the plaintiff requested certain paragraphs of the plaintiff's defence be struck out pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 14.25 on the basis of res judicata and abuse of process. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Court found that there was no final decision or judgment on any of the issues alleged by the plaintiff to be the subject of issue estoppel. 2)The court found that the plaintiff should have raised the point now asserted in the second action in early 1993 and well before trial. It appears to have been well aware of the factual basis for the present allegation and that only certain aspects of negligence had been decided by the previous decisions in the first action. It was satisfied that to allow Granview to now basically relitigate the same action on the same factual basis on a different legal concept which it considered but did not proceed with would be an abuse of the process.
