column2: An appeal from an order varying a child maintenance order which had been based on a written agreement between the parties entered into a week before the Federal Child Support Guidelines came into effect. The application to vary made about a year later was based mainly on the coming into effect of the guidelines. The decision to not to allow evidence on all issues because of conflicting affidavits gave rise to the first ground of appeal. The appellant also argued that the judge erred in finding that an order to vary would not be inequitable within the meaning of s.17(6.2) by reason of the terms of the written agreement and resulting order which contained special provisions to benefit the children. He also objected to the s.7(1)(f) order for $230 per month for extraordinary extracurricular expenses. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with the exception of the payments under s.7(1)(f) which were set aside. 1)The applicant was not denied the right to lead evidence on any relevant issue. Although the judge made no reversible error the procedure followed was not approved of. The principles stated in Zaba v. Bradley were reaffirmed. 2)No reversible error was found in the finding the appellant did not have custody of or access to the children for enough time to bring him within s.9; that the appellant's income for purposes of the Guidelines should include the bonuses received from his employer; and that he did not have a business based in his home. 3)The judge erred in not addressing the question as to whether the expenses were extraordinary within the meaning of s.7(1)(f). The activities were ordinary given the income of the parents and fell within the table amount fixed under s.3(1)(a).  4)Each party was to bear his/her own costs.
column3: The appellant appealed an order which varied a child maintenance order. The original order had been based on a written agreement between the parties. The judge thereupon decided not to allow evidence on all issues in dispute between the two parties. She thought that evidence was required on only three issues. The appellant objected to payment of these amounts only because the respondent never consulted him in respect of incurring the expenses. She erred in requiring the appellant to pay a portion of them under s7(1)(f) in addition to the table amount fixed under s3(1) and the portion of the judgment relating to payments under s.7(f) of the Guidelines was set aside. The appeal was dismissed.
column4: [1] At the conclusion of the hearing of this appeal, the result of the appeal was announced from the bench with brief written reasons to follow. [2] The appeal was from an order which varied a child maintenance order. The original order had been based on a written agreement between the parties entered into about a week before the Federal Child Support Guidelines, SOR/97-175, came into effect. We can find no reversible error in the judge’s decision, explained in the reasons for judgment, to reject the appellant’s arguments respecting that issue. [5] Similarly, we can find no error in the judge’s decisions, supported by written reasons, that (a) the appellant did not have custody of or access to the children for enough time to bring him within s. 9 of the Guidelines; (b) the appellant’s income, for the purposes of the Guidelines, should include the bonuses he received from his employer in 1996 and 1997, and (c) Mr. Elliott did not have a business based in the home. Accordingly, the judge erred in requiring the appellant to pay a portion of them under s. 7(1)(f) in addition to the table amount fixed under s. 3(1)(a). [8] That portion of the judgment relating to payments under s. 7(1)(f) of the Guidelines is set aside. In all other respects, the appeal is dismissed.

column8: The appellant appealed an order which varied a child maintenance order. The original order had been based on a written agreement between the parties. The respondent had custody of or access to the children for enough time to bring him within s. 9 of the Guidelines. Absent any evidence to the contrary, it seems to us that the activities were ordinary activities and the expenses were of an ordinary rather than an extraordinary nature, given the income of the children's parents. The judge erred in requiring the appellant to pay a portion of them under s. 7(1)(f) in addition to the table amount fixed under s3(1) as she thought that evidence was required on only three issues. The appellant objected to payment of these amounts only because the respondent never consulted him in respect of incurring the expenses. She then proceeded on the assumption that the appellant objected only because he was denied the right to lead evidence on any relevant issue. HELD: The appeal was set aside. The portion of the judgment relating to payments under s7(1(f) of the guidelines is set aside and the appeal is dismissed. There was no reversible error in the judge's decision, explained in the reasons for judgment, to reject the appellant's arguments respecting that issue. Similarly, we can find no error in either the judge’s decisions supported by written reasons, that (a) the appellant did not have custody or access of the parties for enough amount to bring them within s9 of the guideline; (b) Mr. Elliott did not own a business based in the home; and (c) Mr Elliott did have no business based here.

column2: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle while impaired contrary to s.255(1) and s.253(a) of the Criminal Code and with having consumed alcohol in such a quantity that his blood alcohol concentration exceeded .08 contrary to s.253(b) and s.255(1). The accused contended his right to be secure against unreasonable search and seizure as guaranteed by s.8 of the Charter and his right not to be arbitrarily detained or imprisoned as guaranteed by s.9 of the Charter were breached. In issue was whether the RCMP officer had the jurisdiction to carry out his duties as a peace officer in the City of Prince Albert; if so, was he acting in the lawful execution of his duties in conducting random stop. HELD: The accused was found guilty of driving with a blood alcohol level greater than .08. A judicial stay was entered in relation to the impaired count on which he would have been found guilty if it were necessary. 1)The language used by Parliament in the Royal Mounted Police Act is clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country of Canada. When there is a limitation on their duties it is clearly stated. The Police Act does not mention any exclusivity between one force and another. Given the ultra vires statute construction doctrine it would not be appropriate for provincial legislation to take away powers given by the Federal legislation. The Police Act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not a manner of taking away jurisdiction granted to RCMP officers. 2)The law is now clear that the police can detain vehicles as long as they do so for the purposes of checking for sobriety, licences, ownership, insurance and other mechanical fitness of motor vehicles. The R. v. Emke decision is outdated. 3)The officer was acting in the lawful execution of his duty. There was no breach of the accused's rights under the Charter.
column3: The accused was charged with two counts of impaired driving. The accused was on duty, in uniform, and driving a marked police vehicle. The officer observed that the vehicle displayed an out of date sticker on it's license plate in violation of S. 27(5) of the Highway Traffic Act. The police conducted a traffic stop and observed the accused's vehicle approach a curb and then proceed to the police station. The vehicle struck the curb and bounced off the curb. The officers approached the driver, who produced photo driver identification in the name of the accused. The driver asked the officer why he had not stopped. The RCMP responded by arresting the accused and arresting him. The Crown argued that the officer was acting within his jurisdiction and was in the lawful execution of his duty. The court concluded that the police act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not a manner to take away jurisdiction granted to R.C.M.P. officers by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act. HELD: The accused's charges were dismissed. 1)The police act is to be read as providing for the purposes of funding police and a manner in which the Crown can take away the jurisdiction granted by the R. C.M.'s officers by The Royal Canadian RCMP Act. 2)The language used by the police was clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country. There is nothing in the scheme or object of The Royal Canada Mounted police Act that derogates from that basic presumption. The Court concluded that when there is a limitation on their duties it is clearly stated. The Police Act clearly outlines the duties of members who are peace officers. The Queen's Bench judge referred the court to several cases dealing with the jurisdiction of the RCMP. The wording used by parliament was clear and unambiguously clear. The language used was clear. There was nothing in that scheme or the police Act derogates. The only presumption that a police officer is acting in the proper execution of their duties is not to be attributed to a legislative body. The Act must be interpreted in the context of providing a 'way of funding' policing not 'a manner of taking away jurisdiction' granted to the officers by a Royal Canadian Crown Mounted. column8: The accused was charged with two counts of impaired driving. The accused was on duty, in uniform, and driving a marked police vehicle. The officer observed that the vehicle displayed an out of date sticker on it's license plate in violation of S. 27(5) of the Highway Traffic Act. He engaged the police lights, followed the vehicle north on 4th Ave. West, bounced off the curb, then proceeded to stop within 30 feet of the vehicle. When the officer approached the driver, he asked him why he had not stopped. He could not understand the reply. He asked the accused if he wished to call a lawyer. The police officer asked him to return to the police station where he remained for another two minutes. The Crown argued that the language used by the police was clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country. HELD: 1) The Police Act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not a manner to taking away jurisdiction granted to R.C.M.P. officers by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act.  2) The police act is to be read as providing for the purposes of policing, not a way of taking away it's jurisdiction. 3) The language used in the police act was clear-cut, broad, unambiguous and in harmony with that intention, object and scheme and with the general body of the law. There is no good public policy reason for the police officer to be excluded from operating in any specific geographic area. It would not make sense for the legislature to limit the opportunity for policing of community by making sure fewer police officers are able to act in any particular setting within the province. 4) In reviewing the scheme and object of The Royal Canadian RCMP Police Force it was clear that section and section of the Act operate to render the Royal Canadians Mounted police officers part of 'police force for Canada' and peace officers 'for every part of Canada' with 'all the powers, authority, protection and privileges that a peace officer has by law.' 5) The Court found that when there is a limitation on their duties it is clearly stated that the officer is acting in the lawful execution of his duty if his stopping of the Abrametz vehicle should be regarded as a 'random stop'. 6) The Crown referred the court to several cases dealing with the jurisdiction involving provincial and municipal jurisdiction as examples of the different issues and problems that arise in the cases of municipal and provincial police forces

column13: The accused was charged with two counts of impaired driving contrary to s. 255(1) and s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was found not guilty. 1) The Police Act provides that police officers are restricted in enforcing the laws in force in any province in that they are given jurisdiction only in relation to provincial laws of the province in which they are employed. 2) The police act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not a manner to taking away jurisdiction granted to R.C.M.P. officers by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act. The language used by parliament was clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country. There is nothing in the scheme or object of The Royal Canadian RCMP Act that derogates from that basic presumption. 3) The Court was of the view that there is no good public policy reason for the police to be excluded from operating in any specific geographic area. It would not make sense for the legislature to limit the opportunity for policing of community by making sure fewer police officers were able to act in any particular setting within the province. 4) In reviewing the scheme and object of the RCMP, it is clear that section and section of the Act operate to render the police officers part of 'police force for Canada' and peace officers 'for every part of Canada' with 'all the powers, authority, protection and privileges that a police officer has by law.' 5) Section 21(3) makes it clear that when there is a limitation on their duties it is clearly stated. In this case the officer engaged the police lights, followed the vehicle north on 4th Ave. West, then right on to 27th Street where the vehicle hit the curb, bounced off the curb and then proceeded to stop within 30 feet. Therefore clearly the Police Act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not as taking away jurisdiction granted to R.C.M.P. officers by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act.  2) The language used by parliament was clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country. There is nothing in the scheme or object of the police Act that derogates from that basic presumption. 3) The Court concluded that the accused's right to be secure against unreasonable search and seizure guaranteed by Section of the Charter and his right not to be arbitrarily detained or detained was clearly stated. 4) In reviewing the scheme and object of The RCMP, it is clear that section and section of the Act operate to render the police officers part of 'police force for Canada' and peace officers 'for every part of Canada' with 'all the powers, authority, protection and privileges that a police officer has by law.' 5) The words of the RCMP are clear, unambiguous and in harmony with that intention, object and scheme and with the general body of the law. 6) There is no good public policy reason for the police officer to be excluded from operating in any specific geographic area. 7) The police officer was not acting in the lawful execution of his duties and responsibilities when he pulled over the accused. 8) The court found that the officer was acting within his jurisdiction and in the context of the intention of Parliament, the object, the Act or the scheme of the Police. 9) The evidence showed that the words 'are assigned' refer to the three distinct objects and not to specific areas of jurisdiction where Royal Canadian RCMP officers are employed within the province, as council for the defence would suggest. 10) The officer acknowledged that there was no basis to suspect the accused had done anything wrong and that the soul purpose was to ensure that his papers were in order and he had a valid driver’s licence. HELD: The accused was found not guilty. 1) The Police Act provides that police officers are restricted in enforcing the laws in force in any province in that they are given jurisdiction only in relation to provincial laws of the province in which they are employed. 2) The police act must be read in context as providing a manner of funding policing not a manner to taking away jurisdiction granted to R.C.M.P. officers by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act. The language used by parliament was clear, broad and unambiguous as it was their obvious intention to create a police force that operates without jurisdictional barriers throughout the entire country. There is nothing in the scheme or object of The Royal Canadian RCMP Act that derogates from that basic presumption. 3) The Court was of the view that there is no good public policy reason for the police to be excluded from operating in any specific geographic area. It would not make sense for the legislature to limit the opportunity for policing of community by making sure fewer police officers were able to act in any particular setting within the province. 4) In reviewing the scheme and object of the RCMP, it is clear that section and section of the Act operate to render the police officers part of 'police force for Canada' and peace officers 'for every part of Canada' with 'all the powers, authority, protection and privileges that a police officer has by law.' 5) Section 21(3) makes it clear that when there is a limitation on their duties it is clearly stated. In this case the officer engaged the police lights, followed the vehicle north on 4th Ave. West, then right on to 27th Street where the vehicle hit the curb, bounced off the curb and then proceeded to stop within 30 feet. The officer concluded, quite reasonably in the circumstances, that the accused's ability to operate motor vehicle was impaired and arrested him at 11:50 p.m. He was placed in the police vehicle was immediately allowed a call. 6) The officer referred the court to several cases dealing with the jurisdiction involving provincial and municipal jurisdiction as examples of the different issues and problems that arise in the cases of municipal and provincial police forces.

column2: The wife sought an order for equal distribution of matrimonial property. They married in 1988, each for a second time, and separated in 1997. Each had significant assets at the time of the marriage, which had increased in value. They agreed at the time of the marriage to keep their assets separate and to not make a claim on the assets of the other and that their entire estates would be left to their respective children.  The wife argued the agreement was not applicable to the present situation where they have separated and was only in effect during the time of the marriage or upon their deaths. HELD: The wife was entitled to judgment for $54,000. 1)There was no conflict in the evidence as to the verbal agreement made at the time of the marriage nor as to their intention. This is an appropriate situation to apply s.40 of the Family Property Act. The fact they each executed a will to give effect to that intention and the husband paid practically all of the day-to-day expenses led to the conclusion their verbal agreement should be considered binding, notwithstanding their marriage ended by separation rather than death. 2)The condominium purchased by the husband was the 'family home' as provided for in s.2(1)(a). There was no extraordinary circumstance as provided in s.22(1), which would prevent equal division of the value of the family home. The Melville residence owned by the wife at the time of the marriage was exempt in accordance with their agreement. It had not increased in value and the wife solely paid its maintenance. 3)No costs.
column3: The petitioner seeks an order for equal distribution of matrimonial property. The parties married in 1988 and separated in 1997. Each had significant assets at the time of the marriage which had increased since that date. They agreed to keep their assets separate and not make claim on the assets of the other. After their deaths their entire estates would be left to their respective children. They each completed new wills shortly after the marriage leaving all of their assets to their heirs. HELD: The petitioner was entitled to judgment for half of the value of the assets acquired after marriage being: 1) half of one-half of the values of the condominium, camper and truck; 1) one-third of the furniture, vehicle and camper $12,000.00; 1-half the value in the furniture and vehicle $12.00.  2) there was no 'extraordinary circumstance' as provided in s. 22(1) of the Act which would prevent the value from being divided equally between the parties. The petitioner is entitled to a half of that value for half.

[12] In the present circumstances where there is no conflict in the evidence of the parties as to their intention at the time of the marriage, the fact that they each executed a will to give effect to at least part of that intention and the respondent paid practically all of the day to day expenses of the marriage leads me to conclude that their verbal agreement should be considered binding upon each of them notwithstanding the fact the marriage ended by separation and not by death. [13] Furthermore, I conclude that the condominium purchased by the respondent to be the "family home" as provided for in s. 2(1)(a) as set out in The Family Property Act. ➢ One-half of the value of the condominium $42,000.00
➢ One-half of the value of the furniture, vehicle and camper $12,000.00
$54,000.00

column8: The petitioner seeks an order for equal distribution of matrimonial property. The parties married in 1988 and separated in 1997. Each had significant assets at the time of the marriage which had increased since that date. They agreed to keep their assets separate and to not make claim on the assets of the other. After their deaths their entire estates would be left to their respective children. They each completed new wills shortly after the marriage leaving all of their assets to the petitioner. HELD: 1) The petitioner was entitled to judgment for half of the value of the assets acquired after marriage being: 1/2 of the amount of the condominium, $42,000.00, 1/4 of the furniture, vehicle and camper $12,000 and $54,000 respectively.  2) There was no 'extraordinary circumstance' as provided in s. 22(1) of the Act which would prevent the values of the family home from being divided equally between the parties. 3) The respondent's assets were greater in value than the petitioner's. 4) The court was not satisfied there was any extraordinary circumstance under s22(1)(a) as provided for in the Family Property Act. 5) The parties agreed to separate their assets from their common assets and to make no claim on their assets. The petitioner's investments and assets increased significantly during the time the parties lived together. 6) There is no evidence that the parties' verbal agreement that they would divide their assets was binding. 7) The evidence in writing of their intentions was the respective wills executed shortly after their marriage. There is, however, no conflict in the evidence of the parties as to the verbal agreement they made at the marriage. Although it may be argued that the Melville home was at one time the 'family home' of the Parties, designate the Regina condominium to be the family homestead for most of the years, the parties resided therein for most years. The court is not satisfied that there is any 'extraordinarily' circumstance' which would deprive the family of its value.

There was no conflict in the evidence of the parties as to the verbal agreement they made at the marriage. Although it may be argued that the Melville home was at one time the 'family home' of both parties, designate the Regina condominium to be the family home of the Parties pursuant to s22(3) of the Act as the parties resided therein for most of the years. 2) There is no 'extraordinary circumstance' as provided in ss. 22(1) and ss. 40(1)(a) which would prevent the value from being divided equally between the parties. The petitioner is entitled to a half-of-the-assets awarded after marriage. The only evidence in writing of the consenting parties' intentions is the respective wills executed shortly after their marriage. There is, however, no conflict. 3) The parties' verbal agreement that they would separate their assets was not binding. The verbal agreement between them was not a binding one. 4) It was not applicable to the present situation where the parties have separated and was only in effect during the time or upon the deaths of the respective parties.

column2: The vendor's application for an order declaring that the purchaser's objection was without merit was commenced 13 days after the closing date. column3: The applicant vendor applied for an order pursuant to the Vendors and Purchasers Act for an an order declaring that the objection raised by the defendant is without merit. The applicant had entered into an agreement with the purchaser that allowed the closing of the transaction to be held on November 15, 2002. The purchaser agreed to extend the closing date to November 15. The application was not made during the pendency of the contract. The closing date of the agreement was not automatically extended by reason of the application. The Closing date of a transaction must be commenced before the date of closing. The Applicant applied to have the application dismissed. HELD: The application for an application for adjudication was dismissed. The Court dismissed the application as it was not in the pendencies of the contractual contract.

column2: FIAT. After the tenant vacated the home, the landlord, pursuant to Residential Tenancies Act s.47, sought $3,746.76 for rent loss, cleaning, damage to the premises and unpaid utilities. The Rentalsman's order required the tenant to pay $2,930.01. The tenant appealed on the grounds the Rentalsman erred in law, as the decision was patently unreasonable as unsupportable by the facts; there was a denial of natural justice and due process because there was insufficient notice of particulars of the cleaning claim to allow the tenant to prepare a full and proper defence. column2: The company applied for an order granting court approval of a proposal made by its creditor pursuant to Part III of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. A former 28-year employee objected on the grounds pension plan members should be treated as a different class of creditor rather than under the unsecured creditor classification ascribed to them by the proposal; the indemnification of past directors under the terms of the proposal was inappropriately wide. He submitted the unfunded pension liabilities constitute trust funds pursuant to provincial pension legislation (the Pension Benefits Act s.43(3)) and as such the pension fund claimants are entitled to preferred or secured creditor status. HELD: The Proposal was accepted.  1)Provincially created statutory trusts such as the one created by the Pensions Benefits Act are not recognized in bankruptcy including Proposals submitted under the BIA. The Trustee and the company acted appropriately in identifying the nature and status of the pensioners' claims. Although it might have reflected the status of his claim against the employer outside the BIA, the specific objection did not constitute a valid ground of legal objection to the Proposal. 2)The Proposal met the statutory and judicial criteria for acceptance by the Court. The Court takes into account the interests of the debtor, general body of creditors and the public at large in maintaining the integrity of the bankruptcy legislation. Of the 15 employees in the same position, 12 voted in favour of the proposal, 2 failed to file proofs of their claims; 89 percent of all creditors voted in favour of acceptance.  3)Each party was to assume their own costs of the hearing.
column3: The applicant trustee licensed in bankruptcy pursuant to the BIA applied for an order granting court approval of a proposal made by it to its creditor (the 'W.R.T. Proposal'). The trustee argued that the terms of the collective bargaining agreement with respect to certain production employees (the "Pension Plan Employees") were too widely cast and inappropriate. The applicant proposed amendments to the Proposal that would have made the pension plan members a different class of creditor than the unsecured creditor classification ascribed to them by the Proposal. The Trustee accepted the terms set out in the Pro proposal with respect the pension plans of past and past officers and directors. The proposed amended para. 9.1 of the Proproposal was consistent with the provisions of ss. 50(13) and ss.50(13). The Trustees were in agreement with the second ground of Mr. Tilk's objection and they accede to an amendment of the proposal on this basis as clerical amendment. Taking into account all of these interests the Court concluded that the proposed amended proposal was reasonable and calculated to benefit the general body of creditors. It was also consistent with s. 50 of the Act.

column8: The Trustee for W.R.T. Equipment applied for an order granting court approval of a proposal made by it to its creditor pursuant to Part III of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. The Trustee opposed the application on the ground that the terms of the indemnity set out in the Proposal were too widely cast and inappropriate. The applicant Company and Trustee accepted that the indemnification of past directors, officers and directors proposed by the terms was inappropriately wide. The trustee accepted that it was inappropriate for the proposal to have a reasonable possibility of being successfully completed in accordance with its terms. HELD: The proposed amended para. 9.1 of the W. R. T. Proposal was consistent with the provisions of s. 50(13) of the Act and was ordered accordingly. Taking into account all of the interests the Court concluded in the circumstances reviewed and for the reasons outlined in this judgment, that the proposal presented by the Trustee does meet the statutory and judicial criteria for acceptance by the Court. The amendment to para. 8.1 is consistent with ss.50(13). 1) The Court found that taking into account these interests the proposed amended proposal was reasonable and calculated to benefit the general body of creditors. The indemnity of past and past directors proposed was inappropriate.  2) The indemnification was inappropriately broad. 3) There was no prejudice to creditors in accepting and treating it as such.

column13: W.R.T. Equipment applied for an order granting court approval of a proposal made by it to its creditor pursuant to Part III of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. The applicant was a former 28-year employee of the Company. The Company was bound by the terms of collective bargaining agreement applicable to certain of its production employees including Mr. Tilk. At the December meeting of creditors, approximately 93 percent of the creditors who had proven claims voted in favour of accepting the Proposal. The draft order filed on January 13, 2003 was amended to reflect the more substantive basis upon which the applicant opposed court approval. Taking into account all of these interests the proposed amended para 9.1 of the W.R.'s Proposal was consistent with the provisions of s. 50(13) of the Act and it was ordered accordingly. HELD: The proposal was accepted. The court found that the applicant's proposal did meet the statutory and judicial criteria for acceptance and that the amendment was appropriate. The proposal did not stand up to the scrutiny of the BIA and the court was satisfied that the proposed amendment was properly drafted. The proposed amended paragraph is consistent with all of the provisions set out in the revised para. of the draft order.  1) The applicant's proposed proposal was not supported by the evidence of the pension plan members. 2) The court was of the opinion that the terms were not reasonable or were not calculated to benefit the general body of creditors. 3) Taking into consideration all the interests the Court concluded in the circumstances reviewed and for the reasons outlined in this judgment that the proposal presented by the Trustee was a valid proposal.  4) The Court found that there was no prejudice to the creditors in accepting and treating it as such. 5) The amendments were not appropriately drafted.

column18: W.R.T. Equipment applied for an order granting court approval of a proposal made by it to its creditor pursuant to Part III of Division I of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. The applicant was a former 28 year employee of the Company. The Company was bound by the terms of collective bargaining agreement applicable to certain of its production employees including Mr. Tilk. The meeting of creditors was adjourned to allow certain questions raised by the creditors at the December meeting to be further investigated and to permit examination. At the reconvened December meeting approximately 93 percent of the creditors who had proven claims voted in favour of accepting the proposal. The draft order filed may issue including the amendment to para. 9.1 of the Proposal. Taking into account all of the interests the Court concluded that the proposal presented by the trustee did meet the statutory and judicial criteria for acceptance. The proposal was consistent with the provisions of s. 50(13) of the Act and it was ordered accordingly. HELD: The proposed amended para. 8.1 is consistent with that of the BIA and the proposed amendment is ordered accordingly [see Re Cosmic Adventures Halifax Inc. (1999), 13 C.B.R.(4th) 22 (N.S.C.)). Taking into the interests of the debtor (to give him an opportunity to meet with his creditors and to find a way of producing assets or revenue outside of bankruptcy), the general body of creditors (to protect creditors generally by insuring that what is put up by way of proposal is reasonable one), and (c) the public-at-large in maintaining the integrity of bankruptcy legislation (including considering whether or not the proposal complies with standards of commercial morality).

column2: Fulltext of judgment follows: [1] The appellant wife appeals the decision of the chambers judge varying the amount of child support and reducing the amount of arrears. She contends that the chambers judge erred in varying the order for maintenance and reducing the amount of arrears in the absence of evidence that there was a change in the conditions, means and needs of the respondent or the children as contemplated by s. 17(4) of the Divorce Act.[FOOTNOTE 1][2] The respondent contends that the amount of child support should be reduced by reason of his reduced income caused by his unemployment or reduced employment over the last four years. The appellant argues that the respondent has failed to satisfactorily explain his unemployment. There is evidence that his change in income is due to his own voluntary action and, as a result, he has failed to establish the threshold 'change in circumstances' which could result in a variation of the order. [3] The appeal is allowed and the decision of the chambers judge is set aside. There is evidence from which this Court can impute income to the respondent in the amount of $27,000, and the child support shall be varied to $510.00 per month as of February 1, 2004 in accordance with the Child Support Guidelines. The sum of $1,926.78 currently held by the Maintenance Enforcement Office shall be applied to the arrears. The respondent shall pay the sum of $200.00 per month on the arrears commencing April 1, 2004. [4] The appellant shall have her costs in the usual way.1R.S.C. 1985, c. 3 (2nd. Supp.).

column2: FIAT: The issues to be determined on this application are custody, child support and cancellation of the arrears of child support. HELD: 1) On the issue of custody, the mere passage of time, in this instance 9 years, would constitute a material change in circumstances relevant to custody. The child is now 15 years old. The parties are not candidates for joint custody and shared parenting. The child's view of the dysfunctional relationship between her parents compels this Court to preserve the status quo as being in the child's best interests. The petitioner will continue as the sole custodian.  2) The access was varied in January 2004. Nothing has changed to warrant a variation. 3) There was no evidence to support the respondent's statement that the child is living with him half the time. There was no evidence or explanation as to why he has failed to pay child support, which creates the present arrears. The evidence with respect to the respondent's finances was unsworn and out of date. In oral argument, the respondent asserted that he contributed to his daughter's care and that he is contributing to her education trust fund. If these expenditures were in fact made over and above his own cost of living, the Court would be compelled to accept the fact that he has financial resources available to him other that the $9,940 of social assistance which is disclosed in his tax return and financial statement. 4) The essence of the respondent's application for variation of the child support is based on his claim that his health has precluded him from working. The respondent's doctor was examined and, based on that medical evidence, the Court could not conclude that the respondent's generalized anxiety and depression disorder is beyond his control. The evidence was that the respondent could choose to help himself by eliminating alcohol and marijuana use. The respondent failed to meet the burden of proof by demonstrating that his depression and anxiety disorder was the consequence of factors beyond his control and thus preventing him from working and having an income with which to pay his child support obligations during the period under review. The application for variation of child support and cancellation of child support arrears is dismissed with costs.
column3: FIAT. The respondent applied to vary the custody and access provisions of the May 2, 1995 consent judgment. The petitioner argued that the 1995 judgment was no longer appropriate. The appellant argued that there had not been a material change in circumstances and that the respondent should be allowed to vary his access. The court dismissed the appellant's application and directed trial on the issue of whether there should be variation of the custody order. The evidence on file showed that nothing had changed to warrant a variation. The material change threshold was not met. The applicant was awarded 10 months arrears of child support.
column4: Wayne Dorosh applies to vary the custody and child support order of May 2, 1995. Mr. Dorosh seeks to vary the custody order on the basis that his daughter, Letitia, born August 22, 1989, (currently 14 years old) wished to spend more time with him. I dismiss Mr. Dorosh’s application to vary child support and arrears. Nothing has changed to warrant a variation. [34] Based upon this medical evidence I cannot conclude that Mr. Dorosh’s generalized anxiety and depression disorder is beyond his own control—that is, Dr. Hatfield does not say that Mr. Dorosh was, is or will be incurable. The application for variation of child support and cancellation of child support arrears is dismissed with costs.

column2: The 23 year old defendant pled guilty to two counts of breaking and entering a dwelling house and one count of breaking and entering a shed. He cooperated with the police and provided evidence against his co-accused. He had a previous criminal record, which included convictions for mischief, theft, break and enter, breach of an undertaking and possession of stolen goods. Defendant sentenced to four years imprisonment; in assessing the appropriate sentence, the court allowed a credit for time already served (which was served virtually throughout in protective custody), a credit of 25% for the fact that the defendant had pled guilty and a further reduction of one and a half years for the defendant's assistance in pursuing the successful prosecution of his co-accused.
column3: The accused was charged with breaking and entering and theft of property. The accused had previously entered guilty pleas to five counts contained in an indictment. The Crown had withdrawn action on the remaining counts. HELD: The Court found that the accused was guilty of breaking and enter and theft. The Court also reduced the sentence to a further ten years. The court also reduced its sentence to four years imprisonment. The sentencing judge noted that the evidence was so extensive that a further reduction of one-half years would be justified. The evidence was that the defendant had a Grade X education and that he had sporadic employment over his adult years at his employment as a labourer. The sentence was based on the factors outlined in the pre-sentence report. The offender had a previous criminal record. The judge also noted that there was a low end of the range suggested by the Court of Appeal in Harris. The defendant plead guilty to three counts of break and enter. The sentences were reduced to a range of eight years.
column4:
[1] The accused, Steven Lee Pinch, had previously entered guilty pleas to five counts contained in an indictment. [3] The second count is number three in the indictment, that the accused:

on or about the 12th day October, A.D. 2004 at or near Aldersville in the County of Lunenburg, Province of Nova Scotia, did break and enter the dwelling house of James Eustace and did commit therein an indictable offence contrary to Section 348(1)(d) of the Criminal Code. [4] The fourth count, which is the third count to which the accused pleaded guilty, is that he:



on or about the 12th day October, 2004, at or near Aldersville in the County of Lunenburg, Province of Nova Scotia, did break and enter the shed of Brian MacNutt and did commit therein an indictable offence contrary to section 348(1)(e) of the Criminal Code. [5] The fifth count, which is the fourth count to which a guilty plea has been entered, is as follows that he:

on or about the 12th day of October A.D. 2004 at or near Berwick, in the County of King, Province of Nova Scotia, did break and enter the dwelling house of Dorothy Benedict and did commit therein an indictable offence, contrary to section 348(1)(d) of the Criminal Code. [6] And finally count six, that he:

on or about the 12th day of October A.D. 2004, at or near Waterville in the County of Kings, Province of Nova Scotia, did break and enter the dwelling house of Roger Quirk and did commit therein an indictable offence, contrary to section 348(1)(d) of the Criminal Code. [13] The report indicates that the accused is now 23 years of age, that he has a Grade X education and that he has had sporadic employment over his adult years at his employment as a labourer. From that one should deduct a credit of two years at 25 percent for the fact of Mr. Pinch pleading guilty. A further credit, however, should be given for the time already served which, depending on which factor one chooses to use, either the two for one or three for one, would amount to another 14 to 21 months. To my mind a further reduction of one and one-half years would be justified. [32] As I have indicated, I have concluded ,therefore, that the appropriate sentence in this case, having regard to all of the factors that I have mentioned, is that the accused serve a term of four years and six months in a federal institution.

on or about the 12th day of October A.D. 2004, at or near Waterville in the County of Kings, Province of Nova Scotia, did break and enter the dwelling house of Roger Quirk and did commit therein an indictable offence, contrary to section 348(1)(d) of the Criminal Code. column27: The accused was charged with breaking and entering and theft of property. The accused had previously entered guilty pleas to five counts contained in an indictment. The Crown had withdrawn action on the remaining counts. HELD: The Court found that the accused was guilty of breaking and enter and theft. The Court also reduced the sentence to a further ten years. The court also reduced its sentence to four years imprisonment. The sentencing judge noted that the evidence was so extensive that a further reduction of one-half years would be justified. The evidence was that the defendant had a Grade X education and that he had sporadic employment over his adult years at his employment as a labourer. The sentence was based on the factors outlined in the pre-sentence report. The offender had a previous criminal record. The judge also noted that there was a low end of the range suggested by the Court of Appeal in Harris. The defendant plead guilty to three counts of break and enter. The sentences were reduced to a range of eight years.

column2: The accused is on trial for armed robbery and the central issue is identity. The Court admitted a letter into evidence in which the accused attempts to induce a potential witness to fabricate an alibi for him. HELD: Accused found guilty. The accused was correctly identified. The Court drew an adverse inference against the accused by his attempt to induce a potential witness to fabricate an alibi by. The Court was convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused's purpose in writing the letter was not to insure himself against the prospect of wrongful conviction, but to induce perjured evidence for his benefit in order to discredit the identification evidence adduced at the preliminary inquiry. The letter is direct evidence of where the accused was not at the time of the robbery and is corroboration for the identification evidence of the Crown witness.
column3: The accused was charged with robbery. The accused wrote to a fellow inmate within one month of the trial. The letter was not an alibi but rather an attempt to induce a potential witness to fabricate an alibis. The witness to the robbery testified that she had seen the accused leave the club and that he had asked her to come back. The defence argued that the letter was an attempt by the accused to deceive the witness into believing that he was not at the club at the time of the robbery. HELD: The accused was convicted of robbery. 1)Of course, the letter is not an 'alibi.' It is not fabricating. 2)The accused's admission that he wasn't at the Club at the night of the robberies was tantamount to an admission that the accused was not there at the moment of the robbing. 3)The letter was a fabrication. The evidence of the alleged robbery was not corroborated by the letter. 4)The evidence of a witness who testified that he saw the accused leaving the club after consuming a meal was not supported by the evidence of an alabis. 5)The defence argued the accused's letter was motivated by a desire to deceive and to induce perjured evidence. 6)The Court held that the evidence was not conclusive. The only conclusion drawn was that the defence had failed to establish that the alleged witness was the accused.
column4: He is charged with armed robbery. He is seeking a witness to testify that he was at the Eureka Club on the date and at the time of the robbery. [6] Of course, the letter is not an alibi — it is an attempt to induce a potential witness to fabricate an alibi. [7] I do, however, draw an adverse inference against the accused by his attempt to induce a potential witness to fabricate an alibi by perjury. I am convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the purpose of the accused in formulating his letter was not to insure himself against the prospect of wrongful conviction, but to induce perjured evidence for his benefit in order to discredit the identification evidence adduced at the preliminary inquiry. [9] I view the evidence of Mr. Hanson to be direct evidence to prove the accused\'s identity, and the accused\'s letter is corroborative evidence of such a nature that leads me to a reasoned conclusion that Mr. Hanson correctly identified the accused in the photo ID line-up. The admission by the accused that he was not at the Eureka Club at the time of the robbery, taken together with his knowledge of all of the circumstances of the offence and his plan to meet that evidence at trial by fabricating evidence, warrants an adverse inference against him which, together with the identification facts which have been proved, leads to the reasonable and just conclusion that the accused is the person who committed the robbery. [18] Accordingly, I find the accused guilty as charged in the Indictment.

The accused admitted that he did not intend to deceive the witness and that he intended to induce the witness into fabricating the alibi. The only other conclusion drawn was that the accused had not seen the victim in the first place and that if the witness were to appear at trial, then the witness would not be required to testify.

column2: The proposed appellants applied to extend the time for filing a notice of appeal of an order awarding costs payable jointly and personally by Tapp and Spelliscy on the basis the award was punitive and inordinately high. HELD: The application was dismissed with costs on double Column V. The Court is still of the view the proposed appellants would have little chance of success on appeal. Costs are a discretionary award and there was material on file upon which the trial judge could base his decision. The appellants failed to first apply to the trial judge to obtain leave to appeal as required by Queen's Bench Act s.38.

column2: The appellant sought an order under Rule 15 staying execution and garnishment proceedings with respect to an order granted in January 2003 for child support and s.7 expenses and costs. column2: The applicant applied by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents, Zurich and Sovereign, were obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against the applicant. The underlying action claims damages from the applicant with respect to the construction of a hog barn. The applicant was the general contractor. Each of the respondents issued a comprehensive general liability policy to the applicant. The law is clear that the pleadings determine whether or not the respondents have a duty to defend. If the claim alleges a state of facts, which would fall within the coverage provided by the policy, the obligation of the insurer to defend is triggered. The Court reviewed the claim and concluded that the true nature of the claim was that the applicant failed in its contractual duty to construct and deliver a hog barn suitable for the purposes intended. HELD: The application was dismissed with costs.  1) It is a fundamental principle of insurance law that a comprehensive general liability policy is not intended to be a means for a contractor to cover the expenses to correct its own faulty or defective workmanship. They are not performance bonds. 2) The claims in negligence are inseparable from the claims in contract and do not exist but for the contractual relationship. 3) The insuring agreement provided for the payment of all sums the applicant might become legally obligated to pay as compensatory damages because of property damage caused by an occurrence, which was defined to mean an accident. What is alleged in the underlying action was not an accident or occurrence. Further, the work/product exclusion clauses in the policies relieve the respondents from any duty to defend.
column3: The applicant applies by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents are obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against Westridge and others by Genex Swine Group Inc. (the 'underlying action'). The applicant was the general contractor and the general contractors issued comprehensive general liability policies in favour of Westridge. The respondents take the position under the policies they issued they are not obligated to defend. The plaintiff is also entitled to recover costs from the defendants. The defendant is also required to pay costs to the plaintiff. The defendants are also entitled, pursuant to the terms of the Westridge Tender, to correct any errors in the tender documents, to the specifications of the general contract, to any errors by the plaintiff in the specifications, to provide advice on the appropriate remedy, to make the necessary corrections, to ensure the plaintiff's safety and to provide expert advice to the general counsel. The Defendant is also liable for the costs of the plaintiff’s defence. The court reviewed the pleadings of the defendants and found that the defendant’ s position was that under the policy they were not obligated, and that the plaintiff was not obligated. The Court reviewed the defendant and its pleadings and found the defendant was not guilty of a breach of contract. The parties were found to have breached the terms and responsibilities of the defendant. The liability for the defendant is limited to the amount it is obligated to bear in the amount of the liability it is owed. The failure of the Defendant to provide adequate protection to the plaintiffs is a serious and life-threatening condition. The Plaintiff’S position was not supported by the pleadments. The claim was not covered by reason of an exclusion under the terms. The Defendants were found not guilty. The Onus of establishing that the terms, the terms in the policy obligate the insurer to defend rests with the applicant. The onus shifts to the insurer.
column4: [1] The applicant (“Westridge”) applies by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents (“Zurich” and “Sovereign”) are obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against Westridge and others by Genex Swine Group Inc. (the “underlying action”). [23] In my view, a careful reading of the statement of claim leads to the inescapable conclusion that, the true nature of the claim by Genex is that Westridge failed in its contractual duty. Contrary to the terms of the contract it did not construct and deliver to Genex a hog barn that was suitable for the purposes intended. The cause of the accident was found to be faulty welding of the support brackets by the plaintiff’s employees. The cost associated with repairing the defective work cannot be interpreted to be property damage in these circumstances. [41] The applicant has failed to meet the onus of establishing that the claims in the underlying action would fall within the insuring agreements contained in the CGL policies issued by Zurich and Sovereign. [42] Further I am satisfied that the work/product exclusion clauses found in the policies would relieve the respondents from any duty to defend. [43] In the result, the application is dismissed with costs.

column8: The applicant applies by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents (Zurich and Sovereign) are obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against Westridge and others by Genex Swine Group Inc. (the 'underlying action'). HELD: The application is dismissed. 1) The pleadings determine whether or not the respondents have a duty to defend. It matters not whether Genex may or may not succeed in the action. 2) The defendants are negligent and breached the contractual and other duties owed by them to Genex. The onus shifts to the insurer to establish that the claim is not covered by reason of an exclusion under the policy. 3) Genex alleges both negligence and breach of contract is of no moment. The mere fact that the plaintiff subcontracted with the general contractor and it was responsible for the construction of the Tullymet Nucleus Unit does not, for the purpose of this appeal, change the intentional nature of the acts. 4) There is no evidence that Genex is guilty of any crime. The only evidence that the defendants are guilty of a crime is that the defendant sub-contracts with the plaintiff to furnish all material, plans and labour necessary for the proper completion of the entire work. The defendant submits that it is guilty. 5) The defendant is found to have breached the terms of the agreement. The plaintiff is found guilty of breach of the contract. 6) The Defendant is found liable for the costs of the plaintiff's defence. 7) The plaintiff was found to be guilty of negligent misrepresentation. The Defendant was found guilty in all respects of the pleadings. 8) There was no evidence of any errors by the defendant in its preparation of the materials used to prepare the materials for the installation of the scaffolding. 9) The Plaintiff was found not guilty of all charges related to the failure of the roof. 10) The Court found that the Defendant was guilty of negligence and breached its obligations to the plaintiff. It was found liable to pay costs to the defendant.

(the 'underlying action'). Westridge was the general contractor. Each of the respondents issued comprehensive general liability policies in favour of Westridge. The respondents take the position under the policies they issued they are not obligated to defend (and to pay defence costs) for the claims brought against them in the underlying action. HELD: 1) The onus of establishing that the terms of the policy obligate the insurer to defend rests with the applicant. If there is any possibility that the claim falls within liability coverage, the insurer is obliged to provide defence. This principle is congruent with the broader tenets underlying the construction of insurance contracts, namely the contra proferentem rule, and the principle that coverage provisions should be construed broadly, while exclusion clauses should receive narrow interpretation. 2) The amount we will pay for compensatory damages is limited as described in SECTION III—LIMITS OF INSURANCE; Exclusions This insurance applies only to “bodily injury” or “property damage” which occurs during the policy period. The claim is triggered where, on a reasonable reading of the pleadings, a claim within coverage can be inferred. 3) The fact that Genex alleges both negligence and breach of contract is of no moment. There is nothing fanciful about the statement of claim. It is only where there is genuine ambiguity or doubt that the duty to defend is to be resolved. 4) The defendants are negligent and breached the contractual and other duties owed by them to Genex. It matters not whether Genex may or may not succeed.
column24: [1] The applicant (“Westridge”) applies by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents (“Zurich” and “Sovereign”) are obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against Westridge and others by Genex Swine Group Inc. (the “underlying action”). [23] In my view, a careful reading of the statement of claim leads to the inescapable conclusion that, the true nature of the claim by Genex is that Westridge failed in its contractual duty. Contrary to the terms of the contract it did not construct and deliver to Genex a hog barn that was suitable for the purposes intended. The cause of the accident was found to be faulty welding of the support brackets by the plaintiff’s employees. The cost associated with repairing the defective work cannot be interpreted to be property damage in these circumstances. [41] The applicant has failed to meet the onus of establishing that the claims in the underlying action would fall within the insuring agreements contained in the CGL policies issued by Zurich and Sovereign. [42] Further I am satisfied that the work/product exclusion clauses found in the policies would relieve the respondents from any duty to defend. [43] In the result, the application is dismissed with costs.
column27: The applicant applies by originating motion for a declaration that the respondents (Zurich and Sovereign) are obligated to pay a proportionate share of defence costs to defend a claim brought against Westridge and others by Genex Swine Group Inc. (the 'underlying action'). The respondents issued comprehensive general liability policies in favour of Westridge. The respondents take the position that under the policies they issued they are not obligated to defend (and to pay defence costs) for the claims brought against them in the underlying action. HELD: 1) The claim is triggered. Whether a claim could trigger indemnity is a three step process. The onus of establishing that the terms of the policy obligate the insurer to defend rests with the applicant. If there is any possibility that the claim falls within liability coverage, the insurer is obliged to provide defence. 2) The pleadings determine whether or not the insurer has a duty to defend. It matters not whether Genex may or may not succeed in the action. The mere fact that Genex alleges both negligence and breach of contract is of no moment. The fact that the plaintiff subcontracted with the general contractor for the construction of the Tullymet Nucleus Unit does not, for the purpose of this appeal, change the intentional nature of the acts.

column2: The plaintiff in a rear end motor vehicle accident applied for summary judgment and an interim payment. The defendant argued that there was an arguable issue to be tried in that even if one accepted the plaintiff's evidence, there was the issue of contributory negligence to be considered. The defendant also argued that he did not see any brake lights on the plaintiff's vehicle and thus there was an issue as to whether or not they were working. Application for summary judgment granted as to liability with damages to be assessed; application for interim payment dismissed. There was no 'air of reality' to the defence; to strike the plaintiff's vehicle from behind on these facts meant that the defendant was travelling too close or didn't have proper care or control of his vehicle. However, the affidavit evidence showed that there were several other factors affecting the plaintiff's health besides the injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident; serious issues existed between the parties at to whether or not the plaintiff's injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident resulted in any ongoing inability to work in any capacity; any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at would largely depend upon credibility and the medical evidence at trial.
column3: This was an application for summary judgment pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13.01 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rules 31.01. The plaintiff was operating her motor vehicle and said in her affidavit she was struck from behind by the defendant. Defence counsel had gone to great extent to show the plaintiff's prior conditions would all combine to contribute in significant way to her current health complaints. The defendant argued there was an 'air of realty' to the plaintiff’s argument. HELD: The application was allowed. 1)Any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and the medical evidence at trial. The Defendant argued there had yet to even be an independent medical examination of the plaintiff. 2)Costs were awarded to the parties. The court was satisfied there was no 'air to reality' to defendant’ s argument. 3)Judgment was entered against the respondent as to liability for the accident itself and not causation. The evidence submitted by the plaintiff submitted as attached to the affidavit of the defence counsel caused the court difficulty. 4)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant's counsel and reads the material attached to his affidavit, one finds there are significant other factors affecting the plaintiff that could be overcome by a reasonable amount of money.
column4: [1] This is an application for an Order for summary judgement pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rule 31.01. We must accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of His Honour Judge Burke dated June 14, 1976. I am satisfied there has to be an “air of realty” to the defendant’s argument. In any event, I am satisfied when you read the material there was no “air of reality” to the defendant’s arguments. Judgement is entered against the respondent/defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. The plaintiff is making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant’s counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant’s affidavit, one finds there are significant other factors affecting the health of the plaintiff. I am satisfied any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and the medical evidence at trial. [25] On a review of the material supplied for this application, I am not satisfied this is an appropriate case to order an interim payment at this point in time and I decline to do so. [26] However, as I said before, I would order summary judgment be entered against the defendant with damages to be assessed.

column2: The parties were married for thirteen years and had four children, who resided with the mother immediately following the divorce. The father paid one monthly sum ($6,000) comprised of both spousal and child support. Over a ten year period, all of the children had graduated from high school; two of the children had moved in with the father and he provided support directly to the other two children while they continued their education. After the first two children moved out of the mother's home, the parties orally agreed to reduce the child support payments. The parties were unable to negotiate a further reduction in the combined child and spousal support after the third child moved out of the mother's home. Since the parties' separation and divorce, the mother had not seriously pursued any educational retraining or furthered her education in her field of expertise; since the children had become independent, she occupied herself with volunteer work. The father now applied to terminate spousal support. The father shall continue to pay the sum of $3,000 per month as spousal support for one year; for the following year, the support will be reduced to $2,500 per month; in the following year, support shall be reduced to $2,000 per month, after which support will cease completely; the father shall continue his direct support of the children remaining dependant as they complete their current courses. Although the mother's effort in looking after four children and her absence from the workplace during the children's early years were significant factors, she had ignored her responsibility to move towards some sort of self sufficiency; given the number of children, the court extended the formula under the Spousal Support Guidelines beyond the maximum 13 year period; however, the mother must develop a reasonable strategy immediately to ensure that she either begins work in an area with better employment prospects or immediately attends courses to upgrade, refresh or enhance her ability to support herself.
column3: The parties were married for 22 years. They had four children. The oldest, who was now 23 years old, was assisting her with her studies. The mother was unable to negotiate with the father for a reduction in the current combination child and spousal support. The father was to pay $6,000 per month. The wife was to contribute $2,000 to the total child and child support. She was to receive $3,000 in monthly support. In 2005, the father ceased paying support. He made arrangements for monthly payments of $163.92 and $2.500 to the respondent. In 2006, the mother was forced into bankruptcy. The respondent was awarded $29,672.00. The court found that the respondent's monthly expenditures were not excessive.
column4: [1] This application to terminate spousal support was commenced on the 22nd day of September, 2005. Given his circumstances and his obligations, his monthly expenditures are not excessive. The effort and the Respondent’s absence from the workforce during their early childhood is a significant factor. [102] Given the number of children, I am extending the guideline beyond the maximum suggested of 13 years but at a rate well within the ability of the Applicant. The mother must develop a reasonable strategy immediately to ensure September enrollment is possible. [106] To assist her in effecting this goal, the Applicant shall continue to pay $3,000 per month from January, 2006 to December, 2006. [108] Thereafter, between January, 2008 to December, 2008 he shall pay $2,000 per month, to assist in a transition to the workplace completely. [111] The third party payments for her car shall, in accordance with the allowable tax law, be considered third party payments by way of support.

column8: HELD: The application to terminate spousal support was commenced on the 22nd day of September, 2005. The parties were married in November 1980 and began living separate and apart in 1993. They entered into an agreement in February 1996 that the biweekly payments would be reduced to $2,000. There was no financial contribution by the mother to the children in the father's care. The father provided financial support directly to the mother and the combined support increased to $52,000 in July 1996. The mother destroyed any cheques she received from Maintenance Enforcement. The respondent continued to pay full child and spousol support to the respondent, notwithstanding the fact that the children were leaving their mother's care and moving in with their father or being supported by their father. There has been no variation of this order by court order since the Corollary Relief Judgment.

Over a ten year period, all of the children had graduated from high school; two of the children had moved in with the father and he provided support directly to the other two children while they continued their education. After the first two children moved out of the mother's home, the parties orally agreed to reduce the child support payments. The parties were unable to negotiate a further reduction in the combined child and spousal support after the third child moved out of the mother's home. Since the parties' separation and divorce, the mother had not seriously pursued any educational retraining or furthered her education in her field of expertise; since the children had become independent, she occupied herself with volunteer work. The father now applied to terminate spousal support. The father shall continue to pay the sum of $3,000 per month as spousal support for one year; for the following year, the support will be reduced to $2,500 per month; in the following year, support shall be reduced to $2,000 per month, after which support will cease completely; the father shall continue his direct support of the children remaining dependant as they complete their current courses. Although the mother's effort in looking after four children and her absence from the workplace during the children's early years were significant factors, she had ignored her responsibility to move towards some sort of self sufficiency; given the number of children, the court extended the formula under the Spousal Support Guidelines beyond the maximum 13 year period; however, the mother must develop a reasonable strategy immediately to ensure that she either begins work in an area with better employment prospects or immediately attends courses to upgrade, refresh or enhance her ability to support herself.
column23: This application to terminate spousal support was commenced on the 22nd day of September, 2005. The parties were married in November 1980 and began living separate and apart in 1993. They entered into an agreement in February 1996 that the biweekly payments would be reduced to $2,000. There was no financial contribution by the mother to the children in the father's care. The father provided financial support directly to the mother, notwithstanding the fact that the children had left their mother's care and were moving to Nova Scotia to pursue their post-secondary pursuits. The husband continued to pay the full child and child support and the combined support increased to $52,561 per month. Given his circumstances and obligations, his monthly expenditures are not excessive. They include the secondary school expense for his children. There has been no variation of this order by court order since the Corollary Relief Judgment.
column24: [1] This application to terminate spousal support was commenced on the 22nd day of September, 2005. Given his circumstances and his obligations, his monthly expenditures are not excessive. The effort and the Respondent’s absence from the workforce during their early childhood is a significant factor. [102] Given the number of children, I am extending the guideline beyond the maximum suggested of 13 years but at a rate well within the ability of the Applicant. The mother must develop a reasonable strategy immediately to ensure September enrollment is possible. [106] To assist her in effecting this goal, the Applicant shall continue to pay $3,000 per month from January, 2006 to December, 2006. [108] Thereafter, between January, 2008 to December, 2008 he shall pay $2,000 per month, to assist in a transition to the workplace completely. [111] The third party payments for her car shall, in accordance with the allowable tax law, be considered third party payments by way of support.
