column2: Civil Procedure – Queen’s Bench Rules, Rule 3-72, Rule 3-84Statutes – Interpretation – Enforcement of Money Judgments Act, Section 5, Section 8 The proposed plaintiff, Alternatifbank (Abank) applied pursuant to Queen’s Bench rules 3-72 and 3-84 to be added as a plaintiff to the action of the plaintiff, Sekerbank, against the defendants and to amend the statement of claim. ABank asserted a debt claim against the defendants. The defendants applied pursuant to s. 8 of The Enforcement of Money Judgments Act (EMJA) to terminate the preservation order, which prohibited any dealings with 850,000 shares, or alternatively they sought an order reducing the number of shares subject to the order and requiring the plaintiff to post $3 million as security pursuant to s. 5(7) of the EMJA and $40,000 security for costs. Regarding ABank’s application, it argued that its claim in debt against the defendant arose out of the same transaction based on the allegation that Arslan transferred the shares to a trust (the other defendant was the trustee) in June 2013, the time at which he stopped paying his debts in full and thus denied it the opportunity to collect its debt. ABank sought the same relief as Sekerbank: judgment against both defendants under The Fraudulent Preferences Act and The Fraudulent Conveyances Act. The defendants argued that the limitation period that applied to ABank’s claim had expired and the application should be denied. Regarding the defendants’ application, they argued that the plaintiff’s strategy in the Saskatchewan action was to await the outcome of the proceedings they had initiated in Turkey against the plaintiff. The Saskatchewan action was independent from the Turkish action, and the plaintiff’s approach was unacceptable in the circumstances of the preservation order made against them in 2014. The plaintiff had not prosecuted its actions against them without delay as required by s. 5(c) of the EMJA. The defendants asserted that the share prices increased since 2014 and were now worth $18 million more than the plaintiff’s claim. If the preservation was not terminated, they requested that the number of shares be reduced to 100,000. HELD: The proposed plaintiff’s application was granted. The defendants’ application to terminate the preservation order or to reduce the number of shares subject to the order was dismissed. The court ordered the plaintiff to post $1 million as security under the EMJA and an additional $40,000 as security for costs. The court found that although the limitation period had expired, it would add ABank as a plaintiff and amend the statement of claim pursuant to s. 20 of The Limitations Act, because to do so would not create a wholly new proceeding and the defendants had not provided evidence that they would suffer prejudice. The preservation order was not terminated after the court reviewed the history of the proceedings in both Saskatchewan and Turkey and found that the plaintiff had not failed to prosecute its action without delay. The court found that there was insufficient evidence to justify the reduction in the number of shares subject to the order.  The information of the value of the security fell short of demonstrating a sufficient change in circumstances, especially in light of the addition of ABank’s claim. The court found that the order should be modified under s. 5(7) of the EMJA to have the plaintiff provide security because there was evidence that the trust may have suffered and could suffer losses in the future as a result of the order. The order for security for costs was justified based on the considerations specified in Queen’s Bench rule 4-24.
column3: The defendants applied to terminate the preservation order pursuant to s. 5 of The Enforcement of Money Judgments Act. In the alternative, they sought an order reducing the number of shares subject to the order and requiring the plaintiff to post $3,081,463.14 as security pursuant to ss. 5(7) and s. 7(2) of the EMJA. The defendants applied pursuant to Queen's Bench Rules for an order that ABank be added as a plaintiff, and to amend the Statement of Claim. HELD: The application was denied. 1)The court found that the plaintiff had failed to prosecute this action without delay. The amendments sought would not create a wholly new proceeding.  2)The Court found that neither of the defendants would suffer actual prejudice as a result of the proposed amendments. The Court found the following: 1)Absent the existence of a third action, the Court found there was sufficient temporal and factual relationship between the original and amended claims. 2)Absence of a fourth action, which would result in a final decision against the defendant, and amending the Statement, would not be a wholly different proceeding.
column4: [1] On January 9, 2014, a preservation order was granted in this action [Order], pursuant to s. 5 of The Enforcement of Money Judgments Act, SS 2010, c E-9.22 [EMJA]. The Order prohibited any dealings with 850,000 shares of Alliance Green Traders Inc. [AGT], pending a final decision on the merits of the plaintiff’s claims against the defendant Hṻseyin Arslan in Turkey, and the conclusion of this action. The following applications are now before me: 2. On March 8, 2016, the plaintiff Ṣekerbank T.A.S. [Ṣekerbank] and Alternatifbank A.S. [ABank], a second Turkish bank which asserts a debt claim against Mr. Arslan, applied pursuant to Rules 3-72 and 3-84 of The Queen’s Bench Rules for an order that ABank be added as a plaintiff, and to amend the Statement of Claim. For the reasons that follow, that application is denied. The application to add ABank as a plaintiff, and to amend the draft Amended Statement of Claim which has been filed, is granted. The plaintiff alleges that the defendant Hüseyin Arslan has defaulted on his obligation to pay the plaintiff $13,813,544.88 pursuant to certain guarantees. The addition of ABank as a plaintiff, and amending the Statement of Claim in the manner proposed, would not create a wholly new proceeding. [27] In the result, the two conditions specified in ss. 20(a) and (b) exist. [46] For these reasons, the application to terminate the Order is dismissed. [52] The defendants’ evidence as to the value of the security also falls short of demonstrating a sufficient change in circumstances. There is accordingly insufficient evidence to conclude that the plaintiff’s claim, including interest and costs, would be secured for the necessary period and to the extent contemplated by this consent Order, by a lesser number of shares. CONCLUSION [65] For the foregoing reasons, it is ordered as follows: 1. The defendants’ application to terminate the preservation order dated January 9, 2014, as amended by the order dated October 30, 2014 [Order], is dismissed. 2. The Order shall be amended to provide that Ṣekerbank shall provide security in the amount of $1 million within 30 days of the date of this order, in a form to be agreed by the parties, and failing such agreement, in a form determined by this Court on further application by any party. 4. Alternatifbank A.S. shall be added as a plaintiff, and the Statement of Claim may be amended in the manner specified in the draft filed.

HELD: The application to add ABank as a plaintiff was denied. The two conditions specified in s. 20(a) and (b) did not exist. The addition of ABank would not create a wholly new proceeding.  1)Absent the expiration of the limitation period, the court may allow an amendment to the pleadings that asserts a new claim or adds or substitutes parties if the plaintiff has chosen to await the outcome of the Turkish Proceedings before taking any steps to advance this action. 2)The court should not terminate the order or revisit the issues which the parties intended to resolve through that order. There need only be some temporal and factual relationship between the occurrences on which the original claim was based and those on which a proposed counterclaim or similar claim is based.
column24: [1] On January 9, 2014, a preservation order was granted in this action [Order], pursuant to s. 5 of The Enforcement of Money Judgments Act, SS 2010, c E-9.22 [EMJA]. The Order prohibited any dealings with 850,000 shares of Alliance Green Traders Inc. [AGT], pending a final decision on the merits of the plaintiff’s claims against the defendant Hṻseyin Arslan in Turkey, and the conclusion of this action. The following applications are now before me: 2. On March 8, 2016, the plaintiff Ṣekerbank T.A.S. [Ṣekerbank] and Alternatifbank A.S. [ABank], a second Turkish bank which asserts a debt claim against Mr. Arslan, applied pursuant to Rules 3-72 and 3-84 of The Queen’s Bench Rules for an order that ABank be added as a plaintiff, and to amend the Statement of Claim. For the reasons that follow, that application is denied. The application to add ABank as a plaintiff, and to amend the draft Amended Statement of Claim which has been filed, is granted. The plaintiff alleges that the defendant Hüseyin Arslan has defaulted on his obligation to pay the plaintiff $13,813,544.88 pursuant to certain guarantees. The addition of ABank as a plaintiff, and amending the Statement of Claim in the manner proposed, would not create a wholly new proceeding. [27] In the result, the two conditions specified in ss. 20(a) and (b) exist. [46] For these reasons, the application to terminate the Order is dismissed. [52] The defendants’ evidence as to the value of the security also falls short of demonstrating a sufficient change in circumstances. There is accordingly insufficient evidence to conclude that the plaintiff’s claim, including interest and costs, would be secured for the necessary period and to the extent contemplated by this consent Order, by a lesser number of shares. CONCLUSION [65] For the foregoing reasons, it is ordered as follows: 1. The defendants’ application to terminate the preservation order dated January 9, 2014, as amended by the order dated October 30, 2014 [Order], is dismissed. 2. The Order shall be amended to provide that Ṣekerbank shall provide security in the amount of $1 million within 30 days of the date of this order, in a form to be agreed by the parties, and failing such agreement, in a form determined by this Court on further application by any party. 4. Alternatifbank A.S. shall be added as a plaintiff, and the Statement of Claim may be amended in the manner specified in the draft filed.
column27: The defendants applied to terminate the preservation order pursuant to s. 5 of The Enforcement of Money Judgments Act. In the alternative, they sought an order reducing the number of shares subject to the order and requiring the plaintiff to post $3,081,463.14 as security pursuant to ss. 5(7) and s. 7(2) of the EMJA. The defendants applied pursuant to Queen's Bench Rules for an order that ABank be added as a plaintiff, and to amend the Statement of Claim. HELD: The application was denied. 1)The court found that the plaintiff had failed to prosecute this action without delay. The amendments sought would not create a wholly new proceeding.  2)The Court found that neither of the defendants would suffer actual prejudice as a result of the proposed amendments. The Court found the following: 1)Absent the existence of a third action, the Court found there was sufficient temporal and factual relationship between the original and amended claims. 2)Absence of a fourth action, which would result in a final decision against the defendant, and amending the Statement, would not be a wholly different proceeding.

column2: The plaintiff was found to be two-thirds and the defendant one-third responsible for an accident which occurred when the defendant's car hit the plaintiff as she tried to cross the highway on her bicycle. The court awarded costs to the plaintiff fixed at the amount involved - the quantum of general damages. The parties were unable to reach an amount of settlement. In this matter, the defendant argued that the costs should be fixed at the amount actually recovered by the plaintiff. Awarding the plaintiff one-third of her taxed costs, that to reduce costs by the percentage of fault of the plaintiff and to reduce the amount involved would be a double reduction.
column3: The plaintiff was found two-thirds and one-third responsible for the injuries suffered by her husband. The defendant was found one-half responsible for her general damages at $50,000, including non-pecuniary loss of life, $25,000 and loss of future employment including loss of past and future income, in the amount of $25. Damage to the defendant's vehicle was determined at $1,255. The plaintiff submits that the award to the plaintiff, with interest for six years at 9.41 percent per annum and disbursements, less the Counterclaim, approximates the amount awarded. The Court concludes that the double recovery of costs created by the rate of interest is not followed in this case.
column4: Counsel have advised that they have been unable to agree on a number of matters related to interest and costs and counsel for the defendant lists as outstanding issues: To reduce the "Amount Involved" would, in the circumstance, create a double reduction in the costs to which the plaintiff is entitled and would, therefore, not be appropriate. In the circumstances the appropriate rate of interest to be applied is 2.5 percent per annum.

column8: The plaintiff was found two-thirds and one-third responsible for the injuries suffered in an automobile accident. The defendant was found one-half responsible. The plaintiff was awarded $50,000 plus interest and costs plus a pre judgment interest rate of 3.5%. Counsel advised that they had been unable to agree on outstanding issues. The court reviewed the history of apportionment of costs in motor vehicle negligent cases and concluded that the practice was followed in this court, at least, where the findings of fault relate to the happening of the event causing the accident rather than to any aggravation of the injuries or failure to mitigate their effect. The Court concluded that inflation was built into the award and that a rate such as the discount rate of 2.5% per annum would not be appropriate.

column18: The defendant was found two-thirds and one-third responsible for the injuries suffered by the plaintiff. The plaintiff was awarded $50,000, including non-pecuniary loss of pain and suffering and loss of amenities of life, in the amount of $25,000. The defendant contended that the award to the plaintiff was in excess of five years following the accident and was withdrawn less than month later. The court found that the offsetting negligence was negligence that contributed directly to the accident. Although the plaintiff had been successful on her counterclaim, her recovery was less than the doctors had expected. The Court held that the trial judge should have exercised his discretion to adjust the interest rate so that it was not taken into account for a second time.

column2: FIAT. The accused applied for an order pursuant to s.581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing count 1 on the grounds it offended the 'single transaction rule'; an order pursuant to ss.7 and 24(1) of the Charter and the common law doctrine of abuse of process that portions of the indictment as amended be quashed or stayed on the basis of the judgment in the trial of the former co-accused, Reginald Schafer; alternatively, an order staying the proceedings on the grounds of unreasonable delay in bringing the accused to trial. He argued the Crown would be in breach of an agreement in which he waived delay to proceed on the charges on which inconsistent findings could be made and would constitute bad faith. HELD: 1)The application to quash count 1 on the basis it charges more than one transaction was dismissed. The count particularizes in the alternative various ways in which the accused is alleged to have defrauded the investors of ICC by using funds of ICC to advance his or Schafer's interests. The case law cited by both parties clearly establishes that the word 'transaction' as used in s.581(1) is to be interpreted broadly and flexibly, and that a single transaction may, in this sense, include a number of acts or incidents occurring over a period of time. 2)Count 1 of the indictment was to be amended. The application to stay proceedings on the basis of findings made in the Schafer trial was allowed in relation to the particular charge in subpara.(b) of count 1 regarding use of ICC funds in the amount of $513,000 for Trirak along with subpara.(j) regarding alleged representations to ICC's investors that 30% of their investment would be invested in GICs. To allow the Crown to pursue these allegations would be an abuse of process. The Crown had indicated it would not proceed with subparagraphs (c) or (d). 2)There had not been unreasonable delay in light of the complexity of the charges, reasons for the delay, and the agreement by the applicant not to object to certain portions of delay. There was ongoing disclosure and there were various court appearances following the laying of charges.
column3: FIAT. The accused applied for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing Count #1 of the indictment on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction. The Crown had in the past brought an application to quash Count #2 on the basis that it was not bound by the findings of the Schafer judgment but rather by the Crown's decision to proceed with the trial of the co-accused. The applicant argued that the Crown had breached its agreement to provide particulars to the impugned count, which was similar to the one in the amended indictment but without enumerating particulars. The application was dismissed. HELD: The application to dismiss counts #1 and #2 was dismissed as not being relevant to the trial. The Court would consider an application for separation pursuant to ss. 590 if the accused could show that it would be prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. The court reviewed the evidence and concluded that the Court was not in any way bound by any of the findings in the Schaper indictment. The only conclusion that could be drawn from the evidence was that the findings were not inconsistent with the Crown’s decision. The evidence was not conclusive that the accused had defrauded the Crown. The facts were not conclusive. The respondent’ s.581(2) was not used to determine the extent to which the Crown could proceed with a single transaction, but rather to establish that the evidence did not advance the Crown in light of the decision of Klebuc J. in the previous indictment.
column4: [1] This is an application by the accused for: (1) an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code of Canada quashing Count #1 of the indictment as now amended on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction; (2) an order pursuant to ss. 7 and 24(1) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the common law doctrine of abuse of process that portions of the indictment as amended be quashed or stayed on the basis of the judgment of Klebuc J. in the trial of the former co-accused, Reginald Schafer; and, alternatively, (3) an order staying the proceedings on the grounds of unreasonable delay in bringing the accused to trial. between the 13th day of October A.D. 1988 and the 26th day of March A.D. 1993 at the City of Saskatoon and elsewhere in the Province of Saskatchewan did by deceit falsehood or other fraudulent means, by using the funds of International Capital Corporation (ICC) to advance their personal business interests of Reginald Schafer and/or Richard Leibel over those of ICC, defraud the said Corporation and its preferred shareholders of money in excess of $1,000.00, contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code by one or more of the following ways: (a) through (j) describe separate transactions, within the meaning of s. 581(1) and that count #1 of the indictment is therefore void. The case law cited by both parties clearly establishes that the word “transaction” as it is used in s. 581(1) is to be interpreted broadly and flexibly, and that a single “transaction” may in this sense include a number of acts or incidents occurring over a period of time. On that application, I dismissed the application to quash count #1, indicating that I did not believe that the application raised a question substantively different from that already determined by Matheson J., but ordered the Crown to provide particulars (as it now has done in the amended indictment) and indicated to counsel that once particulars were supplied, I would consider an application to order the indictment separated pursuant to s. 590, if the accused could show, for example, that it would be prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. The application to quash count #1 of the indictment on this basis is therefore dismissed. [58] On a review of this matter, I am in fundamental agreement with the submission of the Crown that there has not been unreasonable delay in light of the complexity of the charges, the reasons for the delay, and the agreement by the applicant not to object to certain periods of delay. This application to quash the proceedings is dismissed. Conclusion [65] The application to quash count #1 on the basis that it charges more than one transaction contrary to s. 581 of the Code is dismissed. [66] The application to stay proceedings on the basis of findings made by Klebuc J. in the Schafer trial is allowed in part as follows: [68] The Crown’s proceeding in relation to the particular charged in subpara. (j) of count #1 regarding the alleged representation to investors that 30 percent of their investment would be invested in GICs is stayed on the ground that to allow the Crown to now proceed against this accused with that allegation would constitute abuse of process. [70] The application for stay of proceeding on the ground of delay is dismissed.

column8: FIAT: An application for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing Count #1 of the indictment on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction. The Crown alleges that Richard Leibel, who was originally charged jointly with Reginald Schafer and was convicted of defrauding the plaintiff corporation of money in excess of $1,000, contrary to ss. 380(1)(a) and (j)of the Code. Leibel alleges that he was the sole director and shareholder and president of ICC whereas the Crown alleges he was working 'behind the scenes'. HELD: The application to quash counts #1 and #2 is dismissed. The Court will consider an application to order the indictment separated by s.590 if the accused could show that it would be prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. 1) The Court is not bound by the conclusions of Klebuc J. in the Schafer case. 2) It is important for the Court to examine the extent to which the conclusions in the indictment can be said to provide support for the argument, for, if on proper reading, the findings of the trial judge in Schafer do not exonerate the accused, (in the sense that the Crown was no longer alleging that the applicant together with his co-accused had charged unauthorized management fees), then the Court has power to order a single count be divided where it is satisfied that the ends of justice require it. 3) The applicant's application to have the indictment quashed or stayed on the basis of the judgment in the trial of the former coaccused is dismissed with costs.

column13: FIAT: An application for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code of Canada quashing Count #1 of the indictment on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction. The Crown alleges that Richard Leibel, who was originally charged jointly with Reginald Schafer and the two were committed to stand trial before judge and jury after preliminary inquiry that concluded on December 8, 1997. After the separate trial and conviction of Schafer, the Crown amended the indictment against Leibel to charge him with fraudulently obtaining and defrauding the plaintiff corporation of money in excess of $1,000 contrary to the s. 380(1)(a) rule. HELD: The application to quash counts #1 and #2 is dismissed. There was clearly no promise by the Crown that it would be bound by the findings of Klebuc J. in the Schafer matter. It is important for the Court to examine the extent to which the conclusions of the judge in Schafer can be said to provide support for the argument, for, on proper reading, the findings are a permissible relaxation of its terms extending to exceptional cases in which number of acts each in itself constituting an offence is capable of being treated as one transaction. There is also a possibility that even if Schafer is acquitted we might still proceed against him.

The application to stay proceedings on the basis of findings made in the Schafer trial was allowed in relation to the particular charge in subpara.(b) of count 1 regarding use of ICC funds in the amount of $513,000 for Trirak along with subpara.(j) regarding alleged representations to ICC's investors that 30% of their investment would be invested in GICs. To allow the Crown to pursue these allegations would be an abuse of process. The Crown had indicated it would not proceed with subparagraphs (c) or (d). 2)There had not been unreasonable delay in light of the complexity of the charges, reasons for the delay, and the agreement by the applicant not to object to certain portions of delay. There was ongoing disclosure and there were various court appearances following the laying of charges.
column18: FIAT: An application for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing Count #1 of the indictment as amended on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction; alternatively, an order staying the proceedings on the grounds of unreasonable delay in bringing the accused to trial. HELD: The application to quash counts #1 and #2 was dismissed. The Crown argued that the findings of Klebuc J. did not exonerate the accused, but rather that certain of the express findings of the trial judge raised issues of res judicata or issue estoppel in relation to the matters now alleged against the accused. In these circumstances the Court has power to order that single count be divided where it is satisfied that the ends of justice require it. The application is dismissed.  1) The Crown argues that the facts raised by the application raise substantively the same question as that of whether the Crown would consider a single transaction rule or, alternatively, to order the Crown provide particulars. 2) There was clearly no promise by the Crown that it would be bound, in its proceedings against the applicant, by the findings in the Schafer case. 3) It is important for the Court to examine the extent to which the conclusions of the Court in that case can be said to provide support for the argument, for, on proper reading, the findings are a permissible relaxation of its terms extending to exceptional cases in which number of acts each in itself constituting an offence is capable of being treated as one transaction. 4) The Court is not bound in this proceeding by any factual or legal determinations.
column19: [1] This is an application by the accused for: (1) an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code of Canada quashing Count #1 of the indictment as now amended on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction; (2) an order pursuant to ss. 7 and 24(1) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the common law doctrine of abuse of process that portions of the indictment as amended be quashed or stayed on the basis of the judgment of Klebuc J. in the trial of the former co-accused, Reginald Schafer; and, alternatively, (3) an order staying the proceedings on the grounds of unreasonable delay in bringing the accused to trial. between the 13th day of October A.D. 1988 and the 26th day of March A.D. 1993 at the City of Saskatoon and elsewhere in the Province of Saskatchewan did by deceit falsehood or other fraudulent means, by using the funds of International Capital Corporation (ICC) to advance their personal business interests of Reginald Schafer and/or Richard Leibel over those of ICC, defraud the said Corporation and its preferred shareholders of money in excess of $1,000.00, contrary to s. 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code by one or more of the following ways: (a) through (j) describe separate transactions, within the meaning of s. 581(1) and that count #1 of the indictment is therefore void. The case law cited by both parties clearly establishes that the word “transaction” as it is used in s. 581(1) is to be interpreted broadly and flexibly, and that a single “transaction” may in this sense include a number of acts or incidents occurring over a period of time. On that application, I dismissed the application to quash count #1, indicating that I did not believe that the application raised a question substantively different from that already determined by Matheson J., but ordered the Crown to provide particulars (as it now has done in the amended indictment) and indicated to counsel that once particulars were supplied, I would consider an application to order the indictment separated pursuant to s. 590, if the accused could show, for example, that it would be prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. The application to quash count #1 of the indictment on this basis is therefore dismissed. [58] On a review of this matter, I am in fundamental agreement with the submission of the Crown that there has not been unreasonable delay in light of the complexity of the charges, the reasons for the delay, and the agreement by the applicant not to object to certain periods of delay. This application to quash the proceedings is dismissed. Conclusion [65] The application to quash count #1 on the basis that it charges more than one transaction contrary to s. 581 of the Code is dismissed. [66] The application to stay proceedings on the basis of findings made by Klebuc J. in the Schafer trial is allowed in part as follows: [68] The Crown’s proceeding in relation to the particular charged in subpara. (j) of count #1 regarding the alleged representation to investors that 30 percent of their investment would be invested in GICs is stayed on the ground that to allow the Crown to now proceed against this accused with that allegation would constitute abuse of process. [70] The application for stay of proceeding on the ground of delay is dismissed.
column22: FIAT. column23: FIAT: An application for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing Count #1 of the indictment on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction; alternatively, an order staying the proceedings on the grounds of unreasonable delay in bringing the accused to trial. HELD: The application is dismissed. 1) The Crown did not promise that it would be bound by the findings of Klebuc J. in the Schafer case but ordered the Crown to provide particulars (as it now has done in the amended indictment). 2) It is common ground that the Crown is not bound in this proceeding by any factual or legal determinations made by the trial judge in Schafer. 3) There was clearly no promise by the Crown that the charges against Leibel would be dropped by the outcome of the trial. 4) The application to quash count #1 raises substantively the same question as that of whether the Crown would consider an application to order the indictment separated pursuant to ss. 590, if the accused could show, for example, that it is prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. 5) The Court has power to order a single count divided where it is satisfied that the ends of justice require it.

column27: FIAT: An application for an order pursuant to s. 581(1) of the Criminal Code quashing Count #1 of the indictment on the ground that it applies to more than one single transaction. The Crown alleges that Richard Leibel, who was originally charged jointly with Reginald Schafer and was convicted of defrauding the plaintiff corporation of money in excess of $1,000, contrary to ss. 380(1)(a) and (j)of the Code. Leibel alleges that he was the sole director and shareholder and president of ICC whereas the Crown alleges he was working 'behind the scenes'. HELD: The application to quash counts #1 and #2 is dismissed. The Court will consider an application to order the indictment separated by s.590 if the accused could show that it would be prejudicial to put the complex indictment to a jury. 1) The Court is not bound by the conclusions of Klebuc J. in the Schafer case. 2) It is important for the Court to examine the extent to which the conclusions in the indictment can be said to provide support for the argument, for, if on proper reading, the findings of the trial judge in Schafer do not exonerate the accused, (in the sense that the Crown was no longer alleging that the applicant together with his co-accused had charged unauthorized management fees), then the Court has power to order a single count be divided where it is satisfied that the ends of justice require it. 3) The applicant's application to have the indictment quashed or stayed on the basis of the judgment in the trial of the former coaccused is dismissed with costs.

column2: The accused was charged with operating an overweight vehicle on a weight restricted road contrary to s.38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. No permit had been issued for the tractor trailer. The defence argued the document entitled 'order for road restriction on provincial highway #332 pursuant to s.35 of the Highway Traffic Act' was not proof of the Minister's order according to law; even if the document is proof, the order is a 'regulation' under the Interpretation Act and so the provisions of the Regulations Act applies; since those requirements have not been met, the Crown has not established an order had been made for the purposes of this case. HELD: It was not proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused violated s.38(1)(b). It was not established that the order was published for the purpose of this prosecution nor that the document filed in court is proof of the order itself.  1)It is well known that in a criminal case a provision that enables the Crown to expeditiously prove certain elements of an offence must be strictly satisfied. Since a violation of the HTA is prosecuted under s.4 of the Summary Offences Procedure Act, which in turn adopts the Criminal Code summary conviction procedure, the Crown must strictly comply with the provisions respecting proof.  2)It is mandatory for the Minister to give notice of the order and there was no evidence he exercised his discretion by determining the most advisable manner in which notice was to be given. The Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of the order to be given. The Department of Highways placed road signs warning and advising of weight restrictions on the highway and along grid roads accessing #332, but no notice was given to the general public. Notifying persons who reside or do business in the immediate area of the road is not sufficient to satisfy the requirement to publish. 3)Even if it could be said sufficient notice was given, it could not be concluded that the endorsement upon the order that the order 'conforms to the original' meets the statutory requirement that the copy must be a certified copy 'under the hand of an officer or person in whose custody the...public document is placed' (s.12 SEA) since it was not known if she had custody of the document or under the hand of any of the persons set out in s.7(c) of the SEA since her official capacity is not described. The order was not published in the Saskatchewan Gazette and so a copy of the order so published could not be produced (s.7(a) SEA). It was not proven that the copy of the order had been printed by the Queen's Printer (s.7(b) SEA).
column3: The accused was charged with operating an overweight vehicle on a Saskatchewan highway to which the Minister's weight restriction applied. The accused was stopped by a police officer on patrol in the northwesterly direction and he was about to turn left onto a highway when he noticed a tractor trailer travelling in an easterly direction approaching the junction of two highways. The officer stopped the vehicle and the accused was arrested. The Crown argued that the document referred to was proof of the Minister ordering the restriction and the order was a regulation under the provisions of the Interpretation Act. HELD: The accused's commission was established. 1)Even if the document was proof, the order is a regulation pursuant to s38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. 2)Even though the document is not proof of an order according to law, even if the documents are proof, even the copy of the order has established the commission of an offence under s38. The court found that the accused violated s38 of the Highway Traffic Act. The Court found that even if it could be said that the Minister had not taken appropriate steps to cause notice of the Order to be given, the Minister failed to take appropriate steps. Even if it was said that she had set out to set out the steps in the municipality, she could not have set out in any other way. Even though the municipality had taken sufficient steps to set up signs, the municipality could not be found to have set up any of the signs. The Minister failed in this regard. Even with the municipality's endorsement of the legislation, the court could not conclude that she set out a statutory requirement to set forth the statutory requirements. Even the document referenced above is proof of order. Even in the absence of an endorsement of legislation, it is not proven that the copy was printed by the Queen's Printer. The order is not a regulation. The municipality could be found in any of its subdivisions.
column4:
1 The accused is charged that he did, on February 26, 2001 in Swift Current district, Saskatchewan, operate a motor vehicle that violated the Minister\'s weight order contrary to section 38(1)(b) of The Highways and Transportation Act, 1997. In essence, it is alleged that the accused operated an overweight vehicle on a road to which the Minister\'s weight restriction applied. 6 The Crown tendered a copy of a document entitled "Order for Road Restriction on Provincial Highway #332" and the documents purports to be issued under section 35 of The Highway Traffic Act, 1997. 9 The defence argues the following:

a) the document is not proof of the Minister\'s order according to law, and
b) even if the document is proof, the order is a "regulation" under the provisions of The Interpretation Act and so the provisions of The Regulations Act applies to it. I can only conclude that the Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of the order to be given. Even if it could be said that the steps taken by the municipality satisfy the notice provisions for the purposes of this prosecution, I cannot conclude that notifying persons who reside or do business in the immediate area of the road affected by the order is sufficient notice to satisfy the requirement to publish. 24 Even if it could be said that sufficient notice was given, I cannot conclude that Ms. Melnychuk\'s endorsement upon the order that the order "conforms to the original" meets the statutory requirement that the copy must be a certified copy "under the hand of an officer or person in whose custody the ... public document is placed" (section 12 SEA) since I do not know if she had custody of the document or under the hand of any of the persons set out in section 7(c) of SEA since her official capacity is not described. The order was not published in the Saskatchewan Gazette and so a copy of the order so published could not be produced [section 7(a) SEA] and it was not proven that the copy of the order had been printed by the Queen\'s Printer [section 7(b) SEA]. Accordingly, it has not been proven, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the accused violated the provisions of section 38(1)(b) of HTA.

column8: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle that violated the Minister's weight order contrary to s38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. The accused was stopped by a police officer on patrol in the northwesterly direction and he was about to turn left when he noticed a tractor trailer travelling in an easterly direction approaching the junction of highways #32 and 332. The officer stopped the vehicle and the accused was arrested. HELD: The Crown had not established that the accused had violated the provisions of the HTA. 1)Even if the document was proof of the order, the order was a regulation under the provisions under the Highway Traffic Act and so the Crown could not establish that an order had been made for the purpose of this case. 2)The Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of the Order to be given. Even if it could be said that the steps taken by the municipality were sufficient to satisfy the statutory requirement, the Minister could not be found to have set out the statutory requirements for the issuing of a notice. The Minister could only advise the Minister that she failed to do so. The municipality appears to have taken it upon itself to advise persons in the municipal division affected by the weight restriction and to advise other persons in that area that were in the business of hauling. Traffic signs were in place prior to the last one going up on February 23. There was no publication in any local newspaper or provincial daily. No notice was given to any other media.

1 The accused is charged that he did, on February 26, 2001 in Swift Current district, Saskatchewan, operate a motor vehicle that violated the Minister\'s weight order contrary to section 38(1)(b) of The Highways and Transportation Act, 1997. In essence, it is alleged that the accused operated an overweight vehicle on a road to which the Minister\'s weight restriction applied. 6 The Crown tendered a copy of a document entitled "Order for Road Restriction on Provincial Highway #332" and the documents purports to be issued under section 35 of The Highway Traffic Act, 1997. 9 The defence argues the following:

a) the document is not proof of the Minister\'s order according to law, and
b) even if the document is proof, the order is a "regulation" under the provisions of The Interpretation Act and so the provisions of The Regulations Act applies to it. I can only conclude that the Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of the order to be given. Even if it could be said that the steps taken by the municipality satisfy the notice provisions for the purposes of this prosecution, I cannot conclude that notifying persons who reside or do business in the immediate area of the road affected by the order is sufficient notice to satisfy the requirement to publish. 24 Even if it could be said that sufficient notice was given, I cannot conclude that Ms. Melnychuk\'s endorsement upon the order that the order "conforms to the original" meets the statutory requirement that the copy must be a certified copy "under the hand of an officer or person in whose custody the ... public document is placed" (section 12 SEA) since I do not know if she had custody of the document or under the hand of any of the persons set out in section 7(c) of SEA since her official capacity is not described. The order was not published in the Saskatchewan Gazette and so a copy of the order so published could not be produced [section 7(a) SEA] and it was not proven that the copy of the order had been printed by the Queen\'s Printer [section 7(b) SEA]. Accordingly, it has not been proven, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the accused violated the provisions of section 38(1)(b) of HTA.
column22: The accused was charged with operating an overweight vehicle on a weight restricted road contrary to s.38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. No permit had been issued for the tractor trailer. The defence argued the document entitled 'order for road restriction on provincial highway #332 pursuant to s.35 of the Highway Traffic Act' was not proof of the Minister's order according to law; even if the document is proof, the order is a 'regulation' under the Interpretation Act and so the provisions of the Regulations Act applies; since those requirements have not been met, the Crown has not established an order had been made for the purposes of this case. HELD: It was not proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused violated s.38(1)(b). It was not established that the order was published for the purpose of this prosecution nor that the document filed in court is proof of the order itself.  1)It is well known that in a criminal case a provision that enables the Crown to expeditiously prove certain elements of an offence must be strictly satisfied. Since a violation of the HTA is prosecuted under s.4 of the Summary Offences Procedure Act, which in turn adopts the Criminal Code summary conviction procedure, the Crown must strictly comply with the provisions respecting proof.  2)It is mandatory for the Minister to give notice of the order and there was no evidence he exercised his discretion by determining the most advisable manner in which notice was to be given. The Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of the order to be given. The Department of Highways placed road signs warning and advising of weight restrictions on the highway and along grid roads accessing #332, but no notice was given to the general public. Notifying persons who reside or do business in the immediate area of the road is not sufficient to satisfy the requirement to publish. 3)Even if it could be said sufficient notice was given, it could not be concluded that the endorsement upon the order that the order 'conforms to the original' meets the statutory requirement that the copy must be a certified copy 'under the hand of an officer or person in whose custody the...public document is placed' (s.12 SEA) since it was not known if she had custody of the document or under the hand of any of the persons set out in s.7(c) of the SEA since her official capacity is not described. The order was not published in the Saskatchewan Gazette and so a copy of the order so published could not be produced (s.7(a) SEA). It was not proven that the copy of the order had been printed by the Queen's Printer (s.7(b) SEA).
column23: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle that violated the Minister's weight order contrary to s38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. HELD: The accused was found not guilty. 1)Even if the document was proof of the order, the order was a regulation under the provisions of The Interpretation Act and so the Court could not establish that an order had been made for the purpose of this case. The Court could only conclude that the Minister failed to take appropriate steps to cause notice of an order to be given. Even if it could be said that the steps taken by the Minister were sufficient to satisfy the statutory requirement, it was not proven that the copy had been printed by the Queen's Printer [section 7(b) SEA]. 2)The accused did not reside in the province.

column27: The accused was charged with operating an overweight vehicle on a Saskatchewan highway to which the Minister's weight restriction applied. The accused was stopped by a police officer on patrol in the northwesterly direction and he was about to turn left onto a highway when he noticed a tractor trailer travelling in an easterly direction approaching the junction of two highways. The officer stopped the vehicle and the accused was arrested. The Crown argued that the document referred to was proof of the Minister ordering the restriction and the order was a regulation under the provisions of the Interpretation Act. HELD: The accused's commission was established. 1)Even if the document was proof, the order is a regulation pursuant to s38(1)(b) of the Highways and Transportation Act. 2)Even though the document is not proof of an order according to law, even if the documents are proof, even the copy of the order has established the commission of an offence under s38. The court found that the accused violated s38 of the Highway Traffic Act. The Court found that even if it could be said that the Minister had not taken appropriate steps to cause notice of the Order to be given, the Minister failed to take appropriate steps. Even if it was said that she had set out to set out the steps in the municipality, she could not have set out in any other way. Even though the municipality had taken sufficient steps to set up signs, the municipality could not be found to have set up any of the signs. The Minister failed in this regard. Even with the municipality's endorsement of the legislation, the court could not conclude that she set out a statutory requirement to set forth the statutory requirements. Even the document referenced above is proof of order. Even in the absence of an endorsement of legislation, it is not proven that the copy was printed by the Queen's Printer. The order is not a regulation. The municipality could be found in any of its subdivisions.

column2: The applicant grandparent applied to the Court of Appeal to be made a party to the proceeding so that she could appeal a permanent care order made in respect of her granddaughter. Application dismissed; a judge of the Court of Appeal in Chambers does not have the authority to make the order requested; in any event, an application in the Family Division for leave to terminate the permanent care order would be a more appropriate way for the applicant to proceed.
column3: The paternal grandmother applied in Chambers for an order that she be added as a party so that she can appeal a permanent care order respecting her granddaughter. The paternal grandmother was the subject of protection proceedings brought by the Children's Aid Society in the Family Division. The child did not participate in those proceedings. The Society had indicated to the appellant that she was willing to be considered as a placement for the child if the plan to return the child to her mother did not progress as anticipated. The applicant found that the Society had shut her out of the process and that the judge in the family division erred in not considering family placement with her before making the permanent care decision. HELD: The application was dismissed. The court held that a judge in Chambers did not have the authority to make the order sought. The evidence from the counsel and authorities was that a Chambers judge would not have jurisdiction to make an order. Even if he had jurisdiction to do so, the order would be an order as, in the opinion, an application to the Family division for leave to terminate the permanent custody order appeared likely to be a more appropriate initial way for the applicant to proceed. The Court dismissed the application. The Chambers judge had jurisdiction in the past to make orders. The Family Division not only has intimate knowledge of the permanent proceedings but is better equipped to deal with the evidentiary matters which are likely to arise in the course of the child's attempts to place her position before the Court. The Children's aid Society contests the jurisdiction of this Court or judge to make a order sought in Chambers. The children's aid society contests the jurisdictional jurisdiction of the Chambers judge to do the order seeking. The Child and Family Services Act does not provide a judge with jurisdiction to appoint an order for the purposes of appeal. The principles of the Children and Family Service Act do not confer jurisdiction. The only authority vested in the Chambers Judge is the judge of the Family Court.
column4: [1] R.B. applies to me in Chambers for an order that she be added as a party so that she can appeal a permanent care order respecting her granddaughter. [4] Having considered the helpful briefs of counsel and the authorities, I am of the view that a judge of the Court of Appeal in Chambers does not have authority to make the order requested. Even if I had jurisdiction to do so, I would not make the order as, in my opinion, an application to the Family Division for leave to terminate the permanent care order appears likely to be a more appropriate initial way for R.B. to proceed. I, therefore, dismiss the application. [21] In the result, the application is dismissed.

column8: The paternal grandmother applied to the Court of Appeal Chambers for an order that she be added as a party so that she can appeal a permanent care order respecting her granddaughter. The paternal grandmother was the subject of protection proceedings brought by the Children's Aid Society in the Family Division. She did not participate in those proceedings. The Society had indicated to the appellant that she was willing to be considered as a placement for the child if the plan to return the child to her mother did not progress as anticipated. In the end, the Court placed the child in the permanent care and custody of the Children’s Aid Society of Halifax. She found out about the order after the fact. She sued the Society, claiming that the Society had shut her out of the process and that the judge in the family division erred in not considering family placement with her before making the permanent custody order. HELD: The application was dismissed. The Court of Appeals Chambers judge has the authority to make the order sought. Even if he had jurisdiction to do so, the order would be an order as, in my opinion, an application to the Family division for leave to terminate the permanent Care order appears likely to be a more appropriate initial way for R.B. to proceed. There is no rule or enactment to which have been referred which authorizes a judge in Chambers to exercise it.

column2: FIAT. The issue in this application to vary spousal support was whether there had been a material change in either the husband's or wife's employment status, financial means or needs, warranting an increase in spousal support since their 1999 interspousal contract. The wife requested a 50% increase based on the husband's income increase of 50%. She suffered from MS and was unable to work. HELD: Spousal support was varied to $3,500 monthly. The only material change in the wife's means and needs is that fact she is residing with a new partner who resides in her home in exchange for yard work and housework. Although he worked, he made no apparent financial contribution to the household. The wife was awarded costs fixed at $1,000.
column3: FIAT. In this application to vary spousal support, the issue is whether there has been a material change in circumstances by virtue of a change in either the husband's or wife's employment status, or financial means or needs, warranting an increase in spousousal. This is the standard of review prescribed in the parties' interspousal contract of September 14, 1999. Under that agreement the husband pays $3,000 per month in spouse support. Under the agreement the wife is residing with a new partner. Spousal Support will be varied to $3.500 per month effective May 1, 2002 and continuing on the first day of each month thereafter until further order. The wife will have costs fixed in the amount of $1,000.
column4: [1] In this application to vary spousal support, the issue is whether there has been a material change in circumstances by virtue of a change in either the husband’s or wife’s employment status, or financial means or needs, warranting an increase in spousal support. [10] I am satisfied the only material change in the wife’s means and needs is the fact she is residing with a new partner. [11] In all the circumstances, an increase is warranted, but not to the extent claimed by the wife. Spousal support will be varied to $3,500 per month effective May 1, 2002 and continuing on the first day of each month thereafter until further order.

column2: This is an appeal brought by the R.M. from a judgment of the Court of Queen's Bench determining that a mortgage held by the R.M. was subordinate to a mortgage held by the respondent Farm Credit Canada (FCC), even though the R.M. mortgage was registered before the mortgage of FCC. The R.M. had agreed with the mortgagor that its mortgage would be subordinate to that of FCC. The appeal raises the application of the priority provisions of The Land Titles Act, 2000 and in particular the application of s. 54 of the Act. HELD: The mortgage of the respondent has priority over the mortgage of the appellant. The appeal is dismissed with costs.  1) It is not necessary in this case to consider whether the priority provisions of the Land Titles Act are overridden by commercial postponement agreements in mortgages, or whether reliance by the competing security holder is necessary in order to displace the doctrine of privity of contract in relation to a covenant to postpone, for the court consider the matter to be governed by a consideration of the nature of the interest created by the R.M. mortgage in light of s. 54(3) of the Act. 2) Registration does not and cannot alter the nature of the legal interest granted by the instrument registered. In the present case the mortgage instrument states that it is pursuant to the prior Grant Agreement executed by the parties. This agreement, in turn, clearly provides that any security granted by Mainline to the R.M. is subject to the prior security interest of the respondent to the extent of $3,125,000. In effect, Mainline granted to the R.M. a mortgage of a limited interest, being Mainline's equity of redemption after any mortgage held by the respondent, to the extent of $3,125,000. The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and Mainline, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to that of the respondent. Mainline granted a mortgage to the appellant subject to the prior interests, as defined, of the respondent and of CIBC. The appellant is therefore, seeking to increase the interest actually accorded to it by the debtor by relying on its prior registration and the priority provision of the Act.
column3: The respondent bank agreed to foreclose its two registered mortgages against the subject land. The R.M. held that a mortgage held by the respondent was subordinate to a mortgage made by the R. M. even though the RM. mortgage was registered before the mortgage of the respondent. The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and the respondent, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to that of the bank. The appeal is dismissed with costs to the respondent and the fee simple mortgage of Mainline. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with the costs to respondent. 1)The respondent agreed to a postponement in favour of the R-M. The trial judge held that the respondent had priority over the R.-M. Mortgage. 2)The trial judge concluded that the feesimple mortgage of a respondent had a priority over that of Mainlin. 3)The appellant admits it was not intended, between itself, and Mainline that it will obtain a special interest in a priority to the bank of the corporation. The respondent admits that the mortgage was never conceived, as it was between itself. The applicant admits that its mortgage was not registered by the bank but by virtue of the Grant Agreement. 4)The Court held that registration, while arguably conclusive on the issues of notice and priority, does not and cannot alter the nature of the legal interest granted by the instrument registered.
column4: [1] This is an appeal brought by the R. M. of Chaplin No. 164 (hereafter “the R.M.”) from a judgment of the Court of Queen’s Bench determining that a mortgage held by the R.M. was subordinate to a mortgage held by the respondent, Farm Credit Canada (hereafter “FCC”), even though the R.M. mortgage was registered before the mortgage of FCC.  The Rural Municipality of Chaplin ("R.M.") has approved the application of Mainline Pulse Inc. (the "Corporation") for grant aid in the maximum sum of $150,000.00 (the "Grant"). FCC commenced the action to foreclose its two registered mortgages against the subject land. [59] I would have to conclude on the basis of the above authorities that the second FCC Mortgage has priority over the R.M. Mortgage, as the R.M. specifically agreed to a postponement in favour of FCC. In effect, Mainline granted to the R.M. a mortgage of a limited interest, viz., Mainline’s equity of redemption after any mortgage held by the respondent, to the extent of $3,125,000. The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and Mainline, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to that of the respondent. Mainline granted a mortgage to the appellant subject to the prior interests, as defined, of the respondent and of CIBC. [25] For these reasons, we concur in the trial judge’s conclusion that the fee simple mortgage of the respondent has priority over the fee simple mortgage of the appellant. The appeal is accordingly dismissed with costs to the respondent.
column7: This is an appeal brought by the R.M. from a judgment of the Court of Queen's Bench determining that a mortgage held by the R.M. was subordinate to a mortgage held by the respondent Farm Credit Canada (FCC), even though the R.M. mortgage was registered before the mortgage of FCC. The R.M. had agreed with the mortgagor that its mortgage would be subordinate to that of FCC. The appeal raises the application of the priority provisions of The Land Titles Act, 2000 and in particular the application of s. 54 of the Act. HELD: The mortgage of the respondent has priority over the mortgage of the appellant. The appeal is dismissed with costs.  1) It is not necessary in this case to consider whether the priority provisions of the Land Titles Act are overridden by commercial postponement agreements in mortgages, or whether reliance by the competing security holder is necessary in order to displace the doctrine of privity of contract in relation to a covenant to postpone, for the court consider the matter to be governed by a consideration of the nature of the interest created by the R.M. mortgage in light of s. 54(3) of the Act. 2) Registration does not and cannot alter the nature of the legal interest granted by the instrument registered. In the present case the mortgage instrument states that it is pursuant to the prior Grant Agreement executed by the parties. This agreement, in turn, clearly provides that any security granted by Mainline to the R.M. is subject to the prior security interest of the respondent to the extent of $3,125,000. In effect, Mainline granted to the R.M. a mortgage of a limited interest, being Mainline's equity of redemption after any mortgage held by the respondent, to the extent of $3,125,000. The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and Mainline, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to that of the respondent. Mainline granted a mortgage to the appellant subject to the prior interests, as defined, of the respondent and of CIBC. The appellant is therefore, seeking to increase the interest actually accorded to it by the debtor by relying on its prior registration and the priority provision of the Act.
column8: This was an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Queen's Bench determining that a mortgage held by the R.M. was subordinate to that of the respondent, even though the mortgage was registered before the mortgage of FCC. The appeal was dismissed with costs to the respondent. HELD: 1) The R. M. appealed the respondent's application for grant aid in the amount of $150,000.  2) The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and Mainline, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to the contrary. It admits that the mortgage created in favour of Mainline was never conceived, as the title on which the interest was based was a mortgage of only limited interest. The respondent admitted that it had a covenant, in the Grant Agreement, to postpone its security interests to those of the appellant. 3) The respondent obtained priority over the appellant by virtue of the filing of its caveat. 4) The appeal is accordingly dismissed. 5) The Court of Appeal held that the second FCC Mortgage has priority. The appellant is seeking to increase the interest actually accorded to it by relying on its prior registration and priority provisions of the LTA.

column13: This was an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Queen's Bench determining that a mortgage held by the R.M. was subordinate to that of the respondent, even though the mortgage was registered before the mortgage of FCC. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with costs to the respondent. 1) The respondent agreed to foreclose its two registered mortgages against the subject land. 2) The appellant admits that it was never intended, as between itself and Mainline, that it would obtain a security interest in priority to the contrary. 3) Mainline granted a mortgage to the appellant subject to prior interests, as defined by the Land Titles Act. 4) The trial judge held that the fee simple mortgage had priority over the respondent's mortgage. 5) The court found that the respondent did not even know about, and certainly did not rely upon, the covenant in the Grant Agreement between the appellant and the FCC. The appellant admitted that the mortgage created in favour of Mainline was never conceived, as the title on which that interest was based remained subject to that interest. 6) It was not in this case necessary to consider whether the priority provisions of the LTA are, as general rule, overridden by commercial postponement agreements in mortgages or whether reliance by the competing security holder is necessary in order to displace the doctrine of privity of contract in relation to covenant to postpone. 7) The Court held that registration, while arguably conclusive on the issues of notice and priority, does not and cannot alter the nature of the legal interest granted by the instrument registered. In this case, the mortgage instrument states that it is pursuant to the prior Grant Agreement executed by the parties. This agreement, in turn, clearly provides that any security granted by Mainline to the applicant is subject to a prior security interest. 8) It is not an action by the respondent to enforce the trust deed. 9) The appeal is accordingly dismissed.

column2: Decision, following a voir dire, on the admissibility of statements made by the accused to a police officer, beginning with: 'Excuse me, I was in a roll-over accident and I am intoxicated.' The officer, who observed symptoms of impairment, asked the accused how much he had had to drink and was told he had consumed about 15 beers. The officer placed the accused under arrest for impaired operation of a motor vehicle, and read him his Charter rights, the Police Warning and a Demand for Blood Sample. The officer then detained the accused by remaining with him while awaiting the Blood Kit to arrive and for a blood technician to take the blood. During this time, the officer interrogated the accused about the accident and the accused provided additional information. The Crown contended that if he was given the police warning then it would be clear to the accused that he did not have to continue to answer questions the officer's questions. The Defence argued that since the arrest and the blood demand were based upon self-incriminating evidence obtained by breach of the accused's s. 7 rights, the arrest was illegal and all evidence obtained thereafter should be excluded; or, at least, that the information obtained was illegally obtained and the police could not rely on that information to make the demand. The accused testified that he talked to the police officer only because he believed he had a legal obligation to do so, based on advice he had received from others that there was a legal obligation to report the accident promptly to the police. The Crown conceded that the accused did have a legal obligation to report the accident promptly, and that if the accused believed he was reporting the accident when he gave self-incriminating statements to the police officer as a result of that belief, those statements must be excluded according to law. HELD: All of the statements of the accused, including those made after the arrest, are excluded and will not form part of the Crown's case. The evidence obtained, and the statements, in particular, were self-incriminating and conscriptive. The officer was acting in good faith, not with serious intentional disregard of the accused's rights. He was not taking a statement under the Traffic Safety Act. He did not know that the accused was only saying things because he believed he had to under compulsion of statute. Even though the investigator did nothing that violated the accused's rights, they were nevertheless violated. Because the violation resulted in the making of statements that amounted to self-incriminating evidence, following the logic of the case law, it is necessary to exclude those statements. The accused did approach the police officer with the intention of reporting the accident as is required by the Traffic Safety Act. As such, and as the Crown correctly concedes, his initial statement, anything said by the accused while providing his personal information and the answer to any question while registering at the hospital are excluded from this trial. As the self-incriminating statements made under compulsion of statute have been excluded, it follows that any evidence that came about as a result of the officer following up on those excluded statements are also in breach of the accused's s. 7 rights.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired operation of motor vehicle and driving while intoxicated. The Crown appealed the voir dire decision following a voir de dire on the admissibility of statements made by the accused to a police officer. The accused testified that after the roll-over, he received a ride to Saskatoon with truck driver, who dropped him off near his cousin's home. While walking there he phoned his father, cousin and 9-1-1 operator. He received advice that there was a legal obligation to report the accident promptly to the police. He then went to the hospital to attend to his injuries. The officer detained the accused and detained him while awaiting the Blood Kit to arrive and for a blood technician to take the blood. During this time the accused was also awaiting treatment for his injuries and provided additional information to the officer. HELD: The accused's statements were not admissible. The evidence obtained was as a result of self-incriminating statements made to the arresting officer as a matter of fact. The police could not rely on that information to make the demand. The defence argued that if the accused's statement was made as a consequence of the arrest, it would be clear to the accused that he did not have to continue to answer questions of the officer and that he had no right to make a demand. It was not clear to him that he was making these statements because he was afraid of being arrested. The Court held that the arrest was illegal and excluded all evidence obtained thereafter. The arrest was not illegal and the information obtained was illegally obtained. The information obtained by the information was illegally obtain and the police cannot rely on it to make that demand. There was nothing to prevent the accused from making these self- incriminating statements. The Police were instructed to look into the injuries and to contact the accused. The Accused's statements made after the arrest were self-initiative and self-confirming. The court concluded that the evidence received by the officer was as the result of breach of his section rights. The trial judge concluded that this was the case. The admission would render the trial unfair. The only conclusion that the officer made was that the accused believed he was reporting the accident and gave self-insulting statements to the officers as a reason for his belief. The fact that the police were instructed not to make these statements was irrelevant. The officers were instructed by the Crown to not make these self incriminating statement. column4: [1] This is a decision, following a voir dire, on the admissibility of statements made by the accused to a police officer. The accused called out to him and said; “Excuse me, I was in a roll-over accident and I am intoxicated.” [10] The Crown concedes that the accused did have a legal obligation to report the accident promptly, and if I find that the accused believed he was reporting the accident when he gave self-incriminating statements to the police officer as a result of this belief, then the law requires me to exclude those statements. [11] I find in this case that the accused did approach the police officer with the intention of reporting the accident as is required by the Traffic Safety Act. The Crown contends that if I accept that he was given the police warning then it would be clear to the accused that he did not have to continue to answer questions of the officer. [14] The Defence also argues that since the arrest and the blood demand were based upon evidence that was obtained by breach of the accused’s section 7 rights and was self- incriminating, I should find that the arrest was illegal and exclude all evidence obtained thereafter, or at least that the information obtained was illegally obtained and the police cannot rely on that information to make the demand. Does is it not follow that any evidence that came about as a result of the officer following up on those excluded statements are also in breach of the accused’s section 7 rights? I believe so. [20] That being the case I have concluded that even though the investigator did nothing that violated the accused’s rights, they were nevertheless violated.

column8: The accused was charged with impaired operation and driving under the influence. The Crown appealed the voir dire decision following which it held that the accused was in a roll-over accident and that he was intoxicated. The defence argued that if the accused believed he was reporting the accident when he gave self-incriminating statements to the police officer as a result of this belief, then the law requires me to exclude those statements. HELD: The accused was acquitted. 1) The Crown conceded that the officer gave the accused a warning and that it would be clear to the accused that he did not have to continue to answer questions of the officer. 2) It is useful to divide the series of statements that were made into groups. Those before the arrest and those given after. The evidence received, the statements in particular were self- incriminating and conscriptive. If the Crown determined that the Crown had given the accused warning, it would make clear to him that he had not had to continue answering questions. 3) The defence contended that if he was given the police warning, then it would not be clear that he didn't have a reasonable expectation that he would continue to make the demand. 4) The accused testified that he understood his rights, his warning and his demand for blood. 5) The police were instructed to concentrate on the fact that he could recall his rights. 6) The evidence obtained was self-initiative and self-recriminating. The accused did not recall his right to make a demand. The arrest was illegal and the information obtained was illegally obtained. column18: The accused was charged with impaired operation of motor vehicle and was found to be intoxicated. The Crown appealed the voir dire decision. The accused testified that after the roll-over, he received a ride to Saskatoon with truck driver, who dropped him off near his cousin's home. While walking there he phoned his father, cousin and 9-1-1 operator. He received advice that there was a legal obligation to report the accident promptly to the police. He then went to the hospital to attend to his injuries. The defence argued that if the accused was given a police warning, it would be clear to the accused that he did not have to continue to answer questions of the officer. HELD: The Crown conceded that the accused believed he was reporting the accident when he gave self-incriminating statements to the officer as a result of this belief, its admission would render the trial unfair. The evidence obtained though process of self--incrimination will generally be excluded in order to ensure the accused has a fair trial. The fair trial test tends more towards an absolute rule of exclusion because courts are instructed to look behind the curtain and see what the accused says. In this case, the accused's statements were self- incriminating and conscriptive. He testified that he was only saying things because he believed he had to under compulsion of statute. He did not remember the officer placing him under arrest, giving him the warning or making the blood demand. He had no recollection that the officer following up on those excluded statements was also in breach of his section 7 rights.  1) The evidence received by the officer was as the result of a breach of the accused’s s. 7 rights and was self incriminating. 2) It is useful for me to divide the series of statements that were made into groups. Those before the arrest and those given after. Those given after are instructive as to the effect of the continuing belief the accused would not have been obliged to answer the questions under the compulsion of law. 3) The officer was not acting in good faith and was co-operative throughout. Perhaps, that is why he approached the officer in the way he did and was cooperative throughout. However, he had no memory of being placed under arrest and advised that he knew his rights and understood the warning.
