column2: The claimant brought an action in the Small Claims Court to enforce a default judgment it had been granted against the defendant in Alberta for breach of contract. The claimant attempted to proceed in Nova Scotia on the basis of reciprocal enforcement under the common law or enforcement of the debt as a contract. The adjudicator dismissed the action, finding that the Small Claims Court did not have the authority to enforce an order arising from a foreign jurisdiction and that it could not proceed with the claim for breach of the agreement under the contract as there was no evidence that the Alberta action had been withdrawn, struck or transferred out. The adjudicator also found that the defendant had not attorned to the jurisdiction of the Alberta court. The claimant appealed. Appeal dismissed; although the adjudicator's interpretation of sec. 15 of the Act and his finding that the defendant had not attorned to the jurisdiction of the Alberta court when there was no evidence before him on that issue constituted errors in law, the present claim was beyond the scope of the Small Claims Court Act, given that the adjudicator would first be called upon to settle a dispute regarding the original court's jurisdiction, the locus of the original contract and a factual dispute concerning attornment.
column3: The parties appeared before the Small Claims Court adjudicator for hearing on the issue of whether the Small claims court had jurisdiction to hear the claim filed by the Claimants. The Adjudicator found that Section 9 of the Act did not provide the Court with authority to enforce an Order arising from foreign jurisdiction. Rather than determine a claim based on a fixed amount, it is apparent an adjudicator would be called upon first to settle a dispute regarding the original Court's jurisdiction, the locus of the original contract, and a factual dispute concerning attornment. The claim was reduced from the amount of its judgment to fall within the monetary limits established by the Small's Court Act and the fact that the debt so created was simple contract debt and not specialty debt, and was subject to the appropriate limitation period. The applicant appealed. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The adjudicator erred in finding that the Small’s jurisdiction did not attorn to the Alberta jurisdiction. The appellant’ s interpretation of the Small Act was an error in law. The trial judge erred by finding that Eastside did not have jurisdiction to render the judgment. The issue was whether the Court had jurisdiction in Nova Scotia and Alberta. The court found the claim extends beyond the authority of the small claims court. The fact that default judgment may be set aside at some time in the future, as argued by the Respondent, does not make it any less final or conclusive. Once judgment is rendered there is no proceeding that can be withdrawn, abandoned, struck out or transferred as contemplated by the Act. The present claim extends into the authority and extent of the Alberta Small Claims court Act.
column4: [1] This is an appeal from the decision of the Small Claims Court Adjudicator wherein he determined that he lacked jurisdiction to hear the action filed by the Claimants. [10] The Appellant appeals the findings of the Adjudicator on the grounds that he committed errors in law in interpreting the relevant sections of the Small Claims Court Act and in his finding that Eastside did not attorn to the Alberta jurisdiction. [16] I find the Adjudicator’s interpretation of Section 15 represents an error in law. I find the Adjudicator erred in finding that Eastside did not attorn to the jurisdiction of Alberta as there was no evidence on this issue and therefore, no basis to support this conclusion. [24] Rather than determine a claim based on a fixed amount, it is apparent an Adjudicator, in a case of this nature, would be called upon first to settle a dispute regarding the original Court’s jurisdiction, the locus of the original contract, and a factual dispute concerning attornment. [25] Taking into account the purpose of the legislation, the remedial goals, the underlying values of efficiency and access to justice, and the potential for a complex and lengthy fact finding process in this action, I find the present claim extends beyond the authority of the Small Claims Court Act. CONCLUSION [26] Accordingly, I dismiss the Appeal.

The claim was reduced from the amount of its judgment to fall within the monetary limits established by the Small claims Court Act and a factual dispute concerning attornment. Taking into account the purpose of the legislation, the remedial goals, the underlying values of efficiency and access to justice, and the potential for a complex fact finding process in this action, the present claim extends beyond the authority of the small claims court.
column19: [1] This is an appeal from the decision of the Small Claims Court Adjudicator wherein he determined that he lacked jurisdiction to hear the action filed by the Claimants. [10] The Appellant appeals the findings of the Adjudicator on the grounds that he committed errors in law in interpreting the relevant sections of the Small Claims Court Act and in his finding that Eastside did not attorn to the Alberta jurisdiction. [16] I find the Adjudicator’s interpretation of Section 15 represents an error in law. I find the Adjudicator erred in finding that Eastside did not attorn to the jurisdiction of Alberta as there was no evidence on this issue and therefore, no basis to support this conclusion. [24] Rather than determine a claim based on a fixed amount, it is apparent an Adjudicator, in a case of this nature, would be called upon first to settle a dispute regarding the original Court’s jurisdiction, the locus of the original contract, and a factual dispute concerning attornment. [25] Taking into account the purpose of the legislation, the remedial goals, the underlying values of efficiency and access to justice, and the potential for a complex and lengthy fact finding process in this action, I find the present claim extends beyond the authority of the Small Claims Court Act. CONCLUSION [26] Accordingly, I dismiss the Appeal.

column2: Applicant seeks an order for an assessment of his legal bill. A Registrar may assess any bill for legal services, provided that the application is filed within 30 days or more if a judge makes a discretionary order to extend the period for assessment if it is in the interests of justice to do so. The issue if whether the applicant's two bills fall with the said 30 days or if this is a case where it is appropriate to abridge the time for allowing an assessment. HELD: It is in the interest of justice to order an assessment. The bills were issued in two separate matters. In the first matter, the final bill was rendered and the applicant had a lengthy opportunity to raise the issue. There will be no extension of time for the first bill. The second bill is different in that the applicant disputed the amount of the bill when he first received it. He was advised that the bill would be adjusted. An initial adjustment was made and when still not satisfied, ongoing discussions about the bill continued. The Court held that the last document received by the applicant was not the final bill as it was still subject to change. In this case, the lawyer has been paid from monies held in trust for the client, the time being abridged is relatively short and neither party has alleged that any prejudice would result.
column3: FIAT. The applicant sought an order pursuant to s. 67(1) of The Legal Profession Act for an assessment of his legal bills for services rendered to him by the respondent. HELD: The application was granted. The court was not satisfied that it was in the interests of justice to abridge the time and order the assessment. The bill was rendered in May 2007 and was not provided to the respondent until after July 16, 2007. The defendant had a lengthy opportunity to raise the issue or hire alternate counsel but did not do so. The Court was not convinced that the bill was a final bill. The respondent had a considerable opportunity to raised the issue and hire alternate lawyers but did so.
column4: [1] The applicant, Stanley Postnikoff, seeks an order pursuant to s. 67(1) of The Legal Profession Act, 1990, S.S. 1990-91, c.L-10.1, as am. 2005, c.38 (“The Legal Profession Act) for an assessment of his legal bills for services rendered to him by the respondent, James A. Morrison. If Mr. Postnikoff had genuine concern respecting the cost of the services provided by Mr. Morrison on the Back-Track matter, he had a lengthy opportunity to raise the issue or hire alternate counsel, but he did not do so. [22] I am not satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to extend the time for an application for an assessment of the Back-Track account. [24] I am not convinced that the billing document sent to Mr. Postnikoff on July 16, 2007 was a final bill, as evidenced both by parties discussions on July 24, 2007, and further evidenced by Mr. Morrison’s letter dated on August 28, 2007. Second, a final account will not be subject to change, and will cover all professional services performed within a certain time. However, since the privilege was held by Mr. Morrison and only waived when he filed his affidavit on February 26, 2008 (as he attached the bill), I am not satisfied it was a final bill. I am satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to abridge the time and order the assessment.

HELD: The application is dismissed. The court is not satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to abridge the time and order the assessment. The applicant's two bills fall within the period of time allowable for assessment by the registrar and if not, the issue is whether the respondent's bill is a final bill. The time being abridged is relatively short. There were discussions between the respondent and the applicant concerning the appropriateness of the account at the time the account was rendered. The last bill rendered for Back-Track was on September 27, 2006 after three day trial and receipt of the trial judgment. On December 31, 2007 Mr. Morrison transferred the monies from trust to the BASF account. On February 5, 2008 Mr. Postnikoff applied for an order for assessment. In this case, there has been no lawsuit commenced for the collection of the accounts. The respondent has been paid from monies in trust. The Court is satisfied that the privilege was held by the applicant and only waived when he filed his affidavit on February 26, 2008 (as he attached the bill). The respondent is entitled to return the balance of monies being held in trust to him.

column2: Criminal Law – Motor Vehicle Offences – Driving with Blood Alcohol Exceeding .08 – Conviction – AppealConstitutional Law – Charter of Rights, Section 10(b) – Appeal The accused appealed her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code of driving with a blood alcohol content over .08 on the grounds that the trial judge erred in law finding that there was no breach of her s. 8 Charter rights or of a breach of her s. 10(b) Charter rights. The first ground pertained to the defence’s contention that the officer who stopped the accused and made the breath demand did not have sufficient evidence of impaired driving. The officer testified that he was patrolling for impaired drivers on the night in question and observed the accused make a very tight right-hand turn, entering the untraveled portion of the road where the snow was soft. He noticed that her eyes were glassy and she was slurring her speech. She had just lit a cigarette, which suspects often do to mask the smell of alcohol. When she did put the cigarette out, he smelled alcohol on her breath. He asked her to step out of the vehicle and noticed that she swayed while standing still. She walked with a wide stance to the police cruiser and had to lean against it to maintain her balance. When he first asked the appellant if she had had anything to drink, she said that she’d had three but later said that she’d had five. He arrested her and made the breath demand. The defence argued that the trial judge erred in failing to consider other evidence that other vehicles had made similar turns and that the appellant did not require any assistance in leaving her vehicle and walking to the police cruiser, among other things. With respect to the second ground, the appellant advised the officer that she wanted to speak to a specific lawyer after being arrested. At the detachment, the appellant located the lawyer’s number and the officer dialed it. A voice message was left on the lawyer’s telephone but no return call was received. The officer advised the appellant she could call another lawyer, and initially she responded that she did not want to but wished to provide a breath sample. The officer was about to read her a waiver of her right when the appellant indicated that she wanted to call another lawyer. The officer called the number but received an after-hours message. He asked the appellant if she wanted to try another lawyer and she declined, stating that she was satisfied with leaving a message. She then provided her first breath sample. The defence argued at trial that the officer failed to advise the appellant of the availability of Legal Aid and failed to provide the Prosper warning, thereby breaching s. 10(b) of the Charter.  HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The court found that the trial judge had not erred: 1) by finding there was no s. 8 breach. The judge had not made any findings of fact that were not supported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he found that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported his belief that the appellant’s ability to drive was impaired; and 2) by finding that there had been no breach of s. 10(b). The appellant had failed to act diligently in pursuing her right to speak with a lawyer and provided a clear and unequivocal indication that she had abandoned her right to counsel when she said she was happy leaving a message.
column3: The appellant appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code for driving with a blood alcohol content over.08. The trial judge erred in finding there was no breach of s. 10(b) Charter rights. The appellant contends the failure of the officer to provide the appellant with a Prosper warning resulted in a breach of her s. 9(b)(c) Charter right. The officer noted that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow. The police had an obligation to refrain from eliciting any incriminating evidence until the detainee was given the opportunity to consult with legal counsel. The appeal court dismissed the appeal. The court found that the trial judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the officer's belief that the appellant's ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired. The evidence provided by the officer was sufficient to support the officer’s conclusion that the breath sample was positive. The respondent’ s. 8 Charter rights were breached. The Court dismissed the appellant’S appeal. It was not found that there was a breach in s. 11(b). The trial court found the trial court erred by failing to consider the factors articulated by the police as forming the factual basis for making the breath demand were reliable and capable of supporting the officer. The error was not the only reason the appellant appealed. The Appeal Court found that it was not a breach because the trial officer had not been trained in the field of sobriety and the officer did not have sufficient evidence to objectively support the appellant. The issue was whether the trial Judge erred on the facts of the case. The test for a Charter breach is whether the officer has had sufficient experience to make a determination that there is a reasonable and probable basis for the officer making a determination. The errors of fact are listed as follows: 1) The trial officer failed to consider that other car tracks in soft snow constituted evidence of impairment. The second issue is whether there was sufficient evidence upon which the officer could reasonably reach the verdict. The standard required for an effective waiver of counsel is very high. 2) The appellant”s appeal is dismissed. The failure of Cst. Schmidt to provide her with a warning resulted. The judge did nothing wrong. The facts as found by the appellant were not the basis upon which he formed his decision that the driver was impaired
column4:
[1] Chantelle Drake [Ms. Drake] appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code, RSC 1985, c C-46, of driving with a blood alcohol content of over .08, on the following grounds:
a) The learned trial judge erred in law in finding that there was no s. 8 Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms [Charter], breach to be secure against unreasonable search or seizure;
b) The learned trial judge erred in law in finding that there was no breach of the s. 10(b) Charter giving everyone the right on arrest or detention the right to retain and instruct counsel without delay. The alleged errors of fact are listed as follows:
a) The trial judge failed to consider that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow; [31] The trial judge, in attributing four and half years’ experience to the officer when in fact the officer had only three years’ experience at the time of the offence, did not commit material error. [34] The trial judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the officer’s belief that the appellant’s ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired. I dismiss ground one of the appeal. [35] The appellant contends that the failure of Cst. Schmidt to provide the appellant with the Prosper warning resulted in a breach of her s. 10(b) Charter rights. Counsel for the appellant contends that failure to advise Ms. Drake of the availability of duty counsel and failure to provide a Prosper warning constituted breach of his client’s s. 10(b) Charter rights. She declined and said she was happy just leaving a message. [61] Even if I am mistaken in that regard, I am satisfied that Ms. Drake provided a clear and unequivocal indication that she had abandoned her s. 10(b) Charter right to contact legal counsel. She said that she was happy with just leaving a message. As such, Ms. Drake’s second ground of appeal is dismissed. Conclusion [62] For the reasons previously stated, Ms. Drake’s appeal is dismissed in its entirety.

He asked the appellant if she wanted to try another lawyer and she declined, stating that she was satisfied with leaving a message. She then provided her first breath sample. The defence argued at trial that the officer failed to advise the appellant of the availability of Legal Aid and failed to provide the Prosper warning, thereby breaching s. 10(b) of the Charter.  HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The court found that the trial judge had not erred: 1) by finding there was no s. 8 breach. The judge had not made any findings of fact that were not supported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he found that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported his belief that the appellant’s ability to drive was impaired; and 2) by finding that there had been no breach of s. 10(b). The appellant had failed to act diligently in pursuing her right to speak with a lawyer and provided a clear and unequivocal indication that she had abandoned her right to counsel when she said she was happy leaving a message.
column8: The appellant appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code for driving with a blood alcohol content over.08. The trial judge erred in law in finding there was no breach of s. 10(b) Charter rights. The appellant contends the failure of the officer to provide the appellant with a Prosper warning resulted in a breach of her s.10(b). HELD: The appeal is dismissed. 1)The trial judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the officer's belief that the appellant's ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired. The evidence provided by the officer was sufficient to establish that there was a material error in the trial judge's assessment of credibility. 2)The appellant contends that the failure by the appellant to provide her with the Prosper warning in light of the fact that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow did not establish a violation of her right to counsel. 3)On the factual and legal grounds, the standard of review is correct. The appeal court must assess the reasonableness of the decision and must not substitute its own view of the evidence for that of the trial Judge. The standard of reviewing is correctness. 4)The appeal court erred by failing to consider the factors articulated by the police officer as forming the factual basis for making the breath demand were reliable and capable of supporting the officer’s belief that she could walk and enter police vehicle without assistance. 5)The evidence was found to support the appellant’ s.8 Charter rights and the trial court erased the evidence. The officer was not trained in the use of profanity in his field notes. 6)The respondent was not the only person who had reasonable and probable grounds to make a demand for a breath sample. The respondent was the only one who was given the opportunity to make the call. 7)The officer was only required to advise the detainee of his right to be given a reasonable opportunity to contact legal counsel and the police have an obligation to refrain from eliciting any incriminating evidence until the detainee has been given an opportunity to consult with legal counsel. 8) The respondent had four and half years’ experience at the time of the incident. 9) The appellant was not a party to the offence. 10)The court dismissed the appeal.

[1] Chantelle Drake [Ms. Drake] appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code, RSC 1985, c C-46, of driving with a blood alcohol content of over .08, on the following grounds:

b) The learned trial judge erred in law in finding that there was no breach of the s. 10(b) Charter giving everyone the right on arrest or detention the right to retain and instruct counsel without delay. The alleged errors of fact are listed as follows:
a) The trial judge failed to consider that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow; [31] The trial judge, in attributing four and half years’ experience to the officer when in fact the officer had only three years’ experience at the time of the offence, did not commit material error. [34] The trial judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the officer’s belief that the appellant’s ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired. She declined and said she was happy just leaving a message. [61] Even if I am mistaken in that regard, I am satisfied that Ms. Drake provided a clear and unequivocal indication that she had abandoned her s. 10(b) Charter right to contact legal counsel. She said that she was happy with just leaving a message. As such, Ms. Drake’s second ground of appeal is dismissed. She walked with a wide stance to the police cruiser and had to lean against it to maintain her balance. When he first asked the appellant if she had had anything to drink, she said that she’d had three but later said that she’d had five. He arrested her and made the breath demand. The defence argued that the trial judge erred in failing to consider other evidence that other vehicles had made similar turns and that the appellant did not require any assistance in leaving her vehicle and walking to the police cruiser, among other things. With respect to the second ground, the appellant advised the officer that she wanted to speak to a specific lawyer after being arrested. At the detachment, the appellant located the lawyer’s number and the officer dialed it. A voice message was left on the lawyer’s telephone but no return call was received. The officer advised the appellant she could call another lawyer, and initially she responded that she did not want to but wished to provide a breath sample. The appellant had failed to act diligently in pursuing her right to speak with a lawyer and provided a clear and unequivocal indication that she had abandoned her right to counsel when she said she was happy leaving a message.
column13: The appellant appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code, RSC 1985, c C-46, for driving with a blood alcohol content over.08. The trial judge erred in finding there was no breach of s. 10(b) Charter rights. The appellant contends the failure of the officer to provide the appellant with a Prosper warning resulted in a breach of her s.10(b). HELD: The appeal is dismissed. 1)The trial judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the officer's belief that the appellant's ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired. 2)The appellant contends that the trial judge, in attributing four and half years' experience to the officer when in fact the officer was only three years’ experience at the time of the incident, did not commit a material error. However, there was a palpable and overriding (or manifest) error in law. 3)The evidence provided by the officer as forming the factual basis for making the breath demand was reliable and capable of supporting the officer’s belief that she could walk and enter police vehicle without assistance. 4)There was no evidence upon which a reasonable person would have believed the appellant did not require assistance for her to exit the vehicle and walk to the police cruiser. The officer was not required to have overwhelming evidence of impairment. 5)The court dismissed ground one of the appeal on the ground that the appeal court erred by failing to consider that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow. The court found that there was reasonable and probable grounds for an unconditional waiver of counsel.

column18: The appellant appeals her conviction under s. 253(1)(b) of the Criminal Code for driving with a blood alcohol content over.08 on the following grounds: 1) The trial judge ignored evidence that the appellant did not require assistance for her to exit the vehicle and walk to the police cruiser. However, there was evidence provided by the officer that she was smoking a freshly lit cigarette which, in the officer's experience, was a tactic sometimes used by people to hide the smell of something. The officer noted that other cars had previously made a tight turn as evidenced by other tire tracks in the soft snow and the appellant pulled over appropriately after being signalled to do so. Smokers will light up cigarette not solely for the purpose of masking the odour of alcohol on their breath but out of nervousness or other cause. The judge did not make any findings of fact that were unsupported by the evidence nor did he fail to consider relevant evidence when he held that the officer had sufficient evidence that objectively supported the appellant's belief that her ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired. 2) The appellant contends that the trial judge erred in law in finding there was no breach of her s. 10(b) Charter rights. The court dismissed ground one of the appeal on the basis that the appeal court failed to consider whether there was a breach of s. 8 Canadian Charter rights and the standard required for an effective waiver of counsel is very high. The appeal court also dismissed ground two on the ground that it was based on an error of law, failure to consider other cars that had previously turned, and the police have an obligation to refrain from eliciting any incriminating evidence until the detainee has been given the opportunity to consult with legal counsel.

column2: Family Law – Custody and Access – VariationFamily Law – Custody and Access – Voices of the Children Report In 2012, after a trial, it was determined that the child should be parented on a shared basis with a one-week rotation between parents. An order was never issued and therefore, no judgment was taken out. The applicant now applied to have a formal judgment issued, and to vary the decision in favour of her having primary residence. Alternatively, she sought a Voices of the Child report. The applicant indicated that the child expressed a desire to live with her full-time. The parties’ affidavits conflicted as to their behaviour. The applicant indicated that the child told her he was required to continue skiing with the respondent even though he was having a seizure. She also indicated that the child told her that the respondent told his roommate he was going to stab the applicant and he called her crazy. HELD: The court found it appropriate to order a Voices of the Child report. It was determined that the variation application decision was dependent on the report. There were more issues at play than a bald statement by the applicant that the child requested to live with her full-time. The child was an appropriate age for the report, being over 12 years old. He was able to communicate effectively and the report would be meaningful to the court. The order was to be paid for through resources provided to the program. The parties were prohibited from discussing the report process with the child and they were ordered not to influence, coach, sway, or prompt the child towards particular views or statements for the purposes of the report. The application was adjourned sine die returnable not sooner than 14 days after the report was received by all parties. The judgment was directed to be issued.
column3: The applicant sought a Voices of the Children report in order to ascertain the respondent's wishes and gain clarity on his best interests. HELD: The application was to have a formal judgment issued and to vary the decision in favour of her having primary residence. In the absence of an order varying the shared parenting order, she seeks a Voices report be prepared in order in order ascertain the petitioner's wishes. A Voice of the Child report would meaningfully assist the court in determining a custody and access plan that is in the best interests of the petitioner.  1) The respondent opposes all relief sought.  2) The affidavits are conflicting in nature and it is appropriate to ascertain whether the appropriate order is the commissioning of a Voice of The Child report. It will be one piece of evidence that will assist the Court in determining what custody and parenting arrangement is in V's best interests and that a Voice Of The Child Report would meaningly assist the courts in determining the best interest of the child.  3) The petitioner is of an appropriate age, being over 12 years old, that he is able to communicate effectively and that he would like to reside full time with her. He is of a suitable age being over the age of 12 years. His desires and motivations are clear and that the Voice of a Child report will meaningfully help the court determine a custody plan that was in the petitioner’s best interests
column4: BACKGROUND [1] This matter arises following a trial in 2012 wherein Justice Kraus found that shared parenting regarding V.M., born March 8, 2005, [V.] should occur on a one week rotation basis (2012 SKQB 130 (CanLII), 395 Sask R 165). In the absence of an order varying the shared parenting order, she seeks a Voices of the Children, (here a Voice of the Child as V. is the only person in issue), report be undertaken in order to ascertain V.’s wishes and thereby gain clarity on his best interests. [4] For the reasons that follow, I find that it is appropriate to order a Voice of the Child report be prepared regarding V. I find V. is of an appropriate age, being over 12 years old, that he is able to communicate effectively and that a Voice of the Child report would meaningfully assist the court in determining a custody and access plan that is in the best interests of V. [23] This application is therefore to be adjourned sine die returnable not sooner than 14 days after the Voice of the Child report has been received by all parties. I attach the copy of the judgment with notations that is appropriately issued at this time and I direct its issuance in that form.

column2: Contract Law – Sale of Land – FormationReal Property – Sale of Land – Oral Contract The plaintiff brought an action against the defendant for specific performance and damages. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant agreed to sell him three quarters of land. The defendant’s position was that there was no agreement and if there was, it was not in writing as required by The Statute of Frauds. The plaintiff made this application for a resolution of the initial question of liability as to whether an agreement was created and if it was, then proof of damages would follow. The plaintiff argued that a contract was created and that it complied with the statute because he made his offer in writing, via an internet-based land auction program, and the acceptance was orally communicated by a telephone conversation. Therefore, all the requisite elements of a valid land sale were present. The defendant had used a website to list 17 quarters of land for sale, including six quarters of relevance to the action. The website was intended to connect sellers of farmland with interested buyers in a type of “non-binding auction” to permit sellers to gauge interest in their land, find the best possible price and avoid realtor’s commissions if a sale were completed. The listing showed three groups of the farmland for sale, described as 1) three adjoining quarters (the subject quarters); 2) two quarters (the adjacent quarters) and 3) one quarter (unsold quarter). In his online comments to the defendant during the auction, the plaintiff said that he wanted all five quarters (the subject and adjacent quarters). The plaintiff bid on each of the above parcels and had the highest bid on the subject quarters, but that in itself did not guarantee the purchase under the terms of the online auction program. He stopped bidding on the adjacent quarters because he thought they were becoming overpriced. After the auction, the plaintiff consulted with family members regarding whether to pursue negotiations with any of the bidders. They discussed the problems that would occur if the subject quarters were separated from the adjacent quarters because the two blocks were owned by different individuals. The defendant then telephoned the plaintiff and gave him two package options for the sale, both of which resolved the identified problem by including the purchase of the adjacent quarters. The package options were to purchase the subject and the adjacent quarters for $1,050,000 (which was 5 percent more than the $625,000 the plaintiff offered for the subject quarters and his last bid of $375,000 on the adjacent quarters) or the subject quarters and one of the adjacent quarters for $840,000. At the end of the conversation, the plaintiff testified that he wanted to be sure that regardless of his response to the package option offers, he would be able to buy the subject quarters for $625,000. The plaintiff did not have concerns about the purchase because he said that the defendant told him that “we had them”. He believed that this indicated the defendant’s willingness to accept his bid on the subject quarters and that if he accepted either of the two options, then either of the newly accepted offers would replace the agreement respecting the subject quarters. The defendant’s interpretation of the conversation was that he declined to accept the offer on the subject quarters until he heard back from the plaintiff respecting the package options and then he would decide whether or not he would sell the subject quarters. He either misheard or misunderstood the plaintiff’s question about the subject quarters and denied that he gave any assurance that he would sell them to him regardless of his response to the package offers. The plaintiff called the defendant shortly after the first conversation and advised that he would not accept either of the package option offers but would immediately bring the deposit for the purchase of the subject quarters. The defendant told him to “hold off”. The plaintiff interpreted that to mean that there was no urgency regarding the deposit rather than that no agreement existed respecting the subject quarters. The defendant testified that he said he was not prepared to accept the deposit at this time, which meant that he was not prepared to accept the plaintiff’s bid on the subject quarters. Three days later, the defendant emailed the plaintiff and said that he would not be accepting the bid. The issues were: 1) whether a contract was formed; 2) if so, did the Statute of Frauds apply.  HELD: The plaintiff’s action was dismissed. He had not established on a balance of probabilities that he and the defendant were parties to a valid and enforceable agreement of sale regarding the subject quarters. The court found with respect to each issue that: 1) there was no contract. In interpreting the words of the first telephone conversation and the context of the bidding process, using the standard of the reasonable bystander, there was no consensus ad idem between the parties. The second telephone conversation had done nothing to alter that finding. Both the plaintiff and the defendant reasonably believed different things; and 2) the Statute did not apply as there was no contract.
column3: HELD: The Court accepted the respondent’s submission that the plaintiff had entered into a contract with the respondent. The Court held that the contract was valid and that the respondent had not made any errors in the contract. The court also held that there was no evidence that the agreement was created between the respondent and the respondent in any event. The respondent”s submission was not supported by the evidence. The evidence was that the parties had exchanged information during the bidding process and that they had not discussed the terms of the contract in any way. The plaintiff was also awarded specific performance and damages. The issue was whether the agreement existed between the parties and whether the respondent was entitled to receive the appropriate deposit respecting the purchase of the respondent property. The petitioner was awarded general damages.
column4: [34] The court must determine whether a contract was created between Mr. Petrie and Mr. Ziola respecting the Subject Quarters. Looking to the words exchanged and the context of the bidding process following Mr. Petrie’s conversation with Jennifer Petrie, the court finds that a misunderstanding could readily and objectively characterize the nature of the telephone conversations so that no consensus ad idem was ever reached between Mr. Petrie and Mr. Ziola. Conclusion [58] Mr. Ziola has not established on a balance of probabilities that he and Mr. Petrie were parties to a valid and enforceable agreement of sale respecting the Subject Quarters. His action is dismissed.

column19: [34] The court must determine whether a contract was created between Mr. Petrie and Mr. Ziola respecting the Subject Quarters. Looking to the words exchanged and the context of the bidding process following Mr. Petrie’s conversation with Jennifer Petrie, the court finds that a misunderstanding could readily and objectively characterize the nature of the telephone conversations so that no consensus ad idem was ever reached between Mr. Petrie and Mr. Ziola. Conclusion [58] Mr. Ziola has not established on a balance of probabilities that he and Mr. Petrie were parties to a valid and enforceable agreement of sale respecting the Subject Quarters. His action is dismissed.
column22: Contract Law – Sale of Land – FormationReal Property – Sale of Land – Oral Contract The plaintiff brought an action against the defendant for specific performance and damages. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant agreed to sell him three quarters of land. The defendant’s position was that there was no agreement and if there was, it was not in writing as required by The Statute of Frauds. The plaintiff made this application for a resolution of the initial question of liability as to whether an agreement was created and if it was, then proof of damages would follow. The plaintiff argued that a contract was created and that it complied with the statute because he made his offer in writing, via an internet-based land auction program, and the acceptance was orally communicated by a telephone conversation. Therefore, all the requisite elements of a valid land sale were present. The defendant had used a website to list 17 quarters of land for sale, including six quarters of relevance to the action. The website was intended to connect sellers of farmland with interested buyers in a type of “non-binding auction” to permit sellers to gauge interest in their land, find the best possible price and avoid realtor’s commissions if a sale were completed. The listing showed three groups of the farmland for sale, described as 1) three adjoining quarters (the subject quarters); 2) two quarters (the adjacent quarters) and 3) one quarter (unsold quarter). In his online comments to the defendant during the auction, the plaintiff said that he wanted all five quarters (the subject and adjacent quarters). The plaintiff bid on each of the above parcels and had the highest bid on the subject quarters, but that in itself did not guarantee the purchase under the terms of the online auction program. He stopped bidding on the adjacent quarters because he thought they were becoming overpriced. After the auction, the plaintiff consulted with family members regarding whether to pursue negotiations with any of the bidders. They discussed the problems that would occur if the subject quarters were separated from the adjacent quarters because the two blocks were owned by different individuals. The defendant then telephoned the plaintiff and gave him two package options for the sale, both of which resolved the identified problem by including the purchase of the adjacent quarters. The package options were to purchase the subject and the adjacent quarters for $1,050,000 (which was 5 percent more than the $625,000 the plaintiff offered for the subject quarters and his last bid of $375,000 on the adjacent quarters) or the subject quarters and one of the adjacent quarters for $840,000. At the end of the conversation, the plaintiff testified that he wanted to be sure that regardless of his response to the package option offers, he would be able to buy the subject quarters for $625,000. The plaintiff did not have concerns about the purchase because he said that the defendant told him that “we had them”. He believed that this indicated the defendant’s willingness to accept his bid on the subject quarters and that if he accepted either of the two options, then either of the newly accepted offers would replace the agreement respecting the subject quarters. The defendant’s interpretation of the conversation was that he declined to accept the offer on the subject quarters until he heard back from the plaintiff respecting the package options and then he would decide whether or not he would sell the subject quarters. He either misheard or misunderstood the plaintiff’s question about the subject quarters and denied that he gave any assurance that he would sell them to him regardless of his response to the package offers. The plaintiff called the defendant shortly after the first conversation and advised that he would not accept either of the package option offers but would immediately bring the deposit for the purchase of the subject quarters. The defendant told him to “hold off”. The plaintiff interpreted that to mean that there was no urgency regarding the deposit rather than that no agreement existed respecting the subject quarters. The defendant testified that he said he was not prepared to accept the deposit at this time, which meant that he was not prepared to accept the plaintiff’s bid on the subject quarters. Three days later, the defendant emailed the plaintiff and said that he would not be accepting the bid. The issues were: 1) whether a contract was formed; 2) if so, did the Statute of Frauds apply.  HELD: The plaintiff’s action was dismissed. He had not established on a balance of probabilities that he and the defendant were parties to a valid and enforceable agreement of sale regarding the subject quarters. The court found with respect to each issue that: 1) there was no contract. In interpreting the words of the first telephone conversation and the context of the bidding process, using the standard of the reasonable bystander, there was no consensus ad idem between the parties. The second telephone conversation had done nothing to alter that finding. Both the plaintiff and the defendant reasonably believed different things; and 2) the Statute did not apply as there was no contract.

column2: During a hearing involving an application for custody contested by three parties, the trial judge heard only the appellants' evidence and the direct examination of the natural mother before calling counsel to his chambers and advising them that the hearing was a waste of time and custody should be granted to the natural mother. Counsel for the appellants subsequently put the matter on record and requested the trial judge withdraw, alleging an apprehension of bias. He refused, and after completing the trial, awarded custody to the natural mother and her common-law companion. The decision was appealed. Allowing the appeal, setting aside the decision and ordering a new trial, that the circumstances created a reasonable apprehension of bias which resulted in a denial of natural justice. In the conduct and carriage of civil actions the law requires a fair and impartial hearing.
column3: The appellant appealed a Family Court decision which set aside the trial and remitted the matter for a new trial. The appellant contended that certain conversations the trial judge had with counsel during the course of trial created an apprehension of bias. Dismissing the appeal, that the trial court judge erred in his decision that the appellant had not shown a bias in his approach to the matter. The trial judge, in his remarks to counsel, indicated that he had already written his decision and considered the arguments before him. The appeal court judge then asked all three counsel to come to his chambers which presumably means his office outside the courtroom. There he had a conversation with them which was subsequently placed on the record by counsel of the appellants. The appellants contended that the actions of the trial Judge amounted to a denial of natural justice by creating an apprehension that bias. With these submissions, the Court agreed that the appeal court's decision was a waste of time and should be set aside.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal allowed, decision of Judge of the Family Court set aside and the matter remitted for a new trial, per reasons for judgment of Clarke, C.J.N.S.; This case concerned a custody application in the Family Court involving two infant children. There he had a conversation with them which was subsequently placed on the record by counsel of the appellants. Ah, following J.A.B.\'s direct evidence on Friday, ahm, when we adjourned for lunch, when we returned after lunch, ah, Your Honour requested that all three counsel meet with you in your chambers and at that time you indicated that you felt it would be a waste of everyone\'s time to proceed with the trial. Nevertheless I\'m going to continue with the trial. After the trial judge made the ruling noted above, he continued the case and rendered a decision awarding custody of the two children to the natural mother and of the younger child to her father, the male companion of the mother. The appellants contend in this appeal that the actions of the trial judge amounted to a denial of natural justice by creating an apprehension of bias. With these submissions, I agree.

column8: This was an appeal of a Family Court decision which set aside the trial and remitted the matter for a new trial. The appellants sought custody of the two children, ages three and one-half years old and the younger, fourteen months. The trial judge refused counsel of the appellant's client the opportunity to present further evidence. The appellant argued that this would be a waste of everyone's time to proceed with the trial. Appeal allowed; matter remitted for new trial; the court found that the actions of the trial judge amounted to a denial of natural justice by creating an apprehension of bias. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The Court held that the Court had not erred in accepting the appellants' appeal. 2)The trial judge did not expressly deny either the Crown or the respondent's counsel an opportunity to further their argument. 3)Given the opinion of the natural mother, J.A.B., the appellant was effectively denied his right to make a closing submission.

column13: This was an appeal of a Family Court decision which set aside the trial and remitted the matter for a new trial. The appellants sought to have the custody of the two children returned to them to their natural parents. The trial judge, acting pursuant to the Children's Services Act, authorized the appellants to apply for the custody. At the time the trial judge made the ruling, he continued the case and rendered a decision awarding custody to the natural mother and the younger child to her father, the male companion of the mother. The appellant appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that although certain conversations were held during the course of trial, they raised a reasonable apprehension that the judge, whether consciously or unconsciously, would not decide fairly, would have decided the case before he heard all the evidence.

column23: This case concerned a custody application in the Family Court involving two infant children. They were voluntarily placed in the care of the appellants by their birth mother and her male companion. In due time the Administrator of Family and Children's Services in Nova Scotia, acting pursuant to S.N.S. 1976, authorized them to apply for the custody of the two children, the elder being about three and one-half years old and the younger fourteen months. The appellants sought custody pursuant to the authority given them by the Minister of Community Services. The natural father of the elder child wanted custody but in the alternative, if not, then to him rather than his former wife who was the birth mother of the child. All three parties were represented by their own counsel. After the trial judge made the ruling, he asked all three counsel to come to his chambers which presumably means his office outside the courtroom. There he had a conversation with them which was subsequently placed on the record by counsel of the appellant. HELD: Appeal allowed, decision of Family Court set aside and the matter remitted for a new trial. There was no real difference between the expressions found in the decided cases, be they'reasonable apprehension of bias','real suspicion of bias' or'real likelihood of bias'. The appellant had met the evidentiary burden for setting aside decisions in like circumstances as discussed in de Smith, Judicial Review of Administrative Action.

column2: The parties divorced - the appellant later appealed the trial decision dividing property between them as separated spouses. Her appeal was allowed in part, the court holding the judge erred in ruling inadmissible certain evidence about the value of scallop licences. The matter was remitted to Supreme Court for determination on evidence to be adduced by the parties of the value of the respondent's fishing operation. In preparation, the appellant applied to the Supreme Court for an order to inspect the respondent's bank records pursuant to s. 21(1) of the Evidence Act. The respondent argued he had limited involvement in the enterprise being discovered. The judge granted the order with limitations: the examination was to be limited to income received by the respondent and covering the period from the trial date forward. The appellant appealed, arguing the limitations disallowed full disclosure. In the interim, the respondent went into bankruptcy and argued the examination would be fully conducted by the trustee. Allowing the appeal, that a possible duplication was no reason to limit full disclosure.
column3: This was an appeal from a Chambers decision granting an application under s.21(4) of the Nova Scotia Evidence Act ordering inspection of banking records to the appellant but imposing two limitations. The appellant contended that the examination ordered by the Chambers judge was nothing but a duplication of the detailed and searching examinations that will be made of his assets by the trustee in the bankruptcy proceedings. That may or may not be the case but for the purposes of securing full disclosure in this proceeding which is the one with which we are concerned, it is insufficient reason to limit full disclosure. The appeal is allowed and the two restrictions placed in the order of the Chambers Judge respecting the books or records relating to Fundy Associates Limited and the motor vessel Lady Marion II are deleted.
column4: THE COURT: The appeal is allowed with costs as per reasons for judgment of Chipman, J.A.; This is an appeal from a decision of a judge of the Supreme Court in Chambers granting an application under s. 21(4) of the Nova Scotia Evidence Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 154 ordering inspection of banking records to the appellant, but imposing two limitations thereon. However, he has given no valid reasons for the two restrictions and we order that they should be deleted. He contends that the examination ordered by the Chambers judge is nothing but a duplication of the detailed and searching examinations that will be made of his assets by the trustee in the bankruptcy proceedings. The appeal is allowed and the two restrictions placed in the order of the Chambers judge respecting the books or records relating to Fundy Associates Limited or the motor vessel "Lady Marion II" are deleted.

column2: The applicant sought an order requesting an absolute order of discharge in bankruptcy. The bankrupt was indebted to Canada Student Loans and Saskatchewan Student Loans. He had obtained a Bachelor of Science degree but was unable to complete his final year of Veterinary Medicine because he had received the maximum amount of financing available. The bankrupt had been employed for 5 years as a taxi driver earning a less than average income; he lived at home with his parents; he was single with no dependents. He was reluctant to leave secure employment in an effort to obtain employment related to his educational qualifications. Counsel for the objecting creditor argued that the bankrupt had a minimal income and had the capacity to make small payments toward his obligation. HELD: An absolute order of discharge was granted in accordance with the principles of The Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act.
column3: The bankrupt obtained a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemistry and an Advanced Certificate in Science-Physio as result of student loan funding. column2: This application under s.2 of the Saskatchewan Farm Security Act (SFSA) requires the Court to consider a number of points in relation to the act. The applicant's materials are deficient. Several necessary documents must be filed. In addition, the Farm Land Security Board has not completed its mandatory tasks under the Act. HELD: Application adjourned and leave is given to each party to file further materials. The Farm Land Security Board is requested to provide its report to the Court. Ordinarily, the deficiency in the applicant's motion might merit dismissal, but the Act would then give the respondent a 1 year grace period. This result is unwarranted given that the scheme of the legislation is to encourage discussions between debtor and creditor and the respondent has refused to discuss mortgage issues. Further, the respondent's refusal to provide information should not be allowed to derail the process of financial review by the Farm Land Security Board. No costs to any party.
column3: FIAT. The applicant motion materials filed by the respondent were deficient and ought to include a copy of the notices of intention with proper proofs of service and a certified copy of title to the land in question to establish that the 'equitable mortgage' is registered and that the proper parties are before this court. The Farm Land Security Board ought to complete it mandatory tasks under the Act and provide its report in the format described in the legislation. The apparent refusal by the applicant to provide information should not be allowed to derail the process of financial review as information is available from other sources to deal with the matters in Section 12 (12)(a) and (b). The review if necessary could express the limitations evident from any refusal by any refusal. The Board may apply incentives to the respondent to participate by following the procedures in Sections 12(4), (5) and(7) of the Act.

column2: An appeal from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman ordering the landlord to pay $3,414.50 to the tenant. In issue was the jurisdiction of the Deputy Rentalsman to impose an award on the appellant who was acting as a representative for the landlord and not in his own right and who had not received notice that he was to be a named party at a hearing where an award could be made against him and who was unable to prepare and present a defence on his own behalf. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The material clearly showed the appellant received notice that he was named as a party and in fact was the only party named as landlord. An itemized list of the damages claimed was attached to the notice. There was nothing to indicate he was unable to prepare and present a defence. 2)There was no error of law. The definition contained in s.2(d)(ii) was considered in Lachance v. Auzano Asset which held s.2(d)(ii) was determinative of the issue. The Act is intended to provide an informal and efficient procedure for determining landlord and tenant disputes. This goal is facilitated by permitting such individuals as property managers to assume the role and status of landlords (Lachance).
column3: This was an appeal from a Deputy Rentalsman ordering the landlord to pay the sum of $3,414 to the respondent. The appellant was not party to the hearing in his own name but in his capacity as representative of the landlord and therefore had no responsibility for the financial obligations of the tenant. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The material received from the Rentalsmans clearly showed that the appellant received notice that he was named as a party. The material received clearly showed the appellant was named by a party and that the respondent was the only party named as landlord. There was nothing to indicate that the applicant was unable to prepare and present a defence on his own behalf. 2)There was no error of law by the Rentalman. The respondent was not liable for damages to the appellant.

column23: This was an appeal from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman ordering the landlord, Bradley Calvin Dafoe/Formula 1 Real Estate Service to pay the sum of $3,414.50 to the respondent. The appellant was not party to the hearing in his own name but in his capacity as representative of the landlord and therefore had no responsibility for the financial obligations of his landlord. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)There was no error of law by the deputy landlord. The material received clearly showed that the appellant received notice that he was named as a party. In fact, Formula 1 is the only party named as landlord. There was no mention of the appellant's authorized agent. 2)The appellant was unable to prepare and present a defence on his own behalf.

AND- THIS APPEAL IS BROUGHT to have determined the following question respecting the Jurisdiction of the Rentalsman:
1. To impose an award on the appellant whose [sic] was acting not in his own right but as a representative for a landlord. 2. To impose an award on an appellant who had not received notice that he was to be a named party at a hearing where an award could be made against him. 3. To impose an award against an appellant who was unable to prepare and present a defence on his own behalf. [4] The material received from the Rentalsman clearly shows that the appellant received notice that he was named as a party. Furthermore, there is nothing to indicate that the appellant was unable to prepare and present a defence on his own behalf. [12] In the result, there is no error of law by the Deputy Rentalsman. The appeal is therefore dismissed.

column2: The applicant sought a declaration that the charges against her could not constitute professional misconduct without contravening the Charter and Saskatchewan Human Rights Code; an order of prohibition to prevent the SAPLN discipline committee or Association from hearing the charges; a declaration that the charges are res judicata; an order for particulars; costs. HELD: The application was dismissed in its entirety with taxed costs to SAPLN.  1)No order for further particulars was made at this time. The Hearing Notice particularizes the factual allegations and is specific as to time and their nature. 2)The only matter previously considered by the discipline committee dealt with whether there was any professional misconduct established arising out of criminal convictions for illegal picketing prior to the applicant becoming a member of SALPN. 3)The Act provides an adequate alternate remedy, which should be pursued. There were no special circumstances upon which the court could exercise its discretion to determine the merits of this application or to provide the relief sought.
column3: The applicant was charged with professional misconduct contrary to s. 24 of The Licensed Practical Nurses Act. He also demonstrated outside Planned Parenthood. He carried signs that displayed actions that were harmful to the public or members; and/or tended to harm the profession; and, breached the Act or the bylaws, including the Code of Ethics. HELD: The application was granted. The court found that the applicant was guilty of professional misconduct. The Court ordered that the charges be res judicata and that costs be served. The application for particulars was granted and the court ordered that costs of the application be paid in full. The applicant sought a writ of prohibition to prohibit the discipline committee from proceeding with the hearing into his conduct on the grounds that whatever occurred while he was picketing Planned Parenthood amounts to professional misconduct within the meaning of the Act. The facts were admitted as admitted as admitting the applicant. The appeal against the prohibition was dismissed. The Appeal Court found that there was no evidence that the appellant had professional misconduct and that the Court should not entertain the application where there was a convenient alternative remedy provided in the Act which provided for an elaborate complaints investigation and discipline process.

He also displayed signs that displayed actions that were harmful to the public or members; tended to harm the profession; and caused harm to the reputation of the profession. HELD: The application was granted. The court found that the applicant's right of appeal to the senate committee constituted an adequate alternative remedy and even better remedy than recourse to the courts by way of prerogative writs. Several factors should have been taken into consideration, among which the procedure on appeal, the composition of the Senate committee, its powers and the manner in which they were exercised were not exercised by a body which was not a professional court of appeal and was not bound to act exactly as one nor likely to do so. The Court found that Harelkin v. University of Regina established the doctrine of the 'adequate alternative remedy' as a bar to judicial review. The facts alleged in the Notice of Hearing were admitted by the applicant. They were the following: 1) A declaration that the charges were res judicata; 2) A request for particulars; 3) Costs.  4) The court ordered the application for particulars.

column2: FIAT: The respondent brings an application for a court order requiring Reginald Sauer to withdraw as solicitor for the petitioner. The basis of the application is that the parties participated in a Collaborative Law process whereby it is alleged by the respondent that confidential information was shared. The respondent also relies on the provisions of the collaborative law agreement signed by the parties. HELD: 1) The conflict in the facts was apparent and was not resolved by additional evidence. 2) Mr. Sauer agreed to withdraw as counsel so the parties may proceed to pre-trial and a trial without the necessity of a viva voce hearing.
column3: FIAT. The applicant brings an application for a court order requiring Reginald Sauer to withdraw as solicitor for the respondent. The parties participated in a collaborative law process whereby it is alleged that confidential information was shared. The only way to resolve the conflicts would be by holding a viva voce hearing. The respondent acknowledges that the only way is by holding the viva vce hearing, which the parties have not agreed to. On that basis, the parties may proceed to pre-trial and a trial if necessary. HELD: The application for the court order is granted. The court agrees to withdraw from the position of solicitor for Nadine Therrien. The solicitor agrees to resign as counsel so the parties can proceed to a pre- trial and a Trial if necessary on the issues. 1) The court accepts that the parties participated as a collaborative process. The evidence did not resolve the conflict. The petitioner acknowledges that it would be a conflict of interest for the solicitor to continue to act as her lawyer at trial. On the basis, Mr. Sauer agrees to withdrawal as counsel. The Court agrees that the best way to deal with the conflicts is by having a viv voce Hearing. The agreement is that the court may proceed at a pre trial and trial if the issues are resolved. 2) The parties have agreed to withdraw the solicitor as counsel, so the court can proceed with a trial. The decision to withdraw is made by the parties. 3) The Court accepts that Mr.Sauer agrees that it is the only solution to resolve conflicts. The viva- voce process did not solve the conflicts. On this basis, he agrees to retire as counsel and the parties are proceeding to a trial on the issue.

column2: At the time of the deceased's death, she held a bank account jointly with her daughter. Although the signature card signed when the account was opened could not be found for the hearing, the probate court relied on the evidence of the bank representative (who testified that she had the card when she closed the account and she was 100% sure that the account was a joint account and who was able to present to the court the form of the applicable account agreement) in determining that the monies in the joint account belonged to the daughter.  It was also found, on a strong balance of probabilities, that the deceased intended to make an inter vivos gift to her daughter and, alternatively, that the evidence rebutted any presumption of resulting trust in favour of the deceased or her estate. Another of the deceased's children appealed. Appeal dismissed; the probate court judge did not misapprehend the evidence, lack an evidentiary basis for his findings, rely upon incorrect legal principles or fail to apply or misapply the law.
column3: At issue in this appeal was the ownership of monies in a joint bank account in the names of the deceased and her children. The respondent and the respondents were children of the late Mrs. Scott. The probate court judge determined that the monies were in the joint account and placed it in an investment certificate in the sole name of Ms. Akerley rather than her own name or in their joint names. The interest was to be paid to the joint bank and, on maturity, Ms.Akerley was entitled to the funds. The court dismissed the appeal. The standard of review applicable for all factual conclusions made by the trial judge is palpable and overriding error. The same standard applies to questions of mixed law and fact, unless question of law is readily extricable when the standard will be that of correctness. The appellant challenges the judge's findings of fact based on the credibility of witnesses. HELD: Appeal dismissed. The trial judge erred in making a determination when the evidence was not sufficient for him to do so and based only on speculation and hearsay rather than as required in law. The Court found that the standard of reviewing applicable for the factual conclusions he made was palpable and overruled incorrect legal principles. The Standard of review applied for all facts made by him was palpable, overriding error and the same standard applied to questions where the ownership is in dispute. The judge focussed on assessing the evidence available to the court and applying the appropriate legal principles in order to determine the ownership. The question of ownership is not properly handled by the Probate Court and further investigation is required.
column4: Held: Appeal dismissed per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; The standard of review applicable for all factual conclusions made by the trial judge is palpable and overriding error. Having reviewed his decision, the written arguments provided by the parties and their oral submissions, I cannot say that the judge misapprehended the evidence, lacked an evidentiary basis for his findings, relied upon incorrect legal principles, or failed to apply or misapplied the law. [18] I would dismiss the appeal, and order the appellant to pay costs of $500 to Ms. Gregoire.

The evidence was such that there was no presumption of resulting trust in favour of the estate. 3)The probate judge erred in making a determination when the evidence was not sufficient for him to do so, and based only on speculation and hearsay rather than as required in law. 4)There were no grounds for appellate intervention in his decision regarding ownership of the joint account.

HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1) The court found that the judge misapprehended the evidence, lacked an evidentiary basis for his findings, relied upon incorrect legal principles, or failed to apply or misapplied the law.  2) There was no grounds for appellate intervention in his decision regarding ownership of the joint account.

column22: At the time of the deceased's death, she held a bank account jointly with her daughter. Although the signature card signed when the account was opened could not be found for the hearing, the probate court relied on the evidence of the bank representative (who testified that she had the card when she closed the account and she was 100% sure that the account was a joint account and who was able to present to the court the form of the applicable account agreement) in determining that the monies in the joint account belonged to the daughter.  It was also found, on a strong balance of probabilities, that the deceased intended to make an inter vivos gift to her daughter and, alternatively, that the evidence rebutted any presumption of resulting trust in favour of the deceased or her estate. Another of the deceased's children appealed. Appeal dismissed; the probate court judge did not misapprehend the evidence, lack an evidentiary basis for his findings, rely upon incorrect legal principles or fail to apply or misapply the law.
column23: At issue in this appeal is the ownership of monies in a joint bank account in the names of the late Mrs. and Jeanne Akerley. At the time of her passing, over $50,000 was held on deposit in that account. The appellant and the respondents were children of the deceased. All parties were self-represented on the appeal. The probate court judge made a determination when the evidence was not sufficient for him to do so and based only on speculation and hearsay rather than as required in law. The evidence rebutted any presumption of a resulting trust in favour of the estate. Appeal dismissed. The standard of review applicable for all factual conclusions made by the trial judge is palpable and overriding error. The same standard applies to questions of mixed law and fact, unless question of law is readily extricable when the standard will be that of correctness.

column2: The two plaintiffs were forced to jump from the window of their third-floor apartment after a fire erupted in the building. The fire alarm system was not functioning and, despite being aware of previous problems with the 25-year-old system, the defendant had never maintained or inspected it; the self-closing hallway fire doors were continually in an open position; the battery-operated fire alarm in the plaintiffs' apartment was not functioning; and the plaintiffs were unaware of whether their smoke detector was wired into the building or was their responsibility. The male plaintiff suffered serious fractures to both ankles and a fractured fibula. He underwent four surgeries, was non-weight bearing for three months and was unable to run or engage in various sports. Although he had returned to work as a production worker, his condition would continue to deteriorate due to post-traumatic arthritis, most likely resulting in a future ankle fusion. The female plaintiff suffered a pelvic ring injury with bilateral pelvic and sacral fractures, a fractured elbow and a broken rib. She underwent surgery on her pelvis, was unable to look after her own hygiene for five months and developed bursitis in the hip. She continued to experience pain in the tailbone with extensive sitting and in the elbow with extension of the arm, had a permanent loss of elbow extension and walked with a limp. The worsening of her pre-existing anxiety and depression led to the diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder. The landlord argued that the plaintiffs' injuries had not been caused by any of its actions. Male plaintiff awarded the sum of $75,000 for general damages, $15,000 for past and future loss of valuable services and $45,000 for loss of earning capacity; female plaintiff awarded the sum of $55,000 for general damages, $35,000 for past and future loss of valuable services and $75,000 for future loss of income. Although there was no evidence that the defendant was responsible for the fire, its conduct created an unreasonable risk of harm in the event of a fire. Without evidence as to how much time the plaintiffs would have had to escape down the stairwell or how long they would have had to wait for the fire department had the smoke or fire alarms activated, the 'material contribution' test was applied to the causation issue. When the plaintiffs first awoke, the fire had already worked its way up through the attic hatch to the roof, where the flames in the eaves were visible to the plaintiffs. Smoke and fire were able to flow freely through the adjacent stairwell as a result of the fire door being left open, and the failure of the smoke detectors and fire alarms allowed the smoke and fire to progress before being detected by the plaintiffs. The female plaintiff was found to have no meaningful residual earning capacity due to the combination of her physical and psychological injuries.
column3: The plaintiff and her tenant escaped a three-storey apartment building fire by jumping from the top floor. The plaintiff's apartment was located on the third floor. It was a wooden structure with vinyl siding on the exterior and asphalt roof. The ceiling was blackened and the attic was covered in smoke. The fire alarm system was not working at the time of the fire. The tenant's son was asleep in the living room when the fire broke out. The smoke detector in the building was not functioning at the moment of the blaze. The tenants were unable to escape the building due to the smoke detector malfunctioning. The battery operated smoke alarm in the plaintiff's building did not function at the scene of the incident. The defendant's conduct created an unreasonable risk of harm in the event of a fire.
column4: [37] Although there is no evidence the defendant was responsible for the fire, I find the defendant’s conduct created an unreasonable risk of harm in the event of a fire. There were problems with the fire alarm system not functioning prior to the fire which was known to the defendant’s supervisor; the defendant did not maintain, test, or inspect at all, its fire alarm system that was in excess of 25 years old at the time of the fire; the self-closing hallway “fire doors” on the third floor were continually in an open position and the north hallway door adjacent to the plaintiff’s apartment, which was open at the time of the fire, had a broken self-closing latch at the time of the fire; the battery operated smoke alarm in the plaintiff’s apartment did not function at the time of the fire. Smoke and fire were able to freely flow to the north stairwell as a result of the fire door being open at the time. [63] Under the circumstances of this case, I award general damages in the amount of $75,000.00. [72] Recognizing that in cases of this nature valuation of impairment of earning capacity is somewhat speculative, I award the sum of $45,000.00. Recognizing that his capacity to perform pre-accident duties at home will be impaired to a limited extent, I will allow the sum of $15,000.00 for past and future loss of valuable services. [96] I assess Ms. Leslie’s general damages in the amount of $55,000.00. [103] Based on the evidence I find Ms. Leslie has no meaningful residual earning capacity. Under the circumstance, I award the sum of $75,000.00 for loss of future income. [105] The plaintiffs shall recover pre-judgment interests and costs.
