column8: The plaintiff and her tenant escaped a three-storey apartment building fire by jumping from the top floor. The plaintiff's apartment was located on the third floor and was accessed by way of a common hallway with two apartments on each side. The tenant's residence was completely burned out and the ceiling was blackened. The fire alarm system was not working at the time of the fire. The tenants were unable to escape the building due to the smoke alarms not working. Although there was no evidence the defendant was responsible for the fire, the defendant's conduct created an unreasonable risk of harm in the event of a fire. There were problems with the system which were known to the supervisor; the fire alarm was not functioning at the location where the fire started; the self-closing hallway doors were continually in an open position and the north hallway door was locked. The battery operated smoke alarm in the plaintiff's building did not function at the moment of the blaze. The plaintiffs were uninformed as to whether the smoke detector formed part of the Firearm System or was self-contained and the tenants were not advised by the defendant that the doors were to be kept in closed position. The smoke detector in the tenant's apartment did not operate when pulled by him and there were problems in the system. The Fire Chief was required to determine whether the plaintiffs, on balance of probabilities, suffered damages.

column13: HELD: The plaintiff was awarded damages for injuries suffered when she jumped from the top floor of a three-storey apartment building. Liability and damages were at issue in this case. The fire alarm system was not functioning at the time of the fire. There were problems with the fire alarm systems not functioning prior to the fire which was known to the supervisor; the defendant did not maintain, test, inspect, or inspect its fire engine system that was in excess of 25 years old; the self-closing hallway doors on the third floor were continually in an open position and the north hallway door adjacent to the plaintiff's apartment had a broken self-closure latch. The battery operated smoke alarm in the plaintiff’s apartment did not function at the incident. The plaintiff suffered serious injuries from the fall. The defendant was also subject to statutory obligations. The common law duty of care arises from the proximity of the relationship between landlord and tenants of its multi-unit residential building. In this case the defendant owed duty of caring to the plaintiffs to ensure they were reasonably safe from injury while residing in the premises. In my view this would reasonably include the installation and maintenance of an operational fire alarm.

column2: An application for an interim injunction restraining the Regina Exhibition Association (REAL) from interfering with GCB's enjoyment of certain leasehold premises in the Jubilee Building and from entering into any lease with Regina Central Bingo (RCBA) and preventing the operation of a bingo hall by RCBA within Exhibition Park except as sub-tenant of GCB. The original five year lease for use of the Jubilee Building as a bingo hall between Fundraising td. and REAL was assigned to GCB with REAL's written consent. GCB further sublet the building without REAL's consent or knowledge. Written notice of renewal was not sent to REAL. The basis of GCB's application was estoppel on the basis that REAL entered negotiations regarding a relocation of the bingo hall and then began to deal directly with CGB's sub-tenant after the renewal date had passed. HELD: The application was dismissed. Costs in the cause. 1)There was no evidence that Fundraisers, the original party to the lease, attempted to exercise the option to renew. 2)GCB did not have a strong prima facie case on the merits. It appeared that there were no negotiations between GCB and REAL. 3)There would not be irreparable harm. Under the current arrangements, the bingo would be operated by RCBA. If successful at trial the damages to GCB can be easily calculated based on the time it was unable to occupy the premises. 4)On balance GCB failed to satisfy the burden of proof that the inconvenience it will suffer by the refusal of the injunction will be greater than that suffered by REAL if granted.
column3: The plaintiff sought an injunction restraining the defendant from entering into any leasehold lease with the plaintiff and preventing the defendant, the plaintiff from permitting the operation of a bingo hall in the Jubilee Building. The defendant sought an interlocutory injunction restraining it from permitting a bingo hall in its premises except as a subtenant. The plaintiff had entered into written agreements with the defendant for the day to day operation of the bingo halls, including a further sub-lease by the defendant to RCBA for the same space. The parties met once to discuss the relocation of the venue but there was no sign that the parties had discussed the future of the facility. The applicant entered into a written agreement with the respondent for the purpose of the day-to-day operation of bingo facilities but there had never been any indication that the applicant wanted to renew the lease. The respondent failed to satisfy the burden of proof that the plaintiff's inconvenience was greater than that of the defendant if it was declined. The court dismissed the application for an inter-locutory injunctive injunction. The sublease contains a provision whereby GCB could have compelled the plaintiff to renew a lease but there is no indication it acted in any way to exercise that right. On the balance of convenience and convenience the plaintiff would suffer if the injunction was granted, the defendant's interests must receive the same consideration as the plaintiff’s.

column7: An application for an interim injunction restraining the Regina Exhibition Association (REAL) from interfering with GCB's enjoyment of certain leasehold premises in the Jubilee Building and from entering into any lease with Regina Central Bingo (RCBA) and preventing the operation of a bingo hall by RCBA within Exhibition Park except as sub-tenant of GCB. The original five year lease for use of the Jubilee Building as a bingo hall between Fundraising td. and REAL was assigned to GCB with REAL's written consent. GCB further sublet the building without REAL's consent or knowledge. Written notice of renewal was not sent to REAL. The basis of GCB's application was estoppel on the basis that REAL entered negotiations regarding a relocation of the bingo hall and then began to deal directly with CGB's sub-tenant after the renewal date had passed. HELD: The application was dismissed. Costs in the cause. 1)There was no evidence that Fundraisers, the original party to the lease, attempted to exercise the option to renew. 2)GCB did not have a strong prima facie case on the merits. It appeared that there were no negotiations between GCB and REAL. 3)There would not be irreparable harm. Under the current arrangements, the bingo would be operated by RCBA. If successful at trial the damages to GCB can be easily calculated based on the time it was unable to occupy the premises. 4)On balance GCB failed to satisfy the burden of proof that the inconvenience it will suffer by the refusal of the injunction will be greater than that suffered by REAL if granted.
column8: The plaintiff sought an interim injunction restraining the defendant from entering into any leasehold lease with the plaintiff and preventing the defendant, through the plaintiff, from permitting the operation of a bingo hall by the defendant in the Jubilee Building as a tenant. The defendant sought an interlocutory injunction preventing the plaintiff from entering any lease with either the plaintiff or the defendant except as a subtenant. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The plaintiff had failed to satisfy the burden of proof that the plaintiff's inconvenience was greater than that of the defendant's if it was declined. 2)The defendant had undertaken a new course of conduct for bingo at the Exhibition Park. There was no promise on the part of REAL to follow up on these discussions nor was there any discussion about waiving any requirements with respect to its exercising the option to renew either through the defendant or directly.  3)On the balance of convenience the plaintiff would suffer if the injunction was granted and the defendant would sustain if it were refused. 4)The applicant failed to show that the inconveniences it will suffer by the refusal of the injunction were greater than the ones suffered by the plaintiff if it is declined. 5)The court was not satisfied on the basis of Mullin's affidavit that GCB had a strong prima facie case on the merits.

column2: Associates, which held purchase money security interests pursuant to its 1997 leases, applied under s.63 of the Personal Property Security Act for an order declaring the priority of competing security interests held by Associates and Humboldt Flour Mills in two reefer trailers. Humboldt's security interests were acquired pursuant to a security agreement granted in 1996 on present and after acquired property as amended in 1998 to specifically include the trailers. It also applied for an order giving directions respecting the exercise of the rights of the secured party with the prior interest. At issue is what is meant by 'possession' in s.34(2)(a) and when Lake Air obtained possession or constructive possession of the trailers. HELD: The application was allowed with costs from Humboldt.  1)The parties filed an agreed statement of facts and focused on the priority issue as if the application had been brought under s.66. 2)'Constructive possession' means possession of the collateral by 'another person at the request of the debtor' as set out in s.34(2)(a). What constitutes 'possession' of collateral by the debtor within s.34(2)(a) was in dispute. Unless the property qualifies as 'collateral' a person cannot possess it as a 'debtor' within the meaning of the priority section. 3)The case law in Saskatchewan has interpreted 'possession' to constitute more than mere physical possession. Sections 22 and 34(2) of the new Act are essentially unchanged except for the addition of the constructive possession. S.22(2) restricts the scope of constructive possession somewhat but it applies only to s.22 not to s.34. 4)A person is not in constructive possession of collateral within s.34(2)(a) unless that person is a 'debtor' as defined, unless the collateral is 'collateral' as defined and unless another person 'obtained physical possession of the colateral at the request of that debtor'. 5)The first term of each lease agreement contained an acknowledgement by Lake Air that the trailer was delivered by Associates at the date and location set out in the lease. Such a clause is inconsistent with Lake Air having actual or constructive possession at an earlier date. Lake Air did not have constructive possession prior to December 1997 through either Bell or Mid-Canada. Neither was in possession of the trailers at the request of Lake Air.  6)The protection the Act gives to purchase-money security holders should be interpreted broadly. To deny Associates priority over Humboldt would provide Humboldt with an unmerited windfall at the sole expense of Associates who gave full value for the purchase-money security interest it obtained from Lake Air.
column3: HELD: The application was allowed. The court found that the respondent was not in possession of the two trailers but that it had constructive possession of them. The issue was what was meant by the term 'possession' in s. 34(2)(a) and when, in the circumstances of this case, Lake Air obtained possession orconstructive possession of these trailers within the meaning of s. 33(2). The court ordered that the security interests in the trailers had priority to Humboldt's security interests. The respondent did not have possession prior to December 22, 1997. The applicant could not rely on s.34(2) for priority because its purchase money security interests were not perfected within fifteen days of that date as required by the section. The Court found that Lake Air had actual or constructive possession prior thereto.

[1] Associates applies under s. 63 of The Personal
Property Security Act, 1993 for an order declaring the
priority of competing security interests held by Associates
and Humboldt in two reefer trailers. The Issue [5] The issue to be determined is what is meant by the
term "possession" in s. 34(2)(a) and when, in the

constructive possession of the trailers within the meaning of

column8: Humboldt applied for an order declaring the priority of competing security interests held by Associates and Humboldts in two reefer trailers. The respondent argued that the security interests were acquired pursuant to its leases of the trailers to Lake Air in May 1996 on present and after acquired property as amended in January 1998 to specifically include the trailers. Associates denied that it had actual or constructive possession of the trailer and asserted that Lake Air had 'constructive possession' of them at an earlier date. HELD: The application was allowed and the respondent was ordered that its purchase-money security interests in the two trailers had priority to the respondent's security interests. The issue to be determined was what is meant by the term 'possession' in the act and when, in the circumstances of this case, Lake Air obtained possession orconstructive control of these trailers within the meaning of s. 34(2)(a). The respondent did not have constructive possession prior to December 22, 1997, through either GJ Bell or Mid-Canada.  1)The respondent was granted a security interest by Lake Air pursuant to a security agreement granted to it in May 1997. 2)It is obvious that the trailers were not in the physical possession of Lake Air until it agreed, on November 2, 1989, to accept the debt. The first term of each lease agreement contained an acknowledgement by the respondent that the respective trailers were delivered to it by Associates at the location and on the date set out in the lease. Such a clause was inconsistent with the submission that Lake had actual possession at an early date.  3)The application of Associates was allowed. It is ordered that the parties had prior verbal agreement.

column13: Humboldt applied for an order declaring the priority of competing security interests held by Associates in two reefer trailers pursuant to s. 63 of the Personal Property Security Act. The parties filed an agreed statement of facts and focussed their submissions solely on the priority issue as if the application had been brought under s. 66. The application was allowed and the respondent was ordered that its purchase-money security interests in the two trailers had priority over those of the secured party with the prior interest. The issue to be determined is what is meant by the term 'possession' in s. 34(2)(a) and when, in the circumstances of this case, Lake Air obtained possession orconstructive possession of the trailers within the meaning of s.34(2). Humboldts did not become debtor in possession until December 22, 1997, through either GJ Bell or Mid-Canada. The respondent was entitled to its costs from the University of Regina. The court concluded that the application of Associates was allowed. The terms of the agreement were not contained in either s. 21 or s.33(1) of the previous Act. There was no dispute that the 15-day period in section 22 begins to run from the date the lessee obtained possession as lessee and not the date that the the prior party became buyer of the goods.

HELD: The application was allowed with costs from Humboldt.  1)The parties filed an agreed statement of facts and focused on the priority issue as if the application had been brought under s.66. 2)'Constructive possession' means possession of the collateral by 'another person at the request of the debtor' as set out in s.34(2)(a). What constitutes 'possession' of collateral by the debtor within s.34(2)(a) was in dispute. Unless the property qualifies as 'collateral' a person cannot possess it as a 'debtor' within the meaning of the priority section. 3)The case law in Saskatchewan has interpreted 'possession' to constitute more than mere physical possession. Sections 22 and 34(2) of the new Act are essentially unchanged except for the addition of the constructive possession. S.22(2) restricts the scope of constructive possession somewhat but it applies only to s.22 not to s.34. 4)A person is not in constructive possession of collateral within s.34(2)(a) unless that person is a 'debtor' as defined, unless the collateral is 'collateral' as defined and unless another person 'obtained physical possession of the colateral at the request of that debtor'. 5)The first term of each lease agreement contained an acknowledgement by Lake Air that the trailer was delivered by Associates at the date and location set out in the lease. Such a clause is inconsistent with Lake Air having actual or constructive possession at an earlier date. Lake Air did not have constructive possession prior to December 1997 through either Bell or Mid-Canada. Neither was in possession of the trailers at the request of Lake Air.  6)The protection the Act gives to purchase-money security holders should be interpreted broadly. To deny Associates priority over Humboldt would provide Humboldt with an unmerited windfall at the sole expense of Associates who gave full value for the purchase-money security interest it obtained from Lake Air.
column23: The respondent applied for an order declaring the priority of competing security interests held by the respondentand Humboldt in two reefer trailers. HELD: The application was allowed. It was ordered that its purchase-money security interests in the two trailers had priority over those of the respondent. The issue to be determined was what is meant by the term 'possession' in s. 34(2)(a) and when, in thecircumstances of this case, Lake Air obtained possession orconstructive possession of the trailers within the meaning of the priority section. The respondent did not have actual or constructive possession prior to December 22, 1997, through either GJ Bell or Mid-Canada.  1)The respondent's security interests were acquired pursuant to its security agreement granted to it by Lake Air in May 1996 on present and after acquired property as amended in January 1998 to specifically include the trailers. 2)It was not clear that the respondent was a debtor or debtor prior to that date. 3)Although each of these cases were decided under the former Act, sections 22 and 34(1) of the new Act are essentially unchanged except for the addition of the concept of constructive possession which I will discuss later. It is not applicable to the type of priority dispute that arises in this case.

column27: Humboldt applied for an order declaring the priority of competing security interests held by Associates in two reefer trailers pursuant to s. 63 of the Personal Property Security Act. The parties filed an agreed statement of facts and focussed their submissions solely on the priority issue as if the application had been brought under s. 66. The application was allowed and the respondent was ordered that its purchase-money security interests in the two trailers had priority over those of the secured party with the prior interest. The issue to be determined is what is meant by the term 'possession' in s. 34(2)(a) and when, in the circumstances of this case, Lake Air obtained possession orconstructive possession of the trailers within the meaning of s.34(2). Humboldts did not become debtor in possession until December 22, 1997, through either GJ Bell or Mid-Canada. The respondent was entitled to its costs from the University of Regina. The court concluded that the application of Associates was allowed. The terms of the agreement were not contained in either s. 21 or s.33(1) of the previous Act. There was no dispute that the 15-day period in section 22 begins to run from the date the lessee obtained possession as lessee and not the date that the the prior party became buyer of the goods.

column2: The accused was charged with first degree murder. Prior to jury selection, he applied for a stay of proceedings, alleging that there had been a breach of his right to a fair trial due to negative pre-trial publicity. Dismissing the application, that the application was premature. However, the accused would be permitted to challenge potential jurors for cause due to the highly prejudicial and inflammatory pre-trial media reports.
column3: The accused was charged with murder. He did not have the benefit of preliminary inquiry as result of the Crown preferring the indictment against him. There is no evidence before the Court on the merits of the case as the trial has yet to begin. The accused brings this application for a stay of proceedings alleging that his rights under s.11(d) and s. 11(f) of the Charter have been infringed due to the pre-trial publicity generated by this case. HELD: The application for stay of proceeding was dismissed. 1)The pre- trial publicity had prejudiced the accused's right to be tried by an impartial jury of his peers. 2)The Court was satisfied that the pre trial publicity, filled as it was with prejudicial and inflammatory information, had not affected the accused on the effect of pre-sentence publicity. 3)The court was satisfied the pre pre-judgment publicity had not caused a reasonable apprehension of bias.
column4: J. The accused, Dany Kane, is charged with murder in the first degree. Accordingly the application for a stay of proceedings is dismissed.

column2: FIAT. The mother applied to vary the terms of the 1999 child support order under which she was to pay $400 per month composed of $334 for regular support plus $66 for s.7 medical and extraordinary expenses for their three children based on an imputed annual income of $18,000. She sought to cancel arrears of $3,800 on the basis she will overpay if child support had been calculated in accordance with the Federal Child Support Guidelines on the basis of her actual income for 1999 and 2000. She also sought to reduce child support to $17 per month based on a projected income of $7,000. HELD: 1)One-half of the arrears were cancelled. The mother must accept responsibility in part for allowing arrears to accumulate over the 2 years. 2)The mother was to pay $250 per month based on an imputed income of $15,000. She was capable of contributing more than $17 per month. Her share of s.7 expenses was reduced to $50 per month. Neither filed current information. 3)Costs would have been ordered if the mother had been more reasonable in her submission for variation.
column3: FIAT. The applicant mother applied to vary the terms of a child support order made against her on March 1, 1999. It provided that she pay $400 per month support for the three children of the marriage, namely Brady, Jessica, Jessica and Kory. The order was made in connection with a previous variation application brought by the applicant to vary former $450 per month child support. HELD: The application was granted. The court ordered the cancellation of arrears of $1,900 and ordered that the ongoing child support be increased to $17 per month.
column4: [1] The applicant mother applies to vary the terms of the child support order made against her on March 1, 1999. She also seeks a variation of the ongoing child support to $17.00 per month, being the Guideline amount based on her projected annual income for 2001 of just over $7,000. I order the cancellation of arrears of $1,900, being one-half of the total of $3,800 in arrears. I fix basic child support for the three children under the Guidelines at $250.00 per month based on an imputed annual income of $15,000. I reduce the applicant\'s share of the s. 7 expenses to $50.00 per month for total ongoing child support of $300.00 per month commencing April 1, 2001.

column2: The father was unemployed by reason of health problems and was in arrears on the December 13, 2002 child support order for $454 per month. He was seeking damages against the federal government for alleged abuses suffered while attending an Indian Residential School. The mother sought to attach the possible damage award for child support. HELD: The first $50,000 of any settlement proceeds, after payment of reasonable solicitor fees and disbursements, shall be paid into Court by his counsel. The Court agreed with the conclusion in Anderson that an order can be made with respect to damage awards even though, at the moment of the order, there is only a cause of action in existence and no precise amount of damages are known. There was no question that a cause of action or chose in action is property and thus the subject of an order under the Family Maintenance Act s.8. It is of no consequence that the order may be in another form such as money. To adopt any different analysis would be to unnecessarily limit the remedial application of s.8. Given the overarching purpose to ensure property is not wasted, thus impairing or defeating a claim under the FMA, it was logical orders can be made by the Court that are ancillary or a natural incident of the primary order preserving the property. The mother was awarded costs of the application set at $350.
column3: The parties have three children aged four to eight years. The respondent is involved in a litigation against the Government of Canada regarding alleged abuse he allegedly suffered while attending an Indian Residential School. The parties have been unemployed for the most part. Arrears of child support are constantly accruing. The father is restrained from disposing of any money he has received or may receive in relation to the lawsuit without an order from the Court. HELD: 1) The respondent's counsel is required to report to the Court forthwith as to the potential for damage to the respondent's property. 2) The court concluded in Anderson that it was not necessary to find predilection or intention on the part of the respondent to waste assets in order to issue an order under s. 8. The threshold to be met in such an application was simply that the disposition or wasting of the asset would impair or defeat claim under the Act. 3) In the event the respondent receives damages from the Government he may well be his only significant asset and, more to the point, the only asset that can be used to meet the respondent’s outstanding and ever accruating child support obligations. 4) In Anderson, the section relied upon by the petitioner is s.7 of The Family Maintenance Act, 1997, S.S. 1997, c.F6.2 (the “Act”). Section 8(1) of the Act only authorizes restraining orders against those against whom claim under a certain Act may be made and therefore made no order vis-a-vis the respondent. The petitioner bases her application on the ground that if the respondent received damages from Canada that may well well be the only significant object that can reasonably become source of satisfying claim under this Act. The only asset to meet his outstanding and always accruation child support obligation is the one asset that could reasonably become a source of source of income for the respondent and society as a whole. The first $50,000.00 after payment of reasonable solicitor fees and disbursements shall be paid into Court so that the parties might speak to the distribution of same. It is further ordered that the respondent shall pay the settlement proceeds into Court in accordance with the foregoing.
column4: [2] Since the issuance of the order the respondent has been, for the most part, unemployed by reason of health problems and, as a result, arrears of child support are constantly accruing. (b) the Respondent, [M.E.H.], is hereby restrained from disposing of any money that he has received or may receive in relation to the lawsuit without further Order of the Court with the exception of paying any and all legal fees and disbursements plus taxes owing to his solicitors. [10] I must respectfully reject the respondent’s analysis and confirm that I am in full accord with the conclusion in Anderson that an order can be made with respect to damage awards even though, at the moment of the order, there is only a cause of action in existence and no precise amount of damages are known. [11] There is no question that a cause of action or chose in action is property and thus the subject of an order of s. 8 of the Act. [15] Accordingly, it is ordered that in the event the respondent receives a settlement in his law suit against the Government based on his claim of abuse suffered at the Indian Residential School, the first $50,000.00, after payment of reasonable solicitor fees and disbursements, shall be paid into Court so that the parties might speak to the distribution of same. It is further ordered that the respondent’s counsel, the Merchant Law Group or any new counsel shall pay the settlement proceeds into Court, in accordance with the foregoing.

There was no question that a cause of action or chose in action is property and thus the subject of an order under the Family Maintenance Act s.8. It is of no consequence that the order may be in another form such as money. To adopt any different analysis would be to unnecessarily limit the remedial application of s.8. Given the overarching purpose to ensure property is not wasted, thus impairing or defeating a claim under the FMA, it was logical orders can be made by the Court that are ancillary or a natural incident of the primary order preserving the property. The mother was awarded costs of the application set at $350.

column2: The parties were married for twelve years; there were no children of the marriage. The husband was in the military; the wife was a cleaner on a military base when the parties met and she changed jobs at the husband's direction. She now stated that she was unable to return to work due to health problems, including irritable bowel syndrome, depression and obsessive compulsive disorder. Both parties accused the other of conduct which diminished matrimonial assets. The wife's mother had advanced the parties a considerable amount of money during the marriage, with the final advance being the subject of an IOU. The husband is to be responsible for the matrimonial debts, with the net proceeds from the sale of matrimonial home to be paid ratably to those creditors; the wife is to receive 35% of the husband's pension entitlement; husband to pay spousal support in the amount of $1,000 per month for a period of ten years with the order open to variation if the wife obtains a C.P.P. disability pension or becomes fit to work or if the husband retires from the military or makes a proposal or an assignment in bankruptcy which has the effect of requiring the wife to pay any of the matrimonial debts.
column3: The parties were married for more than one year and had no children. The respondent was receiving $1,600 monthly spousal support. The court found that the respondent was entitled to spousa for the duration of the marriage. The parties had lived separate and apart for more more than a year and there was no possibility of reconciliation. The petitioner was entitled $1.5 million in spousas for the period of cohabitation. The Court held that the petitioner was responsible for the payment of matrimonial debts. The issue was whether the usual equal division dictated by the Matrimonial Property Act would be unfair or unconscionable. The evidence did not support the claim that the parties were in a relationship. The husband was receiving spouso for the term of the agreement. The wife was receiving a spousarium for the purposes of the cohabitations. The amount of spousousa was reduced to $1 per month. The judge found that there was insufficient evidence to establish that the agreement was in any way binding. The agreement was not made to allow the judge to pick the outcome that he preferred from among various alternative dispositions.
column4: [36] It is appropriate to hold Mr. Bishop responsible for the payment of the matrimonial debts. [52] I award 35% of the pension entitlement to Ms. Bishop and 65% to Mr. Bishop, from February 1977 to the date of separation of June 29, 2003. 34. [70] I direct Mr. Bishop to pay to Ms. Bishop $1,000 per month in spousal support, commencing August 31, 2005, for a period of 10 years, up to and including July 31, 2015. The spousal support order will be open to variation if Ms. Bishop obtains a CPP disability pension or if Mr. Bishop retires from the Armed Forces. Similarly, if Ms. Bishop becomes fit to work, Mr. Bishop will be entitled to seek a variation. Finally, if Mr. Bishop makes an assignment in bankruptcy or a proposal under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, which has the effect of requiring Ms. Bishop to pay any of the matrimonial debts, she will be entitled to apply for a variation in spousal support to cover any amount she is required to pay.

column2: FIAT: The applicant school division asks for a vesting order regarding an un-subdivided parcel of land. The requested relief cannot be granted unless the court has authority to order that a subdivision of land be effected outside the requirements of The Planning and Development Act. HELD: 1) Even if this was a proper case for the making of a vesting order, there is a further difficulty presented by the fact that the applicant school division is asking the court to order that a subdivision be effected, as a pre-condition to the vesting order. Whether under the former legislation or the present, the court is not free to subvert the statutory requirements in the exercise of its authority to make vesting orders. The court reviewed the relevant caselaw. 2) While the court is precluded from directing the Registrar to effect a subdivision that is prohibited by the legislation, a resolution of the matter could be achieved if, for example, after adjudicating on all the rights and obligations at issue, the Court was prepared to direct that the pre-conditions to subdivision approval be met by a party to the proceedings. Once the proposed subdivision meets the required standards and is approved, then a vesting order can be made in the appropriate circumstances under the provisions of s. 6.5 of The Land Titles Conversion Facilitation Regulations, or under The Improvements Under Mistake of Title Act. The court reviewed the applicable caselaw. 3) The court requested that further written submissions be provided by the parties on the matter of directing a trial of the issues.
column3: FIAT. The applicant asks for a vesting order regarding a presently unsubdivided parcel of land owned by the respondent. The respondent argues that the provisions of the Planning and Development Act must, of necessity, be considered merged in conveyance. HELD: The appeal is allowed. 1) The respondent's claim is totally separate from the claim. The landowner has no title save to the extent that he initiated complaints about the livestock operations and the damages it was causing to his land. The proposed subdivision is in contravention of the Act, the regulations and the Zoning bylaw. 2) The applicant, the School Division, is asking the court to order subdivision of Parcel G as precondition to the vesting of the order. The application in question is tantamount to a judicially ordered partition of land to avoid the effect of legislation. The Court was obliged to prevent such wholesale frustration of the legislature's objects. 3) The original transaction between the School and the Flads was concluded in 1996, conditional on subdivision approval, which the Court was to continue until further order of the Court. The issue on appeal was whether the trial judge erred in holding that the appellant retained a legal interest in the farm site which could form the basis of registrable transfer under The Land Titles Act. The appeal was allowed.

The respondent is a bona fide purchaser with no notice of the Flads' interest and relying on the indefeasibility of his title. The issue arises in a rather complex fact situation. At the time of the purported reservation of title in favour of the respondent, no subdivision of agricultural land was permitted in respect of an area less than five acres. The person claiming to be the rightful owner of the interest had done nothing for 20 years, both parties to the transaction had died, and the action was between the executors of their respective estates. The original transaction appeared to have been concluded in an effort to avoid compliance with subdivision regulations, rather it was made in the mistaken belief that an already subdivided parcel was being transferred. Adjoining cottage owners had all built on lots one removed from the lot to which they had title. As the school was built directly adjacent to church (Parcel D), the confusion was shared by the church. The Flads were in occupation of proposed Parcel G, using the property as a residence and constructing corrals for use in their livestock operation. They failed to obtain development permits before making improvements to the site. The land was transferred to them by way of sale from Mr. Erker, who had purchased the property from the respondent in 1994. This decision was overturned on appeal at a full hearing at trial as opposed the summary fashion in which the order is requested. The appeal was allowed.

column2: The applicant is a doctor enrolled in the orthopaedic surgery residency training program at the University of Saskatchewan (University). He was suspended from the program since approximately March 2000. There have been a number of legal proceedings between the applicant and the University since then. An appeal committee of the University held that the applicant be allowed to resume his residency training on probationary terms. This decision has not been implemented. At issue is a College of Medicine policy governing students who are funded by third party organizations or governments. The applicant is such a student. His third party funding was depleted during the time he was suspended. The College of Medicine insists he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his program. The Lieutenant Governor requested that a judge of the Court of Queen's Bench perform her role as visitor in this matter. HELD: 1) The court found the College of Medicine has not been objectively reasonable in the exercise of its discretion to insist that the appeal committee decision will not be implemented until such time as the applicant obtains third party funding. The court found it did not properly or fairly apply the third party funding policy on the facts. 2) The applicant is entitled to relief. The appeal committee decision will be implemented by the College of Medicine if the following conditions are met. The applicant must enter into a written agreement with the College of Medicine whereby he agrees that the money he was paid while on suspension is prepayment for all of the services he will perform for the College of Medicine in the remainder of his residency, that he will not claim any salary or monetary benefits available to other medical residents pursuant to the PAIRS agreement, and he will indemnify the College of Medicine if it is required to make payments to him pursuant to the PAIRS agreement during the remainder of his residency program. Further, PAIRS will enter into an agreement with the College of Medicine waiving the financial terms of the PAIRS agreement with respect to the applicant for the duration of his residency. 3) The applicant will be responsible for paying tuition fees, administration fees, insurance fees and any other college fees payable by other medical residents but he will be granted a credit for the fees deducted by the College of Medicine during the time he was suspended.
column3: The applicant was an enrolled student at the University of Saskatchewan. He was suspended from the program in 1997. Since then, there have been a number of legal proceedings between the applicant and the University, both internally and externally. The College of Medicine insists that the applicant must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his residency program. The applicant has not yet exhausted his appeals within the internal laws of the University and there is no evidence that the College of Management has any say in the matter. HELD: The applicant's status was changed to suspension with pay pending the completion of the Investigative Committee reviews. The University insisted that the appellant must find another sponsor prior before being allowed back to his program. 1) The applicant had not yet concluded his appeals. The college insisted that he must find his third party sponsors prior to be allowed to return to his residency. 2) The College was in no position to waive the provisions of the collective agreement because it cannot unilaterally change the terms of the agreement. The fact that the respondent was such a student and for reasons which will be outlined hereafter, his third parties funding was depleted during the period he was suspended. The appeal committee recommended that the appeal committee recommend that the student be allowed back on probation. The university insisted that this decision was properly decided. 3) The respondent was not in any position to be a party to the appeal process. The respondent's third party funding was not depleted during his suspension. The Court of Queen's Bench determined that the petitioner should not have been dismissed prior to an investigation into the matters that led to him being placed on probation to begin with. The court found that the Crown had jurisdiction to determine disputes which were governed by the internal law, policies, and procedures of the university. The petitioner was entitled to seek the assistance of a judge of the Court of the Queen's Court. The judge was not to be interfered with. 4) The petitioner had not exhausted his appeal process within the past 5 years. The appellant was not a party in the appeal. The parties were largely agreed the applicant had exclusive jurisdiction to decide disputes which are governed by internal law and policies of the school. The Judge was to perform her role as visitor. The evidence of the appellant's failure to comply with the appeal panel decision was not established. The trial judge was to determine whether the petitioner had a right to appeal. 5) The court was to consider the appellant’s application to have the Court determine his jurisdiction. The issue was whether the court could exercise its jurisdiction to award damages.

That the appeal committee decision be implemented by the College of Medicine if the following conditions are satisfied:

column8: At issue in this matter is a College of Medicine policy governing students who are funded by third party organizations or governments. Dr. Pearlman was a student at the time he was suspended from the program. For reasons which will be outlined hereafter, his third party funding was depleted during the period of his suspension. The College insisted he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his program. HELD: The matter was referred to the Court of Queen’s Bench for review. The court was to perform its role as visitor in the matter. 1) The College of Physicians has a policy regarding supernumerary residents. It is not possible for the College to insist on the applicant obtaining new third party financing before he will be permitted to resume the residency program. 2) It is difficult to accept the College of Medical's concern that creating an exception in this case would somehow affect the integrity of the policy. The fact that the applicant had not yet exhausted his appeals within the internal laws of the University, and specifically to the Council of Student Appeals and Academic Matters, suggests that the jurisdiction is more original than traditional supervisory or appellate jurisdiction. 3) The applicant was a resident funded by the College. His third party sponsorship was depleted. The college insisted he was the only student who had been allowed to continue training without a salary during the time that he had been suspended. 4) It was not clear whether the College had any say in the decision to place the applicant on probation. 5) The evidence of the appeal committee did not show that the College was in any way influenced by the appellant’ s views on the subject matter. It was clear that systemic forces were at work beyond the control of the appellant. The appellant was such a student that for reasons which were outlined hereafter the College would have funded his education through to its conclusion. It would be difficult for the Court to decide whether the appellant should be allowed to return to the program on a probationary basis. The Court of Appeal was to exercise its jurisdiction and powers of the Court. 6) The Court was to determine the extent to which the appellant could exercise his jurisdiction.

column13: At issue in this matter is a College of Medicine policy governing students who are funded by third party organizations or governments. Dr. Pearlman was a student at the time he was suspended from the program. For reasons which will be outlined hereafter, his third party funding was depleted during the period of his suspension. The College insisted he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his program. HELD: The matter was referred to the Court of Queen’s Bench for review. A judge was appointed to perform her role as visitor in the matter. 1) The College of Physicians was at liberty to apply the policy as it has in the past. If an exception is made to the policy based on the unique facts in this case, this would not have precedential value that could affect the integrity of the policy in the future. 2) It is difficult to accept that creating an exception would somehow affect the credibility of the rule of law. It is not reasonable for the College to insist on a finding that a party sponsor has already obtained new funding. The court may exercise its jurisdiction and powers of the court if it wishes. 3) There is no dispute that general visitatorial jurisdiction extends not only to judging that the university satisfy standards which are fundamental to the administration of justice in every sphere but also to assessing the objective reasonableness of the exercise of discretion by those persons charged with administering the internal laws and policies of the university on the facts of any matter. The fact that the applicant chose to have resort to the courts on two occasions suggests that the jurisdiction is more original than traditional supervisory or appellate jurisdiction. 4) There are a number of cases in which the College was granted status to appear at the hearing and did so. The parties relied on the record developed in earlier proceedings.

He was suspended from the program since approximately March 2000. There have been a number of legal proceedings between the applicant and the University since then. An appeal committee of the University held that the applicant be allowed to resume his residency training on probationary terms. This decision has not been implemented. At issue is a College of Medicine policy governing students who are funded by third party organizations or governments. The applicant is such a student. His third party funding was depleted during the time he was suspended. The College of Medicine insists he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his program. The Lieutenant Governor requested that a judge of the Court of Queen's Bench perform her role as visitor in this matter. HELD: 1) The court found the College of Medicine has not been objectively reasonable in the exercise of its discretion to insist that the appeal committee decision will not be implemented until such time as the applicant obtains third party funding. The court found it did not properly or fairly apply the third party funding policy on the facts. 2) The applicant is entitled to relief. The appeal committee decision will be implemented by the College of Medicine if the following conditions are met. The applicant must enter into a written agreement with the College of Medicine whereby he agrees that the money he was paid while on suspension is prepayment for all of the services he will perform for the College of Medicine in the remainder of his residency, that he will not claim any salary or monetary benefits available to other medical residents pursuant to the PAIRS agreement, and he will indemnify the College of Medicine if it is required to make payments to him pursuant to the PAIRS agreement during the remainder of his residency program. Further, PAIRS will enter into an agreement with the College of Medicine waiving the financial terms of the PAIRS agreement with respect to the applicant for the duration of his residency. 3) The applicant will be responsible for paying tuition fees, administration fees, insurance fees and any other college fees payable by other medical residents but he will be granted a credit for the fees deducted by the College of Medicine during the time he was suspended.
column23: At issue in this matter is a College of Medicine policy governing students who are funded by third party organizations or governments. The university insists he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his residency program. HELD: The Court of Queen's Bench has requested that a judge perform her role as visitor in the matter. 1) The respondent was such a student that for reasons which will be outlined hereafter, his third party funding was depleted during the period he was suspended. 2) The College insisted he had not yet exhausted his appeals within the internal laws of the University, and it was not clear whether the funding agency had any say in the decision to place the respondent on probation. 3) At issue was whether it is reasonable for the College to insist on the appellant obtaining new third party financing before he will be permitted to resume the residency program on probationary terms. 4) The applicant was not the only student who had been suspended by the university. 5) The college insisted he was the only person who had ever been permitted to continue training without first obtaining external funding. The College denied this claim. 6) The evidence of the appeal committee did not support the College's position that the appellant was not entitled to be paid his salary during his suspension. 7) There was no evidence that the College was aware of the appellant's employment history prior to the suspension. 8) It was clear that systemic forces were at work beyond the control of Dr. Pearlman. Although the respondent was a student, he was not a party to any of the decisions made by the College.

Dr. Pearlman was such a student, and for reasons which will be outlined hereafter, his third party funding was depleted during the period of time he was suspended. The College of Medicine insists he must find a third party sponsor prior to being allowed to resume his program. The Honourable Dr. Lynda Haverstock has requested that a judge of the Court of Queen’s Bench perform her role as visitor in this matter. Conclusion [35] I find that the College of Medicine has not been objectively reasonable in the exercise of its discretion to insist that the appeal committee decision will not be implemented until such time as Dr. Pearlman obtains third party funding. It follows that I also find it did not properly or fairly apply the third party funding policy on the facts in this matter. 1. That the appeal committee decision be implemented by the College of Medicine if the following conditions are satisfied:

(a) That Dr. Pearlman enter into a written agreement with the College of Medicine in which he agrees:

(i) That the money he was paid while on suspension is prepayment for all of the services he will perform for the College of Medicine in the remainder of his residency program;



(ii) That he will not claim any salary or monetary benefits available to other medical residents pursuant to the PAIRS agreement; and

(iii) That he will indemnify the College of Medicine if, for any reason, it is required to make payments to him pursuant to the PAIRS agreement, or otherwise, during the remainder of his residency program. (b) That PAIRS enters into a written agreement with the College of Medicine waiving the financial terms of the PAIRS agreement with respect of Dr. Pearlman for the duration of his residency program. 2. That Dr. Pearlman will be responsible personally for paying tuition fees, administration fees, insurance fees, and any other college fees payable by other medical residents, but he will be granted a credit for those fees that were deducted by the College of Medicine during the time he was suspended with pay.

column2: A young person who suffered from considerable mental health issues and was in the permanent care of the Minister of Community Services applied to have the court exclude the public and the media from her court convened pre- sentencing conference. The purpose of the conference was to assemble various professionals from diverse fields to discuss the complex issues surrounding the young person and to provide recommendations to the court as to an appropriate sentence. Various of the professionals had expressed their concern as to their ability to participate in the conference if the media was present. Application for access by the media denied; order granted excluding the public and the media from the pre-sentencing conference; the benefits of an exclusion order outweigh the deleterious effect of restricting the public's right to freedom of expression and the freedom of the press. Although the court convened hearing is a public proceeding to which, prima facie, the open court principle applies, the attendance, cooperation and participation of the invitees to the conference (all professionals who were bound by laws, policies and agreements of confidentiality) was strictly voluntary and many, if not all, would be unable and unwilling to participate in a conference that was open to the public and the media. The administration of justice was furthered by the court obtaining the best possible information from those identified as best able to provide it so that recommendations flowing from the conference would lead to the best sentence for the youth. There were no alternative measures which would prevent or reduce the risk of non-participation by the professionals.
column3: The Crown and the youth were asked to give viva voce evidence in support of their application. The Crown sought a ruling from the Court as to whether the public, including the media, should be permitted to attend the pre-sentencing conference scheduled for December 11, 2006. The crown, the young person and the parent argued that the conference should not be open to the public and the media. The court took the position that this was a public proceeding to which they should have access. The Court found that the public's interest was at the forefront of the discussions and that the only thing that would compromise the public’s understanding of the justice system was the adequacy of government programs and support for the young offender. The public was also encouraged to participate in the discussions. The exclusion order was upheld. The appeal court found that it had discretion to exclude the public from the conference. The evidence before the court rebutted the open court principle and supported an order pursuant to s. 132 of the Act. The judge found that this case was a “public proceeding to be of interest to the court.” The court found the following: 1) the public was entitled to participate; 2) the court found there was a danger to the general public and that it would be in the public interest to exclude them; 3) the Court found the public had a right to participate and that public participation was not to be discouraged. The general rule of openness was not absolute. The courts were required to consider the interests of society in the protection and rehabilitation of young people involved in youth court proceedings. The only way to do so was to allow the public to participate. The issue was whether the media should be excluded from the presentencing event. The media were not to interfere with the proceedings.
column4: [1] Counsel on behalf of the media, the crown, the young person, T.C., and the legal parent/guardian of T.C., The Minister of Community Services seek a ruling from this Court as to whether the public, including the media, will be permitted to attend the court convened pre-sentencing conference, scheduled to take place on December 11, 2006. [4] This case has attracted considerable media attention, at least in part, because of a concern, raised by some, as to the adequacy of government programs and support for the young person who apparently suffers from mental health issues and who is in the permanent care of the Minister of Community Services. It seems to me however, that when a judge attends a court convened conference, receives input and recommendations from various parties, and is mandated to consider them during the course of deliberations in arriving at an appropriate youth sentence, it is, prima facie, a public proceeding. [74] The benefits of an exclusion order, obtaining vital information and recommendations needed to assist the court in arriving at a determination on sentencing, outweighs the deleterious effect of restricting the public’s right to freedom of expression and freedom of the press. [76] An order is granted pursuant to s. 132 of the YCJA excluding the public and the media from the pre-sentencing conference in relation to T.C. scheduled for December 11, 2006.

column8: Counsel for the media, the Crown and the legal parent of the young person sought a ruling from the Court as to whether the public, including the public and media, will be permitted to attend a pre-sentencing conference scheduled to take place on December 11, 2006. The Crown, the youth person and the parent argue that the conference should not be open to the public. Counsel for the Chronicle Herald and the Daily News take the position that this is a public proceeding to which they should have access. HELD: The court found that the court had the discretion to exclude members of the public from the conference. The court also found that it had the discretionary power under s. 41 of the Youth Criminal Justice Act to convene a conference under the 'open court principle' to consider recommendations on an appropriate youth sentence. The Court found that this was a matter of public interest and great care must be exercised in deciding whether to use this discretion.

column13: The Crown sought a ruling from the Court as to whether the public, including the media, will be permitted to attend a pre-sentencing conference scheduled to take place in December 2006. The Crown argued that the conference should not be open to the public and the media. Counsel for the Crown and the young person, who appeared before the Youth Justice Court and entered or confirmed guilty pleas to 31 offences involving assaultive behaviour, threats, property damage and breach of court orders in relation to group home placements over the past 14 months. Defence counsel on behalf of the Crown sought to exclude the public from the conference. HELD: The application was granted. The court found that the public was not to be excluded from the proceedings and that the court had the discretion to exclude members of the media and the public. The Court found that: 1) the public has a right to attend any court proceeding subject to the discretion of the court to exclude them. 2) the court found the public's interest in the protection and rehabilitation of young people involved in youth court proceedings was valued of such superordinate importance that it justifies the discretion given to a youth court judge under s. 39(1)(a) [of the Young Offenders Act] to allow the public to participate in the proceedings.

Counsel for the Crown and the young person, who appeared before the Youth Justice Court and entered or confirmed guilty pleas to 31 offences involving assaultive behaviour, threats, property damage and breach of court orders in relation to group home placements over the past 14 months. Defence counsel on behalf of the Crown sought to exclude the public from the conference. HELD: The Court held that the public's interest was a broad concept and included the impact of the criminal justice system on youth offenders and the resulting interface between the family and all members of the public. The Court found that the general rule of openness lies on the party making the application. The court found that, in all but exceptional circumstances, our courts be freely accessible to all. The public and media have a right to attend any court proceedings subject to the discretion of the court to exclude them. This is evidenced by numerous provisions in the Youth Criminal Justice Act which speak to the adequacy of government programs and services for the youth.

column2: The deceased's cousin commenced an action for nervous shock after she observed the accident in which the deceased bicyclist was killed. Since the defendant was an uninsured motorist, the Facility Association defended the plaintiff's action against him; however, the plaintiff also brought an action against the insurer of a motor vehicle policy under which the deceased was insured. At issue was whether the Section D provisions of the deceased's insurance policy extended to cover the plaintiff. The deceased's insurance policy does not provide coverage to the plaintiff as the emotional harm suffered by her was simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties.
column3: The plaintiff was the defendant's cousin and commenced an action to recover damages for nervous shock. The defendant was an uninsured motorist at the time of the accident and the plaintiff was his cousin. She was present although she did not suffer any physical injuries and was not directly involved in the accident, she commenced this action to advance a claim for nervous shocks. The plaintiff was entitled to recover for nervous stress from the defendant. The Court concluded that such was not the result. The emotional harm suffered by the plaintiff is simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties.
column4:
1. This action arises out of a motor vehicle / bicycle accident which
occurred on June 27, 2002. She was present, although she did not suffer any physical injuries and was not directly involved in the accident, she commenced this action to advance a claim for nervous shock. ISSUE [3] Do the Section D provisions of the M/V Insurance policy issued by Wawanesa extend to protect Alicia Hartling, who suffered psychic injury as a result of the “injury or death” of Jonathan Hartling, an “insured person” under the policy? [14] Upon consideration I conclude that such is not the result. I do so because the emotional harm suffered by Alicia Hartling is simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties. I conclude that the emotional injury of an uninjured person is not covered under the “Section D” provisions by reason of the fact that it is too remote from the original contract contemplated.

column8: This was an action arising out of a motor vehicle accident which occurred on June 27, 2002. The deceased was driving his bicycle on the road when he was struck from behind and killed. The Plaintiff was present although she did not suffer any physical injuries and was not directly involved in the accident, she commenced this action to advance a claim for nervous shock. It is admitted that the Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for nervous shocks from the Defendant LeBlanc. Since the defendant was an uninsured motorist, the Plaintiff entered into a state of extreme emotional distress or nervous shock whereupon he struck some object with his fist, causing physical injury and arguably suffering emotional pain. The emotional harm suffered by the Plaintiff was simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties.

Since the father entered into a state of extreme emotional distress or nervous shock whereupon he struck some object with his fist, causing physical injury and arguably suffering emotional pain, such is not the result. column18: This was an action arising out of a motor vehicle accident which occurred on June 27, 2002. The deceased was driving his bicycle on the road when he was struck from behind and killed. The Plaintiff was present although she did not suffer any physical injuries and was not directly involved in the accident, she commenced this action to advance a claim for nervous shock. HELD: The Court concluded that such a result was not the result. The emotional harm suffered by the Plaintiff was simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties.  1) Section 139 of the Insurance Act regulates the insurance coverage which is to be provided by insurers licensed to sell automobile insurance in Nova Scotia. Because it is fact of life that loss and injury occurs as the result of the operation of uninsured motor vehicles or drivers, the Act establishes a scheme for the protection of persons who suffer loss from such an accident to that of physical harm. The impossibility of contemplating the extent of the potential liability constitutes a valid reason for not distinguishing emotional damage resulting from a death of a person insured under the contract.  2) It is instructive and in keeping with the case law that claim for damages surviving under the Fatal Injuries Act does not include claim for emotional distress or psychological injury which might result from the loss of a loved one.

column22: The deceased's cousin commenced an action for nervous shock after she observed the accident in which the deceased bicyclist was killed. Since the defendant was an uninsured motorist, the Facility Association defended the plaintiff's action against him; however, the plaintiff also brought an action against the insurer of a motor vehicle policy under which the deceased was insured. At issue was whether the Section D provisions of the deceased's insurance policy extended to cover the plaintiff. The deceased's insurance policy does not provide coverage to the plaintiff as the emotional harm suffered by her was simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties.
column23: This was an action arising out of a motor vehicle accident which occurred on June 27, 2002. The deceased was driving his bicycle on the road when he was struck from behind and killed. The Plaintiff was present although she did not suffer any physical injuries and was not directly involved in the accident, she commenced this action to advance a claim for nervous shock. HELD: The emotional harm suffered by the Plaintiff was simply too remote from the obligations contemplated by the contracting parties. 1)The Section D provisions of the M/V insurance policy issued by Wawanesa extend to protect the Plaintiff, who suffered psychic injury as a result of the 'injury or death' of Jonathan Hartling, an 'insured person' under the policy?  2)Section 139 of the Insurance Act regulates the insurance coverage which is to be provided by insurers licensed to sell automobile insurance in Nova Scotia. Because it is fact of life that loss and injury occurs as the result of an uninsured motor vehicle or driver, the claim for emotional distress must be piggybacked on the bodily injury or death of the person insured. It is instructive and in keeping with the case law that claim for damages surviving under the Fatal Injuries Act does not include an emotional injury or psychological injury which might result from the loss of a loved one. 3)The Court concluded that such a result was not the result.

column2: The tenants apply pursuant to s. 49(2) of The Residential Tenancies Act for leave to appeal a decision of the Court of Queen's Bench reviewing a decision of the Rentalsman. HELD: Application allowed.  1) The parties agree that the rent for July was paid on July 27. The landlord then immediately applied for and was granted a writ of possession. 2) The tenants advise that the landlord holds the equivalent of one month's rent as security for the payment of the last month rent of the tenancy. The landlord claims it is a security deposit. 3) The tenants claim they tendered the arrears on the basis that the landlord would not apply for a writ of possession and that the arrears were accepted on that basis. 4) The Court of Queen's Bench Chambers judge dismissed the appellant's appeal the same day saying 'the rent for August has not been paid and not paid by required time, appeal is dismissed'. 5) The first issue on appeal is whether the Chambers judge erred in finding the Rentalsman had jurisdiction to make the order granting possession on the basis that 'the rent was 15 days in arrears when the Notice of Termination of the tenancy agreement was served and the tenant has failed to vacate the premises in accordance with the Notice' if the landlord accepted the rent in lieu of seeking a writ of possession. The second issue on appeal is whether the Chambers judge erred in considering that the subsequent month's rent was not paid.
column3: The tenants apply pursuant to s.49(2) of The Residential Tenancies Act for leave to appeal a decision of the Court of Queen's Bench reviewing a decision by the Rentalsman. The tenants allege they tendered the arrears on the basis that the landlord would not apply for writ of possession and that the arresars were accepted on that basis. The Chambers judge dismissed the tenants' appeal the same day. HELD: Application allowed. 1) The Rentalsmans decision was sufficiently proven and that an Order of possession should be made placing the Landlord in possession of the rental premises. 2) The Chambers Judge erred in considering that the subsequent month's rent was not paid. 3) The tenants have until 4:00 p.m. on August 31, 2006 to serve and file their notice of appeal and 15 days thereafter to file their appeal book and factum.

The applicant seeks both a variation and rescission of arrears which have accumulated under the original support order. HELD: 1) The applicant has established the necessary change in circumstance, namely the introduction of the Guidelines. Based on the applicant's income, his child support payment is reduced from $500 per month to $425 per month.  2) The applicant is in arrears in the amount of $56,365.60. He has provided little explanation for his failure to pay the child support he was ordered to pay other than he was stubborn. It is apparent that he had the ability to pay. The application for rescission for arrears is dismissed.

column2: The respondent was charged with impaired driving contrary to s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code and driving while over .08, contrary to s. 253(b) of the Code. The Crown appeals the acquittal on the charge under s. 253(b) of the Code. At trial the Crown argued that, prior to searching the vehicle and having close contact with the accused in the police car, the RCMP officer did not have a reasonable suspicion that he had alcohol in his body and therefore did not make a screening device demand immediately. The Crown submits that the trial judge was in error in concluding that the 17 minute delay was not warranted or necessary and that there was no breach of the accused's right to be free of arbitrary detention within the meaning of s. 9 of the Charter. HELD: The appeal is dismissed. It appears that the officer may have been anxious to search the vehicle in anticipation that more than just a charge of impaired driving could be supported. Had he proceeded with a quick search of the vehicle and then proceeded with the demand in a short time period that may have been a reasonable violation of the accused's Charter rights. It is obvious from the evidence that in the course of searching the vehicle, the police officer returned to the police vehicle where the accused was detained and he had a further conversation with him, following which he returned to continue his search of the vehicle. In the circumstances, the delay of 17 minutes from when the police officer should have made the demand but did not and detained the accused in the locked police vehicle while he conducted a search of the accused's vehicle without arresting him, advising him of his rights and conducting a search of his vehicle is a violation of potentially three separate Charter rights. column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving contrary to s.253(a) and driving while over.08 contrary to S.253. The Court also held that because this was not a random vehicle stop, the accused's right to retain and instruct counsel was violated. The delay of 17 minutes from when the police officer should have made the demand was not made 'forth with' and the accused was taken to Carlyle detachment where he provided two samples of breath, both readings being 120 mgs. The accused was detained for 17 minutes while the police waited for roadside machine and he complied. The court also held the accused had a reasonable suspicion that he had alcohol in his body and therefore did not make a screening device demand immediately. The trial judge accepted the trial judge's decision and the Court held the Court's reasoning was correct. The issue was whether the delay in taking the test and in advising the accused of his rights to counsel violated the Charter. The evidence obtained from the subsequent breathalyser test was excluded under s24(2). The Court concluded that the Court had not made an error in the Charter and therefore there was no breach of the Charter by the Court. The error was not in the Court’s mind.

column2: Civil Procedure – ContemptCivil Procedure – Queen’s Bench Rule 11-16Municipal Law – Zoning Bylaw – Enforcement The applicant rural municipality was granted an order in May 2014 by a Queen’s Bench judge that directed the respondent to comply within 60 days with an order of the applicant’s development officer. That order had been made pursuant to s. 242 of The Planning and Development Act and required the respondent to comply with the zoning bylaw by desisting from operating an equipment storage yard on a parcel of land owned by him and to restore it to the condition it was in prior to his use of it. The respondent had purchased the land in 2009 and immediately began storing equipment and leaving junk cars and other materials on it. The applicant had tried to encourage the respondent’s voluntary cooperation with the bylaw but eventually issued the order. After the court granted the order, the respondent took no steps to comply with it and in August 2014, the applicant applied for an order declaring the respondent to be in contempt of court. The application was heard in September at which time the respondent submitted by affidavit that he had removed the old cars but believed that he was allowed to keep his equipment. He requested that he receive additional time. The respondent was given until December 2014 to comply with the order. At the hearing he deposed that he had spent a significant amount of time and money removing materials from the land and that he had found out from his counsel that his belief regarding the permitted use of the land was incorrect. Based on the appearance of the site, the applicant was not satisfied but agreed to adjourn the matter until May 2015 as nothing could be done during the winter. When the matter was reviewed in May, the respondent had removed more equipment but said that he was not able to move it all as he had no place to put the rest of it. The applicant requested that the court find the respondent in contempt and to impose appropriate penalties, authorize it to remove any remaining machinery and to add the costs of this removal and disposal to the taxes on the land and to make an order for solicitor-client costs in its favour. HELD: The respondent was found to be in contempt of court pursuant to Queen’s Bench rule 11-16(3) for his failure, without reasonable excuse, to comply with the terms of the May 2014 court order. The court authorized the applicant to remove and dispose of the equipment if the respondent had not done so within 30 days of the order issued. The court awarded solicitor-client costs to the applicant in the amount of $15,000 because of the respondent’s continued and unjustified failure to comply with the zoning bylaw. As the applicant might incur additional costs to remove the equipment, those costs would be added to the tax rolls of the property and become payable by the respondent if he had not purged his contempt within the allotted time.
column3: The respondent was found in contempt of court for failing to comply with a court order requiring him to remove all of his equipment from his property. The respondent had taken no significant steps to comply and was now in contempt. The court ordered the respondent to pay solicitor/client costs. The defendant was to appear in court on February 2, 2014. The Court ordered the defendant to pay court costs. It also ordered the plaintiff to dispose of any equipment that remained on his property beyond the time stipulated in the order. The plaintiff was to pay costs to the defendant. The costs of the contempt application were to be assessed at $15,000. The applicant had made significant progress in complying with the order and was prepared to continue to remove the offending equipment. The trial judge erred in finding that the respondent had not shown reasonable concern for his safety and that the court had not fettered its discretion in awarding costs.

column8: HELD: The contempt application was granted. The court ordered the respondent to comply with the court order. The respondent took no significant steps to comply. The respondent was personally present at the commencement of the proceedings and took no substantial steps to ensure compliance. The evidence showed that the appellant had made considerable progress in removing the offending equipment and that his efforts to comply were only limited to rare and exceptional circumstances. The Chambers judge erred in limiting solicitor-client costs to circumstances where there was both scandalous, outrageous or reprehensible conduct.
