As the applicant might incur additional costs to remove the equipment, those costs would be added to the tax rolls of the property and become payable by the respondent if he had not purged his contempt within the allotted time.
column23: HELD: The contempt application was granted. The court ordered the respondent to comply within 60 days with the order of the Development Officer of the RM. The respondent did not appeal the order nor did he appeal the contempt application. It found that the respondent had made significant progress in complying with the orders and that he was prepared to continue removing the offending equipment. The Court found that it was not unusual for a person to be in contempt of court to fail to comply with a court order. The contempt proceedings were not for punishment per se but for upholding the rule of law and respect for court orders.
column27: The respondent was found in contempt of court for failing to comply with a court order requiring him to remove all of his equipment from his property. The respondent had taken no significant steps to comply and was now in contempt. The court ordered the respondent to pay solicitor/client costs. The defendant was to appear in court on February 2, 2014. The Court ordered the defendant to pay court costs. It also ordered the plaintiff to dispose of any equipment that remained on his property beyond the time stipulated in the order. The plaintiff was to pay costs to the defendant. The costs of the contempt application were to be assessed at $15,000. The applicant had made significant progress in complying with the order and was prepared to continue to remove the offending equipment. The trial judge erred in finding that the respondent had not shown reasonable concern for his safety and that the court had not fettered its discretion in awarding costs.

column2: Criminal Law – Murder – Second Degree Murder – Conviction – AppealEvidence – Unsavoury Witnesses – Vetrovec Warning – Charge to Jury The appellant had been found guilty of second degree murder following a trial before a judge and jury. He appealed on the ground that the trial judge had failed to give the jury a Vetrovec warning regarding the testimony of his former common law spouse (S.S.) and a witness who had been his friend (W.D.) who was the source of the gun used in the shooting of the victim. The appellant’s trial counsel had initially identified the need for the judge to issue the warning because W.D. had an interest in the outcome because there were outstanding charges against him and because there was the potential that S.S.would be charged too, she would also have an interest in the case as well. During the pre-charge conference with defence counsel and the Crown, the trial judge noted that in giving the warning to the jury he would also have to convey a summary of the Crown’s confirmatory evidence. The defence counsel then withdrew his application. The victim had been a friend of the appellant. According to S.S.’s testimony, the appellant and the victim had pre-arranged a meeting in an abandoned farmyard. The victim worked as an automated teller machine (ATM) technician and as part of his job, he travelled between ATMs carrying cash. S.S. did not see what happened between the two men but heard two gunshots and then saw the appellant and the victim point guns at each other. She saw the victim on his knees pleading with the appellant and offering money in exchange for his life. The appellant instructed her to collect the money and the victim’s cellphone and place them in his truck and while she was doing so, she heard another gunshot and saw the victim lying face down and the appellant standing over him holding a gun. As she and the appellant left the scene, the appellant gave her the victim’s gun. The appellant hid the other guns and the money at another farm site and then dumped the victim’s cellphone and ammunition in a farm field. Apart from the handguns, none of the other items were ever recovered. The witness remained in a relationship with the appellant for another four years following the crime until November 2013. She was contacted by the police in February 2013 and denied any knowledge of the incident. At trial, S.S. testified that she was afraid of the appellant and he had warned her that as an accomplice, she was as involved as he was. When the RCMP contacted her again in May 2014, she again denied any knowledge but then told the officer what she knew because she felt safer and would receive protection from the appellant. S.S. did not have a criminal record, nor was she charged with any offence arising from this incident. The appellant testified that during the meeting in the farmyard, the victim produced two handguns and they began to test fire the weapons. The victim suggested that they stage a fake robbery. The appellant would rough up his friend and then take the cash from his truck. The victim became quite aggressive after the appellant hit him too hard and began chasing him with one of his guns. S.S. then took one of the guns and shot the victim three times. She took $23,000 in cash from his truck because she had financial problems. The testimony of W.D. was that the appellant had acquired two handguns, a Glock and a .22 calibre handgun, from him, ostensibly on behalf of another friend. Several days later, the appellant returned both handguns and reported that after his friend began to shoot at him with the .22 calibre, he had returned fired and shot him three times. On the appellant’s insistence, the witness changed the barrel of the Glock handgun several months later. The police arrested W.D. and charged him with unspecified offences arising from the incident. In the appellant’s version, he testified that the victim brought the guns to the meeting and assumed that he acquired them from W.D. He therefore returned them to W.D. after the incident and requested that he change the barrel on the Glock to protect W.D. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The court found that the trial judge had not erred by not giving the Vetrovec warning. It was not mandatory for him to do so regardless of the position of the defence counsel. The judge was aware of the need for such a warning in the circumstances and after consulting with the Crown and the defence, he exercised his discretion to decide that he would not instruct the jury. The judge was aware that the defence counsel withdrew his application as a tactical decision to avoid having the judge repeat the Crown’s confirmatory evidence to the jury. The judge’s exercise of his discretion was entitled to deference.
column3: The defendant was found guilty of the second degree murder of his common law spouse. The trial judge sought input from counsel as to whether Vetrovec warning should be given in relation to either witness. The Crown's expert testified that the barrel of the handgun was not the original factory barrel and other indicia from the evidence at the scene did not support the appellant's version of events. The defence argued that Vetrove warning was mandatory, regardless of the position taken by the defendant at the time of trial. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1) The trial court found that the trial judge did not give a Vetrochio warning in relation the testimony of either witness, regardless if the defendant's position was taken at the trial. The Court found that this was an error of law. 2) The Court held that the evidence was not so circumstantial as to suggest that the appellant had made an error in law. The evidence was so strong that it could not be excluded. The court found the appellant was guilty of both counts. The appellant's evidence was unreliable and the Court found the trial court did not err in failing to give a warning. The appeal court found there was no evidence that the jury was misled. The jury was left to decide whether the appellant should give a verbal warning. 3) The court dismissed the appellant’s appeal. The decision was based upon a fundamental misunderstanding of the strength of the ballistic and scientific evidence and the importance of the witness’ evidence to the Crown. The test of credibility was not a factor on its own. The judge was not required to give the appellant a warning in the circumstances. The issue was whether the trial officer should have given a warning to either witnesses. The error was not made lightly. The verdict could only have been salvaged under the curative provision set forth in s. 686(1)(b)(iii) of the Criminal Code if he concluded that the appeal court concluded that he had erred in law by failing to provide a warning when the circumstances required one to be given. The Appeal Court found there were other considerations that inform the decision. The only issue that the Court raised was whether it was an appropriate level of concern and caution.
column4:
Appeal dismissed [1] Daniel Smith was found guilty of the second degree murder of Roger Byer following a trial before a judge and jury. [4] In the end, the trial judge did not give a Vetrovec warning in relation to either witness. [5] For the reasons that follow, I would dismiss Mr. Smith’s appeal. 30] Mr. Smith filed a self-crafted notice of appeal, in which the following grounds of appeal were raised:
a. The judge fell into error in failing to warn the jury as to the dangers of relying upon the evidence of Susan Saxon and Dwight Windrum following the decision in Vetrovec. However, the decision to give the warning is discretionary in nature, as is the content of the warning itself, and a trial judge’s exercise of this discretion is entitled to deference: He took a measured approach with regard to the need for a Vetrovec warning in the circumstances and he carefully solicited input from both Crown and defence counsel. I am also satisfied that, in exercising his discretion not to give a Vetrovec warning, he was particularly alert to the position advanced by defence counsel, which he clearly understood to be a tactical choice. [99] The appeal must, therefore, be dismissed.

column8: The defendant was found guilty of the second degree murder of his common law spouse and friend. The trial judge sought input from counsel as to whether Vetrovec warning should be given in relation to either witness. The Crown's expert testified that, even though the barrel on the Glock handgun was not the original factory barrel, other indicia from that gun enabled him to conclude that approximately $23,000 was missing and unaccounted for. The defendant appealed. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The trial judge did not give a warning in the circumstances requiring one to be given. The evidence was not conclusive. The court found that the trial judge had erred in law in failing to give a verbal warning to the complainant. 2)The evidence in this case was not corroborated by the evidence at the scene. The Court found that there was no evidence that the complainant had changed her mind about the possibility of a fatal bullet being fired from the handgun. 3)The Court found the trial court did not have jurisdiction to interfere with the appeal.

There was no ballistic/forensic pathology evidence which could support the account of the defendant. 3)The jury was not told of the dangers inherent in the testimony of the two witnesses. 4)The evidence was excluded from the jury's view. 5)The Court was not asked to give a warning on the basis of the expert evidence.

Appeal dismissed [1] Daniel Smith was found guilty of the second degree murder of Roger Byer following a trial before a judge and jury. [4] In the end, the trial judge did not give a Vetrovec warning in relation to either witness. [5] For the reasons that follow, I would dismiss Mr. Smith’s appeal. 30] Mr. Smith filed a self-crafted notice of appeal, in which the following grounds of appeal were raised:
a. The judge fell into error in failing to warn the jury as to the dangers of relying upon the evidence of Susan Saxon and Dwight Windrum following the decision in Vetrovec. However, the decision to give the warning is discretionary in nature, as is the content of the warning itself, and a trial judge’s exercise of this discretion is entitled to deference: He took a measured approach with regard to the need for a Vetrovec warning in the circumstances and he carefully solicited input from both Crown and defence counsel. I am also satisfied that, in exercising his discretion not to give a Vetrovec warning, he was particularly alert to the position advanced by defence counsel, which he clearly understood to be a tactical choice. [99] The appeal must, therefore, be dismissed.
column27: The defendant was found guilty of the second degree murder of his common law spouse and friend following a trial before a judge and jury. The trial judge did not give a Vetrovec warning in relation to either witness. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The trial judge gave no reasons for his decision not to give the warning. The evidence presented by the Crown and defence did not support the appellant's argument that a Vetrovvec warning was mandatory. The court found that the trial judge erred in law in failing to give a warning in respect to the testimony of both witnesses. The Court found that in the circumstances of the trial, the appellant should have given a warning. 2)The appellant's evidence was not corroborated by the evidence at the scene. 3)The evidence was found to be unreliable. 4)The court found the appellant was guilty of failing to warn the jury of the potential dangers inherent in his testimony. 5)The Court dismissed the appellant’s appeal.

column2: The appellant appealed his conviction for assaulting a police officer engaged in the execution of his duty. The police officer had responded to a call in connection with a disturbance during which the appellant assaulted a third person. Upon arriving at the scene the officer recognised the appellant as someone wanted by the police. The officer told the appellant that he was under arrest because of two outstanding warrants. The appellant assaulted the officer. The officer did not give evidence as to the grounds for his belief that the warrants met the s. 495(1)(c) Criminal Code requirement, i.e., that they were in a format set out in Part XXVIII and in force within the jurisdiction. In his charge to the jury the trial judge indicated that the arrest was for the assault against the third party and did not direct the jury to consider if the officer had reasonable grounds for believing that there were warrants outstanding. Allowing the appeal and ordering a new trial, that the evidence did not support the conclusion that the officer arrested the appellant for the assault on the third party and it was not made clear to the jury that they must make an essential determination if the officer had reasonable grounds as required in s. 495 of the Code, such that he was acting in the execution of his duty.
column3: The appellant appealed his conviction following a trial in the Supreme Court before a jury on a charge that he did assault a Peace Officer engaged in the execution of his duties contrary to s. 270(2)(a) of the Criminal Code. HELD: Appeal allowed, conviction set aside and a new trial ordered. The Court found that there was a misdirection by the trial judge. Pursuant to s686(1)(a), s6(2) and s6 (2), the Court allowed the appeal and ordered a new Trial.

column2: This was an appeal from a Supreme Court decision dismissing certiorari applications to quash three orders of the Labour Relations Board ordering the appellant to reinstate the respondents and pay them compensation for dismissing them due to their support of a union. The appellant alleged that the Board's order should be quashed because it failed to give reasons for its decision. Allowing the appeal and remitting the matter for rehearing, that there is an implied duty on a tribunal to provide written reasons whenever substantial issues are involved and the reasons for the tribunal's decision are not obvious from a review of the issues and the record. In this case, the order of the Board imposed significant financial liability on the appellant, and the issues were complex and the concerns of the parties were substantial. As a result, the Board acted in a patently unreasonable manner in giving its decision without providing reasons.
column3: The respondent union appealed three orders of the Labour Relations Board, which had overturned three of the individual respondents' convictions. The union alleged that the respondent had committed an unfair labour practice. Dismissing the applications, that the Board's decision was not patently unreasonable. The respondents were hotel employees who had been dismissed from their employment because they were members of a trade union and participated in the activities of trade union. The respondent union had also brought an action for judicial review. The court found that the board's decision to reinstate the individual employees was not unreasonable.
column4: THE COURT: The appeal is allowed with costs; the order of the Chambers judge is set aside and the matter is remitted to the Board for a rehearing as per reasons for judgment of Chipman, J.A.; Matthews and Flinn, JJ.A., concurring. This is an appeal by Future Inns Canada Inc. from a judgment in the Supreme Court dismissing certiorari applications to quash three orders of the Labour Relations Board (Nova Scotia) ordering Future Inns to reinstate the individual respondents, to pay them compensation, and refusing to reconsider the first two orders. As there was evidence upon which the Board could find that Future Inns committed an unfair labour practice, the decision of the Board was not patently unreasonable. I am satisfied that courts can and should require written reasons from a Tribunal wherever there are substantial issues to be resolved. If the determination of the reasonableness of a tribunal\'s decision can only be made by considering "the reasoning underlying it" and these reasons are not obvious from a review of the issues and the record, written reasons are necessary. In the circumstances, the Board acted in a patently unreasonable manner in giving this decision without reasons. I would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the Chambers judge. I would quash the decision of the Board and remit the matter to the Board for a rehearing. As between these two respondents, one-half of the costs should be paid by each.

column8: This was an appeal from a judgment in the Supreme Court dismissing certiorari applications to quash three orders of the Labour Relations Board (Nova Scotia) ordering Future Inns to reinstate the individual respondents, to pay them compensation, and refusing to reconsider the first two orders. Other respondents were Hotel Employees Restaurant Employees Union, Local 662, Hotel Employee Union, Trade Union and the Attorney General of Nova Scotia. The Union had been organizing employees of the respondent in connection with an application for certification pursuant to the Trade Union Act. The respondent was refusing to employ the complainants because they are members of trade union and have participated in the activities of the trade union. HELD: The appeal was allowed with costs; the order of the Chambers judge was set aside and the matter was remitted to the Board for a rehearing as per reasons for the reasons stated in the passage from deSmith. The court found that the Board is not bound by legislation to provide reasons for its decision and that in the absence of such a requirement reasons are not generally mandated. The privative clause in the Act precluded the court from weighing the evidence and coming to its own conclusion on this issue. As there was evidence upon which the Board could find that the respondent committed an unfair labour practice, the decision of the Board was not patently unreasonable.

column23: This was an appeal from a judgment in the Supreme Court dismissing certiorari applications to quash three orders of the Labour Relations Board (Nova Scotia) ordering Future Inns to reinstate the individual respondents, to pay them compensation, and refusing to reconsider the first two orders. HELD: The appeal was allowed with costs; the order of the Chambers judge is set aside and the matter is remitted to the Board for a rehearing as per reasons for judgment of Chipman, J.A.; Matthews and Flinn, JJ.A., concurring. 1)The principles of fundamental justice, natural justice and fairness require that the permanent resident be given the reasons for the determination that he was a danger to the public and should be deported. As there was evidence upon which the Board could find that the applicant committed an unfair labour practice, the decision of the Board was not patently unreasonable. 2)In light of the recent events in Nova Scotia, it is not sufficient for an individual concerned that his or her submissions have been made to the Court of Appeal. There is no general rule of law that reasons must be given for administrative (or indeed judicial) decisions. The privative clause in the Act precludes the Court from weighing the evidence and coming to its own conclusion on this issue. 3)In recent years, with the development of multitude of tribunals with varying degrees of protection from judicial review, it has become fashionable for such a tribunal to give reasons. In many jurisdictions, the giving of reasons is now required by statute. In this case, the reasons stated in the passage from deSmith, Woolf and Jowell do not enable the Court to determine whether the judge had properly directed himself to all the evidence or the legal questions bearing on the issues. The Chambers judge acknowledged that reasons would have been desirable but in practice the Court did not have the power to intervene.

column2: This was an appeal to determine whether a Provincial Court judge is obliged to advise an accused of his right to a trial in either or both of the official languages of Canada, pursuant to s. 530 of the Code. Allowing the appeal and ordering a new trial, that s. 530(3) of the Code is mandatory.
column3: The sole ground of appeal was whether a Provincial Court Judge was obligated to advise an unrepresented accused of his right to trial in either of the official languages of Canada pursuant to s. 530(1) of the Code. The accused's mother tongue was French and the trial judge did not advise him of his rights to trial. The trial judge had no discretion and was obligated only to the unrepresented appellant the right to be tried in either language. The only ground of the appeal was the failure of the Provincial Court judge to advise the appellant of his Rights to trial by French or English pursuant to S. 530. The appellant's mother was French. The failure by the Provincial court Judge to advise him in English constitutes a procedural wrong. The Court would allow the appeal and order a new trial.
column4: The issue in this appeal is whether a Provincial Court Judge is obligated to advise an unrepresented accused of his right to trial in either or both of the official languages of Canada pursuant to Section 530(1) of the Criminal Code. The sole ground of appeal relates to the failure of the Provincial Court Judge to advise the Appellant of his rights to trial in French or English pursuant to Section 530 of the Code. In conclusion, the Trial Judge had no discretion and therefore was obligated to put to the unrepresented Appellant the right to be tried in either of the official languages of Canada or both. In view of the foregoing, I would allow the appeal and order a new trial. new trial ordered.

column2: The plaintiffs sought a detailed accounting from their sister of her dealings with their mother's financial affairs pursuant to a Power of Attorney prior to the mother's death. , plaintiffs' action dismissed; the defendant was not required to account to the plaintiffs for her dealings with her mother's finances. The mother was mentally competent and able to manage her own affairs at all times prior to her death; the Power of Attorney was granted solely for the mother's convenience as she was physically infirm. The daughter could only be called upon to account for her use of the Power of Attorney if it was used when the mother was incapacitated.
column3: The Plaintiffs sought an accounting of their sister's dealings with their mother's financial affairs pursuant to a Power of Attorney. The Court found that the only evidence that suggested the mother was not mentally competent was that of the Plaintiff's 21 year old daughter. The Plaintiff had sold two properties and had a joint bank account. The Power of attorney was used solely for the Plaintiff and the joint bank accounts. The court found that there was no evidence that the Plaintiff was mentally competent at the time of her death. The only evidence which suggested the Plaintiff could not be diagnosed as not mentally incompetent was that the petitioner's mother's telephone conversations with her daughter. HELD: The Court held that it had no difficulty in concluding that the defendant was mentally capable at the age of her passing. The Plaintiffs were jointly and severely liable for payment of these costs which may be deducted from their respective entitlements in the estate. The defendants were jointly liable for the costs which were deducted from the respective entitlement in the Estate.

column2: In January 1992, the parties agreed the petitioner would pay child support of $300 per month and that it would be without tax ramifications to either party. As of September 2007, the petitioner has arrears of about $2,900. He now applies to set his child support obligation and deal with the arrears. The petitioner claims he has been paying too much in child support under the Guidelines. HELD: 1) In terms of ongoing support, it is appropriate to determine the petitioner's income on the basis of the three year average of his employment income being $21,834 and add to that the $5,100 in rental income for a total of $26,934. The petitioner is actively engaged in farming. He pursues reasonable off farm income. In the absence of something further, the Court was not prepared to impute income. He shall pay child support of $221 per month.  2) In terms of the payor's ability to pay at the time the arrears accrued, the petitioner says he was paying in excess of his legal obligation. It is true that if one looked to his employment income the table amount would be approximately half of the $300 per month non-taxable that the petitioner agreed to pay back in 1992. However, one cannot ignore the fact that he agreed to pay it. He did nothing to seek to change this obligation in all of the intervening years. The petitioner's farming operation affords the petitioner an opportunity to manage his financial affairs. By reporting a farm loss each year, the petitioner in fact pays less tax on his employment income than he would otherwise pay. In the circumstances the Court was not prepared to rescind any of the arrears.
column3: FIAT: The petitioner seeks an interim order setting his ongoing child support obligation as well as addressing the arrears. The petitioner says he has been paying at a rate greater than his legal obligation. Arrears have accumulated and he seeks to expunge them. HELD: The child support order was registered pursuant to The Children's Law Act, 1997 S.S. 1997, c.C-8.2 as am. The Family Maintenance Enforcement Office is holding funds obtained through federal garnishment. The respondent takes the position that the petitioner's line 150 income does not reflect his ability to pay. In the absence of something further, the court is not prepared to impute income. In any event, the arsars will be resolved. The court is cognizant of the fact that the respondent's farming operation affords the petitioner an opportunity to manage his financial affairs. By reporting a farm loss each year the petitioner in fact pays less tax on his employment income than he would otherwise pay. The arrear is accumulated and the court was not prepared in the circumstances to rescind any of the arreears.

The respondent takes the position that the petitioner's line 150 income does not reflect his ability to pay. In the absence of something further, the court is not prepared to impute income. In any event, the arsars will be resolved. The court is cognizant of the fact that the respondent's farming operation affords the petitioner an opportunity to manage his financial affairs. By reporting a farm loss each year the petitioner in fact pays less tax on his employment income than he would otherwise pay. The arrear is accumulated and the court was not prepared in the circumstances to rescind any of the arreears.

column2: FIAT: The applicant seeks an order setting aside a wage assessment certificate issued by the Director of the Labour Standards Branch (the Director) and filed with this Court. The applicant disputes liability for the amount set out in the wage assessment and claim that he inadvertently and innocently missed the time within which to file an appeal. The issues are whether this Court has jurisdiction to set aside the Director's certificate filed with the Court of Queen's Bench, if so what criteria ought to be applied in determining whether the Court should exercise its discretion and whether the applicant has satisfied the criteria. HELD: 1) Even though an appeal from a wage assessment to the appeals board and an appeal from an adjudicator to the Court of Queen's Bench both require 'appeals' within '21 days', an appeal to the Court of Queen's Bench is a true appeal while an 'appeal' to the appeals board is essentially a request for a de novo hearing. Consequently, this Court concludes that the consequences of missing the time limitation are not necessarily the same. 2) This Court does have jurisdiction to deal with an applicant's request, on a director appeal, because it is not a 'true appeal' that questions a decision made by an independent adjudicator after a hearing. Accordingly, the reasoning of this Court in Farmers of North America Inc. v. Langridge, 2004 SKQB 375, is not applicable. A finding that this Court is without jurisdiction to set aside a judgment, obtained without any independent adjudicative process, regardless of the basis upon which that judgment was obtained, is inequitable and at odds with existing practices and procedures. Section 62.4(4) of The Labour Standards Act states that a certificate filed pursuant to s. 62.4(3) has the same force and effect as if it were a judgment obtained in the Court of Queen's Bench for the recovery of a debt. This Court certainly would have jurisdiction to determine whether or not the applicant's application to open up a noting for default should be granted pursuant to Rule 114(3), Rule 271 and Rule 346. It follows that this Court is able to look behind the filing and examine the circumstances under which that judgment was entered. The Court of Queen's Bench is a superior Court charged with the administration of justice and enjoys inherent as well as statutory jurisdiction. This inherent jurisdiction cannot be removed by either level of government without constitutional amendment. 3) It is fair and equitable to apply, by analogy, the principles and resulting rules formulated relating to opening up a default judgment to the applicant's request to set aside the judgment registered in circumstances where he has failed to file an appeal disputing a wage assessment to the registrar of appeals.  4) The evidence is that the applicant is a businessman running a commercial enterprise in Foam Lake. It is expected that somebody in his position would have the savvy to read, review and understand the document, or at least seek assistance from someone who could help him. The applicant either failed or declined to read, or chose to ignore, the plain language of the documents served on him by registered mail. This amounts to wilful blindness at the very least. Numerous cases hold that wilful blindness is not sufficient reason to set aside a noting for default. In these circumstances the Court is not prepared to exercise its discretion in favour of setting aside the Director's certificate filed as a judgment of this Court.
column3: FIAT: The applicant brings an application seeking an order setting aside a wage assessment certificate issued by the Director of the Labour Standards Branch and filed with this Court. The applicant disputes liability for the amount set out in the wage assessment and claims that he inadvertently and innocently missed the time within which to file an appeal. HELD: 1) Does this Court have jurisdiction to set aside a certificate filed with the Court of Queen's Bench? 2) Does it have jurisdiction in the circumstances where an appeal from a wage assessor to the Director's Branch (the Director) and an appeal to the Court's adjudicator (the adjudicator) both require appeals within 21 days? 3) The applicant has not met the criteria necessary to set up a hearing on the merits. The consequences of missing the time limitation are not necessarily the same. 4) The Court has jurisdiction to deal with an applicant's request, on a director appeal, because it is not a true appeal that questions a decision made by an independent adjudicator after a hearing. The Queen's B Rules provide for the opening up of a noting for default.
column4:
[1] The applicant, Barry Strange, operating under the trade name of Middle Lake Hotel 2002 (“the applicant”), brings an application seeking an order setting aside a wage assessment certificate issued by the Director of the Labour Standards Branch (“the Director”) and filed with this Court. ISSUES [2] The issues raised in this application are:

(1) Does this Court have jurisdiction to set aside the Director’s certificate filed with the Court of Queen’s Bench?

(2) If so, what criteria ought to be applied in determining whether the Court should exercise its discretion in favour of setting aside the wage assessment certificate?

(3) Has the applicant satisfied the criteria? [34] Accordingly, even though an appeal from a wage assessment to the appeals board and an appeal from an adjudicator to the Court of Queen’s Bench both require “appeals” within “21 days” an appeal to the Court of Queen’s Bench is a true appeal while an “appeal” to the appeals board is essentially a request for a de novo hearing. Consequently, I conclude that the consequences of missing the time limitation are not necessarily the same. [37] I conclude that this Court does have jurisdiction to deal with an applicant’s request, on a director appeal, because it is not a “true appeal” that questions a decision made by an independent adjudicator after a hearing. A finding that this Court is without jurisdiction to set aside a judgment, obtained without any independent adjudicative process, regardless of the basis upon which that judgment was obtained, is inequitable and at odds with existing practices and procedures. If the employee had sued the employer for the wages, which it would be her right to do, and if a statement of claim had been served, but not defended, and the matter was noted for default, this Court certainly would have jurisdiction to determine whether or not the defendant/employer’s application to open up of a noting for default should be granted. The Queen’s Bench Rules provide for the opening up of a noting for default. It logically follows, therefore, that where a judgment is filed in this Court that this Court would be able to look behind the filing and examine the circumstances under which that judgment was entered. [44] Accordingly, I find that it is fair and equitable to apply, by analogy, the principles and resulting rules formulated relating to opening up a default judgment to the applicant’s request to set aside the judgment registered in circumstances where he has failed to file an appeal disputing a wage assessment to the registrar of appeals. [53] The applicant has failed to satisfy me that the third prong of the four-pronged test has been met and, accordingly, I am not prepared to exercise my discretion in favour of setting aside the Director’s certificate filed as a judgment of this Court.

column8: FIAT: The applicant brings an application seeking an order setting aside a wage assessment certificate issued by the Director of the Labour Standards Branch and filed with this Court. The applicant disputes liability for the amount set out in the wage assessment and claims that he inadvertently and innocently missed the time within which to file an appeal. HELD: 1) Does this Court have jurisdiction to set aside a certificate filed with the Court of Queen's Bench? 2) If so, what criteria ought to be applied in determining whether the Court should exercise its discretion in favour of setting aside the certificate? 3) The applicant has not met the criteria necessary to trigger the exercise of the Court's discretion. The consequences for inaction parallel those of defendant who is noted for default as a result of his failure to file statement of defence within the prescribed time frame. 4) The Queen’s Bench Rules provide for the opening up of a noting for default. 5) There are at least two bases upon which it can be found that the Court is clothed with jurisdiction to exercise its discretionary and provide remedy in appropriate circumstances. 6) The principles and the rules that flow from them and which have developed in relation to the opening of noting are much different. There has been no independent evidentiary based finding. After an allegation is made, it becomes an enforceable judgment if the proper steps to dispute it are not taken within the specified period of time. However, there are circumstances where it is simply inequitable to hold a party to an arbitrary deadline, especially where there are compelling legitimate reasons not to do so and the other party has suffered no prejudice. The Court does have jurisdiction, on a director appeal, because it is not a 'true appeal' that questions a decision made by an independent adjudicator after a hearing.

[44] Accordingly, I find that it is fair and equitable to apply, by analogy, the principles and resulting rules formulated relating to opening up a default judgment to the applicant’s request to set aside the judgment registered in circumstances where he has failed to file an appeal disputing a wage assessment to the registrar of appeals. [53] The applicant has failed to satisfy me that the third prong of the four-pronged test has been met and, accordingly, I am not prepared to exercise my discretion in favour of setting aside the Director’s certificate filed as a judgment of this Court.
column27: FIAT: The applicant brings an application seeking an order setting aside a wage assessment certificate issued by the Director of the Labour Standards Branch and filed with this Court. The applicant disputes liability for the amount set out in the wage assessment and claims that he inadvertently and innocently missed the time within which to file an appeal. HELD: 1) Does this Court have jurisdiction to set aside a certificate filed with the Court of Queen's Bench? 2) If so, what criteria ought to be applied in determining whether the Court should exercise its discretion in favour of setting aside the certificate? 3) The applicant has not met the criteria necessary to trigger the exercise of the Court's discretion. The consequences for inaction parallel those of defendant who is noted for default as a result of his failure to file statement of defence within the prescribed time frame. 4) The Court has jurisdiction to deal with an applicant's request, on a director appeal, because it is not a true appeal that questions a decision made by an independent adjudicator after a hearing. 5) There are at least two bases upon which it can be found that the Court is clothed with jurisdiction and provide remedy in appropriate circumstances. 6) The principles and the rules that flow from them and which have developed in relation to the opening up of noting for default and in setting aside default are much different. There has been no independent evidentiary based finding. After an allegation is made, it becomes an enforceable judgment if the proper steps to dispute it are not taken within the specified period of time. In numerous cases wilful blindness has been held to not constitute sufficient reason for the Court to grant an extension.

column2: This is an appeal by the tenant, pursuant to s. 72 of the Residential Tenancies Act from a decision of the hearing officer appointed under the Act, who, pursuant to ss. 58, 68, and 70 of the Act, ordered that the landlord be given possession of the tenant's rental unit and that a writ of possession be issued to place the landlords in possession of the rental unit. HELD: The Court reviewed the facts and found the tenant had not raised any true issues as to the jurisdiction of the hearing. It was the Court's view that the hearing officer had jurisdiction to hear and determine the matter in issue. The notice of appeal and arguments presented by the tenant all relate to the facts as found by the hearing officer and contain no error of law. There were facts before the hearing officer to support his finding that the tenant had significantly disturbed other tenants. Further, the Court found there was ample evidence to support the hearing officer's decision on all his findings of fact. Appeal dismissed.

column2: The accused was convicted of aggravated assault after stabbing another person several times in the mid-section. The Crown brought a dangerous offender application. The accused was 22 years old at the time of sentencing. His prior criminal record consisted of mostly youth convictions. The offender was a known member of an aboriginal gang. The evidence suggested he was somewhere in the middle of the gang hierarchy. The accused had professed some desire to leave the gang. He had written an article directed at other youth warning them of the pitfalls of gang affiliation. The article was published in a book distributed to at risk youth. The accused had looked into getting help to leave the gang, but admitted on the stand that he was not prepared to take steps to leave because he might need protection from the gang in the penitentiary. While incarcerated, he had gang drawings confiscated from him and he had been jumped by members of a rival gang while in custody. The accused had shown some initiative in taking anger management courses and had completed his GED while incarcerated. HELD: The offence was a serious personal injury offence within the meaning of s. 752 of the Criminal Code. The criminal record together with the evidence heard at the hearing establishes that when the accused has committed violent offences he has been under the influence of alcohol or drugs, under supervision by court orders in the community, has used a knife or had one in his possession and most of the offences were a result of the accused's affiliation with the Indian Posse gang. The Crown has established a pattern of repetitive behaviour within the meaning of s. 753(1)(a)(i). Dr. Holden assessed the accused and found him to be a high risk to re-offend violently. The Crown has also proven that the accused constitutes a threat to the life, safety, and physical or mental well-being of other persons as set out in s. 753(1)(a)(ii). The accused was declared a dangerous offender. However, the Court found that given the accused's youth, the fact that he had not had any of the intensive programming that is available in a federal institution and the fact that there was some chance the accused might leave the gang, a determinate sentence and long term supervision order would adequately protect the public. In imposing a determinate sentence, the Court also considered that the accused's acts of violence, with the exception of the predicate offence, had generally resulted in less than severe injuries to the victim and the accused had voluntarily taken some steps to address his issues while incarcerated. The accused was sentenced 6 years or 72 months in custody, less credit for remand, to be followed by a 9 year supervision order under s. 753.4(b).
column3: The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault contrary to s. 268 of the Criminal Code and breach of an undertaking contrary to S. 145(3) of the Code. The Crown applied to have the accused declared a dangerous offender. HELD: The Court found that the accused was a dangerous person and that long-term offender designation was appropriate. The predicate offence was a serious personal injury offence within the meaning of s. 752 of the criminal Code.

column8: The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault contrary to s. 268 of the Criminal Code and breach of an undertaking. The Crown applied to have the accused declared a dangerous offender. HELD: 1) The predicate offence was a serious personal injury offence within the meaning of s. 752 of the Code. The Court found that the accused had less active role and he did not smash windows or inflict any blows. He acted in threatening manner and held in his possession bear spray. 2) Sentence concurrent with a concurrent sentence of twenty-one months custody and supervision, twelve months secure custody followed by seven month supervision in the community.  3) The Court held that the offences committed were the predicate offences. The accused had a history of violent behaviour and had been convicted of assault. 4) The court found the accused to be dangerous and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. 5) The sentence was concurrent with the concurrent sentence. The predicate offences were serious personal injuries offences. 6) The offence was determined to be the predicate offence under s.752 of The Criminal Code. 7) The Crown must establish a pattern of repetitive behaviour by the offender. The offender must be found dangerous and he should be sentenced to imprisonment. The court concluded that the predicate offense was a'serious personal injury' offence.

column2: HELD: This was an extraordinary event for all of the accused and nothing in the evidence suggested that they required rehabilitation or that incarceration would assist in rehabilitation. The victim did not provide a victim impact statement, but the court concluded that the event would have been terrifying for him. The gravity of the offence was high given the maximum sentence of life imprisonment. The court found the following mitigating factors: 1) guilty pleas; 2) the event was not planned in advance, it was prompted by alcohol use; 3) the assault was serious but brief; 4) the accused were all employed and contributing members of society; 5) the accused all accepted responsibility for the offence; and 6) the accused all complied with strict release conditions for three years. The aggravating factors were: 1) s. 348.1 of the Criminal Code was applicable to all accused even though their level of participation differed; 2) they entered the victim’s residence by breaking a window; 3) the crime was intense; 3) two of three accused had weapons and used them on the victim; and 4) the victim had some lasting injuries from losing three to four teeth. The court was prepared to extend leniency to the accused; however, some period of incarceration was found necessary to meet the objectives of deterrence and denunciation. column2: HELD: The order was granted. Following the expiry of the current temporary order, the court found that the children were in need of protection pursuant to s. 11 of The Child and Family Services Act. As the father had taken no steps to deal with his anger, violence and alcohol issues, the children continued to be in need of protection as they were likely to suffer physical harm at his hands. Their psychological well-being required that they remain in protection to allow them to deal with the trauma they had suffered while they were in his care. Therefore, the court found that because the children were doing well in foster care and did not wish to be returned to their father and that the expert had advised against them having any further contact with him, it would make a permanent order rather than a long-term order.

column2: The respondents applied for a declaration that the intensive livestock operation being constructed by Kelvington (KSS) was a development pursuant to s2(d) of the Environmental Assessment Act (EAA) and sought an order for mandamus compelling KSS to conduct an environmental assessment as required by s9 of the EAA. Yellow Quill First Nation applied for intervenor status. The trial judge found, without giving reasons, that the project was a development as defined in the Environmental Assessment Act and the application for mandamus was adjourned sine die. HELD: The appeal was granted and the order set aside without costs. 1)The proposal was not a development as defined in s 2(d) of the EAA. The Department of Agriculture, the Department of the Environment and Resource Management were of the opinion that the KSS project was not a development as defined in the Act as it did not come within any of the criteria listed in s2(d). 2)The Environmental Assessment Branch was of the opinion that no significant impacts on the environment would occur or if they do, mitigation measures would be implemented to reduce or eliminate the potential for significant environmental impact.  3)It was not necessary to decide whether Yellow Quill or the respondents had standing to privately enforce a public right. 4)In light of the decision the following were not in issue: whether the respondent should have applied by way of judicial review in the nature of certiorari; the relationship between the Environmental Assessment and Agricultural Operations Act; and whether a proponent of an intensive livestock operation can be required to make an application under the Agricultural Operations Act and to carry out an environmental impact assessment under s9 of the EAA.
column3: The respondents applied to the Court of Queen's Bench by notice of motion for a declaration that the intensive livestock operation being constructed by Kelvington Super Swine Inc. (KSS) at Kelvingtons is a development pursuant to s. 2(d) of The Environmental Assessment Act. The respondents also requested an order for mandamus compelling KSS to conduct an environmental assessment of the development as required by s. 9 of the Act. KSS applied for intervenor status. The chambers judge granted the application without costs. The court found that the proposal was not a development as defined in s.2(d). The respondents deposed that the operation would turn over hogs three times a year and produce up to 14.7 million gallons of liquid manure per year. HELD: The appeal was granted. 1)The court found the proposal not a developing as defined by s2(D) of the Environmental Assessment act. 2)The respondent's affidavits were not sufficient to establish that the project was a development. 3)The respondents' affidavits filed on behalf of the respondents and the intervenor revealed no disagreement on the essential underlying facts. 4)The applicant's affidavit were not confined to facts as the respondent was not able to prove on their own that the applicant's affidavit evidence was based primarily on information and belief. 5)The Court found that KSS was not developing as a development under the Environmental assessment Act.  6)The petitioner's affidavitts were not examined in their entirety and the court did not rule on the admissibility of the evidence. 7)The affidavit evidence did not establish that K SS was developing as per s2.d of the Assessment Act and therefore the Court was not entitled to grant intervenor rights. 8)The affidavits did not prove that the application was a proper development as the applicant had not obtained the required permits. 9)The environmental assessment was conducted under existing regulations and controls and no secondary developments were required. The petitioner's affidavit was not sufficient for the Court to determine whether the applicant has standing to privately enforce a public right. The Court found the petitioner had not shown that the petitioner's sworn affidavit evidence indicated that the respondent's affidavit material was not inadmissible. The respondent's sworn affidavits do not establish a public interest in the petitioner. 10)The issue was whether the petitioner has standing. The issue was the adequacy of the affidavit evidence. The affidavit evidence is sufficient to show that the petition was made after it had conducted a review of the environmental

column2: The Minister sought numerous orders for production of medical and various other files (including the mother's complete medical files from her family physician, the Nova Scotia Hospital and another hospital, and her files from a woman's shelter and an addiction treatment and prevention service) in an ongoing child protection proceeding. The mother argued that the records sought were irrelevant and that if there was any relevance, they were privileged, were unnecessary to the fair disposition of the proceeding, and their production would not save costs and would be injurious to the public interest. The addiction prevention and treatment service, Nova Scotia Hospital and mental health clinic records and files are ordered to be produced; the medical records of the family physician, the hospital and the woman's shelter are not ordered to be produced as these files would contain some irrelevant information and the relevant information could be obtained by other means. In a child protection proceeding, documents may be relevant to prove a protection finding, to monitor compliance with existing orders, or to develop and evaluate a plan of care. Records held by individuals or organizations to whom an individual has been referred as a result of a child protection proceeding are not privileged as no confidentiality could be expected in those circumstances. Records held by individuals or organizations whose services were accessed independent of a court order or the Minister's involvement that would ordinarily attract privilege may be ordered to be produced in child protection proceedings. However, if the information contained in the records can be obtained by a means targeted specifically to produce the relevant information, then orders for production for all of the records will not be necessary to the fair disposition of the proceeding. Also, since such records contain irrelevant, as well as relevant material, such an order would violate the privacy protections found in the Charter and be injurious to the public interest.
column3: The applicant sought 13 Orders of Production for documents prepared by and in the possession of the respondent's family physician. The respondent consented to the grant of an order for the file and records of her treatment with the Addiction Prevention and Treatment Services. The Minister requested the documents to be produced. The applicant argued that this was a low threshold for a protection proceeding under the Children and Family Services Act. The court found that the Minister had an obligation to investigate any and all information regarding child protection concerns. The Court found that this obligation was met because the respondent had not participated in previous child protection proceedings. The order for production was not necessary to ensure the proper disposition of the proceeding. The documents produced were not necessary for the purpose of monitoring compliance with the order. The application of Rule 69 was dismissed. The Rule 69 rule does not assist in the interpretation of Rule 74. The degree of protection given by the Rule 69 may be absolute or partial depending on what is required to strike the proper balance between the interest in protecting the communication from disclosure and the interest of the Minister to develop and evaluate an appropriate plan of care. The records are not relevant to the proceeding and the court has no authority to prevent disclosure of that information.

The order for production was not necessary because it was a formalistic classification of the nature of the proceedings and the court did not accept the proposition that the Ontario legislation specifically provides the threshold for the determination of relevancy.

column2: The Department of Community Resources (DCR) seeks orders pursuant to The Child and Family Services Act (the Act) placing CS with the Department until age 18 pursuant to s. 37(2) and JS with his grandmother as a Person of Sufficient Interest pursuant to s. 37(1)(b). The parents do not oppose the applications with respect to JS and EK but the mother seeks the return of CS to her care. KS will attend any session at Alternatives to Violence arranged for by DCR. 1) The Court was satisfied that the children were exposed to domestic violence or severe domestic disharmony. 2) Matters did not move quickly once the children were placed in the care of DCR. column3: The Department of Community Resources sought orders pursuant to The Child and Family Services Act placing the respondent with the Department until age 18 but in view of the respondent's stated intention to return to his parents' home on his 16th birthday, which was granted at trial. The respondent did not attend the pre-trial or the trial although he and the respondent were cohabiting. The appellant did attend the trial and the notice of the application. The petitioner did not appear at the pre trial or the proceeding. The court reviewed the evidence and found that the respondent had not shown any signs of mental or emotional distress. The evidence was that the child had been in the presence of his parents for several days and that he had been exposed to a lot of drugs and alcohol. The Court found that there was no evidence that the appellant had been involved in any violence. The child was placed in the care of the Department for three months. The Department of Child andFamily Services sought an order placing the appellant with the respondent until age 16 pursuant to s. 37(2) of the Act. The parties agreed that the Court would consider the best interests of the child and that the best interest of the children was to have them remain in the custody of the Minister until the age of 18. The applicant did not oppose the applications in respect of the appellant and the petitioner but sought the return of the petitioner. The children were placed with the appellant until age 17 pursuant to the Child and Child Services Act. HELD: The Court held that the application was not supported by the evidence. The application was dismissed. The matter was set to be reviewed and the trial date was fixed. The mother was to give 60 days notice of her appointment. The father was to provide counsel to the court. The judge ordered that the children remain in their care until the time of their 18th birthday. The order was made to ensure that the court would consider all the factors that the applicant had to say in the application and that it would be appropriate to include in the order the respondent was to be supervised. The Children were placed in their custody until the expiry of period of 1 year. The trial judge ordered the return the respondent to her care. The issue was whether the Court should consider the appellant's best interests in the best circumstances. The issues were whether the respondent should be placed in a foster home or in a Departmental foster home. The imputed costs of the court's application were $1,000. The costs of providing the respondent a reasonable accommodation.
column4: [1] The Department of Community Resources (“DCR”) seeks orders pursuant to The Child and Family Services Act, S.S. 1989-90, c. Instead of working with DCR to ensure a smooth reintegration of the children into their home, [T.K.] and [K.S.] vacated their apartment, moved to Alberta for a while, lived in a series of motels, camped at [S.K.]’s apartment building and even lived in a tent. During that period of time, some of which encompassed the trial, I am not satisfied that there was an adult person who was willing and able to provide for the children’s needs. [111] I am satisfied that there is a reasonable prospect of change within a reasonable period of time, and that changes have already occurred. ORDERS [118] I find that [J.S.] is in need of protection and that he shall be placed with [S.K.] for an indefinite period. [J.S.] shall not be returned to live with [T.K.] or [K.S.] by [S.K.] without a further order of the Court. [119] I find that [C.S.] is in need of protection and that she shall remain in the custody of the Minister for a period of three months. During that time [T.K.] and [K.S.] shall work co-operatively with and communicate with DCR to develop a case plan for [C.S.]’s return. [T.K.] will have a mental health assessment as arranged for by DCR or by her family doctor and will follow any recommendations of the mental health professional.

column8: The Department of Community Resources sought orders pursuant to The Child and Family Services Act placing the respondent with the Department until age 18 but in view of the respondent's stated intention to return to his parents' home on his 16th birthday, which was granted at trial. The respondent did not attend the pre-trial or the trial although he and the respondent were cohabiting. HELD: The respondent was found not to be in need of protection. The court ordered the respondent to remain with the respondent until age 16 pursuant to s. 37(1)(b) of the Act and ordered that the respondent return to her care. 1) The respondent's conduct was not supported by the evidence. 2) There was insufficient evidence to support a finding of mental or emotional harm to the respondent. 3) The evidence did not support the respondent’s claim that he was hit three days out of seven. 4) The petitioner did not oppose the applications in respect of [J.S.] and [E.K.] but sought the return of [C.S.]. 5) The court found that there was no evidence of a breach of any of the provisions of s. 11(a)(i) and s. 33(2) of this Act. The evidence was that the parties had been in contact for several months prior to the apprehension and that the petitioner had not shown any signs of mental illness. 6) The children were placed in the care of the Department. The petitioner was found to have sufficient interest in [J.'s] mother. The Court ordered that all three children remain in the custody of the Minister until age 19. The applicant did not object to the application in any event. 7) The Court found that the child was not in the best interests of the petitioner and that she did not want the children to be separated. 8) The child was placed with the petitioner in the home of her grandmother. 9) The parties were placed with each other in the foster home. The children had been placed with their mother in the absence of any evidence of mental health problems to support her decision to stay with the child. The parties had a relationship that was not recognized by the Court. The child had been exposed to harmful interaction for sexual purposes. The appellant did not appear to be a party to the proceedings. 10) The mother was given leave to take further steps to obtain counsel. The father was given time off. 11) The Children were placed under the supervision of the Provincial Child and Youth Services Department.

column2: This appeal arises from a dispute between the appellant, Dr. Huerto and the respondent Government of Saskatchewan, over the payment for medical services provided by Dr. Huerto to his patients. Over a period of approximately 10 years, the Government withheld payment in relation to what eventually amounted to some 12,000 of the appellant's accounts. The Government indicated through the use of a billing code, that the accounts would not be paid until further information was provided. The appellant believed the use of the billing code was unlawful and chose not to provide additional information. He started an action in the Court of Queen's Bench to compel payment of his accounts. His claim was largely dismissed on the basis that the action was premature. The appellant appeals from the Queen's Bench ruling and the Government cross-appeal in relation to the limited aspect of the case in which Dr. Huerto enjoyed success. HELD: Appeal and Cross-appeal dismissed.  1) Section 17(1)(c) of The Saskatchewan Medical Care Insurance Act is to the effect that the intention and purpose of the Act is not to establish a medical care insurance plan under which 'the exercise of professional judgment by physicians is in any way diminished'. This broad statement of principle should not be read so aggressively as to mean the Government, as the payor in a publicly funded health care system, has no right to ask questions about the accounts presented for payment by physicians. The Government has not denied payment of the appellant's accounts. Nor has it received the requested information from the appellant. The actions (the Protocol) taken by the Government cannot be characterized as an amendment of the Payment Schedule. The Protocol is an administrative tool which sets out the situations in which the appellant will be asked for further information about the provision of specific services. This is fully in line with the terms of the Schedule. 2) Section 5(1) of the Regulations should not be read as meaning the Government is entitled to ask for additional information about a service if, and only if, the nature of the service is 'unusual'. Rather, it simply stipulates that additional remarks must be included in an account rendered with respect to an unusual service. This does not imply the government can request extra information only in relation to an unusual service. A physician's obligation to include certain material in an account and the Government's authority to ask for additional information are ultimately two quite different things. 3) The Court does not accept that the appellant's claims were barred by s. 16(1) of the Act. It would be perverse to read the Act as requiring that, in order for an account to be paid, every bit of information demanded by the Government through the use of a billing code, or otherwise, must be supplied before the expiration of the 6 month period established by the Regulations. An account submitted the day before the expiration of the 6 month deadline would be voided by the application of the billing code. An account submitted well in advance of the expiration of the 6 month period would also be effectively denied if a request for further information was not made until at or near the end of the six month time limit, with the result that there was insufficient time for a physician to respond before that limit was exceeded. These potential problems are especially troublesome because there is an element of subjectivity in the application of the Protocol and even the most diligent physician might not accurately anticipate when an account or accounts will attract a request for extra comment. 4) The Court cannot accept the Government's submission that the trial judge should have declined to deal with the appellant's claim because the appellant had not fully pursued possible appeals to the Medical assessment Board. The Legislature in s. 40(3) of the Act has expressly provided that the appeal procedure established pursuant to the Act does not prejudice a physician's right to pursue matters in the courts. It stands entirely at odds with the notion that the appeal procedures in the Act should be read as being comprehensive and exhaustive.

column8: HELD: The appeal was dismissed and the cross-appeal dismissed. Both the appeal and the appeal must be dismissed. The principles of the Protocol and the Government's use of the AU code were not inconsistent with the standard procedure. The Protocol was designed to facilitate the payment of physician services and, in appropriate situations, to facilitate payment of accounts, not to deny or frustrate their payment. column18: This appeal arises from a dispute between the appellant and the respondent, Government of Saskatchewan, over the payment for medical services provided by Dr. Huerto to his patients. Over a period of approximately 10 years, the Government withheld payment in relation to what eventually amounted to some 12,000 accounts. He commenced an action in the Court of Queen's Bench to compel payment of his accounts. With one exception, the claim was dismissed on the basis that the action was premature. HELD: Appeal dismissed and cross-appeal dismissed. Both the appeal and the appeal must be dismissed. 1) The principles of the Protocol and the Government's related use of the AU code are invalid because they amount to an attempt to regulate his pattern of practice. Such matters, according to the appellant, can only be addressed through a JMPRC established pursuant to s. 49.2 of the MCIA. 2) There are situations where the Government has the right to ask for additional information before agreeing to pay an account. In this case, the Protocol is best characterized, perhaps among other things, as means by which MCIB, on behalf of the Government, can request further information in circumstances where there are concerns about the relationship between the service covered by an account and other services. 3) The Protocol is obviously an individualized administrative process. However, do not accept the argument that it is a payment schedule uniquely applicable to the physician.

column2: The young person appealed his sentence on an aggravated assault conviction following a drive-by shooting and applied for release pending appeal. Although he alleged that he would suffer unnecessary hardship if kept in custody because he would fall behind in his schoolwork, prior to being remanded the youth had been asked to leave his high school as a result of safety concerns in the school. Application for release pending appeal dismissed. The young person would not suffer unnecessary hardship as he was able to attend high school classes several times per week in the youth facility while he awaited his appeal and, even if his appeal was successful, he would only have served four months custody before it was heard. Given the circumstances of the aggravated assault and his record of violent offences and numerous breaches of court orders, the court was not persuaded that the youth's release would be in the public interest.
column3: The accused, a 16 year old, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault contrary to s. 268(1) of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to 365 days, comprised of 243 days custody followed by 122 days supervision in the community. Prior to being remanded, the accused was not attending school because he had been asked to leave the high school he had previously attended as a result of concern for his and other students' safety after threats had been made against him. The accused appealed his sentence and applied for release pending appeal. Application for release on appeal dismissed. The Court found that the accused had not satisfied the onus on the appellant under s. 679(4)(a) of s. Criminal Code to be much more stringent than for an appeal against conviction. The court found that given the circumstances of the offence, his record of violent offences, and numerous breaches of court orders, the appellant's release would be in the public interest. The onus was on the respondent under s679(5)(a), s. 109(1), s(2) of S. 678 to establish whether an appeal is sufficiently meritorious that, by the time his appeal is heard, he will likely already have served more than what is determined to be a fit sentence and thereby suffer undue hardship if he is not released. The appellant had not met the on-us requirement that he be released pending appeal, given the serious nature of the offences here, the principles of the Y.C.J.A. and the reasons for sentence given by Judge Campbell, the general reluctance of this Court to interfere with youth sentences unless it is clearly excessive or based on wrong principles. The appeal was dismissed.
column4: Held: Application for release pending appeal is dismissed Decision: [1] J.E.S., aged 16, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault contrary to s. 268(1) of the Criminal Code. J.E.S. has appealed his sentence and applies for release pending appeal pursuant to s. 679 of the Criminal Code. [13] J.E.S. says in his affidavit that he will suffer unnecessary hardship if kept in custody until his appeal is heard because he will fall behind in his schoolwork and be unable to complete his high school education in a timely fashion. Prior to being remanded, J.E.S. was not attending school because he had been asked to leave the high school he had previously attended as a result of concern for his and other students’ safety after threats had been made against him. The appellant has not satisfied me that his appeal is sufficiently meritorious that, by the time his appeal is heard, he will likely already have served more than what is determined to be a fit sentence, and thereby suffer undue hardship if he is not released. column27: The accused, a 16 year old, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault contrary to s. 268(1) of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to 365 days, comprised of 243 days custody followed by 122 days supervision in the community. Prior to being remanded, the accused was not attending school because he had been asked to leave the high school he had previously attended as a result of concern for his and other students' safety after threats had been made against him. The accused appealed his sentence and applied for release pending appeal. Application for release on appeal dismissed. The Court found that the accused had not satisfied the onus on the appellant under s. 679(4)(a) of s. Criminal Code to be much more stringent than for an appeal against conviction. The court found that given the circumstances of the offence, his record of violent offences, and numerous breaches of court orders, the appellant's release would be in the public interest. The onus was on the respondent under s679(5)(a), s. 109(1), s(2) of S. 678 to establish whether an appeal is sufficiently meritorious that, by the time his appeal is heard, he will likely already have served more than what is determined to be a fit sentence and thereby suffer undue hardship if he is not released. The appellant had not met the on-us requirement that he be released pending appeal, given the serious nature of the offences here, the principles of the Y.C.J.A. and the reasons for sentence given by Judge Campbell, the general reluctance of this Court to interfere with youth sentences unless it is clearly excessive or based on wrong principles. The appeal was dismissed.

column2: The accused plead guilty to two counts of sexual assault. The victims were his granddaughters. The assaults were alleged to have occurred between 1983 and 1991. A sentencing hearing was held because there was significant disagreement on the facts. The Crown alleged three aggravating factors: 1) that the sexual assaults were numerous, 2) that the accused touched the victims directly on their skin and not just on their clothing and 3) that there was digital penetration by the accused on both victims. HELD: At a sentencing hearing, the Crown must prove aggravating factors beyond a reasonable doubt. The Court held that the two victims were sexually assaulted by the accused on numerous occasions over a period of a number of years. The Court was satisfied these sexual assaults were a common occurrence on every occasion that the accused was in the company of his granddaughters. The Court found that the accused touched the victims under their clothing on numerous occasions and that there were a couple of occasions that the accused digitally penetrated each victim. Finally, the Court concluded that the accused got bolder over time and took more liberties and chances with his victims.
column3: The accused was charged with committing sexual assaults on two young girls. The Crown alleged that the accused touched the victims' skin and touched their genitals, and that there was digital penetration. The accused admitted to touching the victims under their clothes. The evidence of the victims was sufficiently credible to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that digital penetration occurred. The Court concluded that the sexual assaults were frequent occurrences and that the offences were repeated. The court concluded that these sexual assaults occurred on every occasion the accused was in the company of the girls.
column4: [1] Leopold Therrien is charged as follows: that between January 1, 1983 and December 31, 1991, at Willow Bunch, Saskatchewan, and Regina, Saskatchewan, and Winnipeg, Manitoba, did commit sexual assaults on Leanne Eger contrary to provisions of the Criminal Code. [17] From all of the evidence, I am satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that both victims were sexually assaulted by Mr. Therrien on numerous occasions. I am satisfied that these sexual assaults were a common occurrence on every occasion Mr. Therrien was in the company of the girls. [33] Again, I am satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that Mr. Therrien touched Nicole and Leanne under their clothing on many occasions. The evidence of the victims is sufficiently credible to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that digital penetration occurred. [51] I conclude that the accused got bolder as time passed and took more liberties and chances.

column2: The appellant appealed his conviction under s. 253(2)(b) of The Traffic Safety Act for failing to provide his name, address, licence and registration at the scene of an accident. The appellant argued that he was unaware that an accident had occurred and argued that the trial judge's finding that he must have known the accident had occurred was contrary to the evidence. The appellant also argued that the trial judge erred in preferring the evidence of the Crown's witness over his own. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The trial judge gave sufficient reasons for her decision and took all of the relevant evidence into consideration. She was entitled to assess the credibility of the independent witness and to prefer it over the evidence of the appellant.
column3: The appellant appeals against conviction and sentence of a fine and a $50 victim surcharge made by Justice of the Peace on the charge under s253(2)(b) of The Traffic Safety Act. HELD: The appeal is granted. 1) The trial judge gave sufficient reasons for her decision and took into consideration all of the relevant evidence and the law in reaching her decision.  2) The appellant appeals. The trial court gave no articulable reason to prefer the confused and contradictory evidence of the independent witness to that of the appellant. The verdict is unreasonable, the appellant argues, since he had no duty to report an accident which he did not know had happened prior to returning from the store.  3) The respondent submits that the reasons of the trial judge are sufficient, pointing to her assessment of credibility of the credibility of that of that individual to that that of her. 4) The court gave sufficient reason to award the evidence of 'the independent witness' over the clear evidence of appellant.
