column8: The appellant appeals against a conviction and sentence of $200.00 fine and $50 victim surcharge made by Justice of the Peace on the charge under s253(2)(b) of The Traffic Safety Act. HELD: The appeal is granted. 1) The trial judge gave sufficient reasons for her decision and took into consideration all of the relevant evidence and the law in reaching her decision.  2) She was entitled to assess credibility of the independent witness and the appellant, deciding to prefer the evidence of the appellant over the clear evidence to that of the complainant. The verdict is unreasonable, the appellant argues, since he had no duty to report an accident which he did not know had happened prior to returning from the store.  3) The respondent submits that the reasons of the trial judge are sufficient, pointing to her assessment of credibility and the independent witnesses to the appellant and supporting the finding by the trial court that the appellant did have knowledge of the accident before entering the store; 4) The court did not rely upon the testimony of any witness that was inherently improbable, and she applied the correct burden of proof, beyond reasonable doubt, in reaching the verdict.

column2: The appellant mortgagee appealed a chambers decision denying it a deficiency judgment on the basis the application was not made within the time limit set out in the Civil Procedure Rules. The appellant had relied on a prothonotary's order extending the time to apply for a deficiency judgment, which the prothonotary did not have authority to give. Allowing the appeal, setting aside the chambers decision and giving judgment to the appellant. While the prothonotary did not have jurisdiction to extend the time for the application, an additional chambers order had resolved the timeliness issue in the appellant's favour.
column3: The appellant mortgagee sought a deficiency judgment against the respondent, Bezanson, a guarantor of covenants of a mortgage given by Seawood Enterprises Ltd. to Prenor. The mortgage fell into arrears and Prenors commenced foreclosure proceedings against the respondents. The respondent commenced foreclosure action against the appellant in 1990 against Seaweed, the respondent and one Claes, another guarantor. Preno failed to obtain a proper listing price and the plaintiff sued for breach of contract. The appellant sought a judgment against all three defendants. The plaintiff brought a claim for a deficiency against the prothonotary, which had jurisdiction to grant an order for a hearing on the matter. The prothonian did not have jurisdiction to extend the time within which an application for a a deficiency judgement could be made. The order made on May 19, 1992 conclusively resolved the issue of the timeliness of Pren's application for the deficiency judgment. The application was dismissed with costs to the respondent. HELD: The appeal was allowed. 1)The prothoner did not exercise jurisdiction to award an order purporting to extend time within the time in which an applicant for a deficient judgment could be granted. However, the order made in May 19 conclusively resolving the issue. 2)The order made by the prothalonotry in May 1991 did not resolve the issue as to the timiness of the appellant's application. 3)The court was not at arm's length. It is not disputed that the pro-thonotheary did not grant the order of October 17, 1991 purportingto extend the period within which a deficiency application could be allowed. However the order was not one which the protheotary had power to give. The orders made in the May 19 order did not deal with the issue at all.
column4: THE COURT: The appeal is allowed as per reasons for judgment of Chipman, J.A.; Clarke, C.J.N.S. and Matthews, J.A., concurring. The appellant Prenor is a mortgagee which unsuccessfully sought a deficiency judgment against the respondent, Bezanson, a guarantor of the covenants of a mortgage given by Seawood Enterprises Ltd. to Prenor. In the result, the application was dismissed with costs to the respondent. It is not disputed that the prothonotary did not have jurisdiction to grant the order of October 17, 1991 purporting to extend the time within which an application for a deficiency judgment could be made. However, I am of the view that the order made on May 19, 1992 conclusively resolved the issue of the timeliness of Prenor\'s application for a deficiency judgment. I would allow the appeal, set aside the order of the chambers judge and give judgment to Prenor against the respondent and the other two defendants for $186,386, together with interest at 6% from August 14, 1992, costs on the chambers application of $1,500 plus disbursements and costs of this appeal of $600 plus disbursements.

column2: The 53-year-old plaintiff suffered a neck injury (cervical dystonia) in a car accident. After undergoing treatment from 14 specialists, the plaintiff had little relief four years following the accident. He was rendered permanently disabled from all work for which he was trained and could no longer work the farm, sawmill or Christmas tree operation he had developed. Assessing non-pecuniary damages at $60,000. In assessing pecuniary damages, the court accepted the defendant's expert evidence which led to the conclusion the plaintiffs businesses were marginally profitable. The defendants were ordered to pay $30,000 as real, net loss of future income. The court approved a 5% capitalization rate as being appropriate where there was an eight year term to age 65. The plaintiff settled his future Section B benefits just before trial. The court rejected the defence argument that they were entitled to a credit for present value of those benefits which represented a figure over seven times the settlement figure. The defendants were only entitled to a credit for sums actually paid to the plaintiff. The court rejected the plaintiff's actuarial report as being late and in breach of Civil Procedure Rule 31.08.
column3: The plaintiff sustained a very serious neck injury in a motor vehicle accident. His automobile was struck in an intersection. He was driving. His wife was front seat passenger. The plaintiff was not injured. The defendant's solicitor had prepared a report for the plaintiff on the condition that the plaintiff would not recover from his injuries so as to be able to resume working at the same level as he had worked prior to the accident. The court rejected the report. The Court found that the defendant's report did not support the 10% growth rate on which the plaintiff based his estimate. The judge found that there was no evidence that the injuries were serious.
column4:
Mr. Corkum sustained a very serious neck injury in the mishap. His automobile was struck by the defendants' in an intersection. It was for all of these reasons that I rejected Ms. Gmeiner\'s report. Accordingly, in the circumstances, I am satisfied that the use of a net rate of interest (i.e. a real rate of return) of 5% per annum is reasonable in placing a value upon Mr. Corkum\'s future income loss, between now and the date he attains age 65. This graph shows that Mr. Corkum\'s operation is marginally profitable at the best of times; and, on average, has provided him with a net income of 4.6% to 5.2% of gross ‑ sales." For pain and suffering, past, present and future, and for loss of amenities and the permanent adverse impact on his quality of life I award Boyd Corkum non‑pecuniary damages of $60,000.00. I am confident that a higher discount rate should be used and I accept Brian Burnell\'s supplementary report dated June 12, 1992 where he expressed the opinion that it was appropriate to use "a net rate of interest" (i.e. a real rate of return) of 5% per annum in valuing Mr. Corkum\'s future income loss to age 65. Having sued, and settled, the defendants at least are given a credit for all benefits paid, including the amount negotiated as a lump sum. From this must be deducted
$126,658.00 (Exhibit 22, Schedule B) leaving a net loss of earnings to Mr. Corkum of $30,041.00 for which the defendants are liable. CONCLUSION The plaintiff will have judgment for the amounts ordered together with costs.

After undergoing treatment from 14 specialists, the plaintiff had little relief four years following the accident. He was rendered permanently disabled from all work for which he was trained and could no longer work the farm, sawmill or Christmas tree operation he had developed. Assessing non-pecuniary damages at $60,000. In assessing pecuniary damages, the court accepted the defendant's expert evidence which led to the conclusion the plaintiffs businesses were marginally profitable. The defendants were ordered to pay $30,000 as real, net loss of future income. The court approved a 5% capitalization rate as being appropriate where there was an eight year term to age 65. The plaintiff settled his future Section B benefits just before trial. The court rejected the defence argument that they were entitled to a credit for present value of those benefits which represented a figure over seven times the settlement figure. The defendants were only entitled to a credit for sums actually paid to the plaintiff. The court rejected the plaintiff's actuarial report as being late and in breach of Civil Procedure Rule 31.08.
column23: The plaintiff sustained a very serious neck injury in a motor vehicle accident. His automobile was struck in an intersection. Although he was not hospitalized and never required surgery for his injury, he was completely and permanently disabled for any type of employment for which he was suited by education, training or experience. The injuries were so severe that he often had trouble keeping his emotions in check. The plaintiff applied for leave to waive the clear requirements of C.P.R. 31.08. HELD: The Court rejected the plaintiff's report. It was for all of these reasons that the judge rejected the report. 1)The plaintiff's financial records show an aberation in 1986 when he bought the homestead and surrounding lands from his father. He was driving a truck and was not injured. His car was struck by the defendants' vehicle. 2)The court found that the plaintiff had not been properly trained in the field of real estate appraisal and had not made any separate determination as to the interest of the owner or lending agencies. It is inappropriate and unreasonable to project income of $47,000 per year, excluding furnishings, that in 1991 and 1992 there was no increase in the price of pulp. 3)The Court awarded the plaintiff $13,000 in damages.
column24:
Mr. Corkum sustained a very serious neck injury in the mishap. His automobile was struck by the defendants' in an intersection. It was for all of these reasons that I rejected Ms. Gmeiner\'s report. Accordingly, in the circumstances, I am satisfied that the use of a net rate of interest (i.e. a real rate of return) of 5% per annum is reasonable in placing a value upon Mr. Corkum\'s future income loss, between now and the date he attains age 65. This graph shows that Mr. Corkum\'s operation is marginally profitable at the best of times; and, on average, has provided him with a net income of 4.6% to 5.2% of gross ‑ sales." For pain and suffering, past, present and future, and for loss of amenities and the permanent adverse impact on his quality of life I award Boyd Corkum non‑pecuniary damages of $60,000.00. I am confident that a higher discount rate should be used and I accept Brian Burnell\'s supplementary report dated June 12, 1992 where he expressed the opinion that it was appropriate to use "a net rate of interest" (i.e. a real rate of return) of 5% per annum in valuing Mr. Corkum\'s future income loss to age 65. Having sued, and settled, the defendants at least are given a credit for all benefits paid, including the amount negotiated as a lump sum. From this must be deducted
$126,658.00 (Exhibit 22, Schedule B) leaving a net loss of earnings to Mr. Corkum of $30,041.00 for which the defendants are liable. CONCLUSION The plaintiff will have judgment for the amounts ordered together with costs.
column27: The plaintiff sustained a very serious neck injury in a motor vehicle accident. His automobile was struck in an intersection. Although he was not hospitalized and never required surgery for his injury, he was completely and permanently disabled for any type of employment for which he was suited by education, training or experience. The plaintiff had spent many days and weeks visiting the defendant's farm and mill to familiarize himself with the operations. The defendant's report purports to calculate the plaintiffs loss of income resulting from the injuries from the date of the accident until the normal retirement age of 65. HELD: The plaintiff's report was rejected. 1)It was for all of these reasons that I rejected the report. 2)The defendant's expert was qualified as an expert in the field of real estate appraisal. He had prepared the plaintiff's personal tax returns and financial statements since 1981. He was clearly quite familiar with the lands in this area. The only way for the plaintiff to increase revenue would be to either work harder or charge higher prices which would at least exceed inflation. 3)The plaintiff was not injured in the mishap. His injuries were so severe that he was unable to work any longer. He often had trouble keeping his emotions in check. 4)The court reviewed the financial records of the defendants and determined that the plaintiff had suffered a very severe neck injury. 5)The Court reviewed the expert's report and found that it was not a good fit to grant leave to waive the clear requirements of Rule 31.08.

column2: The appellant was convicted of operating a motor vehicle while impaired. His conviction was upheld on appeal to a summary conviction appeal court. This appeal was based on the argument the provincial court judge's decision failed to provide reasons for accepting the evidence of various witnesses, failed to make findings of credibility with respect to witnesses, and failed to comment on the credibility and evidence of the witnesses. The appellant complained the judge did not provide adequate reasons for the decision. Dismissing the appeal, that the decision was supported by the evidence. The court referred to R. v. Burns, [1994] 1 S.C.R. 656 at 664, where the Supreme Court of Canada held that if trial judges state their conclusions in brief, and these conclusions are supported by the evidence, the verdict should not be overturned merely because they fail to discuss collateral aspects of the case.
column3: The appellant was charged with operating a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol or drug. The Provincial Court Judge had reserved his decision and then found him guilty. The Summary Conviction Appeal Court Justice held that the trial judge had erred in law by entering a conviction when the form of Information before the Court was not bilingual in form. The appellant appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that the appellant's reasons for not disclosing his consumption of the drug to the police were not supported by the evidence.

column2: The applicants sought a stay of proceedings pending review of an arbitration award. The union had alleged the employer violated the collective agreement by the way positions for the rank of lieutenant were filled in the fire department two years prior. As a result of the arbitration award, several lieutenants were demoted to the rank of firefighter. Denying the stay, that (1) there was no arguable issue to be tried on appeal; (2) there was no evidence the applicants would suffer irreparable harm if the stay were not granted; (3) the balance of convenience weighed against the applicants; and (4) there were no exceptional circumstances.
column3: The union applied to have the arbitrator's award set aside. The union argued that the arbitrators had not acted in good faith and that the grievance was not in the category of irreparable harm. The employer had not provided sufficient detail to the union as to the extent that it had conducted promotional routines for the positions of lieutenants. The Union alleged that the employer had violated Article 23.01 of the collective agreement by the manner in which the employer conducted promotional routine for the position of lieutenant. The grievance was brought forward through arbitration pursuant to collective agreement between the parties. The unions alleged that this was an attempt to use inexperienced personnel. The arbitrator awarded the contract to the lieutenant who had elected to return to the rank of fire fighter and continue as such. The lieutenancy award was set aside and the union appealed. The appeal court held that the union's position was that only the suitability aspect of the testing procedure was being challenged. The court held the following: 1) the arbitration award was not set aside; 2) the union was awarded the award for 'gross loss of revenue' and the arbiter's award was for 'loss of profits'. The union's argument that the award was unreasonable and unjustified was dismissed. The Court held that as difficult as it is for these individuals who have done nothing wrong, that it is not in any category of 'parable harm'. The movement that might have been brought about if those who were demoted could not act as acting lieutenans and were required to return from the platoons in which they were, prior to being promoted, has not materialized and is not likely to materialize in any real measure until after this matter has been heard. The balance of convenience was not at issue.
column4: It seems to me that as difficult as it is for these individuals who have done nothing wrong, that it is not in the category of irreparable harm, and so I then turn to the balance of convenience. Then you come to the exceptional circumstances that would make it fit and just that a stay be granted in the case and I am unable to find exceptional circumstances of the nature that were found by Mr Justice Hallett. The end result therefore, is the decision of the court that the application must be dismissed.

Dismissing the appeal, that the arbitration decision was not in the best interests of the union and that the union members who had done nothing wrong were not in a category of irreparable harm. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The arbitrator's award was not within the range of what the union was entitled to. 2)The union's position was that it would not be able to use inexperienced personnel in an acting capacity until a new routine was devised. 3)Costs in the cause were reduced to $750.

column2: Members of the Association of Professional Engineers who were also SIAST employees challenged the statutory provisions and collective bargaining agreement whereby they were compelled to become members of the SGEU. In Queen's Bench it was held that the statutory provisions which created two bargaining units for institute employees and required certain employees to be union members did not violate s.2(d) of the Charter. Appeal dismissed
column3: The appeal of the decision to dismiss the appeal of Strickland v. Ermel must be dismissed. The case was put to the court prematurely, with the result that it was put on what was essentially hypothetical basis, and Charter decisions should not be made without sufficient factual base. There was no evidence put before the court that the appellants or any of them had yet suffered any adverse consequences as result of the impugned legislation, although proceedings were pending before the Labour Relations Board which might result in adverse consequences. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The Court of Appeal's reasoning was clear. There is some confusion as to the answers he gave to the questions posed in his judgment. In an addendum, he said the answer to question should be no. It seems clear that he was referring to question 5 rather than question 4. The result is the same, in any event. The appeal [from 1992 CanLII 7943 (SK QB), [1992] 6 W.W.R. 116] must be dismissal. 2)The appeal [again] must not be dismissed under double col. V. The respondents shall have their costs of the appeal under double-col. V, except the Attorney General who did not ask for costs.
column4: The appeal [from 1992 CanLII 7943 (SK QB), [1992] 6 W.W.R. 116] must be dismissed. Appeal dismissed.

column2: FIAT An application was taken under s.180(2) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act to set aside a bankrupt's discharge on the basis that it was obtained by fraud. A Queen's Bench Chambers Judge dismissed the application. This decision was appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The Court found no error in the trial judge's determination.
column3: The appeal, insofar as it is based on s. 180(2) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act may or may not apply to the judgment held by the appellants, must be dismissed because the judge found that the $300,000 discharge had not been obtained by fraud.

column2: The 46-year-old male plaintiff suffered damage to his knee, left ear and exacerbation of a back problem when his vehicle was struck by the defendant's vehicle. Finding the defendant solely at fault, that evidence from the accident reconstruction as to the angle of impact supported a conclusion the defendant was travelling faster than she realized and was inattentive. Damages were set as follows: impairment to hearing in left ear assessed at $8500, damage to left knee assessed at $2500. Exacerbation of a pre-existing back condition which produced consequences in the severe range was assessed at $31,500.
column3: The defendant was found to be in the driver's seat of the plaintiff's vehicle when he was stopped at the stop line at the intersection with Lower Harmony Road. The plaintiff had been travelling south on Lower Harmony when she first observed the defendant vehicle approaching from the left. The defendant had been driving south on Upper Harmony when he crested the hill and came into view at the junction with Lower Halle Road. He was travelling south when he stopped at a stop sign and then entered Lower Harmony. He had been traveling south on lower Harmony when the accident occurred. He claimed to have seen the defendant motor vehicle approaching him from the right. The evidence showed that the defendant had a probable higher rate of speed than he estimated and that he was not justified in entering the lane of opposing traffic. The onus was on the defendant to establish negligence on the part of the Plaintiff and establish negligence.
column4: Mr. Gibbs is a 46 year old married man. I conclude that Ms. Archibald's inattention, coupled with a probable higher rate of speed than she estimates, renders her solely responsible for this accident, and she was not justified in entering the lane of opposing traffic. I conclude in this case a reasonable award for the permanent hearing impairment suffered by Mr. Gibbs which will continue to be a source of concern, irritation and aggravation but where there is no evidence that it will lead to a total loss of hearing in his left ear or any acceleration of further loss of hearing in the left ear is the amount of $8,500.00. For past, present, and future limited pain suffering inconvenience interference with the amenities previously enjoyed by Mr. Gibbs I assess damages at $2,500.00. I conclude for nonpecuniary damages under this heading for his past, present and future pain and suffering, loss of amenities, interference with his active lifestyle et cetera a reasonable award of general damages is $31,500.00. The awards of general damages of $8,500.00, $2,500.00 and $31,500.00 will bear prejudgment interest at 2.5% from the date of the accident May 30, 1992, to date.

column13: HELD: The onus was on the defendant to establish negligence on the plaintiff to determine whether the plaintiff's inattention rendered her solely responsible for the accident, and she was not justified in entering the lane of opposing traffic. 1) The defendant was a 46 year old married man with three children. He was driving erratically when he first observed a motor vehicle approaching from the left side of the road. He had been travelling erratically for the past 3 years. Prior to the motor vehicle accident he had been experiencing low back pain about once per year. He suffered a concussion, hearing loss in his left ear, neck injury, knee injury and knee injury. The defendant suffered a broken ankle and suffered a fractured ankle. 2) The court found that the defendant's in-attention, coupled with a probable higher rate of speed than she estimates, rendered her the sole responsible for this accident. The court concluded that the negligence of the plaintiff was solely attributable to the defendant. 3) There was no evidence of a significant amount of head-on force. The evidence of the driver was that she was driving at a reasonable speed and did not slow down when she first observed the vehicle approaching the intersection. She did not brake to control her vehicle. 4) The evidence was that there was a slight change in the speed of the defendant vehicle from the right to the left of the vehicle. 5) The Court found that there would have been a significant increase in the crossing sight distance from the intersection to the point of impact.

column2: An application was brought under ss.58 and 59 of The Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act seeking approval for a proposal made by Gustafson Pontiac Buick. The proposal had received the necessary proportion of support from Gustafson's creditors. One unsecured creditor opposed the application. HELD: 1)Under s. 59(2), before it can approve a proposal, the Court must be satisfied; (a) that the terms are reasonable; (b) that the terms are calculated to benefit the general body of creditors; and (c) that the proposal is made in good faith. 2)In determining whether to approve a proposal, the court must consider not only the wishes and interests of creditors, but also the conduct and interests of the debtor, the interests of the public and future creditors and the requirements of commercial morality. 3)If, however, a large majority of creditors, i.e., substantially in excess of the statutory majority, have voted for acceptance of a proposal, it will take strong reasons for the court to substitute its judgment for that of the creditors. 4)Gustafson had met the criteria set out in the Act and the authorities referred to in Bankruptcy and Insolvency Law of Canada, and accordingly the proposal was approved.
column3: This was an application pursuant to ss.58 and 59 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act for the approval of a proposal made pursuant to s.50 of the Act by Gustafson Pontiac Buick Cadillac GMC Ltd. to its various creditors. The applicant opposed the application. HELD: 1) Generally Under s.59(2), the court before it can approve proposal must be satisfied that the terms are reasonable; (a) that the proposal is reasonable; and (b) that all monies payable to GM and GM and GAC, specifically those monies paid to GM, were properly approved by the creditors in accordance with s.54(2)(d) of the bankruptcy & Insolvention Act, or alternatively, that the proposals fail to treat all of the unsecured creditors equally. 2) The proposal is primarily calculated to benefit Prairie Security Fund and the guarantors of secured creditors of the corporation and not the general body of creditors. 3) The applicant is a separate class of unsecunds and, as that class did not approve the proposal, the proposal was not properly approved in accordance by the creditor in accordance s.60(2) of S.54.

column2: The young offender appealed his convictions contending an apprehension of bias on the part of the Youth Court Judge who made comments about the police and non-white accused. The Judge also wrote supplementary reasons after the appeal was filed. Allowing the appeal and ordering a new trial in front of a different trial judge, that there was no evidence before the Youth Court Judge as to the comments made. The court applied an objective test and concluded a reasonable apprehension of bias existed. Supplementary reasons should not be written without a request from the Court of Appeal.
column3: The appellant appealed his conviction on three counts of unlawful assault. The appellant argued that the trial judge based his decision on considerations which were not supported in the evidence. The trial judge did not admit the statement at trial and the appellant argued the trial Judge erred in not admitting it at trial. The appeal court held that the appellant's reasons for the assault were not valid and that the judge had erred by not admitting the statement. The Appeal Court held that this was not the trial court's decision and that it was not appropriate to issue supplementary reasons. The Crown argued that it had not received any material from the trial judges prior to the release of the Supplementary Reasons. column2: Guardian was the general liability insurer for Kellogg. Royal was the primary insurer as holder of Kellogg's blanket fleet coverage. Kellogg's employee was involved in a motor vehicle accident while on company business but was driving his wife's vehicle at the time of the accident. Royal denied coverage and refused to defend on the basis of an exclusionary provision regarding the use of substitute automobiles. It was held at trial that Royal was not obligated to participate. HELD: 1)The case law reveals some inconsistencies with respect to the relationship between the duty to defend and the coverage provided by the policy. Where the policy clearly does not provide coverage, the insurer had no duty to defend. Where a policy only provides coverage for some allegations the insurer is only obligated to defend those allegations which may trigger the obligation to indemnify. When a policy is ambiguous some courts have adopted Thames and have stated the mere possibility that the policy may provide coverage is sufficient to oblige the insurer to defend. 2)Section 209 provides no guidelines as to the scope of the inquiry the judge may engage in. The chamber judge did not define the scope of his inquiry and stated that the standard suggestion that Guardian must raise an arguable point was 'off target'. To determine whether an insurer has the obligation to defend a chamber judge must examine the coverage provided by the policy. The judge made no finding of ambiguity in the exclusionary provision. He simply determined the Honda was not covered by the Royal policy and did not decide the issue of indemnity. 3)The affidavit evidence indicated that the parties lived in the same premises thus that argument was without merit. CONCURRING JUDGMENT: The appeal was dismissed for different reasons.  1)There has been an acceptance of the general concept that the duty to defend is broader than the duty to indemnify. To order an insurer to defend a chamber judge need be less sure the policy provides coverage than would be the case for an actual determination of liability under the policy. 2)There was a factual element which could not be determined on this application such as whether a partially deflated tire constitutes a breakdown within the meaning of the policy and whether the automobile the employee was driving was owned by someone living in the same dwelling. 3)The question centered around the words used in clause 5 of the policy and who it referred to. There were inconsistencies in terminology. The policy should not be interpreted as though the restriction it contains on what automobile can be used as a temporary substitute should be ignored.
column3: This appeal arises from an application for directions to determine whether Royal has an obligation to defend. On November 19, 1993, McLeod was involved in a motor vehicle accident. At the time of the accident, his wife's Honda was deflated. At issue was whether Royal was obligated to defend because the Honda involved was not insured by Royal. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The chambers judge found that the policy did not provide coverage for that which was alleged in the pleadings. The chambers judge did not define the scope of his inquiry. 2)The respondent was under no obligation to protect McLeod in the pending action.
column4: Appeal Dismissed: LANE J.A. This appeal arises from an application for directions made pursuant to s. 209 of The Saskatchewan Insurance Act ("the Act"), R.S.S. 1978, c.S-26. On November 19, 1993, McLeod was involved in a motor vehicle accident. At the time of the accident, McLeod was on company business and was driving his wife's Honda because his company car had a deflated tire. The application was heard by a Court of Queen's Bench judge in chambers who ruled Royal was not obligated to participate in defending the action "because the Honda involved is not insured by Royal". Therefore, Royal was under no obligation to defend McLeod in the pending action. Thus having embarked on a wide review of the policy the chambers judge concluded there was no ambiguity in the exclusionary provision. The appeal is therefore dismissed with costs on double Column V. In the result, the appeal is dismissed with costs on double column V.

column2: The accused, convicted of sexual assault, requested a non-custodial sentence pursuant to s742.1 of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was sentenced to 18 months in a provincial correctional institution. 1)It would be contrary to the administration of justice in view of the seriousness of the offence to allow the accused to serve his sentence within the community even though he appeared to satisfy the requirements of s.742.1(a) and (b) of the Code. There were numerous adverse impacts on the victim. 2)Mitigating circumstances included the absence of a criminal record; his abstinence from alcohol since the assault; the absence of penile penetration; his remorse and apology to the victim and to the court; his serious health problems; his ability to rehabilitate and the fact that he was a model citizen prior to the assault.
column3: The accused was convicted of sexual assault. The Crown sought a sentence of 1/2 to years. They indicated there was no prior romantic connection between the victim and the accused and that she pleaded with him not to do this. The accused suffered bruising and soreness from the incident. HELD: A non-custodial sentence was justified. The Court found that a sentence in a provincial correctional centre would seriously affect the accused's ability to rehabilitate. Taking all of the factors of sentencing into account, it was the sentence of the Court that it was sentenced to serve a term of 18 months in a Provincial correctional centre. Taking the factors into account it was a sentence that was served in a province correctional centre, as the accused was a model citizen until the offence and had voluntarily quit using alcohol. The sentence must be increased or decreased from the three year term based on the circumstances of the individual case. The court found that the sentence must not be in the range of three years. The victim was harassed and had her property damaged and was forced to go for counselling. The offence had grave consequences for the victim because some people appeared to treat her as the offender rather than the victim. The defence claimed the Crown failed to prove this assertion. The evidence showed the victim had lost her job, lost her position in the community and was ostracized in the town. The damage and vandalism had no connection to the offence. The only thing that could have been avoided was a lengthy sentence. The sentences imposed were to be served in provincial correctional facilities.
column4: [1] The accused has been convicted of sexual assault. [5] The accused refers to the new sections in the Criminal Code with respect to alternative measures of sentencing and requests that he be given a non-custodial sentence. [20] On the other hand, I cannot ignore the impact upon the victim. The following factors lead me to the conclusion that a lower sentence is justified in this case. 3. The accused was a model citizen until this offence; 10.A lengthy sentence will seriously affect the accused's ability to rehabilitate. [23] Taking all of the factors of sentencing into account, it is the sentence of this Court that you serve a term of 18 months in a provincial correctional centre. [24] Having imposed a custodial sentence of less than two years, I must now deal with s. 742.1 of the Criminal Code which permits the court to allow the accused to serve his term in the community. Therefore, the sentence must be served in a provincial correctional centre.

HELD: A non-custodial sentence was justified. 1)The accused had no prior criminal record. 2)The victim was harassed and had her property damaged and was forced to go for counselling. 3)A lengthy sentence would seriously affect the accused's ability to rehabilitate. The sentence must be served in a provincial correctional centre.

column2: This was an appeal from the decision of a chambers judge striking the appellant's Statement of Claim under Rule 25.01 for being outside the limitation period. The parties did not submit an agreed Statement of Facts. Allowing the appeal, that the chambers judge erred in proceeding with the application pursuant to Rule 25.01. Rule 25.01 requires that the parties file an agreed Statement of Facts, save in exceptional circumstances, such as one where the material facts are clearly not in dispute.
column3: This was an appeal from the decision of a chambers judge striking the appellant's Statement of Claim. The appellant and the respondent bank had been equal shareholders in a company that was based on a stockbroking agreement. The respondent bank sought to strike the statement of claim on the basis that it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The appeal was allowed with costs to the appellant in the amount of $350 and on the appeal in the amounts of $750 plus disbursements. The Chambers judge determined pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 25.01 that the action was statute barred and struck the statement.
column4: THE COURT: Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal allowed per oral reasons for judgment of Bateman, J.A.; This is an appeal from the decision of a chambers judge striking the appellant's Statement of Claim. In a thorough and thoughtful decision the Chambers judge determined, pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 25.01, that the action was statute barred and struck the Statement of Claim. Leave to appeal is granted. The appeal is allowed with costs to the appellant, on the Chambers application, in the amount of $350 and on the appeal in the amount of $750 plus disbursements. The Order of the Chambers judge striking the appellant's Statement of Claim is set aside.

column8: This was an appeal from the decision of a chambers judge striking the appellant's Statement of Claim. The action alleged conversion, breach of fiduciary duty and negligence by the Bank of Montreal. The respondents applied to strike the appellant on the basis that it disclosed no reasonable cause of action or for an order striking the statement of claim as being barred by the Limitation of Actions Act. HELD: Leave to appeal was granted and the appeal allowed. The Chambers judge determined pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 25.01 that the action was statute barred and struck the statement. Having done so, it was unnecessary for her to consider the application under Rule 14.25.

column2: HELD: 1)The officer was to answer any proper questions seeking his opinion on audit issues arising in the context of the Trust Company's records or files. To be proper the questions need only be broadly relevant to the issues raised in the pleadings in the sense that they are in some way connected to the allegations made. Hypothetical questions seeking his opinion consequent upon his professional experience could be asked where his and C&L's conduct were in issue. The officer's expert opinion could not be sought on matters not raised in the pleadings. 2)The disclosure and production of documents was justified under the broad relevance test. A party is entitled to discovery of a document if it directly or indirectly enables him to advance his own case or destroy that of his adversary or may fairly lead to a form of inquiry which may have either consequence. 3)The 'damage claim documents' had been provided. There should be a sameness in the manner and isolation of the documents in the discovery process undertaken by each party. Whether the memoranda of discussions with third parties were privileged or irrelevant was a matter for the trial judge. 4)The issue of compelling a response to undertakings had been resolved. 5)The request for an order for an immediate pre-trial conference was redundant as there was no basis for one until the action was ready for trial. 6)Leave to further amend the statement of claim pursuant to Rule 165 had been granted.
column3: FIAT. The chambers judge returned the plaintiff's notice of motion and granted an order directing the defendants to respond to undertakings given in the examination for discovery of Krake. HELD: The order was granted. There was no basis for a pre-trial conference until the action was ready for trial. The disclosure and production were justified under the 'broad relevance' test, and comported with the general principle that a party is entitled to discovery of documents or records if it directly or indirectly enables him to advance his own case or destroy that of his adversary, or may fairly lead to a form of inquiry.

column2: The primary issue was the appropriate parenting arrangement for the two children. The 1997 interim order awarded joint custody with the primary residence with the mother and reasonable access to the father including alternating weekends, reasonable telephone access and equal sharing of holidays. The father initially failed to pay child support as ordered then paid $250 per month rather than the $424.72 ordered. The parties no longer communicated directly with each other except by e-mail so that there was a record. HELD: 1)It was in the best interests of the children that their primary residence be with their mother. She had demonstrated greater flexibility and sensitivity to their needs. The father was granted access two weekends out of every three and additional time as they may agree upon. Although both were very good parents the parties had not demonstrated an ability to co-parent effectively as illustrated by their communication problems. The father's access initially went beyond the minimum required by the interim order. He failed to make support payments as ordered. The father was to pay child support of $449. Pursuant to s.7 of the Federal Child Support Guidelines he was to pay 54% of the net cost of child care expenses incurred as a result of the mother's employment and for health related expenses in excess of $100 of the insurance reimbursement upon production of receipts.  2)The automobile constituted matrimonial property and was valued at $200. 3)Either could speak to costs.
column3: The primary issue was the appropriate parenting arrangement for the two children. The petitioner was employed outside of the home throughout the marriage. The respondent lived in the matrimonial home. The parties were married for 22 years. During the first two months of the separation the children spent alternate weeks with each parent. During this time the petitioner was involved in the day-to-day care of the children. During their separation the respondent's access went beyond the minimum required by the interim order. The child was placed in the primary residence of the petitioner. The father was given reasonable telephone access with the children and access at other times as the parties may agree. The mother was prepared in the initial stages to be more flexible than the respondent and prepared to promote maximum contact. The court was satisfied that the petitioner's access was adequate and that the father was to have reasonable telephone contact with the child. The issue was whether the respondent was insistent upon things being done his way. The primary issue is whether the petitioner has the best interests of the child in mind. HELD: The parties agreed that the respondent should have more flexibility and that he was to provide the primary home. 1)The respondent was to pay the petitioner 54% of the net cost of child care expenses incurred as a result of the employment arrangement. 2)The parties were to have joint custody of the two young children. They were to provide primary residence. The Petitioner shall however provide the primary residence for the children. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the Respondent shall have reasonable access to include alternating weekends from Friday evening until Sunday evening, and in the event that the Respondent is not working on the Friday prior to such weekend or the Monday following such weekend, the access shall extend to include the extra day or days. The Respondent shall further have access on each Friday that is his earned day off that is not attached to his access weekend, except when such Friday is the Petitioner’s earned day off. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the Respondent shall have reasonable telephone access with the children and access at such other times as the parties may agree. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the paternal grandparents shall care for the two children two days per week to be such days that the child TRAVIS is not in pre-school, except in the event that either parent is caring for the children by reason of day off work. [21] I accept the characterization that these are both very good parents. [26] I find it is in the best interests of the children that their primary residence be with their mother. She has demonstrated a greater flexibility and sensitivity to their needs. [28] There will be an order as follows:

(a) The petitioner shall parent Travis and Jonathan, who shall reside with the petitioner, except during those times when the respondent shall parent the children;

(i) Two weekends out of every three weekends commencing Friday after work to Sunday evening. column2: The accused, Cote, applied for remedy pursuant to s.24 of the Charter of Rights stating that he was denied the right to be tried on a fraud charge within a reasonable time. Twenty-two months passed between the laying of the charge and the trial date. Cote was not responsible for the delay and actively pursued a speedy trial. The delay was caused by the Crown's failure to provide timely disclosure. HELD: The charge was stayed. In applying the decision of the SCC in R. v. Morin, the court found that 22 months is an unreasonable and exceptional period of delay and is of sufficient length to warrant an inquiry. This case had no particular complexity above the norm for cases of this kind and did not require this delay. column3: The accused was committed to stand trial on one count of fraud. He now applies to this court for a remedy pursuant to s. 24 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The application is based primarily on the accused's position that he has been denied the right to be tried on the fraud charge within a reasonable time. HELD: 1) The Court found that the accused had been denied a reasonable opportunity to be heard in a timely manner. 2) The length of delay in proceeding with the preliminary hearing was 8 months. 3) The Crown failed to make sufficient disclosure to the accused. 4) The court found that there was no evidence that the Crown had been negligent in failing to provide timely disclosure. 5) The accused's evidence was not accepted. 6) The evidence was examined. 7) The prejudice to the defendant has been substantial and sufficient to tilt the balance in favour of requiring a judicial stay. The Court was not satisfied that the inherent time requirements of the case require 22-month delay from charge to trial. 8) The fact that the defence failed to provide sufficient disclosure was not a sufficient reason to grant an application for a stay. 9) The trial judge was not able to determine whether the accused was prejudiced by the delay. The court was not convinced that the evidence was so compelling that it would be unreasonable to grant a stay of proceedings. The accused was not entitled to compensation for the delay and the Court was unable to determine if the Crown was negligent in making timely disclosure or not. The trial court was also not satisfied the inherent and temporal time requirements required by s. 11(b) of the Canadian Charter of rights and Freedom. The Crown was not responsible for the prejudice. 10) The amount of time between the preliminary and preliminary hearings was reduced to 2 weeks. The amount that the Court could reasonably expect to be paid to the defence was reduced by 2 weeks to allow the defence to make more detailed disclosure. The length was not unreasonable. The evidence did not support the inference that the delay was caused by the Crown's failure to provide proper disclosure. 11) The costs of the delay were not unreasonable and the prejudice was sufficient to tip the balance of the balance.

column18: HELD: The application was based primarily on the respondent's position that he has been denied the right to be tried on the fraud charge within a reasonable time. There was no dispute on the facts that just over 22 months had passed since the date of the first preliminary hearing and the scheduled trial date. The Crown conceded that the delay had been substantial and sufficient to tilt the balance in favour of requiring a judicial stay. The trial date was set for February 28, 2000 and the preliminary hearing was adjourned to March 2, 1999. A further oral request for disclosure was made at the first court appearance in May 1998 but was not received until later in the day on May 26 and too late to be reviewed prior to the scheduled court time on January 6, 2000. In the second preliminary hearing in June 1999, the Crown indicated that it would have full disclosure by the end of October but the delay was so severe that it was impossible for the respondent to prepare for the proceeding. The delay was attributed to the Crown's failure to provide timely disclosure to the defence.

column23: The accused was committed to stand trial on fraud charges. He now applies to this court for a remedy pursuant to s. 24 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The application is based primarily on the accused's position that he has been denied the right to be tried on the fraud charge within a reasonable time. There is no dispute on the facts that just over 22 months will have passed between the laying of the fraud charges and the scheduled trial date. The Crown concedes that the delay has not been caused by the delay. However, the prejudice occasioned by this delay outweighs the interest of society in bringing the accused to trial. HELD: 1) The accused has been unwavering in his desire for speedy trial. This fundamental principle is often overlooked by the public and especially in highly publicized cases where a public figure is involved. Where no inference as to prejudice can be drawn from the length of the delay, or where the most reasonable inference is the other way, the accused may have to call evidence if he is to displace the strong public interest in bringing those charged with an offence to trial to be established. The balancing of society's interest in requiring an accused to stand a trial and the right of him to trial within reasonable time is best achieved by examining whether the accused had been prejudiced. 2) In requesting an adjournment of the preliminary hearing on September 29, 1999, the Crown conceded that it had been unable to make timely disclosure. 3) The prejudice to the accused was substantial and sufficient to tilt the balance in favour of requiring a judicial stay.

column2: FIAT. An application for summary judgment under Part Forty. In issue was whether a solicitor is bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees. The defendant solicitor, who represented several farmers and farming companies in suits brought against Saskatchewan Crop Insurance Corporation on a contingency fee basis, confirmed in writing in 1993 that his office would undertake to protect the plaintiff consultants for their fees and disbursements and to pay interest at a rate of 12% per annum. The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed as a result of actions of SCIC. When all of the claims were dismissed at trial, the solicitor rejected the plaintiff's demand for payment arguing he had no obligation to pay as the farmers' actions had not resulted in the recovery of any monies. The plaintiff sued the solicitor in 1997 for professional fees of $37,604.33. The plaintiff objected to certain portions of the defendant's affidavit. HELD: The plaintiff was awarded $37,604.33 plus interest at 12% per annum as provided for in the undertaking, and costs of the action.  1)The plaintiff commenced its action under the general rules but amended its claim without objection to continue under the Simplified Procedure. 2)Portions of the defendant's affidavit were struck as being hearsay and opinion or related to matters immaterial to the proceeding.  3)The applicant's admissions at discovery did not confirm the interpretation of the undertaking set out in the statement of defence. It was obvious the plaintiff's officer recognized the farmers were intending to fund their costs from a settlement or judgment and that disbursements, including the costs of any expert's reports commissioned by them or the defendant, would be paid by his clients regardless of the outcome of the suits. 4)The only conclusion that could be drawn was that defendant guaranteed payment of the applicant's account regardless of the outcome of their mutual client's actions. A solicitor is presumed to know the cannons of the Law Society including c.XVI, comm.10 of the Code of Professional Conduct with respect to undertakings. The solicitor's undertaking in 1993 was absolutely clear. The addition of the word 'protect' put the question beyond doubt. His inquiry in 1997 made it clear the defendant recognized his responsibility and was hoping for some resolution of the applicant's account.
column3: FIAT. The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed resulted from the actions of the defendant. The defendant was employed by the farmers on contingency basis, the understanding being that the clients would pay the defendant's disbursements in any event. The plaintiffs' actions did not settle. The defendants' prospects were not encouraging. The farmers' prospects had not encouraging, and serious concerns about how long the action would take and the outcome of the litigation. The respondent's officer, Hamm, paid a deposit to the defendant for remittance to the plaintiff's account. The court was awarded judgment in favour of the plaintiff and the Companies' actions against the defendant, with interest. The applicant was awarded $10,000 in general and $20,000 interest. HELD: The court struck the respondent's affidavit as evidence of the respondent’s commitment to protect the plaintiff’ s account. It was not evidence of his willingness to accept personal responsibility. The portions of the affidavit were not evidence but hearsay and opinion. The addition of the word protect puts the question beyond doubt. The Court was also awarded $5,000.00 in interest.
column4: THE ISSUE [1] Is a solicitor bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees? I agree. They are struck.

column18: FIAT. The defendant represented several farmers and farming companies in suits brought against the Saskatchewan Crop Insurance Corporation (SCIC). The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed resulted from the actions of SCIC. At various times the plaintiff's officer met with the farmers and the defendant to discuss the case, the evidence and the strategies to be followed. The hope was that the provincial agency might settle before trial. The plaintiff agreed to defer payment of his account from the parties until the successful conclusion of the litigation with SCIC, provided he received interest on the amount outstanding to the plaintiff at rate of 12% per annum. The court was also struck with respect to portions of the examination for discovery which placed these statements in context. The respondent guaranteed the payment of the applicant's account regardless of the outcome of their mutual client's actions.
column19: THE ISSUE [1] Is a solicitor bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees? I agree. They are struck.
column22: FIAT. An application for summary judgment under Part Forty. In issue was whether a solicitor is bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees. The defendant solicitor, who represented several farmers and farming companies in suits brought against Saskatchewan Crop Insurance Corporation on a contingency fee basis, confirmed in writing in 1993 that his office would undertake to protect the plaintiff consultants for their fees and disbursements and to pay interest at a rate of 12% per annum. The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed as a result of actions of SCIC. When all of the claims were dismissed at trial, the solicitor rejected the plaintiff's demand for payment arguing he had no obligation to pay as the farmers' actions had not resulted in the recovery of any monies. The plaintiff sued the solicitor in 1997 for professional fees of $37,604.33. The plaintiff objected to certain portions of the defendant's affidavit. HELD: The plaintiff was awarded $37,604.33 plus interest at 12% per annum as provided for in the undertaking, and costs of the action.  1)The plaintiff commenced its action under the general rules but amended its claim without objection to continue under the Simplified Procedure. 2)Portions of the defendant's affidavit were struck as being hearsay and opinion or related to matters immaterial to the proceeding.  3)The applicant's admissions at discovery did not confirm the interpretation of the undertaking set out in the statement of defence. It was obvious the plaintiff's officer recognized the farmers were intending to fund their costs from a settlement or judgment and that disbursements, including the costs of any expert's reports commissioned by them or the defendant, would be paid by his clients regardless of the outcome of the suits. 4)The only conclusion that could be drawn was that defendant guaranteed payment of the applicant's account regardless of the outcome of their mutual client's actions. A solicitor is presumed to know the cannons of the Law Society including c.XVI, comm.10 of the Code of Professional Conduct with respect to undertakings. The solicitor's undertaking in 1993 was absolutely clear. The addition of the word 'protect' put the question beyond doubt. His inquiry in 1997 made it clear the defendant recognized his responsibility and was hoping for some resolution of the applicant's account.
column23: FIAT. The defendant represented several farmers and farming companies in suits brought against the Saskatchewan Crop Insurance Corporation (SCIC). The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed resulted from the actions of SCIC. At various times the plaintiff's officer met with the farmers and the defendant to discuss the case, the evidence and the strategies to be followed. The hope was that the provincial agency might settle before trial. The plaintiff agreed to defer payment of his account from the parties until the successful conclusion of the litigation with SCIC, provided he received interest on the amount outstanding to the plaintiff at rate of 12% per annum. HELD: The court found that the respondent was bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees. The court was also struck with respect to portions of the examination for discovery which placed these statements in context. The respondent guaranteed the payment of the applicant's account regardless of the outcome of their mutual client's actions. The addition of the word 'protect' puts the question beyond doubt. The Court found that these statements of account were all directed to the respondent.
column24: THE ISSUE [1] Is a solicitor bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees? I agree. They are struck.
column27: FIAT. The plaintiff was hired to provide technical evidence as to crop losses and damages the farmers claimed resulted from the actions of the Saskatchewan Crop Insurance Corporation (SCIC). The plaintiff's officer met with the farmers and the defendant to discuss the case, the evidence and the strategies to be followed. The hope was that the provincial agency might settle before trial. HELD: The court was struck with respect to the following portions of the affidavit: 1) The respondent guaranteed the payment of the applicant's account regardless of the outcome of their mutual client's actions. 2) The court had an opportunity to hear both parties in this action on evidence in chief and under cross examination. It was not an appropriate case under either the General Rules or Rule 488 (Simplified Procedure). 3) The portions of an affidavit are not evidence but hearsay and opinion. The addition of the word protect puts the question beyond doubt. The court is struck with regard to whether the solicitor is bound by an undertaking to protect an expert witness for its professional fees.

column2: The accused was charged with sexual assault under s.271 of the Criminal Code. Although the DNA evidence established he had sexual intercourse with the complainant, neither had any memory of it due to their self-induced states of intoxication. Defences raised were consent, an honest but mistaken belief that she gave her consent, and extreme drunkenness such that he was so intoxicated that he was not in a conscious state and was incapable of forming any intent to have sexual intercourse without consent. HELD: The accused was found guilty.  1)Although the defence of 'extreme intoxication' is successful in the rarest of cases, the accused established the Daviault 'extreme intoxication' on a balance of probabilities. He would have been acquitted had it not been for s.33.1 which does away with this defence in sexual assault cases.  2)The court was satisfied on a balance of probabilities that his extreme level of self-induced intoxication rendered him incapable of making a conscious decision to have sexual intercourse with the complainant with or without her consent. The court was satisfied that the complainant had not done anything to suggest that she would consent. The accused was incapable of considering the issue of consent and accordingly did not have a mistaken belief or reasonable grounds for such a belief. It was clear from the testimony of an 11 year old that the intercourse took place long after the complainant passed out. She was incapable of giving consent after that time. Her assertion of lack of consent was inherently unreliable due to her lack of any memory of events that occurred before, during and after the alleged assault and would have been more in the nature of an assumption than a fact, but was found to be consistent with all the other evidence. It was not relevant that she may have withdrawn consent. 3)There was no evidence to give his second defence (that he honestly believed he had her consent) an air of reality. His assertion that she must have consented or he would not have done it was speculative assumption, not evidence. 4)Section 33.1 provides that the act of becoming voluntarily intoxicated to the extent of being incapable of controlling one's behaviour constitutes criminal culpability sufficient to found criminal liability for offences committed against the bodily integrity of others. The public outcry and Parliamentary response to Daviault strongly indicate that s.33.1 is not only consistent with the objectives of the Charter but is justifiable and essential in a free and democratic society. Of four recent cases that held Criminal Code s.33.1 violates the Charter, two held it was saved by s.1 while two held it was not saved by s.1 of the Charter. 5)Section 33.1(1) provides the lack of general intent or voluntariness is not a defence to an assault charge described in ss.(3)if it resulted from self-induced intoxication or the accused departed markedly from the standard of reasonable care generally recognized in Canadian society. The three sub-conditions described in ss.(2) concerning marked departure constitute criminal culpability similar to recklessness. Criminal culpability is not dependent on wilful intention to cause harm but on the wilful intention to engage in conduct that incurs the risk of harm without caring whether or not harm ensues. 6)The strong dissent in Daviault indicated those who render themselves incapable of knowing what they are doing through voluntary consumption of alcohol or drugs possess a sufficiently blameworthy state of mind that their imprisonment does not offend the principle of fundamental justice which prohibits the imprisonment of the innocent. The court has broad discretion to differentiate in sentences imposed for offences that were deliberately committed and those that were committed involuntarily because of self-induced intoxication.
column3: The accused was charged with sexual assault pursuant to s. 271 of the Criminal Code. The DNA evidence established that the accused had sexual intercourse with the complainant. However, neither the accused nor the complainant had any memory of the sexual intercourse. The Court held that the evidence of the complainant was unreliable and that the trial judge failed to charge the jury with the defence of honest but mistaken belief in consent. The accused was acquitted on a balance of probabilities. The court reviewed the various cases and found that the defence was not saved by s. 1 of the Code. HELD: The accused's conviction was upheld on a trial on the basis that the Court had broad discretion to differentiate in sentences imposed for offences that were deliberately committed and those that were committed involuntarily because of self-induced intoxication. The defence of extreme drunkenness was successful in almost every case of intoxication that arose from drinking alcohol as beverage or abusing drugs. The only defence raised by the accused was that he honestly believed he had the consent of the person to have sexual intercourse; the Court held the accused's belief arose from self- induced intoxication and was not a reasonable inference. The evidence of his 11-year old son was inconsistent with the accused’s evidence. The conclusion that the self-inflicted intoxication of the accused and the complainant is caused by the automatic state arises from self induced intoxication is not a defence to an assault type of charge. The fact that the complainant’ s. 33.1 defence is not saved because it is not supported by the evidence.

column8: The accused was charged with sexual assault pursuant to s. 271 of the Criminal Code. Although the DNA evidence established that the accused had sexual intercourse with the complainant, neither the accused nor the complainant had any memory of the sexual intercourse that took place between them. HELD: The accused was found guilty. The Court of Appeal held that the defence of 'extreme drunkenness' was not saved by s. 1(1)(b) of the Code as it was not supported by the expert evidence tendered by the defence. The court found that the appellant had no honest but mistaken belief that the complainant consented to the sexual activity and that there was nothing to suggest that she would consent to the act. The evidence raised by the accused was that he was so intoxicated that he could not remember the events prior to his passing out. The accused's evidence was inconsistent with the testimony of the complainant and he never considered the issue of her consent or lack of it. In addition, the Court found that s. 33.1 now limits the availability of the extreme drunkenness defence.

column2: The Crown appealed the dismissal of charges of impaired driving and driving with a blood alcohol level exceeding .08. The trial judge held the circumstances supported a special plea of autrefois acquit and that the manner of proceeding by the Crown was an abuse of process at common law. Alberta did not withdraw or abandon the charges and suspended his driving privileges for 3 months. Upon request, SGI also suspended his Saskatchewan driving privileges. At issue was whether the Alberta court lost jurisdiction; if so, whether that gave rise to a plea of autrefois acquit in Saskatchewan; apart from any loss of jurisdiction did the police procedure amount to an abuse of process at common law. HELD: The Informations were stayed. The trial judge erred in finding a plea of autrefois acquit was applicable but was correct in concluding Alberta lost jurisdiction. 1)The Information remained dismissed for want of prosecution. Jurisdiction over the respondent was lost when the information was not available in the Alberta Provincial Court, the appearance notice was not confirmed and the matter could not be dealt with (R. v. McGinnis). The Alberta court could have regained jurisdiction by issuing a summons or warrant within 3 months of February 6, 2001. A summons was not issued until August. The information was by then deemed to have been dismissed for want of prosecution pursuant to s.485(3). 'Deemed' in s.485(3) does not mean 'presumed until otherwise proven'. It means that the information is dismissed without any action by the court. Once dismissed the proceeding could only be recommenced with consent of the Attorney General or leave of the court, neither of which were obtained. 2)With respect to jurisdiction in Saskatchewan, s.476(b) grants concurrent jurisdiction to any province in which the offence may have been committed or committed within 500 metres of any province in order to prevent a charge from failing because of uncertainty as to location. The section was not intended to permit simultaneous prosecutions in two provinces or in a second province in the event of a failure in the first. 3)The respondent's appearance in a Saskatchewan courtroom as a result of a summons did not revive jurisdiction in Alberta. The Alberta proceeding was deemed to have been dismissed for want of prosecution on May 6, 2001. The charges have not been disposed of within the meaning of s.730(3). There was no finding in respect of which an appeal can be taken. The special plea of autrefois acquit is not available in these circumstances. 4)The prosecutorial conduct of the police in proceeding simultaneously in two provinces amounted to an abuse of process. The respondent was obliged to defend identical charges arising out of the same incident in two provinces for almost a year at substantial cost and stress. The police acted with arbitrary purpose and without regard for the principles of fundamental justice. The lack of malice or improper motive does not preclude a finding of abuse of process.
column3: The Crown appealed a summary conviction appeal brought when the trial judge dismissed charges of impaired driving and driving with a blood alcohol level exceeding.08 percent. The trial judge held that the circumstances supported a special plea of autrefois acquit and that the manner of proceeding by the Crown was an abuse of process at common law. HELD: 1)The trial judge erred in finding that the court had lost jurisdiction as he specifically found that if there was loss of jurisdiction it was over the offence, but in dismissing the Information he relied on the provisions of s. 485(2) of the Criminal Code which relate to loss of jurisdiance over the accused and not the offence. The special plea was based solely on the found that the Alberta Provincial Court had lost its jurisdiction over the respondent. The Crown appealed. 2)The Court was unable to agree that appearance by the respondent in a Saskatchewan court as a result of a summons issued before May 7, 2001 revived jurisdiction over him. The Alberta proceeding was deemed to have been dismissed for want of prosecution. 3)The court was unable, in the opinion of the Court, to agree the appearance by respondent in Saskatchewan court on May 7/2001 revived jurisdiction. The Court was also unable to conclude that the special plea had been applicable in this case. 4)The Crown was correct in concluding that the Saskatchewan court had not lost jurisdiction over it. 5)The accused was not subject to the possibility of administrative penalties in both provinces. 6)The evidence before the Court was not conclusive that the trial court erred by finding that a special pleading of autRefois acquito was applicable in the case. The court was correct to conclude the Alberta provincial court had regained jurisdiction over this person. 7)The issue before the court was whether jurisdiction was lost in Alberta or Saskatchewan. 8)The only remedy left is an appeal. The accused was to appear in Alberta. 9)The issues before the Appeal Court were whether jurisdiction of the court lost in Saskatchewan? 10)If jurisdiction was not lost in the province, did it give rise to a plea of autorefois? 11)The appeal court was not satisfied that the Crown had lost the jurisdiction to proceed with the charges in Alberta and therefore the appeal court should be dismissed for abuse of the process.
column4:
[1] This summary conviction appeal by the Crown was brought when the trial judge dismissed charges of impaired driving and driving with a blood alcohol level exceeding .08 percent. ISSUES [6] The issues before the Court are:

1) Was jurisdiction of the court lost in Alberta? (2) If jurisdiction was lost in Alberta did it give rise to a plea of autrefois acquit in Saskatchewan? [13] I am unable to agree that appearance by the respondent in a Saskatchewan court as a result of a summons issued here before May 7, 2001, revived jurisdiction over the respondent in Alberta. [20] The prosecutorial conduct of the police in proceeding simultaneously in two provinces amounted to an abuse of process. CONCLUSION [22] The trial judge erred in finding that the special plea of autrefois acquit was applicable in this case. He was correct in concluding that the Alberta Provincial Court had lost jurisdiction over the respondent.

Once dismissed the proceeding could only be recommenced with consent of the Attorney General or leave of the court, neither of which were obtained. 2)With respect to jurisdiction in Saskatchewan, s.476(b) grants concurrent jurisdiction to any province in which the offence may have been committed or committed within 500 metres of any province in order to prevent a charge from failing because of uncertainty as to location. The section was not intended to permit simultaneous prosecutions in two provinces or in a second province in the event of a failure in the first. 3)The respondent's appearance in a Saskatchewan courtroom as a result of a summons did not revive jurisdiction in Alberta. The Alberta proceeding was deemed to have been dismissed for want of prosecution on May 6, 2001. The charges have not been disposed of within the meaning of s.730(3). There was no finding in respect of which an appeal can be taken. The special plea of autrefois acquit is not available in these circumstances. 4)The prosecutorial conduct of the police in proceeding simultaneously in two provinces amounted to an abuse of process. The respondent was obliged to defend identical charges arising out of the same incident in two provinces for almost a year at substantial cost and stress. The police acted with arbitrary purpose and without regard for the principles of fundamental justice. The lack of malice or improper motive does not preclude a finding of abuse of process.

The trial judge held that the circumstances supported a special plea of autrefois acquit. The Alberta proceeding was deemed to have been dismissed for want of prosecution. HELD: 1)The trial judge erred in finding that the court had lost jurisdiction as he specifically found that if there was loss of jurisdiction it was over the offence, but in dismissing the Information he relied on the provisions of s. 485(2) of the Criminal Code which relate to loss of jurisdictional over the accused and not the offence. The special plea was not applicable in this case. 2)The court was unable to agree that appearance by the respondent in a Saskatchewan court as a result of a summons issued before May 7, 2001 revived jurisdiction over the respondent. 3)The Court was not satisfied that the special plea had been substituted by autrefis acquit in this instance. The Court was correct in concluding that the Alberta Provincial Court had lost its jurisdiction over him. 4)The Crown appealed. The court was not aware of the Alberta information being sworn in Alberta or in any other province. The evidence before the court was clear that the Justice had issued a summons within three months of the loss in Alberta and the subsequent appearance in Alberta. 5)Any reference by the judge to loss in the province was unintentional. Any reference to loss is unintentional. 6)If jurisdiction was lost in Alberta the charges in Alberta were already deemed to be dismissed. The Special plea was based solely on the deemed dismissal. The Crown was correct to conclude the Alberta province had lost control over the appellant.

column2: FIAT. Saskatoon's daily newspaper applied for access to a CD-ROM entered in evidence at a sentencing hearing in the matter of R. v. Glen Ivor Jones on May 14, 2002. The journalists had no prior opportunity to hear its contents because Jones entered a guilty plea. The application was not opposed. The applicant sought an order for mandamus or a declaration. HELD: The presumption is in favour of public access to court records and the burden to contrary proof lies with the person who would deny access. This right is tempered by other factors (see R. v. SJS). Requiring the journalists to attend at the offices of the Attorney General and playing the CD ROM and making their own notes balances the interests of innocent parties whose conversations were recorded.
column3: FIAT. The Saskatoon StarPhoenix applied for access to a CD-ROM entered in evidence at a sentencing hearing in the matter of R. v. Glen Ivor Jones. The StarPhoenix's journalists had no prior opportunity to hear the contents of the CD-R played for the sentencing judge. Now, the journalists wish to view that evidence. The applicant applies for mandamus, or a declaration. HELD: The court of Queen's Bench is the appropriate court to obtain such relief. The court ordered the production of a copy of the CDs at its expense. The Court of Queen’s Bench is also the appropriate venue. The issue of access to the CD was remitted to the applicant. The Attorney General did not oppose the application. The only issue was whether the CD should be released to the court. The Courts of Queen and Queen‘s Bench are the appropriate courts to obtain relief. 1) The presumption is in favour of public access to court records and the burden to the contrary proof lies upon the person who would deny the exercise of the right. 2) The Court was the appropriate forum to determine the issue of the issue.
