column8: FIAT. The Saskatoon StarPhoenix applied for access to a CD-ROM entered in evidence at a sentencing hearing in the matter of R. v. Glen Ivor Jones. The StarPhoenix's journalists had no prior opportunity to hear the contents of the CD in their sentencing submissions because Mr. Jones entered a guilty plea. Now, the paper's journalists wish to view that evidence. The applicant applies for mandamus, or a declaration. HELD: The court of Queen's Bench is the appropriate court to obtain such relief. 1) The applicant is entitled to make a copy of the CDs at its expense. 2) Both counsel agree that this exhibit is now under the control of the Attorney General and it is its appropriate respondent in this proceeding. 3) The court must be concerned that no harm befalls innocent parties. This CD- ROM will invariably hold conversations made by innocent parties and is available for the public to view. 4) There is a presumption in favour of public access to judicial records, and the burden to the contrary proof lies upon the person who would deny the exercise of the right. This right is tempered somewhat by other factors. As stated in RJR v. SJ.S., [2000] S.J.A. at para. 8: The right of access to the judicial records has never been considered absolute. The governing principle is that there is a fundamental presumption in favor of the public access but that access must be supervised by the Court to ensure the integrity of the exhibit is preserved and that no abuse or harm occurs to innocent parties or to those who are involved in such a crime. The Attorney General does not oppose the application. It merely seeks the court order to release the CD to the applicant.

column2: FIAT: The defendant applied for security for costs in the amount of $50,000. HELD: The plaintiff was required to supply security for costs in the amount of $18,000. 1) The defendant proved facts, which demonstrated the existence of several of the criteria listed in Rule 538 of the Queen's Bench Rules of Court. The plaintiff failed to establish any of the situations listed in Rule 539.  2) The presence of a counterclaim does not necessarily or automatically prohibit the granting of an order for security for costs. Rather, it is a factor to be considered. In this case, the counterclaim was not a wholly distinct claim. It arises in respect of the same matter and transaction as the claim proper. 3) The defendant commenced the builders' lien action, long before filing a defence and counterclaim within this action. Had the counterclaim not been filed, an order for security for costs as requested would have been appropriate. It is somewhat artificial to now deny that relief because of the counterclaim, which has the effect of facilitating a disposition of all matters within one proceeding. 4) The plaintiff applied ex parte under s. 56(1) of The Builders' Lien Act to have the defendant's lien vacated. The application was granted, but the plaintiff was required to post security for costs in the amount of $50,000. The Builders' Lien Act does not impede the jurisdiction of this Court to deal with the application of the defendant.
column3: FIAT. The defendant applied for an order requiring the plaintiff to provide security for costs in the amount of $50,000. The plaintiff contracted to build a pipeline for Interprovincial Pipelines Inc. in 1998. In carrying out that contract the plaintiff engaged the defendant as a sub-contractor to construct a directionally drilled crossing under the South Saskatchewan River. The defendants embarked upon the project but after time ceased the work. The plaintiffs counterclaim alleged negligence by the defendant. The respondent argued that the plaintiff failed to rectify certain sub-soil conditions which were frustrating the work and eventually directed the defendant to vacate the site. The judge granted the application for security for the costs in a lesser amount of money. The court found that the respondent had a duty to post security for cost in the event of a counterclaim. The counterclaim was dismissed and the court ordered security for $18,000 to be posted. The Court found that there was no absolute prohibition on the granting of security for a cost. The issue was whether the respondent was liable for any award of costs. The question was whether it was. The answer was that the question was: 'Is there a duty of protection?' The court concluded that the answer was yes. The evidence was that there had been a breach of trust and the respondent should be held liable for the award of any award. The fact that the counterclaim had already been filed in Alberta did not preclude the granting an order for security. The only issue that the court could not decide was whether to issue a security for an costs order. The order was made in the absence of any evidence that the claim was not wholly distinct from the claim. The applicant was entitled to security for any costs.

Accordingly, I conclude that the Act does not impede the jurisdiction of this court to deal with the application of the defendant. (1) that the plaintiff, Banister Pipelines Inc., on or before April 30, 2004, shall deposit with this court to the credit of this action as security for costs the sum of $18,000.00;

column18: FIAT: This is an application wherein the defendant, The Crossing Company Inc., seeks an order requiring the plaintiff to provide security for costs in the amount of $50,000. The plaintiff contracted to build a pipeline for Interprovincial Pipelines Inc. in April 1998. In carrying out that contract the plaintiff engaged the defendant as a sub-contractor to construct a directionally drilled crossing under the South Saskatchewan River. The defendant embarked upon the project but after time ceased the work and the plaintiff abandoned the project. HELD: The plaintiff was ordered to post security for $18,000 for fees and disbursements. The amount of the security was reduced to $1,460,246.10. The court found that the presence of the counterclaim did not impede the plaintiff's ability to defend against the claim. 1) The presence of a counterclaim precludes the plaintiff from exercising its discretion to vacate the action. 2) There is no absolute prohibition on the granting of an order for costs where the claim and counterclaim are related. There is a general rule that 'no security will be awarded where there is a claim or counterclaim is not an absolute bar'. 3) The respondent commenced the builders' lien action, which is the other action, long before filing a defence. The counterclaim arose out of the same motor vehicle accident and include all the parties involved in that accident. 4) The plaintiff is called upon to defend the within action brought by the plaintiff. This is case where the plaintiff not only is a non-resident party but there is real likelihood that it will be unable to pay costs if it is unsuccessful. 538(c) is a factor to be considered, albeit a compelling one. It is not the case that the Court has no jurisdiction to do anything more. The Court has discretion to make a determination based on the facts and evidence in this case. 539(d) is an absolute prohibition.

column2: The appellant appeal arguing that the respondent's conduct in soliciting the customers of the appellant constituted a breach of contract. HELD: Appeal dismissed orally. Even if the respondent's conduct constituted a breach of the clause of the contract prohibiting him from soliciting the customers of the appellant, the appellant failed to prove any loss attributable to the breach. The appellant's loss consisted of its inability to continue to obtain Mato products and sell them to its customers at a profit. This loss stemmed from the termination of its distributorship agreement with Mato, not from anything the respondent did. As the trial judge found, the termination of the distributorship was unconnected to the respondent.
column3: The respondent was found to have breached the clause prohibiting him from soliciting customers of the appellant. Belterra appealed. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with costs. 1) Even if his conduct constituted a breach of the clause of the contract prohibiting him to soliciting the customers of an appellant, Belterran failed to prove any loss attributable to the breach. 2) Even though his conduct was a breach, even if his breach of his contract, BelTerra failed to show any loss. 3) In light of the view we take of the matter, it is not necessary for us to decide whether Mr Yaganiski's conduct amounted to a breach if on balance we incline to the opinion it did. Assuming it did (which is to put the case for the appellant at its highest), Belterrail has not satisfied us that it suffered any loss due to the breaches.
column4: Disposition: Dismissed (orally) [2] In light of the view we take of the matter, it is not necessary for us to decide whether Mr Yaganiski’s conduct amounted to a breach of contract, although on balance we incline to the opinion it did. [4] Hence, we have decided to dismiss the appeal. The appeal is dismissed with costs, such costs to be taxed as usual on the basis of double column 5 of the Court of Appeal Tariff of costs.

column2: The accused was found not guilty of having care or control of a motor vehicle while his blood alcohol content was over .08. The certificate of analysis was excluded as a result of the trial judge's decision that the accused's s. 8 Charter Rights had been violated. The trial judge found that the officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds to make the breathalyzer demand. HELD: The trial judge erred in determining that in the totality of the circumstances it was not objectively reasonable for the officer to have relied on the accuracy of the ASD test. A new trial is ordered.  1) There is no fixed rule or formula that an officer must follow when determining whether or not to wait 15 minutes prior to administering a road side test. In this case, the trial judge appears to have concluded that the officer who administered the ASD would not have relied on the results, or should not have so relied, if her partner had informed her of the empty beer can with fresh suds in it that he found at the scene. Implicit in this finding is the conclusion that the existence of the beer can would make a difference to the officer's assessment of whether she should wait 15 minutes for any mouth alcohol to dissipate before she could rely on ASD test results. 2) The trial judge made the same error that was dealt with by the Ontario Court of Appeal in R. v. Einarson. 3) The accused told the officer that he had been drinking in the car 'earlier'. Even if the officer had been told of her partner's discovery of an empty beer can at the scene, it would not constitute 'credible evidence' that the accused consumed alcohol within that 15 minute time frame. Whether or not the accused had consumed beer within 15 minutes of taking the test on the ASD is pure speculation.
column3: The appellant was found not guilty of having care or control of a motor vehicle while his blood alcohol content was over.08. The trial judge found that contrary to s. 8 of the Charter, contrary to the trial judge's finding that the officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds to make the breathalyzer demand, the officer was not obliged to wait 15 minutes on the grounds that the driver had just left a bar. The appellant appealed. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the acquittal set aside. The court found that the trial court erred in determining that in the totality of the circumstances it was not objectively reasonable for the officer to have relied on the accuracy of the ASD test. The officer who administered the ASD would not have relied upon the results, or should not have so relied, if her partner had informed her of the empty beer can at the scene. The Court found that under s. 24(2) of the charter the certificate of analysis should be excluded from evidence. The appeal court found the trial officer was entitled to rely on the results of the screening device test in deciding whether he had reasonable and possible grounds to arrest the appellant when he knew there was a possibility that the respondent had consumed alcohol within the 15 minutes prior to the administration of the test and that if she had, the result of the Test could be inaccurate. The respondent appealed. Appeal allowed. The issue of whether the officer should rely on a breathalyze demand was raised. The evidence was not found to be that the appellant had not shown any reasonable and reasonable grounds to rely upon the accuracy. The certificate of Analysis was not tendered as evidence at trial. The Crown appealed. The Appeal Court found the appellant was entitled, but not required, to rely solely on the ASD results. The error was not made in the manner the trial Judge concluded. The test was administered within 15 minutes of the appellant's vehicle leaving the bar.

In this case, the trial judge appears to have concluded that the officer who administered the ASD would not have relied on the results, or should not have so relied, if her partner had informed her of the empty beer can with fresh suds in it that he found at the scene. Implicit in this finding is the conclusion that the existence of the beer can would make a difference to the officer's assessment of whether she should wait 15 minutes for any mouth alcohol to dissipate before she could rely on ASD test results. 2) The trial judge made the same error that was dealt with by the Ontario Court of Appeal in R. v. Einarson. 3) The accused told the officer that he had been drinking in the car 'earlier'. Even if the officer had been told of her partner's discovery of an empty beer can at the scene, it would not constitute 'credible evidence' that the accused consumed alcohol within that 15 minute time frame. Whether or not the accused had consumed beer within 15 minutes of taking the test on the ASD is pure speculation.
column23: HELD: The appeal was allowed and the acquittal set aside. The trial judge erred in determining that in the totality of the circumstances it was not objectively reasonable for the officer to have relied on the accuracy of the ASD test. The evidence was excluded because the trial judge concluded that contrary to s. 8 of the Charter the certificate of analysis should be excluded from evidence.

column2: The tenant appeals the decision of the Hearing Officer granting her landlord a possession order of her rental premises. The tenant received notice of the hearing late on Friday when the hearing was set for Tuesday morning. She immediately requested an adjournment as she was unable to attend personally. The tenant also submits that the notice failed to disclose a significant aspect of the complaint, namely the conduct of her boyfriend. HELD: Appeal allowed and the matter returned to the Director to schedule a new hearing with at least 7 days clear notice to be given of the date. The decision to grant an adjournment is inherently discretionary and should be made with a view to what is necessary to ensure justice is done between the parties. This should include consideration of the complexity of the issues, the tenant's personal circumstances affecting her ability to attend in person on short notice and any prejudice to the landlord if the request is granted. There is no evidence that any of this was considered by the Hearing Officer. Three days (including a weekend) is not sufficient time to make arrangements and prepare for any hearing. It is clear that the tenant took the matter seriously and spent considerable time preparing written responses to the landlord's claim as she knew it to be. On the issue of sufficiency of the Notice, the Court found that while the Notice outlined many issues, it failed to disclose issues relating to her boyfriend. Since these issues were only discussed at the hearing the tenant was unable to attend she was not able to advise in person or in writing that her boyfriend was now incarcerated and the issue resolved. The Hearing Officer, in accepting evidence from the landlord about the boyfriend when neither the Hearing notice nor the landlord's complaint contained notice of it, breached the rule of natural justice and due process. The reasonableness standard of review applies here.

column2: A couple signed a separation agreement which included a provision whereby they agreed to renounce and waive any claim in the estate of the other and any right to share in the estate of the other, which terms were incorporated into a corollary relief judgment. When he died, the former husband had not changed his will, which left the residue of his estate to his former wife. The Chambers judge held that the separation agreement had not revoked the will and the former wife was entitled to the testamentary gift. The mother of the deceased appealed. Appeal dismissed; although the Chambers judge's reasoning was flawed, the appellant had failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to renounce a testamentary gift after his death. Even if the former spouse were so bound, there did not appear to be any privity of contract which would allow the appellant, who was not a party to the separation agreement, to enforce it.
column3: The chambers judge found that the appellant failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce a testamentary gift after his death had bound a person to be the sole beneficiary under the will. The mother of the deceased appeals. Appeal dismissed. The Chambers judge relied on Billing, supra and Eccleston, supra for the purposes of the corollary relief judgment. The chambers judge held that the separation agreement did not revoke the will nor did it affect the appellant's entitlement to the gift. The respondent's mother appealed. The court found that in the circumstances, the appellant had not produced any legal evidence that a verbal promise to not renounce or refuse a testamentarian gift after the death of her former spouse had resulted in the appellant renouncing any claim against the estate of her late husband and any right to share in the estate with the respondent. The appellant failed in this respect to the extent to which a contractual pledge to renounced a testamentative gift after death had been made by the appellant. The Court found that there was no evidence that the respondent had contractually bound herself to renouncing the gift after her death. The evidence did not support the appellant’s position that the gift to the respondent was a contractual obligation and therefore not binding.
column4: Summary: A couple signed a separation agreement which included a provision whereby they agreed to renounce and waive any claim in the estate of the other and any right to share in the estate of the other. The mother of the deceased appeals. Result: Appeal dismissed. However, the appellant failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to renounce a testamentary gift after his death. Held: Appeal is dismissed with costs per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; A few years later the couple signed a separation agreement. However, the appellant has failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to renounce a testamentary gift after his death. [45] While the chambers judge’s reasoning which led to his determination that Ingrid Ostrom was entitled to take under Ezra Morrell’s will was flawed, in these circumstances I am not persuaded that the result was incorrect in law. [46] I would dismiss the appeal. Held: Appeal is dismissed with costs per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; Saunders and Fichaud, JJ.A. concurring.

It was not clear from the wording of the statement that the respondent consented to the respondent designating whomsoever she wishes to be beneficiary of any life insurance policy on his life even though she may now be designated (by operation of law or previous action of the Husband) as an irrevocable beneficiary. The evidence did not support the respondent's claim. The Court noted that there was nothing on which a verbal promise to be renounced could be binding.

The mother of the deceased appeals. It is undisputed that these are questions of law for which the standard of review is correctness. The issue before the chambers judge concerned the effect of s. 20 of the separation agreement, if any, on Ingrid Ostrom's entitlement pursuant to Mr. Morrell's will.
column24: Summary: A couple signed a separation agreement which included a provision whereby they agreed to renounce and waive any claim in the estate of the other and any right to share in the estate of the other. The mother of the deceased appeals. Result: Appeal dismissed. However, the appellant failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to renounce a testamentary gift after his death. Held: Appeal is dismissed with costs per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; A few years later the couple signed a separation agreement. However, the appellant has failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to renounce a testamentary gift after his death. [45] While the chambers judge’s reasoning which led to his determination that Ingrid Ostrom was entitled to take under Ezra Morrell’s will was flawed, in these circumstances I am not persuaded that the result was incorrect in law. [46] I would dismiss the appeal. Held: Appeal is dismissed with costs per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; Saunders and Fichaud, JJ.A. concurring.
column27: HELD: Appeal dismissed. The Chambers judge's reasoning was flawed. However, the appellant failed to produce any legal authority that a contractual promise to renounce, given for consideration before the death of a former spouse, binds a person to be the sole beneficiary under a testamentary gift. The mother of the deceased appeals. In his will, the testator left his wife the residue of his estate. A few years later the couple signed a separation agreement. When he died, the former husband had not changed his will which left the residue to his former wife. She was entitled to the gift under the testamentary agreement.

column2: The police responded to a call from a woman identified as the defendant's girlfriend's mother to the effect that her daughter was being abused. Initially unable to locate the residence, they spoke to the girlfriend on the phone, who advised them that she was fine and did not require the police. They nevertheless continued to the residence, where they heard a scream from inside. Knowing that the defendant was a suspected drug dealer and potentially violent, they demanded entry into the home. The daughter opened the door and told them everything was fine, there had been no assault and she had simply wanted a ride home. From where they entered, the officers could see a person lying down in the bedroom. They approached the man, searched him for officer safety and then conducted a warrantless search to locate any other occupants. During the search, certain items were noted that caused them to obtain a search warrant, following which drugs were found. The defendant's argument that the search was illegal was unsuccessful as the court found that, in these particular circumstances, the police had a responsibility to enter the home without a warrant, do a pat down search of the accused and search for other occupants. Once drugs were seen in plain view, they proceeded to obtain a search warrant. Judicial notice was taken of the fact that complainants in domestic situations often recant due to threats of coercion by their partners. The defendant appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction set aside; although a violation of the defendant's Charter rights had occurred, the record was insufficient for this court to engage in a s. 24(2) analysis. Although it was reasonable, in the circumstances, for the police to search for the girl, go to the defendant's home and not simply leave once she told them she was fine, the trial judge erred in failing to consider alternatives short of police entry (such as conferring with the girl after they had her step outside and close the door) and the search of the home, without a warrant. Police authority to investigate such a call includes locating the alleged victim and determining if their assistance is required, but, without more, does not extend to the entry or search of the premises.
column3: The appellant was found guilty of several drug offences. The police entered his home and searched the premises. They found a large quantity of drugs and a large amount of alcohol. They also entered a bedroom where the appellant was lying on the bed. The appellant cooperated during the search. The complainant called the police and said that she was fine. The officers entered the home and found the appellant lying on his bed. They searched the house and found a quantity of marijuana. The respondent called the RCMP and asked them to search the premises for the presence of other persons. The RCMP entered the house. The caller called the Police and said she was in trouble. The Crown appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction set aside. The trial judge failed to consider alternatives short of police entry into the home, and the search of the premises without a warrant. The evidence found by the police was not material to the Court's s. 8 Charter right against unreasonable search and seizure. The Court held that the Crown had proved that the police acted reasonably and lawfully in searching the appellant's home and that there was no violation of s. 24(2) of the Charter. The court held that in the circumstances, the police had a responsibility to enter the residence. In those circumstances, police had to enter whether invited or not. The perceived scream meant that either the complainant was lying about being okay or that someone else inside was in danger. The search of premises was justified. The accused was convicted of trafficking. Appeal dismissed; conviction to be set aside; the Court held the trial judge erred in principle in failing to consider alternative strategies short of a police entry and search of his home without a search.
column4: The appellant was found guilty of several drug offences. Result: Leave to appeal granted, the appeal allowed, and the conviction set aside. In the circumstances, although the call was not a 911 call, or made by the alleged victim or from the home of the appellant, it was reasonable for the police to search for her, to go to the appellant’s home, and not to simply leave once the daughter told them at the door that she was fine. However, the trial judge erred in principle by failing to consider alternatives short of police entry into the home and bedroom, and the search of the home, all without a warrant. The record here is insufficient for this court, at first instance, to engage in a s. 24(2) analysis. Held: Leave to appeal is granted, the appeal is allowed and the conviction is set aside per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; [2] For the reasons which follow, I would allow the appeal. [14] In those circumstances, police had a responsibility to enter the residence – whether invited or not. Mr. Timmons appeals against his conviction. [38] In his voir dire decision, the trial judge stated that in the circumstances, including the perceived scream, the police had a responsibility to enter the residence, whether invited or not, and that their warrantless entry, search of Mr. Timmons’ person, and search of his house did not breach his s. 8 Charter right against unreasonable search and seizure. [46] In my view, the trial judge erred in principle by failing to consider alternatives to the warrantless entry of Mr. Timmons’ home and bedroom, and the search of his home. I would grant leave to appeal, and allow the appeal. I would set aside the conviction. Held: Leave to appeal is granted, the appeal is allowed and the conviction is set aside per reasons for judgment of Oland, J.A.; Fichaud and Farrar, JJ.A. concurring.

column8: The appellant was found guilty of several drug offences. The police entered the appellant's home and searched the premises. The appellant's mother called the police. She said that her daughter was being abused and that she wanted her to come pick her up. When the police arrived at the residence, they could see inside a bedroom where the appellant was lying on the bed. The complainant cooperated during the search and said that she was fine and that the police had a warrant to enter the home. The trial judge found that the warrantless entry and search of the home was justified. The evidence found as result of the searches should have been excluded pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter. HELD: Leave to appeal was granted, the appeal allowed, and the conviction set aside. In the circumstances, although the call was not a 911 call, it was reasonable for the police to search for the alleged victim or from the appellant, to go to her home, and not to simply leave once the daughter told them at the door that she had been fine. However, the trial judge erred in principle by failing to consider alternatives short of police entry into the home and the search without a warrant. The Court held that the Crown had a responsibility to enter and search the premises, whether invited or not. In those circumstances, police were obliged to enter.

column2: The petitioner brought an application to compel the respondent to pay his pro rata share of the costs for the child's post-secondary education expenses. The petitioner had previously been ordered to pay $1,000 in costs to the respondent but instead paid the $1,000 directly into the child's credit card balance and there was no evidence that this was done by mutual agreement between the parties. The child was not performing well in her program with no explanation for her poor performance. HELD The burden is on the petitioner to prove the adult child's ongoing economic dependence. Although the child is a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act during the time she was attending classes, her expenses are excessive. The child provided no evidence to rebut the respondent's information that she did not attend many of her classes. The child must take greater responsibility for her own expenses and debts if she does not apply herself to her studies. The respondent was ordered to match the amount paid by the petitioner towards the child's expenses. The costs owed by the petitioner to the respondent are set-off against the amount owing; the respondent shall pay $3,452 to the child's outstanding debts by or before February 15, 2011.
column3: HELD: The court awarded the amount of $4,452.00 in full and complete satisfaction of any claim for retroactive child support for 2008-2009. The court found that the respondent should match the amount paid by the petitioner towards the child's expenses. The parties were unable to settle the sharing of the educational expenses for 2008/2009.

column18: HELD: The court awarded the amount of $4,452.00 in full and complete satisfaction of any claim for retroactive child support for 2008-2009. The parties were unable to settle the sharing of the daughter's educational expenses for 2008/2009. Costs ordered to be paid by the father. The father was ordered to pay $605 per month being the table amount on his income of $79,300 for his 18 year old son Landon who was attending university and living with his mother. He ordered the father to pay the equivalent of 1/3 of the Table amount based on her income. The court found that the father must take greater responsibility for his own expenses if she did not apply herself to her studies.
column19: Analysis [23] I am satisfied that Amanda was a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act during the time she was attending classes. I agree with that conclusion. He shall pay the sum of $4,452.00 in full and complete satisfaction of any claim for retroactive child support for 2008-2009.
column22: The petitioner brought an application to compel the respondent to pay his pro rata share of the costs for the child's post-secondary education expenses. The petitioner had previously been ordered to pay $1,000 in costs to the respondent but instead paid the $1,000 directly into the child's credit card balance and there was no evidence that this was done by mutual agreement between the parties. The child was not performing well in her program with no explanation for her poor performance. HELD The burden is on the petitioner to prove the adult child's ongoing economic dependence. Although the child is a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act during the time she was attending classes, her expenses are excessive. The child provided no evidence to rebut the respondent's information that she did not attend many of her classes. The child must take greater responsibility for her own expenses and debts if she does not apply herself to her studies. The respondent was ordered to match the amount paid by the petitioner towards the child's expenses. The costs owed by the petitioner to the respondent are set-off against the amount owing; the respondent shall pay $3,452 to the child's outstanding debts by or before February 15, 2011.

The father was ordered to pay $605 per month being the table amount on his income of $79,300 for his 18 year old son Landon who was attending university and living with his mother notwithstanding the abandonment of the claim by the mother. The court also awarded costs of $1,000 to the respondent.

column2: The appellants appealed the order of a Queen's Bench chamber's judge striking out portions of the statement of defence and counter-claim. HELD: The chamber's judge was in error in striking out portions of the statement of defence and counter-claim. The error consists of a failure to address the merits of the application. The Court of Appeal opted to deal with the merits of the application themselves, rather than remitting the matter back to Queen's Bench. While the allegation of fraud might have been pleaded more explicitly, the pleading is nevertheless sufficient to answer the requirements of QB Rule 173. The appellants should have been given an opportunity to amend their pleadings. The appeal was allowed and the application to strike was dismissed without prejudice to respondent's right to seek further particulars.
column3: The respondent appealed an order striking portions of the statement of defence and counterclaim. The chambers judge failed to address the merits of the application brought by the respondent to strike portions of these pleadings. HELD: Appeal allowed. The error was not in the application to strike but rather in the failure to address whether the impugned allegations in the statement met the requirements of Queen's Bench Rules, particularly in relation to the allegations of fraud.
column4: Disposition: Appeal Allowed [1] We have concluded that the order made by the chamber judge striking major portions of the statement of defence and counterclaim of Carry the Kettle First Nation was made in error. The error consists of a failure to address the merits of the application brought by Ms Thompson to strike the impugned portions of these pleadings. [5] On the whole, then, we have decided to allow the appeal, set aside the order under appeal, and dismiss the application to strike. The application is dismissed without prejudice to Ms Thompson’s rights to again turn to the Court of Queen’s Bench, in one context or another, to seek further specifics of the alleged fraud. In the circumstances, we have decided to allow the appeal but without an order for costs in favour of Carry the Kettle First Nations.

column2: The tenants appealed a decision of a hearing officer under s. 72 of The Residential Tenancies Act. The hearing officer determined that the landlord's claim for non-payment of rent had been established and that an order for possession as warranted. The hearing officer directed that the order of possession would be deferred if the tenant paid the rent that was owing and future rent. The tenants argued that the hearing officer erred in not considering that the premises were infested with bed bugs and the tenants had been forced to incur personal expense to remedy the problem. They sought to adduce new evidence by affidavit on this point at the appeal. HELD: The Court declined to admit the affidavit evidence about bed bugs. However, the matter was remitted to the hearing officer for rehearing because the reasons provided by the hearing officer were deficient. The Court held that it was impossible to tell whether the hearing officer considered the tenants' evidence at the hearing, made findings of fact in that regard or whether equitable jurisdiction should be invoked in this situation. The reasons are inadequate to allow a meaningful review of the decision.
column3: The tenants appeal the decision of a hearing officer under s. 72 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006. They contend the hearing officer, who rendered her decision on May 31, 2012, committed several errors of law and seek to have the matter remitted back for re-hearing. HELD: The appeal is allowed. The decision of the hearing officers is set aside and the matter is remitted to the hearing office for a re-examination. The reasons for the appeal are inadequate to allow for meaningful review of the decision and for this reason the matter must be remitted. The simple fact tenant's application is not formally before a hearing hearing officer at the same time as landlord's does not bar hearing officer from either considering the facts put forth by the tenant (provided they relate to the landlord's dispute) nor to give effect to the tenant's facts and arguments in rendering decision and formulating an appropriate order. The tenants do not dispute that rent is owing, they contend an infestation of bed bugs in the residential premises has made it uninhabitable and forced them to incur personal expense to address this problem. The tenant's claim for non-payment of rent has been established and in fashioning an appropriate remedy the hearing hearing hearing the tenant failed to take into account the alleged bed bug infestation, associated problems and expenses incurred. The Court found the reasons inadequate to permit for meaningful analysis of the appeal and for that reason the issue must be returned to the Hearing officer for rehearing on a new hearing.

column2: The appellant landlord appealed a decision of the Residential Tenancies hearing officer. The tenancy in question had commenced in April 2012. On September 18, the tenant had given six weeks' notice of her intention to terminate the tenancy. The term of the lease stated that it was for a term of 12 months (April 2012 to March 2013) and continuing thereafter from month to month until one of the parties gave one month's notice. The appellant did not try to rent the premises following receipt of the notice because he had decided to furnish the unit prior to re-renting. He spent $15,000 doing so and advertised the unit in mid-January, increasing the rent by $400 and obtained a new tenant as at February 1. Although it is not stated what relief the landlord sought from the Office of Residential Tenancies, the hearing officer stated in the decision that the lease was a month-to-month tenancy. The appellant argued that the hearing officer made errors in law in that he 1) misinterpreted s. 19(1)(g)(iii) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 in making that finding, as the lease was for a fixed term; and 2) misinterpreted s. 8(2) of the Act in finding that the landlord's efforts at mitigation were not reasonable within the meaning of the section and the landlord was legally disentitled by s. 8(1) of the Act. HELD: The Court held that the hearing officer had erred in law in finding that the lease was for a month-to-month tenancy. The one-month-notice provision only applied if the tenancy was extended beyond the fixed term. The appeal was allowed on this issue. The Court found that the decision of the landlord to furnish the premises was a business decision, and the result of this decision could not be attributed to the tenant. The Court dismissed the appellant's claim for loss.
column3: The appellant landlord appeals a decision of the Residential Tenancies hearing officer on two questions of law. The hearing officer misinterpreted ss. 19(1)(g)(iii) of The Residential Tenancy Act, 2006 in finding the tenancy agreement was not a fixed-term agreement and that the landlord is legally disentitled to compensation pursuant to s. 8(1) of the Act. HELD: The appellant landlord appealed a decision made by the hearing officer in finding a month-to-month tenancy would follow the primary fixed term negated a fixed term. The one-month notice provision referred to in the term of the lease was applicable only if the tenancy was extended to a month to month tenancy following the end of the fixed term and the one-time notice provision was applicable.
column4: [1] The appellant landlord appeals a decision of the Residential Tenancies hearing officer on the following two questions of law: I conclude the hearing officer erred in law in holding that the fact a month‑to‑month tenancy would follow the primary fixed term negated a fixed term. The one-month notice provision referred to in the term of the lease was applicable only if the tenancy was extended to a month-to-month tenancy following the end of the fixed term. This decision was made not with respect to the possibilities of renting an unfurnished premises as of September 19, 2012, but was a macro decision based on his business going forward. [11] The appeal is allowed with respect to the fixed term issue, and dismissed with respect to the claim for loss.

HELD: 1) The appellant landlord appealed a decision made by the hearing officer in finding that a month-to-month tenancy would follow the primary fixed term negated a fixed one. The one-month notice provision referred to in the term of the lease was applicable only if the tenancy was extended to a month to month tenancy following the end of the fixed term.  2) The Hearing Officer erred in law in holding that the fact a month was followed by a monthly tenancy negated the primary term. The 1 month notice provision is applicable only in the context of the respondent's early notice of termination of the tenancy. The respondent vacated the unit on or about October 30, 2012. The monthly rental was $21. The appellant did not advertise the unit for rent until the middle of January 2013 and obtained a new tenant effective February 1, 2013 at $2500 per month.

column13: The appellant landlord appeals a decision of the Residential Tenancies hearing officer on the following two questions of law: 1) that the hearing officer misinterpreted ss. 19(1)(g)(iii) of the Act in finding the tenancy agreement was not fixed-term and 2) that a month-to-month tenancy would follow the primary fixed term negated a fixed term. The one-month notice provision referred to in the term of the lease was applicable only if the tenancy was extended to a month. The respondent vacated the unit on or about October 30, 2012. The monthly rental was $21. The appellant did not attempt to rent the premises following his receipt of the notice, because he spent approximately $15,000 on furnishing the unit prior to re-renting it. He purchased a new tenant effective February 1, 2013 at $2500 per month, which was $400 more than when the apartment was unfurnished. The hearing officer concluded the tenant had not complained to the landlord about the noise was failure to mitigate, and that the one month notice provision was applicable. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The hearing officer erred in law in holding the fact a month to month tenancy would be followed by a fixed fixed term did not eliminate an entitlement to compensation; rather it mandates an adjustment in the amount of compensation.  2)Section of The Rt. Tenancies Act, 2006, S.S. 2006, c.22.0001 (the Act) addresses tenant's liability for not complying with the Act or tenancy agreement. The onus is on defendant to establish that a defendant has failed to mitigate on the part of the plaintiff. It was therefore the appellant who had the obligation to show that he did whatever was reasonable to minimize his loss.

column18: The appellant landlord appeals a decision of the Residential Tenancies hearing officer in finding the tenancy agreement was not a fixed term agreement and that the landlord is legally disentitled to compensation pursuant to s. 8(1) of the Act. HELD: 1) The hearing officer misinterpreted ss. 19(1)(g)(iii) of The Rt. Tenancies Act, 2006 in finding that a month-to-month tenancy would follow the primary fixed term and that a one-month notice provision was applicable only if the tenancy was extended to a month to month tenancy following the end of the fixed term.  2) While the appellant gave evidence before the hearing officer that September was difficult time to rent the premise, the fact is he did not try, because he had decided it would be better going forward to have a furnished premise for rent. column3: The accused was charged with 14 counts of indecent assault and three counts of gross indecency against 14 individuals. The accused attended the residential school between 1959 and 1967. During his time there, he developed the intermural hockey, competitive fastball and softball teams and the Beauval Warriors, which was the regional champion hockey team through most of the years. The Warriors were members of the choir. The Court did not accept that there was less likelihood of moral prejudice, reasoning prejudice and propensity reasoning in a judge alone trial as opposed to jury trial.
column4: [1] The accused has been charged with 14 counts of indecent assault and three counts of gross indecency against 14 individuals, all of whom were boys who attended the Beauval Indian Residential School between January 1, 1959 and December 31, 1967. A conviction shall be entered to Count 1. This count is dismissed. A conviction shall be entered on Count 3. The court does enter a conviction to Count 4. The court does dismiss Count 6. [85] The court does enter a conviction on Count 7. The court has a reasonable doubt respecting this count and does therefore dismiss this count. Therefore, Count 9 is dismissed. Therefore, the court does dismiss Count 10. Therefore a conviction is entered on Count 11. A conviction will be entered to both Counts 12 and 13. Whether there was an indecent assault of M.V.P. in the shower or whether there was only an attempt, the court accepts the evidence of M.V.P. that there was in fact an indecent assault in the bedroom of the accused when M.V.P. was approximately 15 years of age, and I find the Crown has proven the charge beyond a reasonable doubt and a conviction shall be entered to Count 14. column8: The accused was charged with 14 counts of indecent assault and three counts of gross indecency against 14 individuals, all of whom were boys who attended the residential school between January 1, 1959 and December 31, 1967. The residential school was located at Beauval in the Province of Saskatchewan. The accused was considered the golden-haired boy of the priests and nuns and was very popular with the boys at the school. He developed the intermural hockey, competitive fastball and softball teams, and the Warriors, which was the regional champion hockey team through most of the years. The court was required to take into account the potential distraction of the trier of fact from its proper focus on the facts charged, and to allow the evidence of all 14 complainants to apply to all 17 charges. The issue in this case is not identification but the actus reus of the offence. The point is not that the degree of similarity in such case must be higher or lower than in an identification case. It is rather that the trial judge should evaluate the degree and extent of the similarity of the alleged acts and decide whether the objective improbability of coincidence has been established. The relative importance of the issue in the particular trial may also have bearing on the weighing up of factors for and against admissibility. The issues in question are not identification, but the acts which occurred in their childhood often become embellished and distorted and blamed for many of our personal shortcomings or personal failures later in life. The degree of similarities between the similar facts and the offences alleged is far too high. The Court reserved its decision respecting the application and undertook to render decision on this issue at the time of its final judgment.

column2: HELD: The Court held that the cause of the damage was high humidity in the building caused by water leaking into it from the roof. The failure of the tenant to maintain the floor caused approximately 25 percent of the damage to the floor. The estimated span for the flooring was 20 years. As the lease was in good standing at present and would expire in 2018, the age of the floor at that time would be 17 years. The Court awarded to the landlord the amount of $836, which was 25 percent of 3/20 of the damages claimed. The business loss claimed by the tenant was $4,800. Thus the net setoff owing by the landlord to the tenant was $4,800 less $836. The defendant tenant was awarded costs of the three-day trial of $2,500.
column3: The tenant claims damages for negligence by failing to clean, wax and polish the vinyl tile floor in the building, thereby permitting moisture to penetrate between and underneath the tiles resulting in losses to the tenant's restaurant. The tenant also claims economic interference, alleging the landlord interfered with the sale of its restaurant. HELD: The tenant is awarded judgment against the landlord in the amount of $6,464. The damage to the floor is $22,281 and the tenant is contributorily negligent to the extent of 25% of the damage. Leaking of water through the ceiling onto the floor did necessitate closure of the restaurant but the tenant has given Notice of Intention to Renew the Lease to the landlord. Although the evidence shows that water in the basement caused a mildew and moisture in the interior, the evidence does show that a part, but only a part of the moisture entering into the subfloor was due to the negligence of the tenant in failing to properly maintain the floor. Leaked of water into the building did necessitated closure of its premises. The tenants gave Notice of Intent to Renew Lease. The landlord is liable for the $7,700 base monthly rent.
column4: [1] The plaintiff, the landlord, claims damages against its tenant, the defendant, asserting negligence by failing to clean, wax and polish the vinyl tile floor in the building, thereby permitting moisture to penetrate between and underneath the tiles resulting in lifting and cracking. The tenant denies responsibility, contending the cause is normal wear and tear or high humidity arising from water entering the building due to inherent structural defects for which the landlord is responsible. The tenant asserts that the landlord breached the lease by failing to repair the roof and by failing to take other remedial measures to prevent water from infiltrating the building, resulting in losses to the tenant’s restaurant operating in the building. The tenant also claims damages for economic interference, alleging the landlord interfered with the sale of its restaurant. The landlord claims damages in the amount of $22,533 to repair the two bad areas of the restaurant floor. [18] The evidence does show that a part, but only a part, of the moisture entering into the subfloor was due to the negligence of the tenant in failing to properly maintain the floor. I accept that the damage to the floor is $22,281, and I find that the tenant is contributorily negligent to the extent of 25% of the damage. I find the only business loss proven by the tenant for which the landlord is responsible to be $4,800. [20] The tenant shall have costs for this three day trial of $2,500 inclusive of disbursements, in lieu of taxable costs. [21] In the result, the tenant is awarded judgment against the landlord in the amount of $6,464 [$3,964 plus $2,500]. The tenant may set off this judgment against the base monthly rent of $7,700 as specified in clause 8(b) of the lease.

The Court awarded to the landlord the amount of $836, which was 25 percent of 3/20 of the damages claimed. The business loss claimed by the tenant was $4,800. Although the evidence shows that excessive moisture and high humidity within the building undermined the subfloor, causing instability and resulting in lifting and cracking of the vinyl floor tiles, the evidence does not show that a part, but only a small part, of the moisture entering into the basement was due to the negligence of the tenant in failing to properly maintain the floor. The evidence does show that negligence was not the sole cause of the problems with the flooring but was caused by structural defects for which the landlord is responsible. The tenants claim damages for economic interference as the tenant may set off the judgment against base monthly rent of $7,700 as specified in clause 8(b) of the lease.

column2: HELD: The court held that it did not have the power to approve the proposed plan of arrangement. The court applied the rules of statutory interpretation, specifically the presumption of coherence and overlap, to the provisions of the Act and found that the applicant was using s. 186.1 for a purpose that the legislature did not intend. The applicant could have proceeded to dissolution under Division XVI. In s. 210(m) the legislature intended to give the court the ability to order disposition of property of creditors and shareholders but not to deal with a shareholder’s right to distribution on dissolution.
column3: Shareholders of the corporation approved a plan of arrangement and sought an order approving it pursuant to s. 186.1 of The Business Corporations Act. The plan of arrangements involves a proposed liquidation and dissolution with provision that if various shareholders of record cannot be found after outreach efforts, their pro rata entitlement to return of the Corporation's capital will accrue to and be paid to the remaining known shareholders. The corporation argues the plan of agreement is a 'pro rata' arrangement and that it is intended to be used for a purpose which the legislature did not intend. HELD: The court found that s.186.1 was being used by the corporation for a purposes which the corporation did not intended. The court was not satisfied that s.(186.2) of the Act was being misconstrued. The purpose of the arrangement was to circumvent the mandatory requirements of the act and to ensure that the corporation's creditors and shareholders were not shareholders. It was not undertaken for a valid business purpose within the approval criteria set forth in the Act. It is not possible for the court to approve a plan that permits the court, under s.185(4), to override the mandatory directions contained in s.220(3) and s.210(m) of The Act.
column4: [25] It is my opinion that s. 186.1 of the SBCA is here being used by FCC for a purpose which the legislature did not intend. HELD: The court found that s.186.1 was being used by FCC for a purpose which the legislature did not intend. It was not the purpose of the plan. The court was satisfied that the proposal was a reasonable business plan and that the proposed arrangement was fair and reasonable. It found no conflict between the powers given to the court under s.185.1(4) and s.210(m) of the SBCA and the Court was not satisfied that it had the wider purpose and intent of the legislation. The Court was also satisfied that its powers were discretionary and should not be exercised as requested by the applicant.

column13: Shareholders of FCC approved a plan of arrangement and sought an order approving it pursuant to s. 186.1 of The Business Corporations Act. The plan proposed a liquidation and dissolution with provision that if various shareholders of record cannot be found after outreach efforts, their pro rata entitlement to return of the corporation's capital will accrue to and be paid to the remaining known shareholders. The Director of Saskatchewan Corporations opposed approval of the plan on the basis that s. 204 of the Act requires a corporation to distribute its assets according to their respective rights on dissolution. The proposal of FCC will extinguish this basic right and the shareholders will have little, if any, return on their investments over the next thirty years. HELD: The court found that the SBCA was being used by FCC for a purpose which the legislature did not intend. It was not being used to circumvent the requirements of s. 220. The court also found no conflict between the power of the court to approve a proposed distribution and the powers given the court under s. 209 to permit the Court to approve any proposed interim or final distribution to shareholders in money or in property and that the Court could order payment out to them on proof of entitlement.

column18: Shareholders of FCC approved a plan of arrangement and sought an order approving it pursuant to s. 186.1 of The Business Corporations Act. The plan proposed a liquidation and dissolution with provision that if various shareholders of record cannot be found after outreach efforts, their pro rata entitlement to return of the corporation's capital will accrue to and be paid to the remaining known shareholders. The Director of Saskatchewan Corporations opposed approval of the plan on the basis that s. 204 of the Act requires a corporation to distribute its assets according to their respective rights on dissolution and s. 220 directs that property distributable to shareholders who have 'proven claims in establishing their status as Shareholders rather than having portion of the proceeds revert to the Minister of Finance in the right of Saskatchewan pursuant to the SBCA.' HELD: 1) It is my opinion that s.(186.1) is here being used by FCC for a purpose which the legislature did not intend. 2) The court can exercise its power under s. 210(l) while comply with the mandatory direction in ss. 220(m). The context within which this is provided must be considered. It is just and equitable that the court in this case is given the power to override the mandatory directions contained in s220(1) of the CBCA. Given the decision by Saskatchewan and other provinces to pass business corporations' legislation that essentially replicated the BCA, have no difficulty in finding the Supreme Courts analysis in BCE to be equally applicable.

column2: The Minister of Social Services applied for an order committing a two-year-old child to the care of his maternal grandparents for an indefinite period of time. The grandparents were previously designated as persons of sufficient interest. The child had lived with them since birth. The mother and father both suffered from addictions and had stopped living together by the time the child was born. The father had multiple criminal convictions, including drinking and driving offences and weapons offences. The mother’s relationship with her parents, family support worker and child protection worker during the course of the child’s life had been marked by volatility, argumentative behaviour and threats, one of which resulted in criminal harassment charges. The child was the subject of a protection order, which imposed conditions upon his parents. Neither meaningfully complied with the conditions set out in the protection order. Both parents testified at trial that their present circumstances were not suitable to raise a child. Each expressed intention to take steps necessary to provide a home for the child. Each parent asserted that a temporary order was appropriate. | HELD: The child was placed in the custody of his grandparents on an indefinite basis, which, while not temporary, was not as potentially immutable as a permanent order. That the child was in need of protection was not seriously challenged by either his mother or father. The prospect for change at the time of trial was limited to statements of good intentions. On their own, such statements were insufficient. There were opportunities for the parents to demonstrate a reasonable prospect for change. These opportunities were squandered and, in some cases abusively rejected by the mother.
column3: HELD: The Court found that the Minister of Social Services sought an order pursuant to s. 37(1)(b) of the CFSA that the child be committed to the care of the parents for an indefinite period of time. The Ministry's position was that the children had been in need of protection for some time and that a temporary order would be appropriate. The Court also found that there was insufficient stability in the children's lives to justify an indefinite order for the child to be placed with the parents. The Minister also suggested that a permanent order for custody be ordered. The court reviewed the evidence and found that although the children were in need, they were not receiving the level of parenting that was appropriate under s.37.
column4:
In this proceeding, the Minister of Social Services [Ministry] seeks an order, pursuant to s. 37(1)(b) of the CFSA, that C.T. be committed to the care of A.R.’s parents for an indefinite period of time. In its place, A.T. suggests a temporary
order, of up to one year, under s. 37(7) of the CFSA. A.T. contends that,
with this additional time, he will be able to demonstrate sufficient stability, both in his lifestyle and behaviour, that he would be able to resume parenting C.T. Accordingly, A.R. also suggests that a temporary order would be appropriate. In other words, while the proposed order would not be a temporary order, it would not be as potentially immutable as a s. 37(2) order. These were opportunities for the parents to demonstrate a reasonable prospect for change – something more palpable and more meaningful than any statements of good intentions could ever be. It necessarily follows that an indefinite order under s. 37(1)(b), as requested by the Ministry, should issue. CONCLUSION [56] In the result, there will be an order placing C.T. in
the custody of the persons of sufficient interest, Mr. and Ms. R., on an indefinite basis.

column2: /n The accused was charged with violating s. 7(2)(b) of the Saskatchewan Fishery Regulations, 1995 by unlawfully fishing in an area of Canoe Lake, specifically Jans Bay, that had been closed to all fishing since 1993 because of overfishing by the local commercial fishery industry. The accused, a status Indian with Aboriginal and Treaty 10 rights, was fishing for food. He had used a net in the restricted area and had caught eight suckers, two walleye and one northern pike. The Bay was very close to the residence of the accused on the Canoe Lake First Nation and was his preferred area to fish. The remainder of Canoe Lake was subject to restrictions governing all fishing but open to unlimited Treaty sustenance fishing all year round. The accused admitted to the actus reus of the offence. Under the Constitutional Questions Act, 2012 the accused gave notice that he would argue that s. 7(2)(b) of the regulations was invalid because it restricted his Treaty and Aboriginal right to fish food in the restricted area as defined by the Regulations; infringed his Treaty and Aboriginal right to fish for food as protected by s. 35(1) of the Constitution Act, 1982; and infringed his Treaty and Aboriginal right to fish for food as protected by s. 25 of the Charter of Rights. The agreed Statement of Facts confirmed the accused’s Aboriginal Treaty status and right to sustenance fishing. The Crown’s major witness was an expert in fish biology and he testified that the restricted area had been closed to protect it for walleye spawning. He stated that the closed area could not be opened for sustenance fishing. The conservation effort had been supported by the Canoe Lake Band Council./n HELD: The accused was found guilty. The court found that the accused had failed to show a breach of his Treaty fishing right that would raise a defence or a Charter remedy to the charge against him: 1) the challenged regulations were within the implied common law limitations on Aboriginal fishing rights; 2) alternatively, the regulations fell within the provisions that permitted such regulations in Treaty 10; 3) alternatively, if they were not within the implied limitations of the right, the evidence had not established a prima facie infringement of the right; 4) alternatively, if there was a breach, it met the justification principles set out in Sparrow and Pierone.
column3: The accused was charged with unlawfully fishing for or catch and retain fish in waters of the Canoe Lake Band. The evidence was that the accused was a Treaty Indian and that the fishing was conducted in a manner consistent with the terms of the Treaty. The Court found that the evidence was so extensive that it could not be relied on to infringe upon the Treaty right to fish for food twenty-three years later. The accused admitted to the actus reus of the substantial charge but put forth as defence his Treaty rights to fish in any water and at any time he so wished. The court found that there was no evidence that the Treaty rights were infringed upon in any event.

column8: The accused was charged with fishing for or for sustenance in violation of s. 7(2)(b) of the Saskatchewan Fishery Regulations, 1995, made pursuant to The Fisheries Act, 1995. The accused had been fishing for food in Jans Bay and other waters of Canoe Lake since 1991. He had caught eight white sucker fish, two walleye and one northern pike. He put forth as defence his Treaty rights to fish in any water and at any time he so wished. HELD: The accused was found guilty of the actus reus and the charge was stayed. The Court found that the accused was guilty of breaching his Treaty right to sustenance fishing. The court also found that there was no evidence that the respondent had breached his treaty right to fish. The issue was whether the respondent was bound by s.7(2(b)(b)(c)(d)) of the Fisheries Regulations. It was not clear that the Crown had asked the Court to lift the ban. The evidence presented was that there had been a meeting between the respondent and the respondent regarding the issue of the closure of the Jans bay area. The respondent admitted that he had spoken to the respondent's brother and sister and that they had discussed the possibility of a commercial fishing licence in the area.

column2: HELD: The accused were each acquitted of all charges. The court believed the evidence provided by the two accused and found that it was possible that the lease represented the actual arrangement between them and O.G. and that they believed that there only 400 plants in the greenhouses and they were part of a legal grow operation. The letter provided by O.G. purporting to change the address of his licences was found to have been forged by him. Regarding the possession for the purpose of trafficking, the court found that it was not satisfied on the evidence that either of the accused ever had personal possession or control of the marijuana plants nor that they had joint or constructive possession by virtue of some arrangement with O.G. The accused had explained that the cash seized by the police from their house had been received by them after they sold a trailer.
column3: HELD: The Court held that an information expanding the time particulars of the offence can be made at trial based upon evidence that indicates the offence may have been committed within the amended timeframe. The Court also held that the only rational conclusion to be drawn in respect of the cash found in their residence was that it was property obtained by the commission of an indictable offence in Canada. The Crown challenged the evidence of the accused. The court held that a handshake agreement was made with the parties that the parties would work together to grow marijuana plants. The evidence established that the accused were active participants in the marihuana grow operation and were in the possession for the purposes of trafficking. Based on the totality of the evidence, the only conclusion to being drawn in regard of the money found in the residence is that it is property obtained from the commission.

column2: HELD: The court sentenced the accused to a global sentence of 10 years for the manslaughter conviction. A one-year concurrent sentence was imposed for the conviction of prohibited possession of a firearm. The court gave him credit at the rate of 1:1.5 for his time on remand, resulting in a net global sentence of six years, five months to be served in a federal penitentiary. The Gladue report was considered and the background of the accused was assessed as an enormous mitigating factor. The court found that this was not an appropriate case to make an order pursuant to s. 743.6 of the Code both because of the multiple Gladue factors and because it had addressed the principles of denunciation and deterrence in the global sentence.
column3: HELD: The Court found that a global sentence of 10 years was appropriate in this case to be served in a federal institution on the manslaughter conviction. The Crown had changed its counsel and requested a dedicated Gladue Report. The court reviewed the cases provided to it by counsel and the Crown and agreed that a 15 year global sentence was appropriate. The Court reviewed the three cases provided by counsel but the Crown had not provided any evidence as to Gladue factors. The evidence was clear that the Crown did not intend to rely specifically on the Gladue factor. The trial judge had indicated that he did not have the up-to-date record of the accused and that he was not aboriginal. The sentencing judge had also indicated that the accused had a history of violent offending and that the evidence did not show that he had a significant remorse. The sentence for the manslaughter was increased to that of 10. The judge noted that the Gladues factors were not considered in the sentencing decision. The sentences for the offence were reduced to that for the first time in the history of the offence. The accused was given credit for 3 years, 7 months and 1.5 years on remand for the time he spent on remands since being arrested. The amount of time he had spent on a remand was reduced to 1.25 to 1 year. The length of time that he would have been out of the country was reduced by the amount of remand. The average sentence for a manslaughter conviction is between 4 years and 5 months. The maximum sentence for manslaughter is 10 years. The offence is unique in that it covers a broad spectrum of circumstances. There are numerous Gladue Factors relevant to the offence and the degree of responsibility of the offender. The defendant was found not guilty of manslaughter but guilty of second degree murder. The factors relevant to him were the combination of Gladue and manslaughter factors.
column4: [16] On the other hand there is one huge mitigating factor and that is the multiple Gladue factors relevant to Gordon taken as a whole. Having considered all of the purposes and principles of sentencing as outlined in ss. 718, 718.1 and 718.2 of the Criminal Code including the totality principle and the Gladue factors the Court has determined that a global sentence of 10 years is appropriate in this case to be served in a federal institution on the manslaughter conviction. [34] As agreed by counsel for the Crown and defence Gordon shall be given credit of three years, seven months pursuant to s. 719 of the Criminal Code for the time he has spent on remand since being arrested on February 25, 2016 to today’s date at the rate of 1.5 to 1. Denunciation and deterrence have already been figured prominently in my analysis in determining that a 10 year global sentence is appropriate in this case. Conclusion [39] For all the reasons as outlined in this decision I have concluded that as to the manslaughter conviction a sentence of 10 years in a federal institution is an appropriate sentence in the circumstances of this specific case. At the rate of 1.5 to 1 credit is to be given of three years, seven months. Gordon Fiddler shall therefore serve an additional six years, five months in a federal penitentiary with regard to the manslaughter conviction. [40] As to Count No. 2 on the Direct Indictment being the possession of a firearm while he was prohibited from doing so contrary to s. 117.01(1) of the Criminal Code I sentence Gordon Fiddler to a concurrent sentence of one year.

The Court reviewed all of the cases provided to it by counsel and the Crown including the totality principle and the Gladue factor. It was concluded that the sentence for the offence of manslaughter was between 4 years and 12 years. The court reviewed the various victim impact statements of the siblings of the victim and four of his brothers and found that the sentences imposed were similar to those imposed for manslaughter.

column2: The plaintiff vendors claimed damages for mental distress following an aborted real estate transaction. The breach of contract by the defendant purchasers had a domino effect as the plaintiffs had intended to buy a condominium and were sued by their intended vendor, who in turn was a party to a contingent real estate transaction. When the transaction fell apart, the female plaintiff broke down and needed medical treatment. For the plaintiffs and awarding aggravated damages in the amount of $1,000 to the male plaintiff for frustration/hardship and $5,000 to the female plaintiff for mental distress/follow up treatment. The court distinguished between punitive and aggravated damages and noted that the defendants' breach of contract did not have to be 'wanton or reckless' for the plaintiffs' claim in mental distress to succeed. These damages arose naturally from the breach and were foreseeable at the time the contract was executed.
column3: The plaintiffs sought damages for mental distress following an aborted real estate transaction. The defendants had refused to close the deal and the plaintiffs had been unable to complete the purchase. The plaintiffs had obtained an order striking the defendants' defence and entering a summary judgment against them. The plaintiff had been unsuccessful in obtaining financing for the sale of the property. The defendant had then proceeded to waive the conditional sale clause and the plaintiff had to pay $20,000 for the mortgage. The court found that the defendants had been totally irresponsible in allowing the plaintiff's claim for mental anguish to proceed. The Court found that damages for emotional distress were not available in breach of contract cases because contractual damages must be tangible, estimable and compensatory.
column4: This application involves damages claimed for mental distress following an aborted real estate transaction. Mr. and Mrs. Gourlay claim damages from Mr. and Mrs. Osmond due to the defendants' inability to complete the purchase of the plaintiffs' home on June 29, 1990. The defendants knew or reasonably ought to have known that Mrs. Gourlay's mental suffering was a foreseeable consequence. I therefore award Mr. Gourlay $1,000.00 aggravated damages. I award her aggravated damages for mental distress in the amount of $5,000.00, and I note this to be the same sum awarded by Galligan, J. in Widdrington, supra for the vexation, frustration, distress and anxiety caused the vendors as a result of the purchasers' failure to complete their Agreement of Purchase and Sale.

column2: The parties lived together for some 12 years before separating in 1988. The plaintiff was 53 and the defendant 60. The plaintiff sought an order under the Partition Act for the partition and sale of two properties owned jointly and a division of property owned by the defendant based on a constructive trust. The defendant owned and operated residential rental properties. The plaintiff, who had stopped working as a medical records technician in 1988, maintained the household and assisted in the business by answering phones, bookkeeping, showing apartments and helping with minor repairs. (1) that the plaintiff met the three requirements to prove an unjust enrichment by virtue of the plaintiff's contributions of time and money, namely (a) an enrichment, (b) a corresponding deprivation, and (c) the absence of any juristic reason for the enrichment. The proper remedy was an award of monetary damages representing 25% of the increase in the value of the defendant's assets during the relationship, not the imposition of a constructive trust; and (2) jointly held properties were to be sold pursuant to the Partition Act, unless the plaintiff elected to buy out the defendant's one half interest within 30 days. Prejudgment interest was calculated from the date of separation to September 1, 1991, at 10% per year.
column3: The plaintiff sought an order under the Partition Act for the partition and sale of two properties owned jointly by the parties, a declaration of ownership regarding personal property and a division of other property owned by the defendant based on a constructive trust. The parties lived together for twelve years and had three children from prior marriage. The plaintiff was the owner of a mobile home, furniture and car. The defendant owned four other properties in their joint names. The respondent owned a truck and motor vehicle. The two parties lived in the mobile home until 1979 when the parties moved to their log house. For the four years the parties lived there, the plaintiff paid all of household expenses with the exception of the $20 per week that the respondent contributed towards the food. The husband worked part-time as a truck driver. The wife worked part time and the parties' home was in the log house for four years. The court found that the wife had met the three requirements to prove an unjust enrichment. The evidence showed that the husband had a reasonable expectation of receiving an interest in the property and that the defendant knew or ought to have known of this expectation. The Court found that Mrs. Keddy had met these requirements. The only issue was whether the wife was entitled to an interest. The judge must determine whether the contribution was sufficient and direct to entitle the plaintiff to an Interest in the Property.
