column13: The applicant sought injunctive relief pursuant to s. 65 of The Queen's Bench Act and Queen’s Bench Rule No. 387(a) prohibiting and restraining the respondent from producing any potassium sulphate and prohibiting the defendants from selling, marketing or otherwise disposing of any potassium sulfate during the life of the injunction. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The respondent was found not to have a proprietary interest in the scientific principles of ion exchange and crystallization as defined in the Technology Licensing Agreement. 2)The applicant did not establish prima facie evidence that the technology used by the respondent was the technology licensed to it by the defendant. The evidence established that the defendant had no prior knowledge of the technical specifications of the technology and that it was not the only source for such information.  3)The court found that the applicant had not obtained sufficient assurances from the defendant that its technology was efficient enough for its needs. The court ordered costs of the application. 4)The defendant was found to have breached the terms of the Technology License Agreement. 5)The plaintiff was found liable for the costs of this application. 6)The Court found that there was insufficient evidence to support the claim that Big Quill had obtained a proprietary or confidential information from the plaintiff.

column18: The applicant sought injunctive relief pursuant to s. 65 of The Queen's Bench Act and Queen’s Bench Rule No. 387(a) prohibiting and restraining the respondent from producing any potassium sulphate and prohibiting the defendants from selling, marketing or otherwise disposing of any potassium sulfate during the life of the injunction. The factual foundation upon which the applicant relies is set forth in detail in the affidavit of Harvey Haugen, businessman resident at the town of Wynyard, Saskatchewan. HELD: 1) PSC Alsask entered into the Technology Licensing Agreement with the view to considering Big Quill's potassium-sulphate production system as a possible option for its Alask plant. 2) The plaintiff obtained an exclusive license from the defendant to use the ion exchange technology developed by the defendant. The defendant was well aware prior to the commencement of the action that the process used by the plaintiff was clearly a technology licensed to it by Bigquill. 3) The defendant is attempting to assert that it somehow has a proprietary interest in the scientific principles known as ion exchange and crystallization. The fact that the defendant developed its own system from scratch with the assistance of third parties and not Big Quills demonstrates that it was not the only source for such technology. 4) The applicant is also seeking an interlocutory injunction to restrain and prohibit the defendant from producing or marketing any potassium-spiculate produced at its plant. 5) Costs of this application.  6) The court reviewed the Affidavit sworn June 29, 2000 in relation to the within application and make the following comments: 1. The applicant has been the President and Director and Shareholder of the defendant for the past 3 years. The plaintiff has not paid any funds whatsoever to the defendant under the terms of the Technology License Agreement and/or the exclusive marketing agreement and as result thereof, the within litigation was commenced in February, 1998. 7) In addition to the Confidentiality Agreement, the defendant has not been able to establish prima facie case that the ion-exchange technology licensed by BigQuill is the technology used to produce potassium- sulphate. The court is also required to pay the fee specified in the Act. 8) The Court is required to determine whether the plaintiff has a contractual or other relationship with the defendant and whether the parties involved in the action have a contractual relationship. 9) The facts of the matter are set out in Exhibit A of the affidavit.

column2: The applicant was aware that allegations of abuse had been made against him in an alternative dispute resolution process undertaken by the Province with respect to his former employment. He applied under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act for certain information concerning these allegations. The FOIPOP Privacy Coordinator denied access and the applicant appealed. Appeal allowed; in all cases where the claimants had signed release forms the applicant is to be supplied with information as to the number and nature of allegations made against him and the names of the complainants; the specific dates and times of all allegations made against him; the evidence collected in relation to the investigations undertaken as a result of the allegations; the number and dollar amount of payouts made for actions attributable only to the applicant; and information as to whether any of the allegations leveled were dismissed or unproven. The appeal should proceed as an appeal de novo. The applicant was not seeking information from R.C.M.P. files and the release of information which the police had passed on to the Department of Justice would not harm law enforcement as the information was compiled by the Province for its own purposes. The complainants had been required to execute releases whereby the information supplied could be used for various specified purposes, all of which potentially involved public disclosure or disclosure to the applicant. Law enforcement protection was lost when a release was obtained from the complainants and the information was passed to the Province. There was no unreasonable invasion of the claimants' privacy. The applicant was entitled to know what he had been accused of and should have the right to correct the record.
column3: The appellant was involved in an investigation into allegations of institutional abuse in three youth correctional institutions. The respondent had been involved in the investigation of the complaints and provided statements to the public. The public had been exposed to numerous allegations of abuse and the respondent had provided undertakings of confidentiality to former residents of the institutions. He had also provided statements that were not made public. He appealed. Appeal dismissed. The appellant had been aware of the allegations and was aware of their scope of investigation. The investigation was a summary process driven by the applicants. The review process did not include an opportunity for persons against whom allegations of systemic abuse had been made to respond. The applicant had been advised that the respondent's statements would not be circulated elsewhere without his consent. The evidence was not conclusive. The court found that the appellant's statements were not credible.
column4: [1] This is an appeal by Lee Keating (Keating) pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, S.N.S. 1993, c.5 (the Act). The appeal is taken from a decision of Robert Doherty, Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Coordinator of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998, whereby the appellant was denied access to information requested. [43] For the purposes of this appeal I have considered all of the above material including Robert P. Doherty's decision of April 12, 1999 which latter item I have considered to be the decision appealed from in the context of a de novo process. Section 15(1)(a) and (c): For the reasons set forth in my consideration of s.23(b), the disclosure of the information sought will not harm law enforcement and I am not convinced it will harm investigative techniques or procedures. (2) Keating has proved to my satisfaction that disclosure of the information sought, notwithstanding that it may be personal information about a third party, would not be an unreasonable invasion of the third party's personal privacy. 3) the evidence collected in relation to investigations undertaken as a result of the allegations; [63] In complying with this decision the Department of Justice is to take care not to identify by name any other alleged perpetrators of abuse.

column8: This was an appeal pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act. The appellant had made an application for information pursuant to s. 40 of the Act pursuant to which the appellant was denied access to information requested. HELD: The appeal is taken from a decision of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998, whereby the appellant is denied access. 1) Throughout the course of the ADR process there was much publicity and media attention. The allegations attracted much attention and the fact that many past and present employees of the institutions had been accused as perpetrators of abuse was public knowledge. 2) The respondent was given certain 'can say' statements by the respondent regarding all of the accusations made against him. 3) The appellant was given a 13-page letter outlining his background, some of his work and employment history and set forth the reasons for his request for information. 4) The evidence obtained was not conclusive evidence of the abuse. The respondent's statements were not corroborated by the evidence obtained. 5) There was no evidence that the respondent had been sexually assaulted. 6) There were no allegations of institutional abuse. 7) The extent of the respondent's involvement in the investigation of the allegations was not ascertained. The evidence was not corroborative. 8) The court found that the appellant's evidence was unreliable. 9) It was not clear that there was a conflict between the obligation undertaken pursuant to instructions of the former Chief Justice of New Brunswick and those of the Justice Minister. 10) The Court found that although the respondent was not a party to the investigation, he was a witness to some of the alleged abuse. It was also not clear whether there was any evidence that he had been involved in any of the acts. The court concluded that there had been a conflict of interest between the undertakings of confidentiality originally extended by the Justice Department and those extended to the respondent.

HELD: The appeal is taken from a decision of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998. 1) This is an appeal by the appellant pursuant to S.N.S. 1993, c.5 (the Act). The degree to which the various roles of the R.C.M.P., the Departmentof Justice and the ADR Program became meshed and interchangeable is clearly set forth in paras. 11-33 of the affidavit of the appellant. 2) The appellant was aware of the allegations made against him and was aware that the respondent had made a number of so-called 'can say' statements from former residents at the school, making allegations against him. In each and every instance, these allegations are completely and totally false. 3) The respondent was also aware that in the course of the investigation, the respondent was named as and accused of being an abuser. The respondent had been aware of these allegations. 4) Throughout the entire ADR process there was much publicity and media attention and the fact that many past and present employees of the institutions had been accused as perpetrators of abuse was public knowledge. This was especially so for the Sherlburne institution. 5) The degree of overlap between the respondent's allegations and those made by the others was clearly set out in the appellant's affidavit.  6) In many respects as of December 6, 1996, the process may be considered a nightmare for the appellant and other former dedicated employees of that school for boys. The process implemented and/or administered by the Justice Minister of Nova Scotia has commenced anew. This is where the appellant begins to lose his nightmare.

HELD: The appeal is taken from a decision of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998. 1) The appellant is a retired Chief Supervisor of the Nova Scotia School for Boys at Shelburne, Nova Scotia. column19: [1] This is an appeal by Lee Keating (Keating) pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, S.N.S. 1993, c.5 (the Act). The appeal is taken from a decision of Robert Doherty, Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Coordinator of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998, whereby the appellant was denied access to information requested. [43] For the purposes of this appeal I have considered all of the above material including Robert P. Doherty's decision of April 12, 1999 which latter item I have considered to be the decision appealed from in the context of a de novo process. Section 15(1)(a) and (c): For the reasons set forth in my consideration of s.23(b), the disclosure of the information sought will not harm law enforcement and I am not convinced it will harm investigative techniques or procedures. (2) Keating has proved to my satisfaction that disclosure of the information sought, notwithstanding that it may be personal information about a third party, would not be an unreasonable invasion of the third party's personal privacy. 3) the evidence collected in relation to investigations undertaken as a result of the allegations; [63] In complying with this decision the Department of Justice is to take care not to identify by name any other alleged perpetrators of abuse.
column22: The applicant was aware that allegations of abuse had been made against him in an alternative dispute resolution process undertaken by the Province with respect to his former employment. He applied under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act for certain information concerning these allegations. The FOIPOP Privacy Coordinator denied access and the applicant appealed. Appeal allowed; in all cases where the claimants had signed release forms the applicant is to be supplied with information as to the number and nature of allegations made against him and the names of the complainants; the specific dates and times of all allegations made against him; the evidence collected in relation to the investigations undertaken as a result of the allegations; the number and dollar amount of payouts made for actions attributable only to the applicant; and information as to whether any of the allegations leveled were dismissed or unproven. The appeal should proceed as an appeal de novo. The applicant was not seeking information from R.C.M.P. files and the release of information which the police had passed on to the Department of Justice would not harm law enforcement as the information was compiled by the Province for its own purposes. The complainants had been required to execute releases whereby the information supplied could be used for various specified purposes, all of which potentially involved public disclosure or disclosure to the applicant. Law enforcement protection was lost when a release was obtained from the complainants and the information was passed to the Province. There was no unreasonable invasion of the claimants' privacy. The applicant was entitled to know what he had been accused of and should have the right to correct the record.
column23: This was an appeal pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act. The appellant had made an application for information pursuant to s. 40 of the Act pursuant to which the appellant was denied access to information requested. HELD: The appeal is taken from a decision of the Department of Justice, dated October 16, 1998. 1) The appellant is a retired Chief Supervisor of the Nova Scotia School for Boys at Shelburne, Nova Scotia. He was aware of the Stratton Inquiry and the findings of that Inquiry. 2) During the course of the investigation, the appellant arranged to have statements taken from former residents of the institutions. The statements were to be signed by all persons interviewed which releases contained consent for use. 3) Throughout the entire ADR process there was much publicity and media attention. While the claimants were being spared the publicity of a public trial and more importantly cross-examination by experienced defence counsel as to the validity of their claims, they did not anticipate that virtually no effort would be made to ascertain whether or not the allegations being levelled were true. 4) There was a conflict between the obligation undertaken pursuant to instructions of the former Chief Justice of New Brunswick and those of the Justice Minister. This conflict arose as a result of the undertakings of confidentiality originally extended as part of the amended undertakings extended by the Department. 5) In many respects as of December 6, 1996, the process may be considered a nightmare for the appellant and other former employees of the school for boys.

column2: The accused was convicted of having care or control of a motor vehicle while impaired (Criminal Code s.253(a)) but acquitted on the charge under s.253(b). The Provincial Court trial judge did not accept the accused's testimony that his blood-alcohol concentration was between .068 and .081 at the time of driving. On appeal the Queen's Bench judge set aside the conviction and ordered an acquittal. HELD: The appeal was allowed. The Queen's Bench judgment was set aside and the Provincial Court trial judgment was restored. While the appellate judge stated the correct standard of review, he did not in fact apply it and made inaccurate assessments of the evidence and conclusion of the trial judge.
column3: The accused was convicted by a Provincial Court judge of having care and control of a motor vehicle while impaired contrary to s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code. The Provincial Court Judge acquitted him of the charge. On appeal, the Court of Queen's Bench judge set aside the conviction and ordered an acquittal. HELD: The Court of Appeal held that the trial judge erred in concluding that the appellant was impaired and becoming more so during the time at the police station. The Court also held that accepting the breathalyzer demand at 8:31 p.m. was unreasonable. The Crown appealed. The Appeal Court judge did not err in concluding the appellant's ability to concentrate and his judgment were unaffected. The appellate court judge while stating the correct standard of review did not apply to the accused. The trial judge made inaccurate assessments of the evidence and the conclusions of the trial court judge. In her analysis she made inaccurate assessment of the facts and conclusions. The conviction cannot stand. The appellant was acquitted on the count of impaired driving. The appeal court judge's acceptance of the expert evidence that the blood alcohol was rapidly rising and was in the range of.68 to.81 at the time of driving.

The Provincial Court Judge acquitted him of the charge. On appeal, the Court of Queen's Bench judge set aside the conviction and ordered an acquittal. HELD: The Court of Appeal held that the trial judge erred in concluding that the appellant was impaired and becoming more so during the time at the police station. The appellant was acquitted on the count of impaired driving. The appellate court judge while stating the correct standard of review did not apply to the appellant. In her analysis she made inaccurate assessments of the evidence and the conclusions of trial judge thereon. The acquittal because of reasonable doubt on the.08 charge did not have, expressly or inferentially, included in it that he accepted the testimony that the accused's blood alcohol was between.068 and.081 at the time of driving. He did not, in fact, so accept. It is inconsistent with the facts and the judgment of the Court on those facts, which are his sole province, to say that the judge did not see any indicia of impairment but added in re-examination by defence counsel that driving tasks are not affected until levels of 140 150 milligrams are reached. This is reversible error. The conviction cannot stand. The trial judge was correct in concluding the appellant's condition was impaired.

column2: In the context of a divorce proceeding, the husband filed an interlocutory application for, inter alia, the termination of spousal support, and the sale of the matrimonial home. The Chambers judge ordered that the matrimonial home be sold and the assets equally divided between the spouses. The wife appealed. Appeal allowed; certain provisions of the Order struck or temporarily lifted to permit the parties a reasonable opportunity to make timely alternative arrangements to resolve the matters in issue consensually, short of selling the matrimonial home; the court's intervention was necessary to prevent a patent injustice. There was no mention of any division of matrimonial assets in the notice filed by the husband and in the unique circumstances of this case, it was unrealistic and unfair to address the issue of selling the house without at the same time taking into account its value and the parties' individual contributions to that value.
column3: The appellant and his wife had been involved in a dispute regarding the sale of their matrimonial home. The appellant sought to have the matrimonial home sold and ordered that the proceeds of sale be divided equally between the parties. The wife applied for an interlocutory order that the home be sold. The Chambers judge ordered that spousal support be terminated and that the respondent should immediately return the matronly home to her. The respondent applied for a rehearing and a review of the interlocutorship order. The chambers judge ordered the sale and ordered the proceeds to be divided. The petitioner appealed. Appeal allowed. The court found no reason why the matter could not be heard again by the Chambers judge. The facts and history of the case were well known to the appellant and it might accelerate these proceedings and bring about a more timely conclusion if he were to take up the case again. The Court also found no evidence to warrant proceeding with the applications in the manner suggested by the appellant. The application for declaratory judgment was dismissed. The appeal was allowed.
column4: Held: Appeal allowed with costs and case remitted to the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia for a rehearing on an expedited basis, as per reasons of Saunders, J.A.; Bateman and Hamilton, JJ.A. concurring. [1] Cross applications were filed by Mr. & Mrs. Goyetche in Supreme Court Chambers on April 13, 2005 and April 21, 2005 respectively: his seeking orders to terminate spousal support, to sell the matrimonial home, and to return to him certain personal belongings; and hers seeking orders to provide her with interim spousal support, as well as payment of support arrears and a reinstatement of her benefits under his medical insurance plan. [14] In our respectful view, there was no evidence to warrant proceeding with the applications in the manner suggested by counsel. [18] We will intervene so as to correct a patent injustice. [19] We would therefore: (ii) temporarily vacate ¶ 1 Justice Scanlan’s order dated July 19, 2005 so as to permit the parties a reasonable opportunity to make timely alternative arrangements to resolve the matters in issue, consensually, short of selling the matrimonial home. [21] In the unusual circumstances of this appeal, Mr. Goyetche shall have costs in the amount of $1,500 inclusive of disbursements, in any event of the cause, but not payable until the earlier of either the sale of the matrimonial home, or final settlement of the issues outstanding in this matter.

The appellant appealed. Appeal allowed; case remitted to the Supreme Court for a rehearing on an expedited basis. There was no evidence to warrant proceeding with the applications in the manner suggested by counsel. Findings of credibility were entirely within his province and did not require any comment from this Court, should he choose to take up the case again.

column24: Held: Appeal allowed with costs and case remitted to the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia for a rehearing on an expedited basis, as per reasons of Saunders, J.A.; Bateman and Hamilton, JJ.A. concurring. [1] Cross applications were filed by Mr. & Mrs. Goyetche in Supreme Court Chambers on April 13, 2005 and April 21, 2005 respectively: his seeking orders to terminate spousal support, to sell the matrimonial home, and to return to him certain personal belongings; and hers seeking orders to provide her with interim spousal support, as well as payment of support arrears and a reinstatement of her benefits under his medical insurance plan. [14] In our respectful view, there was no evidence to warrant proceeding with the applications in the manner suggested by counsel. [18] We will intervene so as to correct a patent injustice. [19] We would therefore: (ii) temporarily vacate ¶ 1 Justice Scanlan’s order dated July 19, 2005 so as to permit the parties a reasonable opportunity to make timely alternative arrangements to resolve the matters in issue, consensually, short of selling the matrimonial home. [21] In the unusual circumstances of this appeal, Mr. Goyetche shall have costs in the amount of $1,500 inclusive of disbursements, in any event of the cause, but not payable until the earlier of either the sale of the matrimonial home, or final settlement of the issues outstanding in this matter.
column27: HELD: Appeal allowed with costs and case remitted to the Supreme Court for a rehearing on an expedited basis. There was no evidence to warrant proceeding with the applications in the manner suggested by counsel. Cross applications were filed by the appellant seeking orders to terminate spousal support, to sell the matrimonial home and to return certain personal belongings; and to provide an interim order for the payment of support arrears and a reinstatement of her benefits under his medical insurance plan. The appellant appealed the Chambers judge's decision claiming a reversible error on the part of him to justify selling the home and divide the proceeds of sale equally between the parties. At no time did the appellant quantify the division of property he is looking for, let alone express the view that he is seeking an equal division of all matrimononial assets, or specifically half of the home equity. The facts and history of the case are obviously well known to him and it might accelerate these proceedings and bring about a more timely conclusion if he were able to hear them.

column2: Custodial arrangements for the parties two youngest children (aged 15 and 13), who currently lived with the father the majority of the time, were at issue. The marriage had been traditional, with the wife being the primary caretaker of the children. Both children were heavily involved in sporting activities and the father felt that since he was retired, he would be better able to ensure their attendance at various games and practices. The mother, who had recently commenced employment as a social worker, felt that the current interim arrangement was difficult for the children in that they would forget their school books at the other parent's residence and were sometimes left alone for extended periods at the father's residence. Children placed in the custody and primary care of the mother; until the separation, the mother had been the primary caretaker of the children and she appeared to have a stronger emotional bond with them; the father had been physically, emotionally and verbally abusive to the wife throughout the marriage and seemed incapable of putting the children's needs above his own; and the mother was much more likely than the father to encourage the children to have contact with the other parent. Although the father was retired and might have more time to spend with the children, this did not outweigh all of the other factors.
column3: The parties were married for 17 years. They separated in October 2004. They have four children. The oldest child, aged fifteen and three, lives with his mother when they are not attending university. The parties have been living together for more than 30 years. The respondent is a retired taxi driver. He is the primary caregiver to the children. He works part-time and lives in the apartment. The wife works part time. She is a social worker. The husband works part part- time. The children spend most of their time with their mother. The mother works part of the day and weekends. She drives them to sporting events and other activities. The father works part and weekends and is responsible for the children's education. The court has jurisdiction to make final disposition. The best interests of the children are determined by the parents. The test is broad. Parliament has recognized that the variety of circumstances which may arise in disputes over custody and access is so diverse that predetermined rules, designed to resolve certain types of disputes in advance, may not be useful. The Court has concluded that it would be in the best interests for the parties to be in joint custody.
column4: [44] After having considered section 16 of the Divorce Act and all of the evidence I have come to the conclusion that it would be in the best interests of the children to be in the custody and primary care of their mother. 2. The Petitioner appears to have a stronger emotional bond with the children. [45] I am aware that whereas the Respondent is retired he might have more time available to spend with the children. CONCLUSION [46] In conclusion, the Petitioner shall have custody and primary care of Abuchi and Nnkem. He shall therefore have reasonable access to the children including access to the children every second weekend from Friday after school to the following Sunday at approximately 7:00 p.m..

column2: The accused is charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. The Crown applies to admit into evidence oral statements made by the complainant to her neighbor and to the police for consideration of the truth of their contents. HELD: The statements made by the complainant are found to be reliable and are therefore admissible.  1) Hearsay statement may be admitted on a principled basis, the governing principles are reliability and necessity. A number of cases have held that necessity is met when a witness recants or in some other fashion effectively holds hostage evidence that cannot be obtained from another source. 2) There is no other way to obtain the complainant's evidence. Whether her alcohol consumption that night erased her recollection of events or whether she is a hostile witness is immaterial at this stage. Either way she effectively holds hostage that evidence and the court need not determine the reason for the purpose of this application. The test of necessity has been met.  3) With regard to reliability, the question becomes whether there are sufficient indicia of reliability in a particular case to substitute the lack of oath, lack of cross-examination and absence of video taping. Where the hearsay statement was made in circumstances which provide some guarantees of trustworthiness, the test for reliability will be met. The following circumstances are evidence of trustworthiness: the complainant arrived unexpectedly at her neighbor's apartment, she was upset and crying, she asked that police be called, she spontaneously described the assault, she repeated a consistent version to the police, she had fresh red marks which corresponded with her description of the assault and the accused verified aspects of her complaint with comments he made.
column3: The accused was charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. The Crown applied to have the initial statements admitted into evidence for consideration of the truth of their contents for the purposes of this application. The evidence was then called on voir dire. The accused was found not guilty. HELD: The Court found that the test of necessity was met. The Court held that the Court had found that it was not only in situations where statements are recorded on video and taken under oath that there might be sufficient indicia of reliability. Where the hearsay statement was made in circumstances which provide some guarantees of trustworthiness, the test for reliability will be met. Where it was made at a residence which provided some guarantees, the tests for reliability were met.

column8: The accused was charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. The Crown applied to have oral statements admitted into evidence for consideration of the truth of their contents. Evidence was then called on voir dire. HELD: The Court found that the test of necessity was met. The accused was found not guilty. The Court held that the tests for admissibility of hearsay evidence were determined on a principled basis. 1)The accused's evidence was important to the Crown's case and there was no other means of obtaining that evidence. Whether her alcohol consumption that night erased her recollection of events or whether she was a hostile witness was immaterial at this stage. 2)The Court found the test for reliability was met when the accused recanted on an earlier statement. The fact that the complainant was available at trial does not preclude the prior statement from being 'necessary'. 3)The test for necessity had been met.  4)The court found that it was not only in situations where statements are recorded on video and taken under oath that there might be sufficient indicia of reliability.

column2: This is an application by the accused for an order that evidence obtained by way of a telephone interception be ruled inadmissible because it is irrelevant. Alternatively, the accused seeks exclusion of the intercepted communication on the basis that it was conducted in violation of s. 8 of the Charter and ought to be excluded under s. 24(2). The accused is charged with abuse of a position of trust contrary to s. 153(1)(a) of the Code. HELD: The evidence is admissible. The accused's application is dismissed. 1) After examining the transcript of the conversation, it is immediately evident that the contents of the communication are relevant. The complainant and the accused are discussing the intimate details of their relationship. The conversation is logically probative to the charge. 2) The learned provincial court judge did in fact have sufficient evidence before him to issue the telephone intercept authorization. The complainant was prepared to initiate a telephone call to the accused and engage him in a conversation which would likely cause the accused to make admissions or statements which could be confirmatory of her allegations. 3) The authorization clearly permits the police to intercept private communications in relation to an offence under s. 271(1) of the Code. That investigation was live and bona fide at the time that the authorization was obtained. The law in this country is that evidence of other crimes revealed during the course of a lawful intercept process does not render the evidence obtained inadmissible in relation to an offence not named in the authorization. The focus is on whether the interception was lawfully obtained and executed, not on what is discovered. Here the police obtained a valid authorization to intercept private communications in relation to an offence under s. 271(1) of the Code. During the investigation of that charge, they obtained evidence which is relevant to an offence under s. 153(1)(a) of the Code. The fact that the offence of s. 153(1)(a) is not named in the authorization nor included as an offence for which an authorization to intercept private communications could be obtained, does not affect the admissibility of the evidence. Therefore, there is no Charter breach. 4) Even if the evidence was obtained in violation of s. 8 of the Charter, such evidence is considered non-conscriptive evidence. Where the evidence is non-conscriptive, the court ought to go on to do a balancing as to whether or not the evidence ought to be excluded pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter. The factors to be considered are trial fairness, seriousness of the breach and the effect of exclusion. In this case if there is a breach, it was not serious and was inadvertent, the result of unmindful draftsmanship. There is no evidence of bad faith. There is no evidence of manipulation. The seriousness of the breach, if there was one, was minimal, and to admit the evidence would not bring the administration of justice into disrepute.
column3: The accused applied for an order that evidence obtained by way of a telephone interception be ruled inadmissible because it is irrelevant. HELD: The evidence was inadmissible because it was not reasonably supported by the Crown's argument that the police purposely navigated around the fact that offences under s. 153(1)(a) are not eligible for intercept authorizations. The Crown argued that evidence of the offence was inadvertent and that admitting the evidence would not bring the administration of justice into disrepute. The accused argued that there was no Charter breach and that the evidence was admissible because the breach was not serious and was inadvertence. The evidence did not violate the accused's s. 8 rights. The Court of Appeal held that there is no Charter violation. The respondent's applications were dismissed. 1)The evidence was relevant and admissible in that it did not breach the accused s.8 rights. 2)The respondent's evidence was non-conscriptive and did not constitute a breach of s.7(1) of the Charter. The court concluded that there had been no Charter breaches and that there were no Charter violations. The appellant's application was dismissed. 3)The Court of Queen's Bench concluded that the respondent's argument was not supported by any evidence obtained pursuant to s.24(2) of The Charter. It was concluded that it was inadvertently and the evidence is admissible and ought not to be excluded. The trial fairness, seriousness of the breach, and the effect of exclusion were all considerations. The judge did not have sufficient evidence before him to issue the telephone intercept authorization. The matter was resolved in the Court of Justice's favour. 4)The Crown's arguments were not supported. The complainant consented to the interception of private communications and consented. The police believed that the accused sexually assaulted the complainant or alternatively had sexual contact with her while in position of trust and that it would be advantageous to their investigation to intercept telephone communication between the complainant and the accused wherein the complainant would attempt to engage the accused in conversation concerning the alleged improper activity. 5)The court concluded there was a Charter breach. The officer who issued the authorization did not appear to have sufficient information before him. The issue was whether the evidence obtained under s8(2)(c) was admissible. 6)The appellant's evidence is relevant and inadadmissible. The information obtained as result of the telephone conversation is non-consecutive. The applicant's application for exclusion was dismissed

[1] This is an application by the accused, Wendell Willick, for an order that
evidence obtained by way of a telephone interception be ruled inadmissible because it is
irrelevant. [2] The accused stands charged as follows:

WENDELL WILLICK, of the City of SASKATOON, in
the Province of Saskatchewan, stands charged that he, the said
Wendell Willick did

1. BETWEEN THE 8TH DAY OF JANUARY, A.D.
1996 AND THE 23RD DAY OF NOVEMBER A.D.
1999 AT OR NEAR SASKATOON, SASKATCHEWAN
BEING IN A POSITION OF TRUST OR AUTHORITY
TOWARDS [THE COMPLAINANT], A YOUNG
PERSON, DID FOR A SEXUAL PURPOSE TOUCH
DIRECTLY THE BODY OF [L.S.], A YOUNG
PERSON, WITH A PART OF HIS BODY TO WIT,
HANDS AND PENIS, CONTRARY TO SECTION
153(1)(a) OF THE CRIMINAL CODE. the evidence obtained should be excluded pursuant to s. 24(2). [6] I have read the transcript. As a result, I find that there the learned provincial court judge did in fact
have sufficient evidence before him to issue the telephone intercept authorization. [21] However, after analyzing the provisions of the Criminal Code and the

The accused is charged with abuse of a position of trust contrary to s. 153(1)(a) of the Code. HELD: The evidence is admissible. The accused's application is dismissed. 1) After examining the transcript of the conversation, it is immediately evident that the contents of the communication are relevant. The complainant and the accused are discussing the intimate details of their relationship. The conversation is logically probative to the charge. 2) The learned provincial court judge did in fact have sufficient evidence before him to issue the telephone intercept authorization. The complainant was prepared to initiate a telephone call to the accused and engage him in a conversation which would likely cause the accused to make admissions or statements which could be confirmatory of her allegations. 3) The authorization clearly permits the police to intercept private communications in relation to an offence under s. 271(1) of the Code. That investigation was live and bona fide at the time that the authorization was obtained. The law in this country is that evidence of other crimes revealed during the course of a lawful intercept process does not render the evidence obtained inadmissible in relation to an offence not named in the authorization. The focus is on whether the interception was lawfully obtained and executed, not on what is discovered. Here the police obtained a valid authorization to intercept private communications in relation to an offence under s. 271(1) of the Code. During the investigation of that charge, they obtained evidence which is relevant to an offence under s. 153(1)(a) of the Code. The fact that the offence of s. 153(1)(a) is not named in the authorization nor included as an offence for which an authorization to intercept private communications could be obtained, does not affect the admissibility of the evidence. Therefore, there is no Charter breach. 4) Even if the evidence was obtained in violation of s. 8 of the Charter, such evidence is considered non-conscriptive evidence. Where the evidence is non-conscriptive, the court ought to go on to do a balancing as to whether or not the evidence ought to be excluded pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter. The factors to be considered are trial fairness, seriousness of the breach and the effect of exclusion. column8: The accused applied for an order that evidence obtained by way of a telephone interception be ruled inadmissible because it is irrelevant. The accused argued that the evidence was non-conscriptive and that it was the result of unmindful draftsmanship. HELD: The evidence was inadmissible because it did not violate the accused's s. 8 Charter rights. 1)There was no Charter breach and the evidence is in fact admissible and ought not to be excluded. 2)The accused's application was dismissed. 3)The evidence was relevant and admissible in that it does not breach the accused s.8 rights. 4)The Crown did not show that there was a breach of s.16 of the Charter. The Crown argued that because the police believed they were pursuing an offence under s. 271(1) and in the course of that lawful intercept process, obtained evidence relevant to another offence. 5)The Court held that the Crown had reasonable and probable grounds to believe that the accused had committed offences. 6)The respondent's evidence was not conscriptive. The respondent's application to exclude the evidence because it was inadvertent did not raise a Charter breach. 7)The court held that if there was no breach it was not serious and was not inadvertent. 8)The appellant argued that there should be a presumption that the police intended to have the complainant initiate communication with the accused regarding their alleged sexual activity in anticipation of eliciting responses from the accused that would provide evidence concerning the alleged offences. The Court held the respondent had sufficient evidence to issue the telephone intercept authorization. The court also held that although the respondent did not know the police were intercepting private communications, he was prepared to initiate a telephone call to the accused and engage him in conversation which would likely cause the accused to make admissions or statements which could be confirmatory of her allegations. The appellant's argument that such a disclosure would not bring the administration of justice into disrepute was not supported by the evidence. The trial judge did not have sufficient evidence before him to grant the telephone interception authorization.  8)In this case the evidence of the conversation was not admissible because there was nothing material about the conversation. 9)There is no evidence of bad faith. 10)The trial fairness, seriousness of the breach and effect of exclusion were all factors considered. The failure to disclose the evidence to the trial judge was irrelevant.

column27: The accused applied for an order that evidence obtained by way of a telephone interception be ruled inadmissible because it is irrelevant. HELD: The evidence was inadmissible because it was not reasonably supported by the Crown's argument that the police purposely navigated around the fact that offences under s. 153(1)(a) are not eligible for intercept authorizations. The Crown argued that evidence of the offence was inadvertent and that admitting the evidence would not bring the administration of justice into disrepute. The accused argued that there was no Charter breach and that the evidence was admissible because the breach was not serious and was inadvertence. The evidence did not violate the accused's s. 8 rights. The Court of Appeal held that there is no Charter violation. The respondent's applications were dismissed. 1)The evidence was relevant and admissible in that it did not breach the accused s.8 rights. 2)The respondent's evidence was non-conscriptive and did not constitute a breach of s.7(1) of the Charter. The court concluded that there had been no Charter breaches and that there were no Charter violations. The appellant's application was dismissed. 3)The Court of Queen's Bench concluded that the respondent's argument was not supported by any evidence obtained pursuant to s.24(2) of The Charter. It was concluded that it was inadvertently and the evidence is admissible and ought not to be excluded. The trial fairness, seriousness of the breach, and the effect of exclusion were all considerations. The judge did not have sufficient evidence before him to issue the telephone intercept authorization. The matter was resolved in the Court of Justice's favour. 4)The Crown's arguments were not supported. The complainant consented to the interception of private communications and consented. The police believed that the accused sexually assaulted the complainant or alternatively had sexual contact with her while in position of trust and that it would be advantageous to their investigation to intercept telephone communication between the complainant and the accused wherein the complainant would attempt to engage the accused in conversation concerning the alleged improper activity. 5)The court concluded there was a Charter breach. The officer who issued the authorization did not appear to have sufficient information before him. The issue was whether the evidence obtained under s8(2)(c) was admissible. 6)The appellant's evidence is relevant and inadadmissible. The information obtained as result of the telephone conversation is non-consecutive. The applicant's application for exclusion was dismissed

column2: The intestate's biological child, who was one of the personal representatives of the estate, wished to sue the intestate's former employer to have the pension to which he was entitled at the time of his death paid into the estate. The other personal representative of the estate, who was the intestate's spouse, was in receipt of survivor benefits under the pension and, as such, was opposed to the intended court action. The biological child applied to have his stepmother removed as a personal representative of the estate. Application dismissed; the removal of the personal representative would only be in the best interests of those persons interested in the estate if the intended lawsuit was feasible, which it was not. The estate was bound by the terms of the pension plan, which provided that the respondent was clearly entitled, as the spouse of the intestate, to survivor benefits and the payment of a lump sum into her estate if she died within five years of the intestate's retirement.
column3: The applicant was the personal representative of the deceased's estate. She was appointed Co-Administrator of the Estate. The respondent was collecting the pension from the respondent. The applicant had two children, the Applicants and the respondent is not the biological mother of the Applicant. The Respondent was the respondent's spouse within the meaning of the Pension Plan for Employees of the Corporation and the Pension Benefits Standards Act. The deceased's employer had made arrangements with the respondent to designate himself as a single. The applicants alleged that the respondent had made the arrangements with Marine Atlantic to designate him as a homosexual. The respondents contended that the pension should have been paid to the estate rather than the survivor benefits to the respondent, as it was the applicant's position that the Respondent's spouse was not within the Meaning of the legislation and plan and was therefore not entitled to the survivor benefit. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The respondent was in a direct conflict with the applicant. The continuing payment of the survivor payments is an immediate benefit to her, which would be lessened if it were to be paid to her in her personal capacity. Unless the Respondents agreed that the funds should be divided amongst the heirs, the Respondence would be required to bring an action against herself in her own personal capacity in her capacity. 2)The applicant's spouse is defined in s. 1.32 of the pension plan. The intestate is in a position of direct conflict. The Continuing Payment of the Survivor Benefits is an instant benefit to the applicant, which is lessened in the event the respondent agreed that they should be paid into the Estate and divided amongst all of the heirs. Unless there were steps to change the respondent’s status in law, she would be forced to bring action against her in the personal capacity as well. 3)The application must fail.
column4:
[1] This is an Application for an Order removing Joan McGean as one of the Personal representatives of the Estate of David Raphael McGean. [12] The Application must fail. It is not. [13] Section 7.1.1(a) of the Pension Plan reads:
“7.1.1 Except as provided under Section 7.1.2 and Section 7.1.3, on the death of the pensioner, survivor benefits shall be paid

(a) equal to sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the member’s pension to the person who was his spouse at the time of retirement, during the spouse’s lifetime and to the spouse’s estate as a lump sum on the basis of the commuted value of the payments for the remainder of a five-year period from the date of the member’s retirement if his surviving spouse dies within that period.” [19] I am therefore dismissing the application.

The intestate is employed by Marine Atlantic Inc. for approximately thirty-one years. During that period he contributed to a pension plan valued at two hundred eighty-three thousand two hundred thirty-seven dollars ($283,237.00). It is not. The applicant was entitled to costs for the second day but these are offset by the expense she caused the applicants on the first date.

“7.1.1 Except as provided under Section 7.1.2 and Section 7.1.3, on the death of the pensioner, survivor benefits shall be paid

(a) equal to sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the member’s pension to the person who was his spouse at the time of retirement, during the spouse’s lifetime and to the spouse’s estate as a lump sum on the basis of the commuted value of the payments for the remainder of a five-year period from the date of the member’s retirement if his surviving spouse dies within that period.” [19] I am therefore dismissing the application.

The other personal representative of the estate, who was the intestate's spouse, was in receipt of survivor benefits under the pension and, as such, was opposed to the intended court action. The biological child applied to have his stepmother removed as a personal representative of the estate. Application dismissed; the removal of the personal representative would only be in the best interests of those persons interested in the estate if the intended lawsuit was feasible, which it was not. The estate was bound by the terms of the pension plan, which provided that the respondent was clearly entitled, as the spouse of the intestate, to survivor benefits and the payment of a lump sum into her estate if she died within five years of the intestate's retirement.

column2: The appellant was convicted of driving over .08 contrary to s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code. The appellant's memorandum of law and oral argument only addressed whether the police officer had reasonable and probable ground to arrest and demand his breath sample and asserted a violation of his rights pursuant to s. 8 and 9 Charter of Rights. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The trial judge tested the officer's credibility and the judge's conclusion was supported by facts. The officer's belief was based on the observation that the appellant was driving with a flat tire, with windshield wipers operating on a clear night, as well as slurred speech and bloodshot eyes. The officer had reasonable and probable grounds to demand a sample of the appellant's breath.
column3: The appellant appealed his conviction for operating a motor vehicle contrary to s. 255(1) and s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The trial judge was in a position to test the credibility of the officer who made the demand for a sample of the appellant's breath. The officer had reasonable and probable grounds to make the demand, and the appellant had reasonable grounds to do so. The evidence was clear that the appellant was driving with a flat tire and with the vehicle's windshield wipers operating although it was a clear night as well as all the indicia of impairment referenced. Even excluding the slurred speech and bloodshot eyes, the remaining indicia which the officer observed provided ample evidence to support her belief the appellant operated his motor vehicle while his ability to do this was impaired. The appellant's claim for breach of the Charter must fail. The appeal is dismissed.

C-46. [29] The trial judge was in a position to test the credibility of Cst. Forrester. Cst. Forrester’s belief was based on the observation that the appellant was driving with a flat tire and with the vehicle’s windshield wipers operating although it was a clear night, as well as all the other indicia of impairment referenced above. Cst. Forrester had reasonable and probable grounds to demand a sample of the appellant’s breath, and the appellant’s claim for breach of the Charter must fail. [30] The appeal is therefore dismissed.

The appellant's memorandum of law and oral argument dealt only with the contention that the police officer did not have reasonable and probable grounds to arrest him and to demand that he provide a sample of his breath, thereby infringing his right under ss. and of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Part of the Constitution Act, 1982, being Schedule to the Canada Act 1982. Even excluding the slurred speech and bloodshot eyes, the remaining indicia which the officer observed provided ample evidence to support her belief the appellant was operating his motor vehicle while his ability to do so was impaired. The evidence was not clear that the officer had observed the bloodshot eye of the appellant after making the formal arrest as argued by the appellant. column2: The appellant plead guilty to two counts of sexual assault, was declared a dangerous offender and sentenced to an indeterminate sentence. The appellant appealed the sentence arguing that the sentencing judge failed to give adequate consideration to the assessment of two expert witnesses who testified that they thought the appellant should be found a long-term offender. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The sentencing judge was not bound to accept the assessment of the experts. Both experts testified that the appellant's risk to reoffend sexually was moderate to high and was extremely high if he did not receive treatment. Both experts based their opinions, in part, on the idea that the appellant had been a model inmate. Both experts believed the appellant's self report about his behaviour in custody, despite having reached the conclusion that he was a pathological liar. Both experts appeared to take the accused at face value when he said he was motivated to change. In fact, the evidence from correctional officials suggested that the appellant was prone to violent, aggressive and irrational behaviour in custody. He had shown on numerous occasions that he would not follow the rules in the institution and had been involved in several attempts to smuggle drugs into the jail, including picking up a package in the washroom of the court house during his dangerous offender hearing and convincing his lawyer to bring his baby into the jail with drugs in his diaper. The accused had committed two sexual assaults within months of being released from a previous sexual assault sentence. The trial judge was correct to emphasize protection of the public and was entitled to discount the opinion of the experts because it was based on incorrect assumptions. In supporting the sentencing judge's opinion that the accused would not take treatment because he refused to accept responsibility for his offences, the Court of Appeal noted that the accused had stated in his Notice of Appeal that he was serving a life sentence for two sexual assaults that he did not commit and the fact that he sent a letter to the Court saying that he had been falsely accused and did not sexually assault anyone. In addition, the Court considered fresh evidence that the appellant had refused to transfer to another institution in order to participate in high-intensity sex offender treatment pending his appeal.
column3: After the defendant pled guilty to two counts of sexual assault, the Court of Appeal declared him a long-term offender and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. He appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1) The Court of Queen's Bench found that the defendant had not shown adequate consideration to the assessment of two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long term offender. The Court found that this finding was not supported by the experts' evidence. 2) The defendant had vacillated between positions involving the sexual offences. The court found that during the dangerous offender hearing the defendant failed to give adequate consideration the assessment by the two expert experts who both suggested that he was a longterm offender. 3) The Defendant was found to be a dangerous offender because he never had the chance to participate in sexual offender treatment programming. The defendant appealed. Appeal dismissed; the Court was not bound to accept the experts’ assessment. The evidence showed that the Defendant had not exhibited any significant anger or aggression towards the victims. The Defendant had been convicted of two sexual assaults. The trial judge found that he had not engaged in meaningful or meaningful acts of violence. The judge also found that there was a reasonable possibility of eventual control of risk in the community.
column4: Disposition: Appeal dismissed [1] After Orlando Jose Gonzales (“Mr. Gonzales”) pled guilty to two counts of sexual assault, Currie J. declared him to be a dangerous offender and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. Mr. Gonzales appeals from this sentence. [2] Mr. Gonzales contends that during the dangerous offender hearing Currie J. failed to give adequate consideration to the assessment of the two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long-term offender instead of a dangerous offender. [3] For the reasons that follow, I dismiss the appeal. The deciding factor in determining that Mr. Gonzales could not be controlled in the community was, according to the trial judge, the fact that in 2005 Mr. Gonzales committed two sexual assaults within two months of being released from prison where he was serving a sentence for two prior sexual assaults. On August 19, 2010, Mr. Gonzales filed a notice of appeal with this Court stating that “I am doing a life sentence for two sexual assaults I did not commit”. He followed this up with a letter dated August 28, 2010 to this Court where he said that he did not sexually assault anyone and was falsely accused by the victims who were forced to lie by the police. [47] For all these reasons the appeal is dismissed.

HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The defendant was found not to be a dangerous offender because he never had the chance to participate in sexual offender treatment programming. The court found that the assessment of the two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long term offender was correct. 2)The Defendant was found to have a reasonable risk of re-offending as a result of the offences committed within the past five years. The Defendant had been in custody for two years and had been convicted of two sexual assaults. He was sentenced to time served on one charge and on the other to term of imprisonment of 2 years less day. The Appeal Court held that there was no reasonable possibility of eventual control of risk in the community.

The appellant appealed the sentence arguing that the sentencing judge failed to give adequate consideration to the assessment of two expert witnesses who testified that they thought the appellant should be found a long-term offender. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The sentencing judge was not bound to accept the assessment of the experts. Both experts testified that the appellant's risk to reoffend sexually was moderate to high and was extremely high if he did not receive treatment. Both experts based their opinions, in part, on the idea that the appellant had been a model inmate. Both experts believed the appellant's self report about his behaviour in custody, despite having reached the conclusion that he was a pathological liar. Both experts appeared to take the accused at face value when he said he was motivated to change. In fact, the evidence from correctional officials suggested that the appellant was prone to violent, aggressive and irrational behaviour in custody. He had shown on numerous occasions that he would not follow the rules in the institution and had been involved in several attempts to smuggle drugs into the jail, including picking up a package in the washroom of the court house during his dangerous offender hearing and convincing his lawyer to bring his baby into the jail with drugs in his diaper. The accused had committed two sexual assaults within months of being released from a previous sexual assault sentence. The trial judge was correct to emphasize protection of the public and was entitled to discount the opinion of the experts because it was based on incorrect assumptions. In supporting the sentencing judge's opinion that the accused would not take treatment because he refused to accept responsibility for his offences, the Court of Appeal noted that the accused had stated in his Notice of Appeal that he was serving a life sentence for two sexual assaults that he did not commit and the fact that he sent a letter to the Court saying that he had been falsely accused and did not sexually assault anyone. In addition, the Court considered fresh evidence that the appellant had refused to transfer to another institution in order to participate in high-intensity sex offender treatment pending his appeal.
column18: After the defendant pled guilty to two counts of sexual assault, the Court of Appeal declared him a long-term offender and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. He appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The defendant was found not to be a dangerous offender because he never had the chance to participate in sexual offender treatment programming. The evidence established that the defendant vacillated between three positions involving the sexual offences. The court found that during the dangerous offender hearing, the defendant failed to give adequate consideration to the assessment of the two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long term offender. The defendant appealed.  2)Costs of the sentence were reduced to $300,000.
column19: Disposition: Appeal dismissed [1] After Orlando Jose Gonzales (“Mr. Gonzales”) pled guilty to two counts of sexual assault, Currie J. declared him to be a dangerous offender and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. Mr. Gonzales appeals from this sentence. [2] Mr. Gonzales contends that during the dangerous offender hearing Currie J. failed to give adequate consideration to the assessment of the two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long-term offender instead of a dangerous offender. [3] For the reasons that follow, I dismiss the appeal. The deciding factor in determining that Mr. Gonzales could not be controlled in the community was, according to the trial judge, the fact that in 2005 Mr. Gonzales committed two sexual assaults within two months of being released from prison where he was serving a sentence for two prior sexual assaults. On August 19, 2010, Mr. Gonzales filed a notice of appeal with this Court stating that “I am doing a life sentence for two sexual assaults I did not commit”. He followed this up with a letter dated August 28, 2010 to this Court where he said that he did not sexually assault anyone and was falsely accused by the victims who were forced to lie by the police. [47] For all these reasons the appeal is dismissed.

column23: After the defendant pled guilty to two counts of sexual assault, Currie J. declared him a long-term offender and sentenced him to an indeterminate sentence. He appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1) The defendant was found not to be a dangerous offender because he never had the chance to participate in sexual offender treatment. The evidence established that the defendant vacillated between three positions involving the sexual offences. The defendant refused to cooperate with the assessment of the two expert witnesses who both recommended that he be declared a long term offender. 2) For the reasons that follow, the court dismisses the appeal. The trial judge instructed himself properly on the law and noted the appropriate authorities in order to decide the contested issue, namely the third point in s. 753.1(1) of the Criminal Code: whether there is a reasonable possibility of eventual control of the risk in the community. 3) The judge failed to give adequate consideration to the opinions of the experts. He conceded that the dangerous offender criteria were proven. However, the only issue at stake was whether the trial judge was satisfied there was a reasonable risk that he was lying about the offences and that he would not be eligible for programing if he did not accept responsibility.

column2: The appellant appealed the Queen's Bench decision that denied him damages for defamation (see: 2010 SKQB 249). The trial judge held that the defence of qualified privilege protected the Union and its representatives (the defendants in the action) when the latter republished a grievance defaming the appellant by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. The trial judge fixed a provisional award of $25,000. The appellant's grounds of appeal were that the trial judge erred in finding that the defence applied and by assessing damages at $25,000. The respondents cross-appealed on the ground that the trial judge had erred in denying them costs. HELD: The Court held that the trial judge had erred in finding that the defence of qualified privilege applied. Although she correctly identified the law, she had not correctly applied it because she had not given sufficient effect to 1) the wording of the defamatory expressions; 2) the circumstances in which they were published and, in particular, the chronology of events and the separate instances of publication; 3) the persons to whom the words were published; and 4) whether what was published on each occasion was germane and reasonably appropriate to the specific occasion. In general, the Court noted that the respondents could have fulfilled their duty to notify its membership of the grievance filed by the member who alleged the harassment and made its effort to find witnesses to support the member's grievance by sending out a general notice. It did not need to name the appellant and make the allegations it did to achieve its goal. The respondent overreached, thereby placing the statement that the appellant had participated in the harassment of the employee outside the ambit of the defence of qualified privilege. The Court awarded general damages in the amount of $100,000. It held that the trial judge's assessment of damages was erroneous and founded upon mistaken principles of law. The Court was not bound by the range of damages mentioned by the Supreme Court in the Church of Scientology decision but only to apply the principles established in it to the context of this case. The provisional award of $25,000 for general damages was erroneous because the respondents published the documents by mailing them and placing them on the Union's website, over the strong objections of the employer. The respondents left the documents on the website for 6 months after the employer demanded that they be removed. The respondents had never offered an apology and appeared not to have recognized the harm that had been caused to the appellant. An award of aggravated damages was subsumed in the general award and the Court agreed with the trial judge that punitive damages were not warranted because the respondent had not been motivated by malice. The respondent's cross-appeal was dismissed without costs. However, their position was clearly correct in the circumstances: it was not appropriate for the trial judge to decline to order costs in their favour on the basis of 'mixed results', because in defamation cases, the results are invariably mixed.
column3: The trial judge held that the principle of qualified privilege protected the union and its representatives when the latter republished a grievance defaming a member of management by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. He fixed a provisional award of damages of $25,000. The parties argued that the trial judge erred by finding the defamatory statements protected by qualified privilege. The trial judge found the defamed statements were not defamatories but of being untrue. The plaintiff was awarded damages of approximately $50,000 for the defamation. The court also fixed general damages at $100,000 as the plaintiff's reputation would be lowered. The Court concluded that the defence of qualified privileged applies in this case. The claim for general damages was dismissed. The award of general damages is $100. The respondent's claim for damages is dismissed.
column4:
Disposition: Appeal allowed Cross-appeal dismissed [1] This appeal concerns the extent to which the principle of qualified privilege applies to defamatory statements made by a union regarding a member of the employer’s management. The trial judge held that the principle of qualified privilege protected the union and its representatives when the latter republished a grievance defaming a member of management by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. He fixed a provisional award of damages of $25,000 (see: 2010 SKQB 249 (CanLII), [2010] 12 W.W.R. 271). [2] I have concluded that the trial judge erred by finding the defamatory statements are protected by qualified privilege. I would allow the appeal and fix general damages at $100,000. [48] Based on my review of the authorities, I conclude that the trial judge did not give sufficient effect to: (i) the wording of the defamatory expressions; (ii) the circumstances under which they were published and, in particular, the chronology of events and the separate instances of publication; (iii) the persons to whom the words were published; and (iv) whether what was published on each occasion was germane and reasonably appropriate to that specific occasion.  In any event, I am satisfied that in the whole of the circumstances, which I have reviewed extensively in connection with the Respondents’ claim for qualified privilege, $25,000 is a wholly erroneous assessment of the damages in this case. [82] Having regard for the same factors that caused me to conclude that $25,000 is a wholly erroneous assessment of general damages, including what was said, how it was published and the effect on Dr. Rubin, I conclude that general damages should be fixed in this case at $100,000. In fixing this amount, I have considered that: (i) the Respondents published the two documents by mailing them and placing them on the website—over the strong objections of the University; (ii) the documents remained on the website some six months after the University demanded that they be removed; (iii) no apology or retraction has ever been made; and (iv) the Union appears to have had no conception of the harm caused to Dr. Rubin. [85] Having regard for all of the above facts and factors, I have concluded that an award of $100,000 provides sufficient compensation and appropriately balances the positions of the parties. That does not mean that a trial judge in such circumstances could not decline to order costs to a successful defendant, but it is not appropriate to decline to do so on the basis of “mixed results.” [93] The appeal is allowed with costs to Dr. Rubin in this Court and in the Court of Queen’s Bench. Dr. Rubin shall have general damages against the Respondents in the amount of $100,000. Since I have allowed the appeal, the cross-appeal is dismissed, but given that the Respondents are clearly correct


with respect to the issue raised in the cross-appeal, it is appropriate in the circumstances of this case to dismiss it without costs.

However, the impugned words in that document ceased to enjoy that protection once the document was published in such a broad way and for the purposes stated above.

He fixed a provisional award of damages of $25,000. HELD: Appeal allowed. Cross-appeal dismissed. 1) The trial judge erred by finding the defamatory statements are protected by qualified privilege. He found that the statements are not defamed by the publication of the grievance but that the words expressed by the Union would tend to lower the plaintiff's reputation in the eyes of a reasonable person. 2) There was no basis by which the trial judge could have concluded that the impugned statements were contained in the Grievance Report and not in the Union's Statement of Defence. The Union did not plead that its statements were not true or that they were justified in publishing them. 3) The plaintiff was forced to file a grievance when she experienced renewed personal harassment after her return to the workplace. 4) The court reviewed the context in which the words were made when determining whether they were defamed. It concluded the words had no merit to the grievance and that the union's and the Union’s complaints were entirely unfounded and without substance. 5) The Court reviewed the scope of the privilege and the extent to which the statements were protected by the privilege. The Court found the plaintiff was defamed because the words referred to her and her union were published. 6) The award of general damages was reduced to $100,000 as a result of the trial court finding that the plaintiff had not been defamed in the first place. The court found that there was no error in law when he concluded the defamed statements were of no merit. The context and purposes for which the communications were posted are more appropriately considered with respect to the defences to defamation.

The fact that the statements were posted at the Hospital and on the Union's website is not so intimately connected with the process as to justify the extension of the defence of absolute privilege. Furthermore, the extensive publication destroys any possible claim that the Union might have to absolute privilege because the words were published, meaning they were communicated to at least one person other than the plaintiff. The words expressed by the Union would tend to lower the plaintiff's reputation in the eyes of a reasonable person. 2) There was no basis for concluding that the trial judge made a palpable and overriding error by finding Dr. Rubin had in fact been defamed by the publication of the allegations against him.
