In fixing this amount, I have considered that: (i) the Respondents published the two documents by mailing them and placing them on the website—over the strong objections of the University; (ii) the documents remained on the website some six months after the University demanded that they be removed; (iii) no apology or retraction has ever been made; and (iv) the Union appears to have had no conception of the harm caused to Dr. Rubin. [85] Having regard for all of the above facts and factors, I have concluded that an award of $100,000 provides sufficient compensation and appropriately balances the positions of the parties. That does not mean that a trial judge in such circumstances could not decline to order costs to a successful defendant, but it is not appropriate to decline to do so on the basis of “mixed results.” [93] The appeal is allowed with costs to Dr. Rubin in this Court and in the Court of Queen’s Bench. Dr. Rubin shall have general damages against the Respondents in the amount of $100,000. Since I have allowed the appeal, the cross-appeal is dismissed, but given that the Respondents are clearly correct


with respect to the issue raised in the cross-appeal, it is appropriate in the circumstances of this case to dismiss it without costs.
column22: The appellant appealed the Queen's Bench decision that denied him damages for defamation (see: 2010 SKQB 249). The trial judge held that the defence of qualified privilege protected the Union and its representatives (the defendants in the action) when the latter republished a grievance defaming the appellant by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. The trial judge fixed a provisional award of $25,000. The appellant's grounds of appeal were that the trial judge erred in finding that the defence applied and by assessing damages at $25,000. The respondents cross-appealed on the ground that the trial judge had erred in denying them costs. HELD: The Court held that the trial judge had erred in finding that the defence of qualified privilege applied. Although she correctly identified the law, she had not correctly applied it because she had not given sufficient effect to 1) the wording of the defamatory expressions; 2) the circumstances in which they were published and, in particular, the chronology of events and the separate instances of publication; 3) the persons to whom the words were published; and 4) whether what was published on each occasion was germane and reasonably appropriate to the specific occasion. In general, the Court noted that the respondents could have fulfilled their duty to notify its membership of the grievance filed by the member who alleged the harassment and made its effort to find witnesses to support the member's grievance by sending out a general notice. It did not need to name the appellant and make the allegations it did to achieve its goal. The respondent overreached, thereby placing the statement that the appellant had participated in the harassment of the employee outside the ambit of the defence of qualified privilege. The Court awarded general damages in the amount of $100,000. It held that the trial judge's assessment of damages was erroneous and founded upon mistaken principles of law. The Court was not bound by the range of damages mentioned by the Supreme Court in the Church of Scientology decision but only to apply the principles established in it to the context of this case. The provisional award of $25,000 for general damages was erroneous because the respondents published the documents by mailing them and placing them on the Union's website, over the strong objections of the employer. The respondents left the documents on the website for 6 months after the employer demanded that they be removed. The respondents had never offered an apology and appeared not to have recognized the harm that had been caused to the appellant. An award of aggravated damages was subsumed in the general award and the Court agreed with the trial judge that punitive damages were not warranted because the respondent had not been motivated by malice. The respondent's cross-appeal was dismissed without costs. However, their position was clearly correct in the circumstances: it was not appropriate for the trial judge to decline to order costs in their favour on the basis of 'mixed results', because in defamation cases, the results are invariably mixed.
column23: The trial judge held that the principle of qualified privilege protected the union and its representatives when the latter republished a grievance defaming a member of management by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. He fixed a provisional award of damages of $25,000. HELD: Appeal allowed. Cross-appeal dismissed. 1) The trial judge erred by finding the defamatory statements are protected by qualified privilege. The fact that the statements were posted at the Hospital and on the Union's website is not so intimately connected with the process as to justify the extension of the defence of absolute privilege. Furthermore, the extensive publication destroys any possible claim that the Union might have to absolute privilege; the words expressed by the Union would tend to lower the plaintiff's reputation in the eyes of a reasonable person. 2) There was no basis for concluding that the trial judge made a palpable and overriding error by finding Dr. Rubin had in fact been defamed by the publication of the allegations against him.

[85] Having regard for all of the above facts and factors, I have concluded that an award of $100,000 provides sufficient compensation and appropriately balances the positions of the parties. column27: The trial judge held that the principle of qualified privilege protected the union and its representatives when the latter republished a grievance defaming a member of management by falsely accusing him of having participated in the harassment of an employee. He fixed a provisional award of damages of $25,000. HELD: Appeal allowed. Cross-appeal dismissed. 1) The trial judge erred by finding the defamatory statements are protected by qualified privilege. He found that the statements are not defamed by the publication of the grievance but that the words expressed by the Union would tend to lower the plaintiff's reputation in the eyes of a reasonable person. 2) There was no basis by which the trial judge could have concluded that the impugned statements were contained in the Grievance Report and not in the Union's Statement of Defence. The Union did not plead that its statements were not true or that they were justified in publishing them. 3) The plaintiff was forced to file a grievance when she experienced renewed personal harassment after her return to the workplace. 4) The court reviewed the context in which the words were made when determining whether they were defamed. It concluded the words had no merit to the grievance and that the union's and the Union’s complaints were entirely unfounded and without substance. 5) The Court reviewed the scope of the privilege and the extent to which the statements were protected by the privilege. The Court found the plaintiff was defamed because the words referred to her and her union were published. 6) The award of general damages was reduced to $100,000 as a result of the trial court finding that the plaintiff had not been defamed in the first place. The court found that there was no error in law when he concluded the defamed statements were of no merit. The context and purposes for which the communications were posted are more appropriately considered with respect to the defences to defamation.

column2: HELD: The Court held that the replacement of former Queen’s Bench rule 212 requiring the production of documents “relating” to any matter in question and rule 222 permitting examination for discovery “touching” the matter in issue in the action by new rules 5-6, 5-18 and 5-25, which use the phrase: “relevant to any matter in issue”, showed the intention that the broad relevance test was no longer applicable. The test under the new Rules was whether the matter qualifies as being material to the action based upon the matter as pled and whether the evidence tends to prove or disprove the matter in issue. This inquiry must be balanced against the notion of proportionality set out in the foundational rules. The Court dismissed the application, excepting the requested order under 3) wherein the defendant would fulfill its undertaking to have certain employees provide responses. With respect to the rest of the relief requested under 1), which involved the undertaking that the defendant would search its records regarding the loading of railcars, the Court held that the as matter was not an issue in the action, based upon a review of the claim as pled. Having regard to proportionality under the new rules, the defendant should not be required to answer the question in light of the effort and expense required versus the possible benefits. The Court held that the plaintiffs were not entitled to ask the defendants to review a binder containing hundreds of pages of invoices assembled by the plaintiff regarding its expenditures incurred as a result of the derailment in order for it to advise the plaintiff which invoices the defendant believed were not related to it. It was the plaintiff’s burden to prove its damages and the defendant was not required to assist the plaintiff to do so. The plaintiff’s requested undertaking for the defendant to provide any background documents and information that went into the preparation of sketch of the railcar in question by the defendant’s adjuster was also denied. The adjuster’s file was subject to litigation privilege and unless it was tendered as evidence at trial, there was no implied waiver of that privilege. Regarding the plaintiff’s request in 2), the Court agreed with the defendants that that plaintiff’s request that the defendant answer questions now, rather than after it had completed questioning of the plaintiff, was premature. The defendant had not yet taken a position on the cause of the derailment and they would advise the plaintiff when they had developed one. Rule 5-31 makes it an ongoing obligation to correct answers and there was no evidence in this application that the rules had not been complied with. The Court awarded costs in the amount of $1,500 to the defendants due to the complexity of the application, requiring the submission of briefs of law and the amount of time taken to argue them matters in Chambers.
column3: FIAT: The plaintiff asks the court to order the defendants answer certain questions. The plaintiff argues that the defendants, Clarke Transport and Clarke Transport Inc., advised in respect of undertaking 28 that they did not have a position on what caused the derailment and advised CN that they would advise. CN argues that this advice was improper and that the plaintiff's file would be subject to a litigation privilege. HELD: The court found that the questions posed were not an issue in the action. The court ordered the defendants to provide answers to the questions. It was clear that the insurance adjuster's file was subject to litigation privilege and that for proportionality reasons the plaintiff should not be required to answer the question. The Court found that when the defendants moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen's Bench Rules. The claim for negligence was not an important issue and the plaintiff was not required to provide proper responses.
column4:
[18] I am satisfied that when this Court moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen’s Bench Rules. Based on a review of the claim as pled, matters relating to railcars previously loaded by Clarke are not an issue in the action. I am also of the opinion that for proportionality reasons Clarke should not be required to answer the question. [31] The requested undertakings 32 and 33 are to review a binder containing several hundred pages of invoices and other documents assembled by CN that it says are expenditures incurred as a result of the derailment, and to advise which invoices Clarke says are not related to the derailment or which Clarke is currently aware do not relate to the derailment. I find Clarke’s refusal to accept this requested undertaking to be appropriate. However, it is ultimately a plaintiff’s burden to prove its damages, and a defendant is not required to assist plaintiffs to do so. [36] It is clear that the insurance adjuster’s file would be subject to a litigation privilege. Unless and until the sketch is tendered as evidence at trial, I am of the opinion that there is no implied waiver of the litigation privilege that otherwise attaches to the foundational information leading to the preparation of this sketch. But, for the present and in the context of pre-trial questioning, I conclude that Clarke’s refusal to provide a response to requested undertaking 38 was appropriate. [45] Prior to undertaking 28 being taken under advisement, Clarke, through its counsel, advised in respect of undertaking 28 that they did not have a position on what caused the derailment and if they developed a position they would advise. [49] I agree with the position taken by counsel for CN that:

i. Undertaking 34 calls for Mr. Swainson himself to say what he meant or did, as opposed to Mr. Thompson saying what Mr. Swainson meant or did; and that

ii. Undertaking 35 calls for Clarke to make inquiries of Thompson and Swainson and to advise what their personal responses to the questions were. Accordingly, I order Clarke to provide proper responses to CN. [50] In light of the foregoing order that Clarke shall within 10 days of this order provide proper responses to undertakings 34 and 35. The balance of CN’s application is dismissed.

HELD: 1) The court found that when the plaintiff moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen's Bench Rules. 2) It is clear that the insurance adjuster's file would be subject to a litigation privilege. 3) The plaintiff is not obliged to assist plaintiffs to do so. 4) The defendant is not required to assist the plaintiff. 5) The amount of invoices and other documents requested by the plaintiff is approximately $1,500. 6) The claim for damages is not within the proper scope of questioning.

column13: FIAT: The plaintiff asks the court to order the defendants, Clarke Transport and Clarke Transport Inc. (Clarke), to answer certain questions which they refused to answer on discovery. HELD: The application raises interesting issues with respect to the proper scope of questioning or examination for discovery. It is clear that the insurance adjuster's file would be subject to a litigation privilege. Clarke should not be required to answer the question.  1) The court found that when the plaintiff moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen's Bench Rules. 2) It is ultimately a plaintiff's burden to prove its damages and a defendant is not required to assist plaintiffs to do so. 3) The plaintiff is not obliged to provide answers to questions which relate to certain situations. 4) The amount of invoices and other documents requested by the plaintiff is approximately $1,500. 5) The applicant is obliged to answer questions related to the plaintiff's position on what caused the derailment. 6) The respondent's failure to provide proper responses to the undertakings is entirely justified. 7) The Court was of the opinion that for proportionality reasons it should not have been required to provide the respondent with proper responses.  8) Although there is not unanimity of opinion, the prevailing view is that when an expert takes the witness stand or an expert's report is tendered into evidence there is an implied waiver of the information in the expert's file which is foundational to the opinion. 9) The issue is whether production by Clarke of document in respect of which it could have claimed litigation privilege waives any claim of such privilege as regards background information to the document. The history of some 445 cars previously loaded by Clarke are not pled as an issue in the action.  10) The questions were asked while the former court was in effect. The plaintiff's third party liability insurer and its adjuster were involved because of the obligation of Clarke's liability insurer to provide either a defence to the claim or an indemnity. CN says it has its own records that show cars that were not balanced and thus the topic is relevant to its allegation of negligence. In any event, the Court was unable to find much to assist the respondent in this regard.  11) The application is dismissed.  12) The matter of railcars previously loaded is not within the proper jurisdiction of the Court.

column22: HELD: The Court held that the replacement of former Queen’s Bench rule 212 requiring the production of documents “relating” to any matter in question and rule 222 permitting examination for discovery “touching” the matter in issue in the action by new rules 5-6, 5-18 and 5-25, which use the phrase: “relevant to any matter in issue”, showed the intention that the broad relevance test was no longer applicable. The test under the new Rules was whether the matter qualifies as being material to the action based upon the matter as pled and whether the evidence tends to prove or disprove the matter in issue. This inquiry must be balanced against the notion of proportionality set out in the foundational rules. The Court dismissed the application, excepting the requested order under 3) wherein the defendant would fulfill its undertaking to have certain employees provide responses. With respect to the rest of the relief requested under 1), which involved the undertaking that the defendant would search its records regarding the loading of railcars, the Court held that the as matter was not an issue in the action, based upon a review of the claim as pled. Having regard to proportionality under the new rules, the defendant should not be required to answer the question in light of the effort and expense required versus the possible benefits. The Court held that the plaintiffs were not entitled to ask the defendants to review a binder containing hundreds of pages of invoices assembled by the plaintiff regarding its expenditures incurred as a result of the derailment in order for it to advise the plaintiff which invoices the defendant believed were not related to it. It was the plaintiff’s burden to prove its damages and the defendant was not required to assist the plaintiff to do so. The plaintiff’s requested undertaking for the defendant to provide any background documents and information that went into the preparation of sketch of the railcar in question by the defendant’s adjuster was also denied. The adjuster’s file was subject to litigation privilege and unless it was tendered as evidence at trial, there was no implied waiver of that privilege. Regarding the plaintiff’s request in 2), the Court agreed with the defendants that that plaintiff’s request that the defendant answer questions now, rather than after it had completed questioning of the plaintiff, was premature. The defendant had not yet taken a position on the cause of the derailment and they would advise the plaintiff when they had developed one. Rule 5-31 makes it an ongoing obligation to correct answers and there was no evidence in this application that the rules had not been complied with. The Court awarded costs in the amount of $1,500 to the defendants due to the complexity of the application, requiring the submission of briefs of law and the amount of time taken to argue them matters in Chambers.
column23: FIAT. The plaintiff sought orders that the defendants, Clarke Transport and Clarke Transport Inc. (Clarke) answer certain questions and provide answers now based upon their present knowledge, to questions that the plaintiff says are best left to be answered on completion of their discovery of the plaintiff when they will have better information. HELD: 1) The court found that when the plaintiff moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen's Bench Rules. 2) It is clear that the insurance adjuster's file would be subject to a litigation privilege. 3) The plaintiff is obliged to answer questions it refused to answer on discovery. It is ultimately a plaintiff's burden to prove its damages and a defendant is not required to assist plaintiffs to do so. 4) Given the answers provided at the time of questioning, the plaintiff should not be required to answer the question.
column24:
[18] I am satisfied that when this Court moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen’s Bench Rules. Based on a review of the claim as pled, matters relating to railcars previously loaded by Clarke are not an issue in the action. I am also of the opinion that for proportionality reasons Clarke should not be required to answer the question. [31] The requested undertakings 32 and 33 are to review a binder containing several hundred pages of invoices and other documents assembled by CN that it says are expenditures incurred as a result of the derailment, and to advise which invoices Clarke says are not related to the derailment or which Clarke is currently aware do not relate to the derailment. I find Clarke’s refusal to accept this requested undertaking to be appropriate. However, it is ultimately a plaintiff’s burden to prove its damages, and a defendant is not required to assist plaintiffs to do so. [36] It is clear that the insurance adjuster’s file would be subject to a litigation privilege. Unless and until the sketch is tendered as evidence at trial, I am of the opinion that there is no implied waiver of the litigation privilege that otherwise attaches to the foundational information leading to the preparation of this sketch. But, for the present and in the context of pre-trial questioning, I conclude that Clarke’s refusal to provide a response to requested undertaking 38 was appropriate. [45] Prior to undertaking 28 being taken under advisement, Clarke, through its counsel, advised in respect of undertaking 28 that they did not have a position on what caused the derailment and if they developed a position they would advise. [49] I agree with the position taken by counsel for CN that:

i. Undertaking 34 calls for Mr. Swainson himself to say what he meant or did, as opposed to Mr. Thompson saying what Mr. Swainson meant or did; and that

ii. Undertaking 35 calls for Clarke to make inquiries of Thompson and Swainson and to advise what their personal responses to the questions were. Accordingly, I order Clarke to provide proper responses to CN. [50] In light of the foregoing order that Clarke shall within 10 days of this order provide proper responses to undertakings 34 and 35. The balance of CN’s application is dismissed.
column27: FIAT: The plaintiff asks the court to order the defendants, Clarke Transport and Clarke Transport Inc. (Clarke), to answer certain questions which they refused to answer on discovery. HELD: The application raises interesting issues with respect to the proper scope of questioning or examination for discovery. It is clear that the insurance adjuster's file would be subject to a litigation privilege. Clarke should not be required to answer the question. 1) It is ultimately a plaintiff's burden to prove its damages, and a defendant is not required to assist plaintiffs to do so. 2) The court found that when the defendants moved from the words of touching and relating to any matter in issue, it intended to move away from the broad relevance test that existed under the former Queen's Bench Rules. 3) The plaintiff is obliged to provide answers to questions which it believes relate and do not relate to the derailment. 4) There is nothing in Clarke's refusal to provide a response to requested undertaking 38 that is inconsistent with the principles outlined in Rule 5-31. 5) The Court found that it was not obligated to assist the plaintiff to answer questions related to the plaintiff's claim or to the cause of action. It was also not necessary for Clarke to provide responses to undertakings 28, 39 and 40 as it did not have a position on what caused the train derailment and if they had developed a position they would advise the plaintiff. The plaintiff was also required to provide proper responses to all of the undertakings. 6) It was not necessary that Clarke provide answers on the basis of his current knowledge. 7) Given the answers provided at the time of questioning, it is not reasonable to assume that Clarke's documents in respect of which it could have claimed litigation privilege waives any claim of such privilege as regards background information to the document. The Court was also of the opinion that for proportionality reasons the court should not require Clarke to answer.

column2: The Court allowed the application in part. It struck the portion of the claim with respect to damages from debris falling from the defendants’ tree. column3: The plaintiff brought an amended claim for damages from overhanging trees on his property. HELD: The plaintiff was awarded damages for the damage to the plaintiff's property. This was clearly a remedy the Court had not jurisdiction to give. The claim was not frivolous and was not in the context of community standards.

column2: The plaintiff appealed the defendant's decision to grant a partial tax refund only under the Health Services Tax Act. The plaintiff had sought a full refund of tax paid on refrigeration equipment at a pickled herring plant (whose product was to be supplied on contract overseas) on the ground the equipment was used in the 'manufacture or production of goods for sale.' The contract stipulated that most of the processing occur at controlled cold temperatures. The defendant apportioned tax based on the time the equipment was used in the actual 'transformation or conversion' of the product. For the plaintiff, that (1) the tax exemption did not depend on the extent to which the equipment was used in the manufacturing process; and (2) since the contract required most of the process to occur under refrigeration, the use of a cold room was part of the 'manufacture or production' of the product.
column3: This was an appeal pursuant to s. 19 of the Health Services Tax Act, R.S.N.S., 1967, c.126 in respect of a decision of the Provincial Tax Commission to cancel a claim for a refund of health services tax by the applicant, Continental Seafoods Ltd. The contract contained stringent quality specifications governing the processing of pickled whole herring. The use of a cold room in the process performed a function that was part of the manufacture or production of the product. The appellant argued that the Minister and the Provincial tax commissioner were incorrect in not allowing the exemption for the refrigeration equipment in full. The appeal was allowed and the assessment for health services was upheld.
column4: This is an appeal pursuant to s. 19 of the Health Services Tax Act, R.S.N.S. 1967, c. 126 in respect of a decision of the Provincial Tax Commission to cancel a claim for a refund of health services tax by the applicant, Continental Seafoods Ltd. Continental had applied to the Commission for a refund of the tax paid on certain refrigeration equipment which was installed in a new facility for pickled whole herring in Shelburne, Nova Scotia. The contract contained stringent quality specifications governing the processing of this product which included a phase where the pickling occurs in a cooler facility for 28 to 45 days at a strictly controlled temperature of 0ºC to ‑2ºC. The appeal will therefore be dismissed and the assessment for health services tax, as varied by the Provincial Tax Commissioner, upheld. The specification of the Russian contracts required that a significant part of the processing occur in a controlled almost freezing temperature, making it necessary for the use of refrigeration equipment. The use of a cold room in the process performed a function that was part of the manufacture or production of the product, pickled herring. In the result, the appeal is allowed and the appellant is awarded its costs.

column8: This was an appeal pursuant to s. 19 of the Health Services Tax Act. The Act has since been significantly amended. The appellant contended that the Minister and the Provincial Tax Commissioner were incorrect in not allowing the exemption for the refrigeration equipment in full. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the assessment for health services tax was upheld. 1)In order to be eligible for exemption from health services taxes pursuant to clause 10(1)(h)(i) of the Act, machinery and equipment must be used in the actual transformation or conversion of the product actually being produced for sale. Machinery or equipment used prior or subsequent to that actual transformation is not eligible for tax. The function described by the Appellant of refrigeration was not part of the pickled herring process. The use of a cold room in the process performed a function that was part of its manufacture or production. 2)The appellant was awarded its costs.

column2: The Wife sought an interim distribution of matrimonial property and periodic maintenance for the 2 children of the marriage, aged 16 and 13. The Husband had not made an interim lump sum payment in the amount of $2,000.00 ordered in May and had undertaken to provide support monies after harvest. The Husband claimed that the value of the crop harvested was less than the farm expenses and resisted any change in the previous interim orders made. HELD: Application dismissed. The Court was not prepared to make the interim orders requested on the basis of the contradictory affidavits filed. A pre-trial was directed.
column3: The applicant sought an interim distribution of matrimonial property and interim support for her two children, aged 16 and 13. An interim order granted exclusive possession of the parties' farm home with the exception of the tool shed and other parts of the farm yard. Both parties were ordered to have no contact with each other and the respondent was ordered to pay $2,000 lump sum support for the children. HELD: The application was granted and the court ordered that the respondent be denied access to the applicant's workplace. The court also ordered that it be provided with a date for trial.  The court was not prepared to vary or extend the previous order of May 27 and the extended order of October 19 which prevented the husband from approaching the home quarter.

column2: This was an appeal from a trial court decision questioning whether the trial judge erred in determining that the appellant's rights under s.7 and s.8 of the Charter had not been violated. When man involved in an accident checked himself into hospital, the attending physician informed the RCMP of the accident and an RCMP officer came to the hospital. As the appellant had indicated to the physician that he had been drinking, the RCMP constable read demand for blood sample, which the attending physician attempted to obtain. The appellant refused and asked to speak to his lawyer. Unable to contact lawyer, the appellant refused to supply blood sample and was charged with refusal under s. 254(2) of the Criminal Code. The trial judge had held that as the physician attempted to obtain sample for medical purposes, he was not acting in the capacity of agent of the state, and his actions were not subject to the Charter. Dismissing the appeal, that while there may have been some issues of breach of confidentiality, the physician's actions were not analogous to search and seizure within s.8 of the Charter. The trial judge did not err in determining that the appellant's rights were not violated under either s.7 or s.8 of the Charter.
column3: This was an appeal of a decision wherein the appellant was convicted of an offence contrary to s. 254(5) of the Criminal Code. The appellant had been injured in a motor vehicle accident while reclining in an observation bed. While in the hospital, the police officer who had accompanied the appellant to the hospital for treatment for injuries received in a single motor vehicle incident had asked him if he had been drinking and when the accident had occurred as this information might be important to the treatment or prescription he might give. The officer who accompanied the patient to the emergency department had asked the appellant if he was drinking, the accident occurred half hour to one hour prior to the officer seeing him. The police officer acting upon the information provided to him by the officer did not violate the defendant's s.8 Charter right.
column4: This is an appeal by the appellant, Allen Wade Spidell, against a decision of The Honourable Judge Anne E. Crawford dated October 24, 1995 wherein she convicted the appellant of an offence that: Here, the obtaining of the information from Dr. Kydd as the basis of formulating the demand is not analogous to a search and seizure within the meaning of Section 8 of the Charter. I therefore find the trial judge did not err when she found the appellant's rights under Section 8 of the Charter were not violated. I also find the trial judge did not err when she found the appellant's right under Section 7 were not violated. I therefore dismiss the appeal.

column2: FIAT. The Crown applied to have a witness, who was an unindicted co-conspirator and separately charged with drug offences arising out of the same investigation, declared adverse pursuant to s9 of the Canada Evidence Act. She had contradicted her prior video taped statement made shortly after her arrest and had demonstrated hostile attitude towards the Crown. The defence took the position that she was now telling the truth; that the statement was improperly obtained in breach of the confession rules of voluntariness and the statement did not meet the requirements set out in R. v. K.G.B. HELD: The witness' prior statement may be introduced in evidence for the substantive truth of its contents. It will be for the jury to decide what, if any, portions of such statement they wish to accept. 1)A prior inconsistent statement cannot be introduced in evidence for its substantive content, unless the requirement of necessity, and a threshold of reliability arrived at on a balance of probabilities are established. When, as here, a witness recants, the requirement of necessity is established. The real issue is whether the prior statement meets the test for reliability. When, as here, there is only one demonstrably false piece of testimony in the statement, which does not implicate anyone but rather attempts to exonerate someone, the Court was not prepared to say ipso facto the statement is unreliable. 2)The independent evidence sufficiently corroborated her statement in enough different particulars that, but for the demonstrably false portion, it met the threshold of reliability.
column3: FIAT. The Crown applied to have the witness declared adverse pursuant to s. 9 of the Canada Evidence Act on the basis that she has demonstrated a hostile attitude towards the position of the police and has been convicted in a substantial way ofcontradicted in a material way, her prior video-taped statement to police. HELD: The Crown was satisfied that the witness had demonstrated a willingness to cooperate and a threshold of reliability arrived at on a balance of probabilities. The Court was not prepared to say that the balance of the statement was unreliable. The evidence of the complainant's testimony did not corroborate the witness's prior video statement but did sufficiently establish that it met the threshold of reliable reliability. The court was not pre-prepared to say the balance was unreliable in this case.

column22: FIAT. The Crown applied to have a witness, who was an unindicted co-conspirator and separately charged with drug offences arising out of the same investigation, declared adverse pursuant to s9 of the Canada Evidence Act. She had contradicted her prior video taped statement made shortly after her arrest and had demonstrated hostile attitude towards the Crown. The defence took the position that she was now telling the truth; that the statement was improperly obtained in breach of the confession rules of voluntariness and the statement did not meet the requirements set out in R. v. K.G.B. HELD: The witness' prior statement may be introduced in evidence for the substantive truth of its contents. It will be for the jury to decide what, if any, portions of such statement they wish to accept. 1)A prior inconsistent statement cannot be introduced in evidence for its substantive content, unless the requirement of necessity, and a threshold of reliability arrived at on a balance of probabilities are established. When, as here, a witness recants, the requirement of necessity is established. The real issue is whether the prior statement meets the test for reliability. When, as here, there is only one demonstrably false piece of testimony in the statement, which does not implicate anyone but rather attempts to exonerate someone, the Court was not prepared to say ipso facto the statement is unreliable. 2)The independent evidence sufficiently corroborated her statement in enough different particulars that, but for the demonstrably false portion, it met the threshold of reliability.
column23: FIAT: The Crown applies to have the witness declared adverse pursuant to s. 9 of the Canada Evidence Act on the basis that in the course of giving her evidence, she has demonstrated ahostile attitude towards the position of the police and hascontradicted in a substantial way, her prior video-taped statement to police officers made shortly after her arrest. The Crown seeks to use her prior statement, not only for the purposes of impeaching her credibility at trial but also as substantive evidence that may be left with the jury at the end of the trial. When, as here, there is only one demonstrably false piece of testimony in the statement, which does not implicate anyone but rather attempts to exonerate someone, the balance of the statement is unreliable. The real issue is whether the prior statement meets the threshold of reliability. HELD: 1)The Crown has satisfied the requirements for establishing the reliability threshold in the absence of an oath where appropriate substitutes for the oath exist. The reliability threshold is not met even if the witness is sworn and warned prior to giving the statement. The fact that her motivation to do so was to help herself is a factor to be taken into account in assessing the reliability of her statement. 2)It will be for the jury to decide after receiving appropriate instructions with respect to the evidence of an informant and evidence of a person who has provided consistent testimony what portions of such statement they wish to accept.

column2: The accused, employed as doorman and relief bartender at the time of the altercation, was charged with assault causing bodily harm in which the complainant sustained significant injuries to his head and face. Three crown witnesses and five defence witnesses testified as to the altercation in the bar. HELD: The accused was found guilty. 1)The self-defence argument was not accepted. Neither s.34 or s.37 of the Criminal Code justified the assault. 2)The testimony of the Crown witnesses was accepted. The complainant was no threat to the accused in his inebriated state and the accused took advantage of the situation to administer a beating to him. The injuries were not consistent with the scenario described by the accused and the witnesses.
column3: The accused was employed by Uncle Charlie's as a doorman and relief bartender. During the course of the evening there were two minor incidents and exchanges between the accused and the accused. The accused was involved in a dispute with the accused bartender. The Crown witnesses testified that the accused approached them and said 'what's your problem?' The accused said that he had been warned that some penitentiary employees were out to get revenge upon him for his handling of the incident in October. The complainant was employed as a bartender and relief bar bartender. HELD: The accused's defence was accepted that he did indeed attempt to 'get at' the accused whilst being restrained by the accused, but his efforts were quite ineffectual. The Court found that in his 'inebriated state', he was no threat to the accused; the accused took advantage of the situation to administer a 'beating to him'. The Court accepted the defence's argument that the Crown set out to set out a clear assault charge. The facts were as stated by the Crown's witnesses, with the qualification that Baikie did indeed 'get' the complainant whilst being restrain by the defendant. He may have thrown punch at the accused or attempted to do so but his effort was quite ineffective. The court accepted the accused's argument of 'clear assault' and accepted the evidence of 'battery'. The accused did not commit any other offence. The evidence of the accused throwing a punch was not accepted. The defence accepted the Crown was not trying to set up a clear-assault charge.

column8: The accused was employed by Uncle Charlie's as a doorman and relief bartender. During the course of the evening there were two minor incidents and exchanges between Baikie, his associates, and the accused, neither of which progressed beyond the verbal stage. The accused punched the complainant over the shoulder and knocked him down. The complainant then punched the accused on the back of the head and face. He was not drinking on the occasion. The Crown witnesses testified that the accused was in a 'inebriated state' and took advantage of the situation to administer a 'beating to' to the accused. The defence argued that Baikeie did indeed attempt to 'get at' the accused whilst being restrained by the accused and that he may have thrown punch at the accused or attempted to do so, but his efforts were quite ineffectual. In his state, he was no threat to the complainant and that the co-accused in fact took advantage to the situation and administered several blows to Baikey, either at the complainant's head or his face. HELD: The accused was found guilty. 1)The facts were as stated by the Crown witnesses, with the qualification that the Crown witness did not attempt to get the accused's attention or to get involved in a fight. He may have seen the accused make a motion or gesture which he interpreted as an invitation to become involved with him, but he did not initiate the action. 2)The accused's behaviour was consistent with the defence's argument that he was trying to prevent harm from arising out of the altercation. He did not throw a punch but said that he struck the complainant first. He said that the complainant struck him first. The evidence was consistent that the defendant threw a punch and that there was no evidence that he did so. 3)The evidence was not used to set out the charge of assault or to prevent the accused from committing self-defence. The Court accepted the accused guilty of both charges.

column2: The bankrupt applied to annul his bankruptcy on the grounds that he received misinformation or had a misunderstanding concerning the effect of an assignment on the status of potential builders' lien claimants and because his assets had been undervalued. He also asserted that the bankruptcy proceedings were of no value to him as builders' lien claimants have status akin to secured creditors and could pursue the bankrupt personally for any deficiency that may arise if the home is sold and the proceeds distributed among the claimants. The trustee maintained the bankrupt was repeatedly advised or cautioned that bankruptcy may not affect the majority of his creditors. Subsequent appraisals placed the value of his unfinished home at $150,000 rather than $40,000. The bankrupt was now eligible to obtain mortgage financing but first had to get out of bankruptcy. The bankrupt had attempted an orderly payment of debts prior to bankruptcy and had considered proposal post-bankruptcy. HELD: The application for an order annulling the assignment was dismissed. 1)The bankrupt met the definition of an insolvent person at the date of the assignment. It would be dangerous to set a precedent which would allow such an application because of post-bankruptcy circumstances. An improved financial situation and the ability to pay debts in full should not be used as criteria to launch section181 application. 2)The bankrupt had not filed monthly financial statements nor made payments as agreed to cover the costs of the administration of the estate. The onus will be on the bankrupt to comply with the requirements of the trustee to qualify for an automatic discharge on November 15/98 or an early discharge as provided for in s168.1(2).
column3: The bankrupt applied to annul his bankruptcy. Section 181 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act states that the receiving order ought not to have been made on an assignment ought not be filed, the court may by order annul the bankruptcy. The bankrupt submitted that he received misinformation or had a misunderstanding concerning the effect of an assignment on the status of potential builders' lien claimants and secondly the undervaluation of his assets. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)Where in the opinion of the court, receiving order should not have been filed, a court may order annull the bankruptcy." 2)Where the bankruptcy proceedings have been of no value to him, the Court would exercise wide discretion in favour of the bankrupt. Having not met the criteria set out in section 15 of the Act, the bankrupt would be compelled to re-apply for a mortgage on his home. 3)The bankrupt was far from model bankrupt. He has yet to file monthly financial statements and has not made payments as agreed to cover the costs of the administration of the estate. 4)The application was made for an order annuling his assignment.

The majority of creditors, who are secured, would also benefit from the bankrupt's request being granted. If, as the bankrupt states, an annulement of the Assignment would allow him to obtain financing it would likely result in certain builders' claimants having already commenced action.

column22: The bankrupt applied to annul his bankruptcy on the grounds that he received misinformation or had a misunderstanding concerning the effect of an assignment on the status of potential builders' lien claimants and because his assets had been undervalued. He also asserted that the bankruptcy proceedings were of no value to him as builders' lien claimants have status akin to secured creditors and could pursue the bankrupt personally for any deficiency that may arise if the home is sold and the proceeds distributed among the claimants. The trustee maintained the bankrupt was repeatedly advised or cautioned that bankruptcy may not affect the majority of his creditors. Subsequent appraisals placed the value of his unfinished home at $150,000 rather than $40,000. The bankrupt was now eligible to obtain mortgage financing but first had to get out of bankruptcy. The bankrupt had attempted an orderly payment of debts prior to bankruptcy and had considered proposal post-bankruptcy. HELD: The application for an order annulling the assignment was dismissed. 1)The bankrupt met the definition of an insolvent person at the date of the assignment. It would be dangerous to set a precedent which would allow such an application because of post-bankruptcy circumstances. An improved financial situation and the ability to pay debts in full should not be used as criteria to launch section181 application. 2)The bankrupt had not filed monthly financial statements nor made payments as agreed to cover the costs of the administration of the estate. The onus will be on the bankrupt to comply with the requirements of the trustee to qualify for an automatic discharge on November 15/98 or an early discharge as provided for in s168.1(2).
column23: The bankrupt applied to annul his bankruptcy. Section 181 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act reads as "(1) Where in the opinion of the court, receiving order ought not to have been filed, the court may by order annul the bankruptcy." The bankrupt submitted that he received misinformation or had a misunderstanding concerning the effect of an assignment on the status of potential builders' lien claimants and secondly the undervaluation of his assets. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1) An order annulling his assignment was not a dangerous precedent. 2) An annulment of the assignment would result in these creditors being paid in full, much more expeditiously than it would otherwise take. Certain builders' liens claimants have already commenced an action. 3) The bankrupt had been far from a model bankrupt. He has yet to file monthlyfinancial statements and has not made payments as agreed to cover the costs of the administration of the estate. 4) The application by the bankrupt for an order to annull his assignment is dismissed. 5) The bankruptcy proceedings have been of no value to him. It appears from the facts that the majority of creditors, who are secured, would also benefit from the bankrupt's request being granted.

column2: The parties were married in September 1996 and subsequently separated in April of 1999. The parties both seek custody of their only child born in October 1997. The issues before the court is interim custody and primary residence of the child, access by the other parent and interim child maintenance. The parties filed evidence that was considerably contradictory relating to each other and respective abilities as parent. viva voce hearing was held to assist determining the questions of credibility. The mother aged 31 years of age, is employed as secretary. The mother remained at home during the first year of the child's birth then returned to work. The mother suffered from post partum depression following the child's birth and as result attempted to commit suicide. She was hospitalized for three weeks to receive psychiatric assistance. The psychiatrist who treated the mother states the mother is unlikely to have future suicide attempts and has responded well to treatment. The child was with the mother every afternoon during her hospitalization and the mother bonded with her son. The father is currently employed at Ipsco on shift work and is currently living with his parents. The father has had the child since the separation and the child has had little access with his mother. HELD: The child's primary residence should be with the mother. Based on the information before the Court, the mother has always been the primary caregiver of the child and remained at home with the child for the first year of his life. The mother was responsible for the child's day to day needs, health care and child care. As well the father asserts that he was involved in the child's health care needs but was unable to name the child's pediatrician. The father will have access to the child for three days when he is not working including overnight access. The father's gross annual income is $48,897 which results in a payment to the mother for child maintenance in the sum of $393.00 payable on the first day of each and every month until further ordered by the Court. In addition the father will responsible for 75% of the child care expenses.
column3: The parties separated in 1999 and separated in April 1999. They each sought interim custody of their son, W.S.S., born October 10, 1997. HELD: Interim custody was granted to the respondent with access to the primary residence and access to other primary residences. The respondent was to have access to both the primary and secondary residence. The court ordered that the respondent be provided with the primary care of the child and that the primary caregiver be the primary child. The primary caregivant was to provide the child with the medical care and maintenance. The secondary residence was to be provided to the petitioner. The petitioner was to maintain the primary health care of her son. The interim care was to continue in the interim. The child was to remain in the petitioner's custody until the petitioner was awarded interim custody. The Court ordered that all child care costs be paid to the appellant.

The judge also ordered that all costs be paid in the first trimester of the order. The application was not allowed to proceed at any later stage of the proceeding.

column2: The plaintiffs sued based on a contract between the parties that required the defendant to share the proceeds of milk quota sales. The defendant took the position that the contract only required the sharing of fluid milk quota sales, and not all milk quota sales. The plaintiff sought rectification of the contract to change the wording of the contract to milk quota sales from fluid milk quota sales. Finding for the plaintiff and granting rectification, that the parties clearly intended to have the contract cover all milk quota sales. The proceeds from all sales are to be divided between the parties.
column3: The plaintiffs sought to have the agreement terms in regard to the sharing of the proceeds from any sales of milk quota by the defendant in the amount of $33,800. The defendant argued that the agreement only referred to Fluid Milk Quota and therefore it was not obligated to share the proceeds. The plaintiff argued that it was the agreement that was the only reference to the word 'fluid' in the agreement. The agreement provided that the defendant would only share proceeds from the sale of Fluid. The plaintiffs argued that this agreement should be interpreted to mean that if the defendant sold any of the milk quota which it held in 1987 prior to December 3lst, 2003, it was obligated to only share the sale proceeds from that sale of the Fluid milk Quota. The defendants argued that they were not obligated because the agreement did not refer to Flud. The court found that the plaintiff was not in a conflict position. The parties agreed that the terms of the agreement were one and the same. The Court ordered the defendant to provide the plaintiff with the information necessary to make the agreement binding. The evidence showed that the agreements were not signed in any way that would have affected the plaintiff's ability to run the operation. The only agreement that the parties agreed upon was that the respondent and the respondent would share proceeds of the sale from the purchase of Flud and the quota sold. The respondent was not aware that the Agreement only referred specifically to Flid. The terms of that agreement were not in any manner inconsistent with the agreement between the parties. The Agreement was not signed by the parties and the agreement was not binding.
column4: I find that all the parties to the agreement signed in March 1988 intended that the milk quota owned by A.A. Putnam & Sons Limited would be shared by all three if sold within fifteen years of that date. I would therefore rectify that agreement to read milk quota, which I find includes Fluid Milk Quota and Market Share Quota. Based on that rectification I find that the plaintiffs are entitled to their respective shares of all the sales of quota made after March 1988.

The defendants argued that it was the intent of the parties to have the dairy operation continue as family farm in order to continue the tradition established by their parents. HELD: The court found that the defendant was in a conflict position. The agreement only refers to the Fluid milk Quota. It was not the agreement that the brothers and their father had agreed upon. In fact, the agreement was so vague that it became clear that it would not trigger an obligation to share. The court also found that there was a possible conflict of interest between the parties because the defendant and the plaintiff had agreed that Fluid was to be sold separately from the other farm assets and that the value of the farm on going concern basis was about $400,000 less than if the assets were retained.

column2: The appellant and respondent lived together in common law relationship for approximately ten years. Two children were born of the relationship; the parties owned home as well as other assets. They separated in 1995. The appellant brought an application under s. 275 of the Matrimonial Property Act seeking an equal division of assets. She also sought a declaration that the Charter is infringed by the definition of spouse in s. 2(g) of the Act, because it does not include or recognize her common law relationship. The Chambers judge dismissed the application. He found that marital status is not an analogous ground upon which to base claim of discrimination under s. 15(1) of the Charter; or, in the alternative, that s. 2(g) does not constitute discrimination under s. 15(1) of the Charter; or, in the further alternative, that if s. 2(g) is discriminatory, it is saved by s. of the Charter. Allowing the appeal, that marital status is an analogous ground, and that s. 2(g) is discriminatory under s. 15 of the Charter because it denies a person in a common law relationship benefits which are granted to a similar person in a marriage relationship. The Crown did not discharge its onus of proving that the discrimination is demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society. The court rejected the appellant's submission that common law should be read in to the Act, and instead declared s. 2(g) to be unconstitutional and of no force and effect. This declaration was suspended for 12 months to enable the legislature to devise new criteria for eligibility under the Act that do not infringe s. 15(1) of the Charter.
column3: The appellant and respondent were married for ten years. Two children were born out of the marriage. The respondent and the appellant separated in 1995. The appellant commenced an application under the Matrimonial Property Act seeking an equal division of the parties' assets. The applicant sought a declaration that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms was infringed by the definition of'spouse' in s. 2(g) of the MPA. The issue was whether the definition was an analogous ground upon which to base a claim of discrimination under s. 15(1) of The Charter. The Court held that the definition in s2(g)(i) of MPA did not apply to the appellant because they did not come within the definition. The Act also allows judges to make an unequal division in some cases. The application was saved by s. of the Charter.
column4: nan THE COURT: Appeal allowed; s. 2(g) of the Matrimonial Property Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 275 declared to be unconstitutional and of no force or effect — declaration suspended for twelve (12) months per reasons for judgment of Flinn, J.A.; Glube, C.J.N.S. and Roscoe, J.A. concurring. In conjunction with that application, the appellant sought a declaration that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms is infringed by the definition of “spouse” in s. 2(g) of the MPA. [14] As to the first of the three broad inquiries which the Court must make in analyzing a claim for discrimination under s. 15(1) of the Charter (see Law), the MPA denies a person in a common law relationship benefits which are granted to a similar person in a marriage relationship. ..... [18] It is clear, therefore, that marital status is an analogous ground upon which a claim for discrimination may be made under s. 15(1) of the Charter, and the Chambers judge erred in concluding otherwise. [35] The appellant is denied, however, the benefits of the MPA. That being the case, the Crown has failed to discharge its onus of proving that the discrimination in this case is demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society. column18: The appellant and respondent, while not married, lived together in a 'common law relationship' (as they both described the relationship in their respective affidavits) for approximately ten years. Two children were born out of this relationship. The respondent separated in 1995. The appellant commenced an application under the Matrimonial Property Act seeking an equal division of the parties' assets. In conjunction with that application, the appellant sought a declaration that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms was infringed by the definition of'spouse' in s. 2(g) of the MPA. The right to spousal support arises only at the end of marriage. The individual exercises limited but not exclusive control over the designation. The only exceptions to this are the right to equal possession of the matrimonial home and to veto any sale or mortgage of it. These rights arise at the moment of marriage and continue during the marriage. It is only when death, separation or divorce intervenes that questions of title become important. However, the reality may be otherwise. This is even more so where the traditional relationship was in all ways a traditional and fairly long term relationship. In this context, the intermarriage between the appellant and the respondent is analogous to that which occurred in the 1950s and 1960s. column2: Accused is charged with second degree murder in the death of his estranged wife. The Crown sought to admit into evidence a number of statements that were made by the deceased to several crown witnesses concerning two previous incidents she had with the accused in the weeks prior to her death. In the first incident, the accused is alleged to have choked the victim after he confronted her about where she had been. In the second incident the accused confronted the victim and beat and choked her and then sexually assaulted and threatened to kill her. The Crown seeks to admit this similar fact evidence and several hearsay statements to prove the issues of motive, intent and modus operandi. HELD: The statements by the deceased are not admissible. The prejudicial nature of the similar fact evidence has not been overcome by its probative value. It is well established law that similar acts and other discreditable conduct evidence is presumptively inadmissible and that similar fact evidence is the exception to this. To determine its admissibility, three things need examination, 1) the probative weight of the evidence, 2) the assessment of the prejudice and 3) the weighing of the probative value versus prejudicial value. In examining the probative weight of the evidence, factors to be considered include the issues in question, the presence or absence of collusion, similarities and dissimilarities between the facts charged and the similar fact evidence and the strength of the evidence that the events occurred. The two previous incidents are extremely prejudicial in nature leading to potential moral prejudice. That is, reprehensible nature of the assaults could lead the jury to rely on the prohibited inference that the accused is the type of person who could have committed the crime. There is also a great risk of reasoning prejudice. That is, admitting the similar fact evidence may distract the jury from their proper focus which is the second degree murder charge. There is a possibility that the jury will equate the intention to harm with the mens rea required for a murder conviction. With respect to the hearsay evidence, the Court held that statements made by the deceased to her friends, family and colleagues concerning the threats and assaults will not be admitted. The test of necessity is clearly met by the fact that the person making the statements in now deceased and not able to testify. However, the Court was concerned about the reliability of the statements since there is nothing that would serve as convincing indicia of reliability adequate to offset the absence of an oath.
column3: HELD: The Court held that the evidence was admissible as similar fact evidence and that the prejudicial nature of the evidence had not been overcome. The Court also held that there was a risk that the similar fact information would distract the jury from their proper focus on the second degree murder charge and that it would lead them to equate the intention to harm with the mens rea required to be convicted of murder. The court also held there was an issue for which the Crown sought to adduce the evidence. The evidence was found to be admissible on the basis of its probative value and it should not be admitted in order to ensure the possibility of a fair trial. The prejudicial aspects of the similar facts evidence had been overcome by its probativity value and should not in any way be admitted.
column4: Her husband, Kevin Lenius, is charged with second degree murder contrary to s. 235 of the Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46. The Crown tendered a number of statements that were made by the deceased to several Crown witnesses concerning two previous incidents. It is a well established principle in Canadian law that similar acts and other discreditable conduct evidence is presumptively inadmissible. There is a serious potential for moral prejudice. There is also a great risk of reasoning prejudice by admitting the similar fact evidence as it may distract members of the jury from their proper focus which is the second degree murder charge. The prejudicial nature of the similar fact evidence has not been overcome by its probative value and it should not be admitted in order to ensure the possibility of a fair trial. CONCLUSION [52] I am cognizant of the fact that the general exclusionary rule that similar fact evidence is presumptively inadmissible has been affirmed repeatedly and recognizes that the potential for prejudice distraction and time consumption associated with the evidence generally outweighs its probative value. Although a convincing argument may be made with respect to the reliability of the statements, I do have some concerns about this issue in all of the circumstances. [57] For all the above reasons, the statements made by the deceased to her friends, family and colleagues concerning threats and assaults will not be admitted.

In the second incident the accused confronted the victim and beat and choked her and then sexually assaulted and threatened to kill her. The Crown seeks to admit this similar fact evidence and several hearsay statements to prove the issues of motive, intent and modus operandi. HELD: The statements by the deceased are not admissible. The prejudicial nature of the similar fact evidence has not been overcome by its probative value. It is well established law that similar acts and other discreditable conduct evidence is presumptively inadmissible and that similar fact evidence is the exception to this. To determine its admissibility, three things need examination, 1) the probative weight of the evidence, 2) the assessment of the prejudice and 3) the weighing of the probative value versus prejudicial value. In examining the probative weight of the evidence, factors to be considered include the issues in question, the presence or absence of collusion, similarities and dissimilarities between the facts charged and the similar fact evidence and the strength of the evidence that the events occurred. The two previous incidents are extremely prejudicial in nature leading to potential moral prejudice. That is, reprehensible nature of the assaults could lead the jury to rely on the prohibited inference that the accused is the type of person who could have committed the crime. There is also a great risk of reasoning prejudice. That is, admitting the similar fact evidence may distract the jury from their proper focus which is the second degree murder charge. There is a possibility that the jury will equate the intention to harm with the mens rea required for a murder conviction. With respect to the hearsay evidence, the Court held that statements made by the deceased to her friends, family and colleagues concerning the threats and assaults will not be admitted. The test of necessity is clearly met by the fact that the person making the statements in now deceased and not able to testify. However, the Court was concerned about the reliability of the statements since there is nothing that would serve as convincing indicia of reliability adequate to offset the absence of an oath.
column18: The accused was charged with second degree murder. The Crown tendered a number of statements that were made by the deceased to several Crown witnesses concerning two previous incidents of choking. HELD: The Court held that the trial judge must not invade the province of trier of fact and condition admissibility on hearsay as it may distract members of the jury from their proper focus. The prejudicial nature of the similar fact evidence has not been overcome by its probative value and it should not be admitted in order to ensure the possibility of a fair trial. 1) There is a serious potential for moral prejudice by admitting the same fact evidence as it is presumed to be inadmissible. There is also a great risk of reasoning prejudice if other hearsay from the same witness with the same content has already been admitted, then the hearsay may not be necessary. 2) The Court found there must be some evidence capable of reasonably supporting finding that the appellant was implicated in the other similar acts. However, there was no evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused knew the harm was likely to cause death or was reckless whether death ensued.

column2: The Crown appeals the sentence to the extent that the victim surcharge was waived. The appeal is made on the basis that the trial judge did not comply with the mandatory provisions of s. 737 of the Criminal Code. HELD: The imposition of a victim fine surcharge under s. 737 of the code is mandatory subject only to an application under s. 737(5) relating to undue hardship. If an offender is exempted from payment of the victim surcharge, it is also mandatory that the Court give reasons. The sentence is varied to include an order requiring the respondent to pay a victim surcharge in the amount of $30.
column3: The Crown appealed the sentence of $200.00 and a $30 victim surcharge. The sentence was varied to include an order requiring the respondent to pay a victim sur charge in the amount of $30. The Crown had not requested an exemption pursuant to s. 737(5) of the Code. HELD: The sentence varied to reflect an order that the respondent pay a $20 victim surtax in the amounts of $20. The court gave reasons for the variation. The sentencing judge failed to comply with the explicit provisions of s. 730(5), and (6) of Code. The Court gave reasons in the record of the proceedings. The imposition of a victim fine surcharge under s. 6 of the Criminal Code is mandatory subject only to an application under s 737(6) relating to undue hardship. If an offender is exempted from payment of the victim surcharges, it is also mandatory that the court give reasons. If a defendant is exempted, it's also mandatory to give reasons for why the sentencing judge did not comply with s. 8 of the code. The offence was committed under section 730 of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act. The defendant was convicted of failing to attend and complete anger management program as required by probation order. The respondent was sentenced to a fine of $300.00. The trial judge waived the victim fee in the sum of $50. The victim surcharged was also waived notwithstanding that the Respondent had not asked an exemption. The offender was exempted from paying the victim charge. The judge failed in his duty to act in the best interests of the offender. The sentences varied to vary to include the order requiring a victim to pay $30 in the order of the Crown. The appeal is made on the basis that the trial judge did fail to comply. The maximum sentence for a serious offence under the Criminal Procedure Code is 15 years imprisonment. The amount of the surcharge is mandatory in an application for an application of 737(7). The imposition is mandatory to an Application under s741(5). If an offenders is exempted by default from payment, it was also mandatory for the court to give the reasons. The failure to comply is of paramount importance to the offender and the entire criminal justice system. The costs of this offence are of paramount significance. The burden of paying the surcharges is on the offender to pay the surtax.

column2: The plaintiff is an employee of the City of Saskatoon and member of the Union. He commenced this claim based on the Indemnity Clause contained in the Union's bylaws. The plaintiff asserts he is involved in Union related litigation and is thus entitled to the benefit of the indemnity clause. HELD: The plaintiff's application for summary judgment is dismissed. The within action is dismissed in full. 1) The essential nature of the debate between the plaintiff and the Union relates to the interpretation of the indemnity clause in the Union bylaws. This is precisely the type of internal dispute that is not within the exclusive realm of the Labour Relations Board. The forum for this contest is the Queen's Bench Court and this Court has jurisdiction to entertain his claim under Queen's Bench Rule 485 for summary judgment. 2) The plaintiff represents himself. He has incurred no legal fees, other than disbursements, but he nonetheless asserts that he is entitled to $50,000. The figure of $50,000 is proffered by the plaintiff as an appropriate sum as he expects the defendant has spent at least that much defending all four actions. 3) It is plain and obvious that the plaintiff's claim is grounded on an interpretation of the indemnity clause that is so illogical and inconsistent with its plain wording that it cannot succeed. The plaintiff's claim for reimbursement of costs not incurred is equally incapable of success.

Exhausting internal remedies The plaintiff sought guidance from the Court of Appeal in McNairn v. United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry. Rule 485(1) provides that the Court may lend its process to the Fourth Action as the plaintiff has available to him further internal Union appeals. The Court is merely upholding the basic term of the membership contract, without which the union cannot function effectively on behalf of its members. The dispute is, in its essential character, contractual in nature, and is not within the exclusive realm of the Labour Relations Board. It would be inequitable to prevent the plaintiff from bringing this application in the absence of a clear and enforceable provision excluding his access to the Courts.

Rule 485(1) provides that a party may apply with supporting affidavit material either by notice of motion for summary judgment, or application for summary trial. The Court must not lend its process to the Fourth Action as the plaintiff has available to him further internal Union appeals. The dispute is, in its essential character, contractual in nature, and is substantially different from an internecine dispute in a voluntary sports organization respecting the disciplining of high school coach over recruiting practices. column22: The plaintiff is an employee of the City of Saskatoon and member of the Union. He commenced this claim based on the Indemnity Clause contained in the Union's bylaws. The plaintiff asserts he is involved in Union related litigation and is thus entitled to the benefit of the indemnity clause. HELD: The plaintiff's application for summary judgment is dismissed. The within action is dismissed in full. 1) The essential nature of the debate between the plaintiff and the Union relates to the interpretation of the indemnity clause in the Union bylaws. This is precisely the type of internal dispute that is not within the exclusive realm of the Labour Relations Board. The forum for this contest is the Queen's Bench Court and this Court has jurisdiction to entertain his claim under Queen's Bench Rule 485 for summary judgment. 2) The plaintiff represents himself. He has incurred no legal fees, other than disbursements, but he nonetheless asserts that he is entitled to $50,000. The figure of $50,000 is proffered by the plaintiff as an appropriate sum as he expects the defendant has spent at least that much defending all four actions. 3) It is plain and obvious that the plaintiff's claim is grounded on an interpretation of the indemnity clause that is so illogical and inconsistent with its plain wording that it cannot succeed. The plaintiff's claim for reimbursement of costs not incurred is equally incapable of success.
column23: The plaintiff, an employee of the City of Saskatoon and member of the Saskatoon Civic Employees' Union, commenced this action under the simplified procedure of Part 40 of The Queen's Bench Rules seeking judgment for $50,000. The plaintiff asserts he is involved in Union related litigation and is entitled to the benefit of the indemnity clause in the Union's by-laws. The union resists the claim asserting various defences, the primary being that the plaintiff misconstrues and misinterprets the by-law and, more to the point, the Court should decline to become involved in the dispute because the Union is a voluntary association. Exhausting internal remedies The plaintiff sought guidance from the Court of Appeal in McNairn v. United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry. Rule 485(1) provides that a party may apply with supporting affidavit material either by notice of motion for summary judgment or application for summary trial. HELD: The court found that the dispute was not within the exclusive realm of the Labour Relations Board. The issue was whether the plaintiff was entitled to benefit from an indemnity by the Union in the first, second and third actions. The dispute distills to an interpretation of the terms of the Union membership contract in sum, the very type of debate contemplated by the Supreme Court in Berry v. Pulley. 1) In the absence of a statutory regime precluding the Court's involvement, the debate in the Fourth Action is totally appropriate for disposition by the Court. It is illustrative of the shock and awe litigation strategy employed by the plaintiff. 2) The dispute is, in its essential character, contractual. This is substantially different from an internecine dispute in a voluntary sports organization respecting the disciplining of high school coach over recruiting practices. The analysis in Street v. B.C. School Sports is not germane to the within debate. However, it is worth noting that in that case the Court did exercise supervisory jurisdiction to ensure the process was fair. 3) The plaintiff is engaged in litigation respecting the Union and its members is contractual and is governed by a written set of 'Working Rules and Bylaws' constituting the union's contract between the parties. The Union is the contracting party, the liability of the union is limited to the assets of the individual member and cannot extend to its members personally. 4) The Court is merely upholding the basic term of the membership contract.
