column2: The mother applied for retroactive support (table amounts and s. 7 expenses) for two adult children. The father resisted the application in relation to the oldest son on the basis that he was no longer a dependant child when it was filed. The evidence showed the son finished university before the application was filed. His graduation took place after, at which time he was already working full time and living with his girlfriend. He lived with his mother for few months because of relationship problems, but later moved back in with the girlfriend. He also received some assistance from his parents when he took time off work to retrain. The father felt the mother's application in relation to the younger son should be limited because of her unreasonable delay in making it. He argued retroactivity should be limited to three years from the date he received the application (months after it was filed). The mother argued formal notice was given when her lawyer sent a letter requesting additional support several years earlier. She asked the court for support retroactive to three years before that date, or longer (based on what she alleged was blameworthy conduct on the father's part). The evidence showed the mother was slow in responding to the father's request for particulars. Despite threatening legal action several times, it took her years to file the application. The wife's application for retroactive support in relation to the oldest son dismissed. He was no longer a child of the marriage when it was filed. He became independent when his schooling finished and he started working and living with his girlfriend. While his parents provided assistance during his relationship troubles and retraining, they did so voluntarily and not out of any legal obligation. Support for the younger son to be reassessed retroactive to three years from the date the application was filed (as opposed to received). The mother unreasonably delayed her claim by allowing it to languish for years. While normally the letter from her lawyer would be said to constitute effective notice, the notice here was voided by the mother's failure to prosecute the matter. The father did not engage in blameworthy conduct: he made efforts to respond to and settle the mother's claims; he paid a significant level of support; and he reasonably believed he was meeting his obligations. Here, the need for certainty for a payor parent weighs in favour of the father.
column3: The parties were married for seven years and had two children. The respondent argued that the court did not have jurisdiction to grant any relief respecting the older child because the older was not, at the time of the application, a child of the marriage. The parties' corollary relief judgment provided for shared parenting arrangement and equal sharing of all special and extraordinary expenses. The petitioner argued that retroactive support should be limited to three years prior to October 9, 2008. The appellant argued that this was the year the respondent first applied for the change in circumstances and that the respondent should disclose the material change in circumstance to the court. The court did have jurisdiction, however, to deal with the claim for retroactive child support and s.7 expenses for the petitioner's older child. The Court held that the Court had jurisdiction to consider the application of the respondent for retroactivity of child support if any will be calculated for the younger child. It held that jurisdiction was not required to grant the respondent any relief. The issue was whether the respondent had the means to justify his/her obligation to pay child support. The evidence established that the petitioner and her partner took up residence in a downtown Toronto apartment. The trial judge was not blind to prevailing social and economic conditions; bachelor's degree no longer assures self-sufficiency. The issues raised by the petitioner were whether the appellant's obligation to contribute to the support of the younger children was increased, whether the petitioner had a blameworthy conduct conviction, and whether the conduct of the petitioner could be acquitted by buying his/ her child a bicycle. The question was whether there was a sufficient basis for the respondent to make an application for retroactively child support, and if so, what the basis for that application was. The only conclusion was that the appellant had not made a sufficient case for the retroactive award. The fact that the parties' children had not been independent, financially and otherwise from their parents was irrelevant. The matter was whether retroactive payments should be made to the petitioner if the respondent's obligation changed but his payments did not. The applicant's evidence was speculative and conjecture. The judge was unable to provide any other evidence as to the respondent’s financial situation. The respondents’ evidence was not speculative and speculative.
column4: He argued that the court did not have jurisdiction to grant any relief respecting the older child because the older child was not, at the time of the application, a child of the marriage. On April 25, 2008 he and his girlfriend/common law partner took up residence in a downtown Toronto apartment. [13] The subject child commenced full-time employment on May 12, 2008 earning a starting salary of $25,000 plus commissions and benefits. [19] I am satisfied the court does not have jurisdiction to consider the application of Ms. Niles for retroactive variation of child support and a readjustment of the claim for section 7 expenses pertaining to the parties’ older child. As a consequence the recalculation should be three years prior to July 2004 i.e. to 2001. I am satisfied that Mr. Munro did not engage in blameworthy conduct during this period. On the unusual facts of this case I have concluded that communication that represented effective notice in 2004 was voided by the delays of the recipient parent and her failure to prosecute the matter. In my view, the need for certainty for a payor parent weighs in favour of Mr. Munro, given the passage of several years since effective notice was first received; the significant level of support he was providing; his reasonable belief that he was meeting his obligations; the efforts he made to determine Ms. Niles claim, to respond to it and to settle it. Conclusion [75] In light of the foregoing conclusion on the issue of blameworthy conduct, the appropriate period of retroactive reassessment should be three years before formal notice, this being the maximum recommended retroactive period absent , in this case, blameworthy conduct.

column8: HELD: The court held that it did not have jurisdiction to grant any relief respecting the older child because he was not, at the time of the application, a child of the marriage. It ordered retroactive support for the younger child and ordered a recalculation of the period for which retroactive child support if any will be calculated. The court also ordered a readjustment of the claim for section 7 expenses pertaining to the parties' older child. The parties' corollary relief judgment provided for shared parenting arrangement and equal sharing of all special and extraordinary expenses for the parties'. The court found that the respondent's claim was not valid and ordered the recalculation to be three years prior to July 2004. The respondent argued that the court had jurisdiction under s. 2(1) of the Divorce Act to hold parents responsible for children over sixteen during their period of dependency. HELD: 1) The Court held that the Court had jurisdiction to consider the application of Ms. Niles for retroactive variation of child support and a read-justment for section 8 expenses. 2) It was clear from the various authorities cited by the court that courts recognize jurisdiction under the issue of Child Support where fairness to children dictates it, but should also be mindful that fairness to payor parents often demands. 3) The court did not find jurisdiction to deal with the claim of the respondent with respect to retroactive and s. 7 expenses for her older child, nor did it find jurisdiction for the respondent to decide that his/her child's right to an appropriate amount of support can be acquitted. 4) The respondent took issue with the costs claimed by the respondent. The Court found that it was not necessary for the Court to consider a recalculation of all child support costs.

column2: This appeal concerns the assessment for municipal purposes of a building located in the City of Regina and used commercially as an enclosed shopping mall. The building was assessed in each of the years 2003 and 2004 on the basis of its 'fair value' as determined by the City Assessor. The owner of the building, the corporate appellant, was dissatisfied with the Assessor's determination of fair value and appealed the assessment to the local Board of Revision, then to the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal board. The appeals were allowed in part, but the corporate appellant remained dissatisfied. It applied for leave to appeal to this Court pursuant to s. 33.1 of The Municipal Board Act. The issues on appeal all relate to the determination of the fair value of the building and, more particularly, to the market adjustment factor used in that determination. The grounds take issue one way or another with the inclusion of the sales of the Southland and Victoria Square Malls in the array of sales from which the MAF was derived, or alternatively, with the adjustment of the sale price of these properties. HELD: Appeal dismissed. The appeal in relation to the treatment of the sale of the Victoria Square Mall fails, as does the appeal concerning the sale of the Southland Mall. The Court notes that other companies, owning or operating similar malls, also took issue with their 2003 and 2004 assessments. They, too, appealed to the Board of Revision and then to the Assessment Appeals Committee. They too were granted leave to appeal to this Court on the same grounds as the appellant in this case. Counsel for the companies agreed to treat this appeal as representative of the other appeals and to be bound by the result of this appeal. These other appeals are also dismissed.
column3: The appellant company sought and obtained information relating to the sale of a shopping mall. The company was dissatisfied with the City Assessor's determination of the fair value of the property and appealed the assessment to the local Board of Revision, then to the Assessment Appeals Committee. The Committee did not reach the conclusion that the sale was an arm's length sale, as the sale price did not reflect typical market value transactions as required by the adjustment provisions of the Assessment Manual. The appellant company appealed its 2003 assessment. The appeal was dismissed on several grounds alleging error of law on the part of the Committee. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1) The Committee failed to misapprehend the importance, generally, of the sale verification process and the information it yields. The importance lies in the fact municipal assessors are highly dependent on this information in the performance of their assessment duties and are called upon to make number of decisions largely on the basis of fact that emerges through this process, process provided for by sections 171 and 172 of The Cities Act. Nor was the Committee convinced the Committee had erred in relation to the determination of a sale price. 2) The committee did not misappreciate the importance of the sales verification process. The committee failed to take into account the importance the sale's information and the accuracy of the information provided by the parties to the transaction. The fact that Cadillac Fairview transferred an undivided one half interest in the mall to the appellant company was not a material error. The assessment of the Normanview Mall came to rest on the City assessor's determination and application of the Sale Verification Information. The sale price was determined by the City's assessment of its fair value. The City's decision to transfer the remaining interest in a shopping centre was not based on the sale sale price but rather on the assessment of a mall. 3) The assessment was based on a single sale price and the sale value was determined using the sale sales of four enclosed shopping malls. The city's decision was based upon the sale prices of the four enclosed malls. 4) The appeal to the assessor was dismissed. The Court was not persuaded that the Committee erred. The sale price satisfied the criteria of Document 1.1.6, namely, that it represented the fee simple interest in the property, the relationship between the parties, the nature of the financing associated with the sale, and the extent to which the sale warranted adjustment. 4) The committee failed to provide sufficient support to the Committee to have regard for the sale of the 3 sales that it relied upon to calculate the MAF and, more particularly, to the market adjustment factor used in that determination. It did not rely excessively on the sales verification information in arriving at its conclusion.  5) It misinterpreted or misapplied law in deciding that a sale of a property located within the municipality, even though the sale was part of a portfolio sale that included other properties located outside the province, was not an arm's length sale and was not subject to the adjustment provisions of the Assessment Manual.

column2: The plaintiffs have applied for certification of proposed multi-jurisdictional class action involving Paxil, prescription drug approved in Canada for the treatment of depression, anxiety, panic disorder and other conditions. The plaintiffs claim that Paxil is ineffective and harmful to persons under 18 years of age. The defendant applies for leave to cross-examine the representative plaintiff on his affidavit pursuant to Rule 317 of The Queen's Bench Rules. HELD: The decisions reviewed by the Court all support the view that leave to cross-examine under Rule 317 is granted more readily in proposed class actions than it is in other civil proceedings. None support the proposition that proposed representative plaintiff is immune from cross-examination in respect of his or her individual claim. Cross-examination of proposed representative plaintiff may explore matters pertaining to his or her individual claim in the context of issue that must be determined by the court pursuant to s. and s. 6.1 of The Class Actions Act. A cross-examination of the plaintiff in this case may assist the court in applying the criterion set out in s. 6 and s. 6.1 of The Class Actions Act. The application for leave to cross-examine is granted.
column3: HELD: The application for leave to cross-examine was granted. The court found that the application for cross-examination was not supported by the evidence obtained by way of affidavit material filed by the plaintiff. The Court found that cross- examination was not appropriate in this case because the plaintiff was not a representative plaintiff. It found that there was no need for clarification through cross- questioning. The plaintiff was merely a representative for the class. The defendant applied for leave. The cross-and-examination would assist the court in applying the criterion set out in ss. 6 and 6.1 of The Class Actions Act to the certification application. The application was granted on the basis that the common issues being advanced for certification were not the individuals under 18 who took Paxil, but by the corporate health care plans, health care insurers and provincial health departments. The common issues were not only devoid of the allegations of harm in the statement of claim but also inconsistent with the plaintiff's personal expectations and motivation. The examination of the affidavit material may assist the Court in applying s. 6.6 of The Act to this application.
column4: Accordingly, the defendants’ request to cross-examine the plaintiff affiants is granted. [25] I find that a cross-examination of Mr. Field may assist the court in applying the criterion set out in ss. 6 and 6.1 of The Class Actions Act to the certification application. The application for leave to cross-examine him on his affidavit is granted.

column2: The defendant contracted with the plaintiff for supply and installation of materials. The defendant was not satisfied with the plaintiff's work, hired a third party to fix the plaintiff's work and refused to pay the plaintiff. The plaintiff sued for payment of the outstanding account HELD: The plaintiff's claim is dismissed. The Court found enough evidence to conclude that the central purpose of the contract for installation was not achieved and that there was a breach of the implied condition that it would be performed in a workmanlike standard. As the plaintiff's workmanship constitutes a breach of contract, the defendant's damages are set off against the claim.
column3: HELD: The action was set down for summary trial with no examinations for discovery or pre-trial conference. The defendant, the plaintiff, contracted with the plaintiff to supply and install the necessary materials for the installation of eavestroughing, soffit and facia together with two downspouts, capping of three garage doors and capping the wooden trim all to be installed on a new garage building located on the defendant's property. The plaintiff brought a claim for lien under The Builders' Lien Act. The court found that the central purpose of the contract for installation was not achieved and that, therefore, there had been a breach of the implied condition of the Contract. The cost of repair was slightly less than the cost quoted by the defendant for the job. The plaintiffs claim for a lien of $2,800. The Court ordered that the plaintiff's action be set down and the procedure at summary trial be simplified.
column4: [1] The defendant, Vincent McKay, contracted with the plaintiff, George Lawson, for the supply and installation of eavestroughing, soffit and facia together with two downspouts, capping of three garage doors and capping of wooden trim, all to be installed on a new garage building located on Mr. McKay’s land. Mr. Lawson then issued a statement of claim in this Court seeking judgment against Mr. McKay in the sum of $2,800.00 and an order that Mr. Lawson is entitled to a lien under the provisions of The Builders’ Lien Act. However, there is enough evidence of significant problems for me to conclude that the central purpose of the contract for installation was not achieved and that, therefore, there has been a breach of the implied condition of the contract that it would be performed in a workmanlike standard. CONCLUSION [27] As set out above, I have concluded that Mr. Lawson’s workmanship constitutes a breach of contract, and Mr. McKay’s damages are set off against the claim.

column2: The applicant applied for judicial interim release under s. 20(b) of the Extradition Act and s. 679 of the Criminal Code. Romania sought extradition of the applicant so that he might serve a 3 year prison sentence imposed as a result of a conviction in Romania for criminally negligent homicide with respect to a motor vehicle collision where the accused, while impaired, hit a pedestrian and killed him. The applicant offered surety from the Romania community in Saskatchewan who did not appear to have known the accused for long and offered to put up his car as bond. The applicant had common law spouse in Saskatchewan but owned no real property. HELD: Although the Crown conceded that the applicant had met the relatively low threshold of showing that his application for leave to appeal his extradition order was not frivolous, the Court of Appeal declined to release the applicant. The Court of Appeal held that there is an elevated risk of flight in light of the fact that the applicant has exhausted all appeals in Romania and is facing a 3 year prison sentence. Canada's international obligations in extradition proceedings require the Court to look more severely at the risk of non-appearance than it would if the application was made solely under s. 679 in respect of criminal proceeding in Canada. The sureties offered by the applicant were not sufficient to ensure his attendance at Court. The application for judicial interim release was dismissed.
column3: The applicant applies for judicial interim release pursuant to s. 20(b) of the Extradition Act and s. 679 of the Criminal Code. The applicant is a Roma and Romanian national who has resided in Canada since his arrival here exactly eight years ago. He was arrested in 2002 while driving his car in Romania. He did not remain at the scene of the collision. He admitted consuming alcohol and striking the victim. Romania charged him with criminally negligent homicide and leaving the scene. The respondent appealed the decision of the Romanian court, which overturned the sentence of his previous conviction. The appellant appealed the sentence and the trial judge sentenced him to 12 years imprisonment. The trial judge in Saskatoon found that the appellant had not committed any crimes and the appellant's current circumstances did not raise the risk of his non-appearance. The application was dismissed. The court found that there was insufficient evidence to support the appellant’s claim for a judicial interim detention. The petitioner’ s. 43 statement was not frivolous and the court found the respondent’d submissions to be not frivolous. The issue was whether the appellant should be released from custody pending the Minister’S decision on his surrender to Romania. The Court found that it would be non-sensical for the appellant to flee prior to the Minister making his decision on surrender. The appeal court judge also found that his appeal was not motivated by the appellant. The Crown conceded that the petitioner had met this low threshold. The Canadian Court of Appeal was not empowered to delve into the validity of the proceedings against the applicant or assess, other than in limited way, the merits of the appeal. The accused’’a long-term relationship with his common law spouse and his common-law spouse was not a factor in his nonappearance and the respondent had not shown any signs of a propensity to commit any crimes. The fact that the respondent was a refugee and had family in the United States and had a long history of employment in the country did not mean that his noncompliance with the terms of the previous sentence would result in a flight risk. The American Court of Appeals was not able to determine whether the respondent should be extradited. The Appeal Court was not given the opportunity to consider the third test under s.679(3)(c). The Court of Queen’sand was not granted the right to review the appeal court’ decision. column4:
[1] Valerica Cretu applies for judicial interim release pursuant to s. 20(b) of the Extradition Act, S.C. 1999, c. 18, and s. 679 of the Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46. Romania seeks Mr. Cretu’s extradition from Canada so that he might serve a three-year prison sentence imposed as a result of his conviction, in that country, for criminally negligent homicide (an offence equivalent to that of manslaughter in Canada). On October 6, 2002, Mr. Cretu, then a resident of Romania, while driving his car struck and killed a pedestrian. [28] In my assessment, the elevated risk of flight in light of the committal order, Mr. Cretu’s failure to abide by a community-based sentence, the nature of the sentence to which he is now subject in Romania, the exhaustion of his appeal rights in Romania, and his desire not to be returned to Romania are important considerations in this case. Finally, Romania’s submissions as to the deficiencies in the nature and extent of the sureties proffered by Mr. Cretu are compelling and I have concluded that the risk of non-appearance is such that it cannot be sufficiently mitigated by release conditions which, on the materials before me, he might be able to meet.
 [31] I hereby dismiss Mr. Cretu’s application for interim judicial release.

column8: The applicant applies for judicial interim release pursuant to s. 20(b) of the Extradition Act and s. 679 of the Criminal Code.  Romania seeks the respondent's extradition from Canada so that he might serve a three-year prison sentence imposed as a result of his conviction, in that country, for criminally negligent homicide (an offence equivalent to that of manslaughter in Canada). Romania argues that the respondent has met this low threshold. HELD: The application is dismissed.  1) The respondent has not met the low threshold of non-appearance that must be considered in an extradition proceeding. The respondent's status as a Convention refugee affords an arguable basis for submitting to the Minister that he should not be surrendered to Romania.  2) Romania's submissions as to the deficiencies in the nature and extent of the sureties proffered by the respondent are compelling and the risk of non reappearance is such that it cannot be sufficiently mitigated by release conditions which, on the materials before the Court, he might be able to meet.  3) The petitioner has not established that he will surrender himself into custody were to release him. He is not a convention refugee. He has been gainfully employed and his ties to the community are not great. The petitioner's failure to abide by the terms of his community-based sentence, the nature of the sentence to which he is now subject in Romania, the exhaustion of his appeal rights in Romania and his desire not to be returned to Romania are important considerations in this case.  4) The court found that the elevated risk of flight in light of the committal order, the respondent’s failure to comply by a community- based sentence and his failure to make a claim for refugee protection pursuant to the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, and his exhaustion of appeal rights are not factors in this application.  5) The Court found that it would be non-sensical for the respondent to flee prior to the decision on surrender as this would, obviously, not stand in his favour with respect to that pending decision.  6) The fact that he is a Convention Refugee does not mean that the onus on him under s. 515 is insurmountable. It is sufficient that the petitioner has a long-term relationship and his common law spouse has agreed to act as his surety. Romania's submission as to his relationship with the community and his willingness to contribute to his employer and his Mercedes Benz C230 vehicle illustrate his inability to comply with court orders in general

column2: The accused was found guilty of three counts of dangerous driving causing death, contrary to s. 249(4) of the Criminal Code, and one count of dangerous driving causing bodily harm, contrary to s. 249(3) of the Code. During his employment as professional truck driver, the accused had driven into construction zone on highway and hit another vehicle that had been stopped. The three teenage occupants of the vehicle were killed and flag person was severely injured as result of the collision. The accused was sure that he had not been asleep at the time of the accident but felt that he had not been paying attention. He had not noticed any of the signs posted at 100-metre intervals after the start of the construction zone 1.6 km south of the accident. The accused was 41 years of age. He had obtained his A-1 driver’s licence in 2009 and had clean driving abstract. He was married and had three children. He had recently been diagnosed with mild sleep apnea. He expressed remorse to the victim’s families and suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder.| HELD: The accused was sentenced to three years in imprisonment on the first count and three years concurrent for the second and third counts, and one year concurrent to the other counts on the fourth count. He was prohibited from operating a motor vehicle for five years and from possessing a firearm for 10 years after his release from imprisonment. The aggravating factors in the case were that the accused’s inattentiveness caused the death of three people and severely injured another person. The impact of the children’s deaths was devastating on their families. The accused was a professional driver and capable of exercising more skill and vigilance, especially when he was operating a semi-trailer truck in a construction zone. The mitigating factors were that the accused pled guilty and expressed profound remorse. He had not been drinking and had a clear driving record. The accused was at low risk to re-offend.
column3: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public and thereby caused the death of three young flag people. The accused had been driving a semi-trailer when the collision occurred. He had been in the construction zone for two years prior to the collision. He was driving a truck at the time of the collision and had been involved in a construction project. The truck driver had been charged with careless driving and operating a vehicle in an undiagnosed manner. The Crown had not identified the stopped vehicles and the driver had not been aware of them. The Court was satisfied that the accused had not committed any dangerous driving offences. The court found that the defendant had committed no dangerous driving offence. The defendant's unlawful conduct must be denounced. The Criminal Code provides that a sentence must be just and fair and consistent with previous judicial decisions in this jurisdiction. The offences were found to be in the range of dangerous driving causing death and causing bodily harm. The offender was found to have been operating a semi truck in a dangerous manner. He failed to recognize the stopped vehicle in the active construction zone and to allow sufficient distance to bring his vehicle to safe stop before colliding with the rear of the Cobalt. The driver was found guilty of operating a truck in an unauthorised manner.

column8: The accused was convicted of operating a motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public and thereby caused the death of three young flag people. The accused had been driving a semi-trailer when the collision occurred. He had been in the construction zone at normal highway speeds and did not reduce his speed. The three teenage boys were killed when their vehicle was struck in the rear by the semi-truck driven by the accused. HELD: The Court found that the accused was guilty of both offences. The Court ordered a sentence of 6 years to 7 years in federal institution.  The Court also imposed a 10 year driving prohibition pursuant to s. 718 to 718.2 of the Criminal Code. The Criminal Code provides that a sentence must be just and fair and be consistent with previous judicial decisions in this jurisdiction, if at all possible. The offence was committed in a construction zone. The defendant's unlawful conduct must be denounced.  1) The Court was satisfied that the aggravating and mitigating factors in this case were appropriate but did not take any position with regard to the length of driving prohibition. 2) The defendant was found guilty of unlawful conduct. The court found that his unlawful conduct was aggravating. 3) There was no evidence that the defendant had ever driven on a highway before May 3, 2015 and had driven through construction zone 2.6 kilometres into the night. The driver had been convicted of dangerous driving in a previous offence. The offences were found to be related to the defendant's inattention for whatever reason as he drove his huge heavy truck through the construction area. 4) The accused was found to have been in possession of a handgun. 5) The court ordered the defendant to pay $800 in victim impact statements.  6) It ordered the offender to pay the victim impact statement amounting to $1,000.00.  7) It was ordered that the Court consider all of the purposes and principles of sentencing as contained in ss. 717 to 717.2.  8) The offences dealt with the driving of the accused in relation to his education, employment and finances. 9) The offence is a serious and life-threatening offence.  10) It is an extremely high risk of mental and emotional harm to the accused and his family.  11) There is no suggestion whatsoever that alcohol and/or drugs were involved in the collision. The fundamental principle of sentence being proportionate to the gravity of the offence, as well as the degree of responsibility of the offender, must also be considered

column13: The accused was convicted of operating a motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public and thereby caused the death of three young flag people. The accused had been driving a semi-trailer at the time of the collision and had been injured in the rear when the truck struck the flag person standing near their vehicle. The flag person had been working as a flag person for the past two years and had just finished driving a group of southbound vehicles through a construction zone when he was struck by the semi-truck driven by the accused. The Crown argued that the accused had no prior criminal record and that he had no previous driving offences other than the.08 obtained sixteen years earlier. HELD: The accused was sentenced to 6 years imprisonment. The Court found that the aggravating and mitigating factors in this case were that he failed to recognize stopped vehicles in the active construction zone and to allow sufficient distance to bring his vehicle to safe stop before colliding with the rear of the Cobalt in which the three teenage boys were occupants. The Criminal Code provides that sentences in dangerous driving cases must deter others from driving dangerously, particularly in a highway construction zone, we keep getting situations in which individuals are convicted of dangerous driving within those construction zones. This must stop. Not only truck drivers driving huge heavy 'death machines' but all drivers driving in construction zones must follow the law and reduce their speed and drive attentively. Just too many things can go wrong. The only thing the Court can do is to remedy what has happened is to sentence the offender in accordance with the objectives and principles of sentencing as contained within the Criminal Code, RSC 1985, C-46. In this case, the accused's unlawful conduct must be denounced.  1) The Court was totally satisfied that it has sufficiently heard from the victims in this matter. The fundamental principle of sentence being proportionate to the gravity of the offence, as well as the degree of responsibility of the offender, must also be considered by the Court in sentencing Normand Lavoie.  2) The accused's driving record was totally clean. He failed to permit sufficient distance from the stopped vehicles to bring their vehicle to a safe stop.  3) There are no Gladue factors that need to be addressed pursuant to s. 718.2(e) of the Code.

The flag person had been working as a flag person for the past two years and had just finished driving a group of southbound vehicles through a construction zone when he was struck by the semi-truck driven by the accused. The Crown argued that the accused's unlawful conduct was a result of his lack of sleep and mental health awareness. The defence argued that this was an important factor in his decision to operate the motor vehicle. HELD: The Court sentenced the accused to 6 years in federal prison. The Court found that the offences were serious and that the aggravating and mitigating factors in this case were sufficient to warrant a sentence of 6 years plus 1 day in federal institution. The offences were found to be dangerous driving. The court found that there was no evidence that the defendant had ever travelled on Highway No. in the Province of Saskatchewan before May 3, 2015 and, in particular, had ever driven through the construction zone.

column23: The accused was convicted of operating a motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public and thereby caused the death of three young flag people. HELD: The Court found that the accused was guilty of both offences. 1)The accused's unlawful conduct was found to be aggravating and mitigating factors in this case. 2)The Court was satisfied that the Court had sufficiently heard from the victims in this matter. However, the Court was not satisfied that it had addressed the Gladue factors. The Court was also satisfied that there was no evidence that alcohol or drugs were involved in the offence.  3)The offences were committed in connection with the cause of the collision.
